title: Rivals of Aether
review:
One of the few platform fighters that have a separate identity from Smash. All the characters are extremely unique and deep, combos are freeform and creative, and movement is tight and expressive. Has a lot of the good jank from Melee now integrated as official mechanics (like wavedashing and platform cancelling) without any of the dumb jank (L-cancelling, ledgehogging) and a few interesting ideas of their own (hitfalling, parrying).
It completely gets rid of the most awkward part of most platform fighters, the ledge, and replaces it with a much more interesting walljump system which leads to crazy offstage plays and interesting edgeguards.

However, it's mostly a competitive 1v1 game. With the addition of workshop content and weirder modes like FFA, 2v2, and Tetherball it's getting better for casual players but the core audience is people who like playing platform fighters like a subgenre of fighting games.

Online is decent depending on where you are. Where I am I can usually get a good connection in a couple minutes at the worst. 

Overall really great game, don't dismiss it as another smash ripoff.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game gets described as "Pixel Art Smash" but I feel like that description does it a major disservice. This game is a platform fighter, but to call it only a smash like game discredits how much this does different. The multiplayer experience is super solid, and the single player experience is fun. Props to Dan, and I can't wait to see what's next.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Many people are buying this game solely for the workshop. Keep in-mind that your options for multiplayer are more limited with workshop characters (and as expected, workshop characters do not all operate at the same performance level, which can very easily create severely unbalanced matchups, not that this should surprise anyone), and the game still struggles from a lack of singleplayer content that was not addressed at all in Definitive Edition. If you are thinking about buying this game just because of the workshop, I would advise strongly considering if you're willing to spend the money on what will essentially be a platforming version of MUGEN. Do not expect random matchmaking to be useful with the workshop, as its use is restricted to characters that both players have downloaded, and overlap is extremely rare. This issue is compounded by the game's already extremely small playerbase that is at-odds with the workshop so you will frequently meet players that outright have no characters downloaded because they only want to play with the base roster (not that they're in the wrong for wanting to play the game differently, but it is an issue if your goal is to enjoy the workshop).

If you're unsure about this game, don't buy it. The people that picked it up are a very specific audience that was going to enjoy this game no matter what. The play environment is very strongly geared towards players already highly experienced with Smash Bros Melee. You will be constantly told that the game is fun when you get good at it, but unless you're ready to put hundreds of hours into playing the exact same people, it doesn't get better. Playing against the same people over and over is the exact experience you're signing up for.
There are 14 characters in the base game, 6 of these were formerly paid DLC until DE. I'll give the devs credit for finally realizing that was a terrible system, it's still better for it to take 4 years than if they were to never realize it. If absolutely nothing else, I commend the developers for finally making this change as it was previously an enormous flaw in the game's design. Despite this, I still feel the game is horrendously overcosted because it significantly relies on its P2P online with extremely shallow singleplayer content. Most people can probably finish all the offline material before the 2-hour refund period expires.
The abysmal playerbase size combined with how the skill floor is comically high means you will never, ever see a new face. If you're new to playing games that use a Smash Bros Melee playstyle, you will not be able to pick this up. Do not even try, it will not happen. I know there's a lot of you out there that would enjoy a challenge, but this one has no payoff. The only resource for new players to find games is a single Discord server that has such a low playercount that you'll take weeks to find a match with anyone even near your skill level.
Random online matches are a joke where you will sit through an endless cycle of the same 200 ping opponent being suggested until you both finally accept the match, and they pick Kragg to abuse the high latency.
The userbase puts on a face of being welcoming to new players, but it's just that - a face. The game will still take about 100 hours (this is just an estimate based on statistical averages, it is obviously not an exact figure) for a new player to even begin having meaningful matches online, which are precluded by a constant stream of just losing with a strong feeling of helplessness. As it stands it is unlikely the issue of the skill floor and horrendous learning curve will ever get addressed, and it appears that the existing playerbase has come to embrace that, for better or worse. The only way in is if you bring a friend who's equally new and committed to playing the same game against you over and over, until you can branch out to playing the same people online over and over.
Probably the worst-kept secret of this game is how it's really just Smash Bros Melee but for furries. I don't think I need to convince you of this when the game's own roster does all the explaining for me.
For a perspective of how many people have dropped this game, it sold around 750,000 copies (source: SteamSpy) at the time of this review, and has 500 active players (source: Steamcharts, monthly avg players) total. It appears even the release of DE wasn't enough to spark lasting interest, because although I'm writing this review very shortly after the update, it appears most of the playerbase interest has already fallen off. (However this is based on volatile information, being written on the day of DE's release, as a result this statement should not be taken as a fact; I'm drawing a conclusion based on limited information). Even Brawlhalla is able to crush this game with player retention and Brawlhalla is free. This game's playerbase has not grown in years and with good reason. This game's skill floor makes it struggle to keep players.
The fanbase is very avid about defending the quality of their game, but because of the immense entry barrier, it doesn't matter. $20 is a steep price to pay for a game that relies entirely on its very humbly-sized multiplayer scene to carry its weight, and it comes bearing the burden of your first 100 hours being wasted if you aren't already heavily experienced with this very specific type of gameplay. If you're already good enough at Melee that you dominate your local scene, then maybe you can give this a shot if you want to move to a game with an even smaller playerbase.

In short: It's literally just Melee with less content. This game has generally been obsoleted now that Melee on emulator has working netplay, but ultimately it's your decision if you still want to buy. I would be very, very careful with buying this game though as its cost is a joke for what it offers unless you are already extremely committed to playing with a very small community.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
My brother first introduced me to this game back when it was in early access and only had 7 characters. Then a few years went by and it came back on my radar when Ranno and Clairen got announced. I've been playing it and loving every minute ever since.

This game scratches a certain itch that no other platform fighter has been able to do, at least for myself. The assortment of unique character archetypes, the advanced mechanics taken from other titles but made more beginner friendly while at the same time powerful when employed at a top level, the gorgeous art style and sound design --> just all of it is fantastic. Couldn't recommend this game enough. If you've enjoyed other fighters in this genre or have always been interested but just not known where to get your feet wet, give this game a chance. I bet you'll come to love it just like I did.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is an indie platform fighting game with competitive elements as well as some casual elements to attract all audiences and does so extremely well.
When it comes to graphics, it's about as well as you'd expect from indie game graphics with pixel art and assets on par if not better than the likes of games like Celeste or Shovel Knight. Each menu is well optimized to get you in and out of the fight as fast as possible. Stages are made with vibrant colors, animations, as well as little details here and there to breathe life into this world.
The music in this game is simply something to behold, if you don't get the game, then please at least listen to the music. Flashygoodness, the composer, did an absolutely amazing job making new songs, as well as recreating well known songs from other well known indie games. These are songs that will end up in your head after just one listen for the rest of the day and will eventually find their way onto your music playlists. The music is for sure the 2nd best part of this game next to the gameplay.
Now when it comes to gameplay, it captures what a competitive platform fighter should be like, complex movement and mechanics with unique mechanics for each fighter. However, many of these mechanics remain accessible to those who want to play with their friends casually with more difficult mechanics for the core game and characters taking time and practice to master. Rivals does have side modes, however they're something to distract you from the main game for a couple minutes before heading back to said main mode. Furthermore, Rivals has a milestone system that gives you incentive to try new characters and they definitely have payoff with new skins, stages (with more unique music), and pets to keep the game just a little interesting.
The weakest aspect of this game would most likely be the online. Now the connection isn't poor, but it is very likely that every other game or so you'll end up with someone whose way up higher in the rankings than you are with no way of checking before you accept the opponent into the room. However other than that, the online is something worth trying unlike other platform fighters that have come out recently.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game has some of the most creative characters in a fighting game I've seen and I love it. Online is also really enjoyable, haven't had any issues with online as long as I play with people from the same continent (which you can configure in your settings). Tetherball and Abyss mode are really fun gamemodes as well.

The unlock system however is a pretty big disappointment, the milestone system essentially just comes down to grinding and I'm genuinely confused about who thought it'd be a good idea to have grinding in a fighting game. It's a shame really but I guess it explains why they never elaborated on what the system actually meant in any of the promotional videos. It's not a big deal at all but I figured I'd mention it.

Either way, the thing that completely sells this to me as a relatively casual player is the absolutely incredible workshop support and community. Playing with the user created content with friends or just messing around with it in singleplayer is amazing. And as a creator as well this entire facet of the game has been wonderful, it turns this into more than just a game. Either way though even without workshop this game is pretty great, would very much recommend.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I've been playing this game for something around 4 or 5 years now and I can say with honest certainty the developers behind this game are some of the most passionate, talented, overwhelmingly incredible people to ever develop a game like this. The small team are dedicated to making this game the best possible experience for people who love the platform fighting genre.

It strays far from the realm I'd consider a "smash clone" with the introduction of new mechanics and the refining of old. The 10 frame buffer system makes the game feel buttery smooth and much more beginner friendly than other notable games of a similar competitive caliber. I love grabs and shields being ditched for a more interactive style of play. It encourages aggression and rewards reads and timing. Grinding out tech skill and practicing matchups is extremely rewarding. The level of depth combos can have once you master techniques such as hitfalling, baby dashing, etc. feels phenomenal. 

The workshop gives this game new life. The doors that are opened once any character from any game or anyone's imagination can join the fight make the game feel fresh at any given point. Not that you'll need that as the game has virtually infinite value. For $30, the definitive edition of Rivals of Aether is money well spent. Get a couple friends, family, local or online, sit down and give it some time. I know you'll fall in love.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Takes everything you like about smash and makes it better.
- actually balanced
- fast gameplay
- nice visuals
- unique character mechanics
- competitive playerbase

Some issues:
- netcode is not the best, but its not as bad as some will tell you [improved since definitive]
- relatively small playerbase [improved since definitive]
- needs 4 player online [now included with definitive]

Overall, very fun game, very nice community (definitely get involved over discord). 
When new characters come out they're always stupid good for a couple weeks. Then they get nerfed (Unless you're Ellliana, then you get buffed a week later lul). Wait for when a new character comes out to get it. Goes on sale super cheap and all the old dlc is half off for like a week.

update:
900 hours later I can honestly say that if you are competitive person who enjoys the challenge of the platform fighter genre then you will absolutely enjoy this game. If you have friends who are at your skill level, then you will enjoy it even more. If you are a casual player, you will very likely still enjoy this game now that definitive edition has come out, since the default branch now comes with workshop support. Any character you have ever though of being in a platform fighter is probably in workshop already. Game now also has 4 player online, more abyss content, all the characters are out, and the balance is pretty much fleshed out at this point. New netcode also really helps with most connections being significantly better in my own personal experience. Your mileage may vary. Overall, I would highly recommend this game to anyone who has interest in the genre. Just make sure you can find people at your skill level to play with, because the skill gap at times can be quite large.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is absolutely incredible.
The amount of polish and care put into the game really makes it shine. 
Each character has their own unique kit and personality, but they’re not restrictive. It allows freeform, adaptable gameplay- Most of the cast can be played in different ways than expected. The Steam Workshop opens it up even more, allowing players to create new fighters with new gimmicks to play around with.
In terms of Singleplayer, there’s not as much available. Story mode is lacking. Abyss Mode is fun, but it does get repetitive.
The milestone system is great! You have to work to unlock things. And it’s free!
(I hope the milestone system is expanded actually! I want more milestones!)
Definitely worth the money if you have friends to play with.
Absolutely recommended if you’re a fan of competitive fighting games.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you have any interest in competitive platform fighter this game a must buy. Super interesting character design that gives so much creativity to the player. Refining the smash formula to a degree of familiarity but still innovating. The recovery mechanics are a prime example. Taking away the ledges makes recovering far more vulnerable, but with all the mix-ups available through air dodging and wall jumping it creates an excellent balance. Rewarding a correct read very handsomely. Also the movement is fantastic, streamlining pm and melee movement just making it more easy to get moving right away. This game corners a niche to perfection, give it a try !

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is an amazing platform fighter, one of the best of its kind. It takes the mechanics of Melee and combines it with the accessibility of the later Smash games, as well as its own little mechanics to create a game that really is fun, whether you plan to take it seriously or just want to pick up and play with friends. If you get a bit tired of it, the workshop is a great way to add some variety to the game. The idea of being able to add other players characters to your game is such a fun idea and the stuff that people can create always impresses me. I’ve heard a few people say that the pixel art (which btw is gorgeous) does make it pretty hard to pay attention to the action, though. Personally I’ve never had an issue with it but that’s definitely something to keep in mind.

If you’re a Smash Bros. fan, I couldn’t recommend this enough. This is some of the most fun I’ve had with a Steam game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
*--Long Review Ahead--*

TLDR: If you like platform fighters with fast, satisfying gameplay, great chiptune music, and games with pixel art, get this game.

If you're a fan of Smash Bros. or platform fighters in general, this game is DEFINITELY for you. It's fast, easy to learn, incredibly fun to play, with 12 characters designs that feel familiar, but unique. Each character has their own short tutorial that helps you learn their moveset/play-style and they included a staggered tutorial for game mechanics. These range from the very basics (walking, running, what button does what, etc.) to more advanced tech like Wavedashing and Reverse Aerial Rushes (RARs). 

 There is a good amount of single player/ co-op content as well. Story mode, to me, feels similar to classic mode in Smash. Unfortunately, it is limited to the six original characters that they had in Early Access. Essentially, you pick a character and face off in a series of 5 fights, which steadily increase in difficulty, with the goal of finishing as fast as possible. Now there is lore to the characters that is revealed, so if that's your thing then I think you'd enjoy it, but if not they grant you the option of skipping the story and cut straight to the fights. There's Abyss Mode which is pretty similar to the Endless Smash mode that has been included in many of the Smash Bros. games. The major difference here is that its not entirely just yeeting a bunch of low level CPU players off the stage until you get yeeted. Each level is a wave that comes in with different a challenge that you (and a friend) need to endure. Some of the challenges they throw at you range from facing an armored enemy, staying withing a circle of light while being attacked, or destroying an obelisk while (you guessed it) being attacked. After each completed wave, they reward you with this blue crystal that you get to beat the shit out of to gain EXP and level up your character. Every time you level a character up, you gain the ability to equip custom moves that buff your character. These custom moves are unlocked by spending the gold you get from completing games and can make you invincible during certain moves, or make your special moves stronger/go farther. One of the big attractions that Rivals has introduced is Tetherball. Sadly, this is the one mode that I haven't played yet so I can't elaborate much about it. And naturally, like all fighting games, there's a training mode where you can go to practice your character. Here, you can adjust how the CPU will react,  toggle hitbox visualizations, and do so much more within the pause menu. 

Online play is usually pretty good. You can choose to play casually or ranked. Casual online play lets you play 1v1's or 2v2's and allows the use of Steam Workshop characters if you want. However, the only downside is that the person you're connected to MUST have your character downloaded or else they are completely unavailable. I've played a little bit of ranked and got my ass handed to me more times than I'd like to admit, but I still had fun. In both casual and ranked, there are preset messages you can send while on the character select screen. They're pretty tame, and are intended to come across as friendly with messages like "Good Game", "This will be easy", and "Ready when you are". Local play is about what you would expect. You and three others can fight it out and any of the 15 stages included in the game. You can adjust the rules similar to the way Smash does it, where the amount of time/stocks can be adjusted and rules like Turbo mode can be toggled. 

The inclusion of the Steam Workshop was a phenomenal idea. I currently have over 15 pages of characters custom made by the community, which have provided for some of the most insane and hilarious fights. One of my favorite things about Rivals, is the options for creating custom color swaps for each character. They allow for you to create two different variations for each character and I found creating them easier than expected. They break down the characters' renders into sections (i.e. head, tail, fire, horns, etc.) which actively change as colors as you shift the sliders around. To give you an even better idea of what your custom design would look like, they include the sprite that you'd see on screen as you fight. Speaking of sprites, the sprite work for Rivals is beautiful. As someone who is a sucker for good sprite work, I can't help but feel a bit of bias by saying that, however this game just looks and sounds awesome. The music that plays on each stage, or even in the menus, absolutely slaps. Most of the music is chiptune and catchy as hell. The sounds when you hit opponents is very satisfying, especially when playing Shovel Knight. They got that metallic smacking sound absolutely perfect.


I know this review is long as hell, but there's a lot to talk about. Rivals of Aether is incredibly satisfying to play. It's fast pacing, great character designs, catchy music, awesome sprite art and familiar mechanics make it one of my favorite, and most played games on Steam. This is one of those games that I find myself playing all day and never growing tired of.

review: Came from watching melee and playing smash4/ultimate and really connected with rivals. I enjoy the art style, gameplay, and attention to the community this game provides. Super solid combat, every character plays different, improved netplay DRASTICALLY, active community to grind and play with. Honestly, if youre looking for a fighting game to play in this niche genre and found yourself here, do yourself a service and get you this package of a fighting game that you'll keep coming back for more. Shout outs to Dan and the team he built around him to develop this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether has the aspects of the Smash Bros series that competitive players find so appealing while bravely branching out in its own direction to make competition a core part of the game rather than an extra way to play. If you want a Smash Bros game that feels like it was made as a competitive experience first, or you even just want a game like Smash that has great online connectivity so you can mess around with your friends, Rivals is seriously worth your money and time.

On top of all of this, the workshop features go the extra mile to be as accessible and expansive as official content. Almost every core feature of the game, like characters and stages, has additional user created content that are incredibly easy to install. For the creatives and aspiring designers, the tools and documentation provided by the developers makes getting into modding significantly easier for anyone with even minimal experience.

Overall Rivals of Aether is a complete package and then some. The definitive edition, which includes all previously DLC characters and the workshop functionality, is a serious achievement that the developers should be proud of and you should be proud to support.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I'm a Smash player who loves Melee as a spectator sport and Ultimate as a competitor. Rivals feels like the best of both worlds, far more accessible than Melee while maintaining much of the satisfying movement and combos. The varied competitive character design far surpasses Ultimate. I'm still adjusting to neutral and comboing but I'm having fun while learning, instant cop if you're interested in expanding your platform fighter horizons or incredibly tired of Ultimate's terrible online. This game is not Ultimate, it is its own and better off for it than you might think.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is one of the most unique takes on the platform fighter genre, featuring a unique level of depth in EVERY character in the game you play as! It was wonderful pixel art, a goated soundtrack by Flashygoodness, a great training mode for the genre, solid gameplay, and ACTUALLY REALLY GOOD DELAY-BASED NETCODE! Workshop is an even bigger plus, allowing the community to support the game by making content for it, and it also comes with a very welcoming community if you're a new player. I am absolutely EXCITED to see where this series is going to go after this game!

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Started off rough around the edges but this game has really made its mark with the release of the definitive edition. Honestly if you're a smash fan this is a must play; especially with the addition of the steam workshop mods. It also does a lot to separate itself from smash as to not end up being a complete clone.  Tether ball and endless abyss are great side editions that are probably more fun than smashes side/stadium modes. Characters are all unique and generally play very differently from most smash characters. Combat is more comp oriented than most smash games, while also being a lot more beginner friendly. Custom controls can be made  to meet pretty much any players needs. Great game!

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is really fantastic. while it may not be as big as smash (what game ever could be?); every single aspect of this game is fine tuned to perfection. each of the characters are incredibly balanced and use every single move to its fullest potential. I don't think i've played a fighting game where the characters were so fully realized with an entire arsenal of tools available at a button press. There's also plenty of other modes and additional features; not to mention unlimited modding potential! unlike all the other "smash clones" like brawlout and slap city, this game is truly something special and "rivals" smash itself.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you love indie games and smash brothers then this is legit the best game for you. Not only has it been inspired by smash but the fans and supporters who have been with this title since launch have gave their ideas when this game was in early access. The creator, Dan Fornace has put his soul into this game and has even branched out to other indie developers in order to put characters like Ori and Sein and even Shovel Knight in this game. I am sure there is a fighter out there that is perfect for your kind of play style and strategy. If you do end up getting this game then I look forward to seeing you on the battlefield. Have fun being a rival!!!!!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Controls are ridiculously smooth. Workshop support is only making it better, has potential to be the new M.U.G.E.N thanks to it. Would love to see the mechanics and controls implemented into a platforming game.

EDIT: The definitive edition is out now, and the game is better than ever with new unlockable cosmetics, Rivals of Tether's release, and overall just a very polished experience! Plus, workshop support has expanded dramatically since I last wrote the review, now with support for advanced stage and character scripting, buddies that can alter gameplay, character skins that can give alt movesets... It's just a delight to play. I look forward to the future of Aether games, what with Creatures of Aether now out on mobile and the untitled Aether RPG on its way as well. Potential here to be a beautiful franchise.

review: While I don't play Rivals on PC much due to the fact that I don't have a controller and have to use Keyboard, I do play on Switch, which is incredible. It's somewhat similar to Smash, but still feels unique with most of the cast having a unique gimmick, like Shovel Knight's money/shop system or Zetterburn's fire, and entirely new mechanics like Parrying and Wall jumping out of special fall. Plus, the Workshop on PC adds so much. That being said, if you don't have a controller, I do recommend any of the console versions as the base game is still amazing and playing with keyboard is a pain.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals is a smooth, fast-paced platform fighting game with brilliant character design and engaging combat. Smash Bros. fans will feel right at home, but the game is different enough to feel like a brand new and equally fun title. The story mode is a little lacking, but the wave-based Abyss mode makes up for it. You can create custom colors for every fighter, which is very in-depth and fun. You can also download community-made fighters, stages, and more, which adds a lot to the experience. Overall, Rivals of Aether is a very well-made and tightly created package that can be a lot of fun. I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a tight, competitive platform fighter.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: The game is almost perfect, but this one little detail kinda ruins a perfect 10/10. Say you landed a sick combo, and turned it into a replay. Sometime later, you decide to watch said replay, but instead of showing your supreme victory, it shows you looking like a retard and just throwing out random attacks whenever (Random suicide moves, random aerials, etc), while the CPU somehow behaves like that was what actually happened. Sure, not many people will care, but it's slightly annoying if you wanna watch that super cool combo you done again, just to see it either gone, or followed by you looking like You purchased a Mario game and complained about Mario being the default Player 1 character.

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Dev's finally cleaned up their act and realized locking half a roster behind a paywall in a competitive fighter just wouldn't work. The definitive edition may be more money but at least when you by the game you aren't at a passive disadvantage without dlc (explained in the old review). This is the second best platform fighter out next to smash ultimate, mechanics are great, characters are pretty varied and unique (although I wish the tutorials were more indepth like absa's tutorial has a lot but wrastors is pretty much nothing). I love the workshop's extended cast that just adds on to the uniqueness of the cast with pretty balanced characters. Haven't messed around that much with the story mode but its a cool addition.
It is however, kind of difficult to get into a match and even more difficult to get into a balanced match, you are most of the time going to get destroyed or destroy with pretty much no close game inbetween. It's also a damn shame this game couldn't have rollback, rollback netcode would make this game feel so much better but right now it just feels like smash ultimate with less base input delay.
All in all good game, still would recommend smash over rivals but I think they can keep improving and become a top fighter (ROLLBACK WOULD DEFINITELY HELP THIS even if it is only for PC).





___________ OLD REVIEW BEFORE DEFINITIVE EDITION ____________
Stop locking your roster behind paywalls. 
Ranno, Clairen, Sylvanos, and Elliana are all original characters there is no reason they should be locked behind paywalls. You are a competitive fighting game in what serious competitive environment would you have almost half your fucking roster be locked behind a paywall?

The reason why this is anti competitive is because locking characters behind a paywall no matter how balanced they are there will always be an imbalance. The guy who payed money has more options and can do more than the guy who didn't pay up.

Until this company realizes this, this review will stay a not recommended.
__________ THE COMPANY REALIZED THIS__________________________

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Play Melee Slippi Rollback or even Ultimate, this game is NOT worth $30..

POSITIVES:
+The game is amazing Smash Bros. Melee inspiration with it's fast and fluid gameplay with very interesting and dynamic character play styles and it's own art direction use of sprites. It burrows very entertaining abilities such as wavedashing and wavelanding.

+The game creates very unique ideas of it's own, examples like making your own skin colors for each character and also play testing your character within the character selection screen as you are switching your mapping on your controller, before a game can start.

+Inclusion of Mods and steam workshop expands a game's life span and they seemed to have understood that, allowing people to make characters they always wanted, or use of skins.

NEGATIVES:
-It truly was an amazing game around 2017-2018. 
The story mode is nothing to write home about, as it's shallow story telling only pertains to cutscenes only at the beginning and at the end of a character you have chosen. It's just nothing, but 1-on-1 matches.

-In 2020, the release of the Definitive Edition, I strongly recommend you do not buy this game unless you plan on only playing offline matches. 
The game's online was mediocre before, but it's now in all time low, matches take FOREVER to find, ranging from 10-30 mins, only for you to find someone with a horrible ping. Tried numerous times, in different days, and no dice.

-The online was bareable before, but now, you will struggle to at least get into ONE match. The Dev's have not made any official statements for a week and a half since the release of this game, still no response.

-This game does not also use Rollback netplay, and uses delayed based online play, which is another negative as the netcode is awful.

-The fact that online multiplayer is cut from the game because of the bad online net code, even with the little amount of characters within the roster, and the small stage selection, this game is NOT worth the value $30, not even $20. Wait for a price drop.
I strongly urge you to play Melee instead as this game most likely has no future with it's dwindling player base.

Melee Slippi isn't only FREE and has Rollback netcode, but also provides matchmaking that never exceeds over 15 seconds upon searching!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I love Rivals of Aether! My favorite part is how I keep dying and losing because I'm not good at it. I also like Clairen because she's like if Lucina were a furry and if Lucina were a Marth, also because in the dating simulator, looking at her makes me feel good in a way that makes me feel bad.

Jokes aside, this is a really good game. The game's mechanics are very satisfying to get the hang of, it's less about physically being able to use them (since they're pretty easy to pull off) and more about knowing when's the right time to use your skills in a fight. The characters are all a lot of fun and are very unique, compared to both each other and the Smash Bros. characters they took inspiration from. The stages have straightforward designs that work for competitive play, but you can also play their "Aether" counterparts, which are more like the fun, illegal stages you'd find in Smash. There's just a lot of fun to be had here.

While I do want to stress that the base game is still great on its own merit, the workshop is also worth noting. People are able to make characters, "buddies", and stages for others to download. These range from carefully-made original characters with intricate mechanics like the Rivals cast, to flashy, overpowered and exaggerated meme characters. Both ends of the spectrum and everything in between can be a lot of fun when you want to goof around or take a break from the base game.

Overall, if you liked the competitive aspects of Smash Bros., you're going to have a lot of fun with this game, too! I highly recommend it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals is a really fun, yet deep platform fighter that takes the mechanics of Smash bros. melee and streamlines it so everyone can play it. The characters are all super in depth and the various competitive stage layouts are a pro smash player's dream. 

Definitely pick this game up if you're into competitive platform fighters. If you're a casual, the workshop has endless hours of fun for you and you're friends! 

And to top it all off, you pay a single fee for this game. You'll never feel like you lost because you didn't pay $10 for DLC, everyone has the same cast of characters and the same stages.

In conclusion: buy video game

review: The best platformer fighter in pc in my opinion. It is easy to start of if you are familiar to games like these. You will need a lot of training + watching or at least learning about a few terms so it will be easier to understand and get better at the game. I don't know how it is to play without a controller but it is likely to be pretty bad since you couldn't be as agile + the game literally expects you to use a controller so I would suggest one (preferebly a xbox layout but they can be hard to find cheap compared to playstation layouts)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Long story short; this game is the result of what happens if a bunch of passionate smash fans made a smash game that didn't suck. It's so good. They cut the bullshit from Melee and Ultimate and give this ultra-streamlined love letter to a level of quality the actual Smash Bros franchise wishes they could reach.

As someone who plays videogames you owe it to yourself to own and play this.

Try it. Love it. Worship at Dan Fornace's altar. Maybe then I'll be able to buy the Burrito Kragg skin I thought I didn't want but now absolutely do.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether uses the Smash Bros formula and makes a unique selection of characters that appeal to every type of gamer, both casuals and people that are on the competitive scene can have loads of fun. Although there are as many characters as people would hope, however, Rivals more that makes up for that by having the Community Workshop, which allows people to make their own characters, or bring an already existing character towards the game with unique movesets. The stages are also fantastic, and players are also allowed to create their own stages based on their favorite fantasies and videogames. It may not look like it, but Rivals nails the combat mechanics and the player is allowed to experience the game as they wish. 9/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Old Review: This is a very good game, i've played a lot of it with friends on my old account but i've spent these 42 hours on completing all of the achievements. The story mode gets a 3/10. 3 points for what they wanted to do, having all of these characters story intersect in a satisfying way, and no points for anything else since it was bad and no one had an actual character arc. (The main issue is that you can play it in any way you want, the story is already flawed but the way you'll end up playing it will probably make less sense than it already does. If they revamp this in the definitive edition they should make the fights matter more to the story.) I give abyss mode a 1/10, it took way to long to get all of the characters to level 10 and I got nothing for getting to/past wave 45. The only thing abyss mode was good for is letting me use something other than the default skins on ranked mode for the base game cast. I give ranked mode a 3/10, I thought it'd be fun to try and get some of the special kill achievements on ranked mode and I kept getting matched up with people ranked in gold. I dunno if the online is so dead that I can't even find someone even close to the starting level but it's kind of annoying. Overall, 10/10, good game. I like the funny Penguin skin for Absa.

New Review: The story mode still gets a 3/10. The only change they made to it in the definitive edition is that you can turn cut scenes off... Yay! Abyss is still getting a 1/10. It's going to take an ungodly amount of time to get the DLC characters to LV 10. I appreciate all of the cool abilities and stuff but it's waaaaaaaaay too long. I got nothing for getting to/past wave 45 when I downloaded the definitive edition so i'm going to assume it's still just an annoying achievement. I'm pretty burnt out on this game so I haven't tried ranked mode. I'll update the review if I still get matched with some guy in gold on my first game in my journey to get random to diamond. Overall, 10/10, good game. I like the funny bunny skin for Eliana.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This platform fighter is probably the most polished one that has ever been released by a development studio, the pixel art is fantastic and animations are smooth, the movement is ideal and intuitive, it's both expressive and reasonably simple to get accustomed to. The great is great fun both for veterans of various fighting games and newcomers alike, there is a lot of single player content and the online netcode is pretty fantastic.

Overall, I suggest to anyone reading this to download the game, try abyss mode, versus and online as well as some of the steam workshop content, it will definitely be worth it ^^.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I really like Rivals of Aether. It's easily the best platform fighter other than Smash bros and i think that this game could be huge if it got popular. I really like the development team and all the people behind it. They all seem like nice people and i liked the Rivals Directs theyve put on so far. The workshop on this game is definately the best workshop in any game on steam (that i've played at least), giving players the opportunity to make their own characters and stages is a fantastic idea. I love seeing all the creative characters and moves people create and playing as some classic characters as well.  Speaking of characters, all the characters that are part of the game are really well balanced, fun to play as, and just good designs in general. I really hope this game continues to get updates as i really want it to succeed as a little indie gem like among us has recently.

The reason i think it wont, however, is it's barrier to entry.
You have to be at least in Elite Smash on Smash Bros to stand a chance in Rivals. I've put about 200 hours into Smash Ultimate and a lot into Smash Wii U and 3ds as well. I've also put 30 hours into Rivals of Aether, so i consider myself to be pretty good at it.

I go online, and get my ass handed to me every single time. I have played like 10 online matches and haven't won yet.
I think the reason for this is that the game simply isn't popular enough for "casuals" to play consistently and online, and so the game is dominated by people who have tons of experience in the game and so the skill gap is massive, and definately daunting for new players.

If you're looking for a fun game to play with your friends, this is it. If you're looking for a highly competitive Platform Fighting game, this is it. If you're looking to get into the genre, while these tutorials are good, play Smash Bros first.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I've held off on reviewing this game until Definitive Edition finally came out so a full picture could be obtained and let me say that for the price this game is 100% worth its $30 price tag included in this purchase is 14 characters and plenty of game modes to satisfy your needs from casual stuff like story mode which is admittedly a little weak to the wave by wave abyss mode to the new Tetherball mode to play, and now with the additions of the Milestone system you have more to work towards (new skins stages and pets) and a Ranked system that seems pretty nice so far after a few days and now you can do up to 4 player online I bought this game when it was in Early Access and to this day it has yet to leave me bored my only complaints lie in the weak Story mode and how unforgiving it is with getting new players to a high level 9/10

Controller doesn't work too terribly well, and as much as I would love to enjoy this game, I can't bring myself to wade through the sweat in both casual and ranked to get to a point where I'm having fun playing the game. 

Probably fun for other people, but if the above doesn't sound good, I would give it a pass this time around.

review: This game is very identical to the franchise we all know and love Super Smash Brothers but it's like it's own thing. It's very fun and if you're trying to get into the competitive scene for this game it's not hard at all since it plays a lot like Smash Melee but not as technical. And this game is unique in a lot of ways; from it's story mode, to it's abyss mode, to the custom alt costumes you can set, and much much more! I highly recommend getting this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
See, prior to the launch of DE I started watching tournament vods, lots of CakeAssault, and I was instantly hooked. Then bought RoA today and it feels as good as it does to watch. This game appeals better to competitive players than casual players, but with new additions such as Tetherball the game is more accessible to all playstyles. Long story short, "Furry Smash Trash" is one of my favorite games now.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I purchased this game on Steam as my first ever game on steam, and mainly for the reason that I knew it was inspired by Super Smash Bros, which was my most played game as a kid, and it was on PC. I was delightfully surprised at how much this game brings to the table that is unique, and lets it stand apart from other smash-clones. It's somewhat small cast of characters each have their own different playstyle and beautifully animated set of sprites that I can tell went through a lot of work to get down. With this diverse cast of characters, I haven't found any of them to be lame or not fun to play as, either. Each character feels perfect for this game, and that's a feat I haven't seen many fighting games conquer: having a full cast of fun characters to play as. The music in this game is also phenomenal. I can't tell you how many times I've told my friends to play on the ice map just so I could hear that stage's amazing music. The multiplayer locally is fantastic, and my only complaint about that part of it is that 2+ players online have to be playing on the Workshop branch beta of the game, which means I constantly have to swap between normal and workshop if I want to play with more than just one of my friends online, but I have a great feeling that this problem will be more than fixed in the future release of this game's Definitive Edition coming in the future. The way this game now support workshop is pretty amazing. There is so much you can add to your Rivals experience using workshop. There are custom stages you can find, custom cosmetic "buddies" that follow your character around, custom game modes, and even custom playable characters. This level of options is one of the best Steam workshop experiences I have ever seen. It's just a shame that attempting to play with these custom workshop items online with a friend causes the occasional crash or two, but Rivals does support Steam Remote-Play, so there will be a way to use workshop items with your friends if you so wish. Single-player wise, this game is just alright at, however. As amazing as this game is multiplayer with friends, single player wise, you might find yourself a bit bored out. There is a story mode  for you to complete with each of the original cast of rivals characters, but it really isn't anything too special, as all it consists of is a series of quick matches against various rivals opponent cpu's, and maybe a boss battle. I blew through it in about 30 minutes, and it shouldn't take anyone much longer than an hour or two to get everything they can out of it. It does, however, unlock a pretty interesting mode in the form of Abyss Mode, which in an of itself isn't anything spectacular, but it is a nice little arena challenge to see how long you can last against a huge wave of easily killable enemies. It even comes with it's own separate sub-mode, where you can use custom moves for your Rivals characters that make your character much more powerful depending on which moves you select, such as Zetterburn having no time limit between fireballs, and Kragg being able to have more than one rock in play at once. It is unfortunate that none of the current DLC fighters in this game have access to these runes quite yet, but again, this game will be receiving an overhaul in the Definitive Edition coming out soon. One more thought I'd like to share on this game is that this game is absolutely for everyone. I have gotten friends who were into games like competitive Melee into this game, with the ability to Wavedash in this game, and I have gotten friends who weren't necessarily into competitive smash, but like the series anyways, and love playing this game. It sets the entry level quite low for new players, but the skill ceiling is so incredibly high that you can always find a way to improve at this game. It's a great reason why I love this game's online ranking system. It allows you to practice with others who are probably much better than you in a casual, unranked match, and test your skills ranked in a system that puts you in a match with an opponent that's around the same ranking as you, the player. If your want to get good at this game, it'll implore you to. If you don't really want to pick up a fighting game right now, and just want something to play with your friends casually, that's what this game can do too! It functions very well for both casuals and competitive people alike.

It's a very quality game here on Steam, and I'm giving it a fat 8/10. If these complaints I've mentioned in the Definitive Edition of this game become addressed, this game can easily achieve a 9 or higher.

Edit as of September 24, 2020: It's a 9.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Sorry, no. I really wanted to like this game: everything looks great from the graphics, soundtrack and unique move sets to the responsive controls. But.. it takes about half a hour to find a match.

I actually bought and refunded this before about a year ago. It was the same problem, i literally couldn't find anyone online to play against. I guess i somehow expected that it had been a glitch, bad luck, not enough people playing at the time? After a year surely things had changed, and since there's a definitive edition coming out it seemed like a good time to give it another chance. But no, it's the exact same. 

Be it ranked or casual, independently of the region i pick, it takes on average 20 to 30 minutes to find someone, that is if it finds someone. I don't have high ping or bad connection on any online games, so it's not on my end. Don't really understand how everyone else is playing this game, maybe i've just been cursed and it works fine for others, but seeing as nobody is able to give me a concrete answer and there's no solution to this, i'm forced to once again refund it, won't be giving it another chance.

No. But only because it is my favorite game of all time and that's time i will never get back by, i don't know, not getting comboed by the fire characters or zoned by the DLC characters and doing literally anything else with my time, like maybe doing my homework.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Достаточно долго я искал не особо требовательный к компьютеру файтинг,с механиками аналогичными Super Smash Series, так как игры с опорой на знание механик особо привлекали внимание . Случайно наткнувшись на пиксельартовую и не особо примечательную (на первый взгляд ) Rivals, я начал постигать азы этой приблуды.

Мягкая и достаточно живая графика, пул из 14 персонажей,неплохо для начала. После пары часов игра и не наскучила и даже появился азарт к победе.

На данный момент ,кажется я нашел как одно из любимых развлечений с друзьями, так и крайне любопытный и проработанный способ доказать свое превосходство перед пользователями сети.
Основная особенность обучения этой игры ,это креативность в использовании способностей конкретных персонажей и их влияние на поле боя. К примеру, Kragg, жук с навыками покорения земли создает препятствия для противников,что может быть как преимуществом ,так и помехой для создателя. Zetterburn контролирует поле боя, оставляя за собой огненный след ,который вынуждает оппонента смотреть под ноги и выбирать правильную позицию. К слову,каждый герой в игре имеет подобные особенности,которые формируют уникальные площадки сражения .

В отличии от своих братьев в Rivals of Aether нет механики блока,но все компенсируется большей подвижностью героев и значительной разнообразностью атак. На каждое направление движения,включая стационарное состояние ,есть обычный ,сильный и специальный прием. Соответственно вариации комбо редко наскучат.

Из минусов могу отметить только возможность играть онлайн с друзьями лишь вдвоем( все решается переходом на версию игры с поддержкой воркшопа,появляется возможность создать лобби на 4х) и возможно не самая простая кривая освоения игры(хотя в игре есть обучение,оно не особо раскрывает всех мелочей и фишек )

Я говорил что в игре можно играть на созданных комьюнити персонажах?

Могу посоветовать игру новичкам,которые погружаются в мир комбо брейкеров, казуальщикам ,которые просто хотят получить удовольствие от доминирования над друзьями,так и ярым фанатам серии Super Smash.

Спасибо за внимание!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It is a good game. I can see this as a decent substitute for Smash, Melee, and/or Brawl.

Only problem is that the roster's a bit less if you only bought the game, not the DLC included. Plus, the DLC characters do seem to be a bit costly (though they do feel good to use).

EDIT:

After getting some playtime and learning about the game, it really feels like playing with mods from workshop is more worth it than playing online due to the fact that skill difference is HIGHLY noticeable and that the server connection isn't the smoothest/fastest compared to other games.

It's ok (for me atleast) since I'm used to playing offline/single-player games.

EDIT 2:

After having a definite date of when Definitive Edition will be released I think it is worth the price now to buy the game. Workshop mainly is the content of the game if you don't want to dive too deep into the chaotic casual/ranked queues with only the original roster.

Implementing workshop definitely skyrockets the potential of the game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
When I bought this game I had hoped for a fun competitive experience that would allow me to enjoy a fast paced experience with cool combos and movement options. The problem with this game is that the experience gets increasingly slower and more boring as you get better at the game. This is mostly due to 3 things, parrying, character design, and balance.

1. Parrying
There is no blocking in this game, instead of that, the devs thought it would be a good idea to give all characters Bayonetta Witch Time. Essentially its a counter that will stun your opponent if it connects. This means that any move, no matter how weak or strong, can be punished with a huge combo or get you KO'd. It's a mechanic that heavily rewards defensive play and punishes people for trying to rushdown their opponent and go for cool plays. Parrying a projectile reflects it and gives you invincibility for a bit but your opponent can just parry the reflected projectile and now you're at a disadvantage because your invincibility will run out before theirs. 

2. Design
In a game that seeks to be a spiritual successor to Smash Melee its character design has taken a lot of inspiration from the game's NEGATIVE qualities. Pretty much every character in this game has dishonest hitboxes and/or incredibly strong and spammable projectile(s) you can get combos off of, and the characters who don't have been sitting near the bottom of the tier list for most of the game's life. Characters like Kragg, Ranno, and Orcane are everywhere online because parrying projectiles is very unrewarding. The meta is all about zoning and whiff punishing which makes the pace of the game is much slower than you would expect.

3. Balance
These issues I've brought up are nothing new. People have used these reasons to justify why they do not want to compete or even touch the game and yet nothing has been done about it. Balance patches are released almost every month (which also means you lose your replays very quickly) but in the 300+ hours I've had on this game I have yet to see any productive changes made. I wish the devs would take notice of these things but it seems like they are relatively disjointed from the community and want to do their own thing. Thank you for reading.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is absolutely one of the most solid games I've ever played.
Meanwhile single-player options are scarce and overall... passable, the community has made this game really great.
Online is a ghost town, so you're gonna have to search for people to play with.

So... why am I reviewing it positively?
Because once you have all you need, it's one of the best fighters out there!
Solid Movement, a Pretty Cast with AMAZING MOVEMENT, ATTACKS AND SKILLS, incredible depth-
AND there's Workshop support, bringing that singleplayer aspect to a good solution!
For me, with Workshop alone, it's worth it. But the community and the feel of the game...
It's a great game. It has flaws, but it's a great game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Edit: Will update this review after Definitive Edition comes out, since it will change the part about the value of DLC.  Also the workshop update means this game has more content than any vanilla Smash Bros game.  Because dan4nace enjoys fan content like a real human being.

This review is written without online in mind; I hated the online, but I hate online gaming in general, with my favorite games being local MP.  Moving right along.

Well built movement system that I feel really captures what makes Smash Bros Melee such a hit, while at the same time lessening the punishing mechanics that Melee had, leaving you with a much more approachable Smash-like platform fighter with fast speed and depth.  While I feel like tutorials in fighting games are ultimately pointless, this games tutorial does a very good job of showing the advanced, hidden mechanics that separated competitive and casual Smash play.  On a similar note, Training Mode includes several features such as Input Advance and display hitboxes/DI lines that I wish every modern fighting game would put in.  I'm not too steeped in the meta, so all competitive comments I say should be taken with a grain of salt... but I feel like the character balance has taken the "everyone is super" approach.  Many characters excel so well with their own abilities that they are viable, even when matches between differently skilled players can seem one sided.  At the time of writing this, I hear complaints of Ranno the Frog(the most recent DLC character, with another one on the way), though he with his somewhat recent arrival to the game, he hasn't taken over the comp scene so?  All the characters feel capable of playing aggressively, and all do so while having their own unique quirks.

On the topic of the DLC, its hard to come to a conclusion on this one.  I generally dislike DLC because of its inflated price compared to the original game in comparison.  Truth is that relative to the DLC, the original game didn't have that much cotent to begin with... but I'm getting ahead of myself.  The DLC is well built; the new stages and characters are of equal if not better quality to the base game.  I feel like Ori is a bit steep in his price, most likely cause Micro$oft royalties.  Clarien/Ranno seem fair in comparison, $5 for 2 characters and stages seems fine for this game.  A “Definitive Edition” is confirmed down the line, so keep that in mind if DLC is putting you off.

Base game doesn't have much content, but the content it does have is extremely well polished.  I had this game since early access, and the stage/character art has improved significantly since then(community page has some artwork of the old sprites, if you want a flashback).  Stages are simplistic with little variety, probably reflecting Melee's issue of how many stages were un-viable for serious gameplay.  All base stages do have Aether forms though, to spice up casual play(just like Melee, there is still some of them I REFUSE to go to).  Single player is mostly forgettable, consisting of a bland story mode and an Abyss mode featuring Multi man fights and short mini games.  Abyss mode is interesting, and the level up/customization it offers is pretty interesting, especially in the additional versus mode it offers for silly brokeness.

Overall worth the asking price, a definite if on sale.  The value of well made gameplay throws this to #1 in my Smash-like games on PC, and has even put a dent in my interest in Smash 4.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Even though I already owned this game long beforehand, I only came back to it after the addition of Steam Workshop support was announced. I have to say, even without the workshop, this game is a lot of fun and I'm almost ashamed of myself for putting this game aside for so long.

I honestly believe that this game is a better platform fighter than Super Smash Bros, and stands out well enough on it's own with its own unique features, a couple examples being the parry mechanic replacing shielding, and no ledges to prevent overly campy playstyles. 
The characters themselves also feel very unique, each having their own gimmick that their moveset is designed to compliment, and while some characters do borrow a move or two from Smash, this game doesn't rely on taking moves from it.
I think the only thing Super Smash Bros. holds over this game is how casual it is, quantity of characters, and being harder to execute techniques like wavedashing, but almost all of those issues are solved with the addition of workshop mods, and makes up for techniques being easier to do with how deep the character movesets are.

It's a shame that barely anybody plays this game compared to other games, because it's genuinely such a good one. Many people may complain about constantly being matched up with good players, but I think that's to be expected with a game that doesn't have as many players as other games. If you really want a competitive platform fighter experience, this game will definitely be for you. Or if you're putting this game aside purely because most of the cast is consisting of animal characters, it'd be good for you to fall out of that mindset, because you're seriously missing out.

10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The controller settings is the buggiest shit I've ever experienced, I've been trying to get it to work for the past 20 minutes. Every time I save my custom settings and start a online game they are set back to default. And then my custom settings get reset to default as well so I have to redo everything just for it to reset when I start a match and it's infuriating. The only settings literally have my custom controls enabled, so why does it keep using the default?! What am I supposed to do? 

I googled this issue and only see threads from around 2015... Seriously? Why is this still a problem in 2020...

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A fighting game that will be loved for ages. Inspired by smash, specifically the best competitive smash game melee, the game's mechanics as a fighting game are simply BEAUTIFUL, techniques such as wavedashing and vertical recoveries turn this from a smash inspired game into A BEAUTIFUL fighting game that's looks amazing for spectators and plays even better for players. And with all the characters, online play, and the amazing game mechanics, if that's not enough there is official MOD support !!! It is so easy to install mods and have fun ! If you want a good competitive game, or a fun party game you found the right game !

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'm surprised I haven't reviewed this game yet. What else is there to say? After seeing the latest Rivals Direct, I just sit here wondering if they can strike gold twice. You look at my hours on record and assume they were well spent, but I can guarantee you more than half of it was spent sweating on Abyss Mode and styling on A.I. Only a fraction of it has been spent going online and I'll tell you something. Online is absolutely wretched for casuals. That is only because the people we call 'tryhards' are at every corner you look. Other than that, the game is an absolute blast. I can forgive the online play. I don't see a need for validation that I am better than my competition because at the end of the day, everyone is just trying to express their own love for the game.

For all of you people out there who are pissing your pants over all the sweats that plague the online community, just remember that it takes a certain amount of love and ambition to put your all into something that only exists through the LED's in a monitor. Oh god, I'm aimlessly rambling again... Bottom line is, I love people who love what they do! Can't wait to meet you all in the definitive edition!

review:
For anyone that plays competitive Smash Ultimate (and Melee to some degree), there is no reason to keep playing it when this game exists.

[list]
    [*]Freeform combos for all characters
    [*]Balance is very good
    [*]Each character is very unique
    [*]WAY Better netcode than Ultimate
    [*]Solid tutorial
    [*]Good music
    [*] Parrying >>>>> Shielding
    [*]Unlike Ultimate, heavies don't suck in this game
[/list]

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Great game with different and unique characters and ability's the option to customize them and change their colors. Then you have the maps which can be played in two ways Standard Battle Arena or Aether Mode which has map events that can cause changes within it from the story mode boss and arena to the dlc ones which all have unique features in them. Then we have the dlc's which will be made free within one of the updates but at the time I'm writing this they aren't but if you get them prior to being free you get special outfits for them which is pretty neat in my opinion. but in the end I say this game is WORTH the 15$ it can be broadcasted and you can use remote play through steams sharing feature so you can play with you friends! So yes it is worth it in the end have a great day all!

review:
When it comes to platform fighting games all I want is a game with tons of combos and lots of movement tech.
smash bros seems to not get the memo instead we get projectile, and long distance characters while rushdown
characters are left in the dust rivals of aether not only fixes these problems but is just more creative with each character. why have someone with a super charged punch or a counter or reflector when you can have puddle jumping, making a bubble to trap people and use to recover, and ori. and this game thanks to the workshop can have endless content so give this game a try if you like combos, unique movesets and endless content.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
i liek clarion. she has a sword. swords are cool.

In all seriousness: extremely fun indie game for fans of Super Smash Bros who might be overwhelmed by ultimate having three hundred characters. 

Its similar to Melee in the sense that characters feel sluggish before you learn how to play but once you start learning the skill ceiling is very high. 

In alot of ways its superior to Smash. There is an in depth training mode that goes over everything from basic movement and attacks to more advance tech (wave dashing/ landing, Reverse Aerial Rush etc). You can change/playtest controls at the character select screen. Practice mode allows you to turn on hitboxes among other things. There is even a story mode that isn't amazing by any stretch but is fun and provides context/ lore to the game.

10/10 would recommend.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Fun fact. One punch man cannot beat a toenail. Why? Well the hit box of the toenail is just under the one and only attack of One Punch man. Because One Punch man only has one attack, and it can't hit the toenail, this means that you, the toenail, can mercilessly beat the crap out of your friend. This led to getting my friend to rage quit for about 5 seconds before starting another match as Cosmic Ronald and beating the crap out of me by folding the Universe in half. Great game. Would recommend if you have friends to play it with online or locally.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is the best of its kind in the realm of platform fighting for the PC. I originally purchased it before I had a Nintendo Switch but am still impressed by its unique approach. I love the idea of each character being tied to the power of the elements and the short story mode that introduces each one. Those who put the time into learning the advanced strategies for each character through the extensive tutorial system will get the most out of the competitive experience. The art style and movement abilities such as parrying make this game stand out from others like it. While the character roster may not be large, the focus remains on the effective utilization of each move set. If you ever enjoyed any Super Smash Bros. game and are looking for a different approach to that formula, then choose your Rival and jump into the chaos beyond the Aether! Game on.

review:
This game is really fun to play with friends online or in local. 
You can pvp on a same screen or online and improve your skills. (up to 4 players)

It really looks like Smash Bros but it's much more technical and strategic,
with cool pixel graphics. 

It has a good community and has a lot of potential.

It would be nice if it was playable on MacOS with Cross Platform Multiplayer. But the remote play together is awesome, you can play with people that doesn't own the game.


Buy it and try it, that's the best way to make your own idea !

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Its a fun smash clone if you're really into being hyper aggressive. The lack of shielding causes some things to be a little janky and some setups to be ridiculously hard to deal with. On top of that, having no ledge can make recovering a bit linear ( even if you mix it up with air-dodging and delaying your up special). Don't even get me started on how unbalanced the characters are. All these things add up to rivals completely missing the mark on what to update in the smash formula. Instead of adding changes that benefit the players or gameplay it adds changes that deteriorate the formula and make fore a less user friendly experience.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I love how it is easy to play! Not easy that the gameplay is bad and abusable, but the kind of easy that gives you a good headstart when you make a move. Every character has a very different playstyle, Zetterburn being good at neutral stuff, Kraag being good at being a tank, Wrastor is very good in the air, Orcane can sneak up on opponents and surprise them, and so much more! I have not purchased the DLC (as of this review), but the tutorials provided to play them makes me want to buy them because of how much more versatile they are in gameplay, but that is a drawback in how more complicated they are to play. Overall, I really recommend this game, and I encourage those who haven't bought it and like fighting games.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
TL:DR at bottom

The game itself is amazing, each character has its own unique moveset (unlike others like brawlhalla which just have a lot of common weapons that are virtually the same as eachother with signature moves making the difference between legends). Each character also has its own gimmick. For example, Kragg is a super slow and super heavy stone golem thing that is able to create terrain (either a stone pillar or a square boulder that can be thrown around and placed) to change the map in his favor. On the other hand, etalus is a polar bear that can create ice on the map, which either allows him to slide around very quickly or smash it to gain a type of hyperarmor (basically he cant flinch from being hit easily).

So, all this is well and good. The main problem with the game arises with matchmaking. The ranked gamemode is fine for the most part, a bit iffy. But if you just want to have fun, this is the absolutely wrong game to come to. The casual gamemode has no matchmaking whatsoever, which means if this is your first game, welcome to being put into a stunlock until death and then getting taunted while you respawn. It is an overall nightmare. Even 46 hours in, whatever matchmaking the "friendly" gamemode has hasn't picked up that I am unable to deal with someone who probably plays the game 8 hours a day, 7 days a week and that I should be put with players that are also in this predicament.

This game is fun with friends, but that is about it honestly. the Story/Campaign is nonexistent and is basically just a tutorial for learning the basic characters (oh, btw you start with 8 basic characters but the other 10 characters are much better but are locked behind paywalls with no way to obtain them otherwise, kind of EA of the devs but w/e.) The game is basically dedicated to people who either want to play with friends or want to go pro with the game with nothing in between.

TL:DR

Good game with friends, anything else is just a salt-fest nightmare, good characters locked behind a solid paywall with no other way to access them.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is amazing. Came for the workshop, stayed for the solid gameplay. While this game is clearly inspired by Smash, it definitely finds it's own footing and makes for a really fun experience. Every character is fun to play, each with their own combos that you can master. The stages look really nice and feel great to play on, and having the option to turn hazards off means you don't have to feel scared about trying to play in a more competitive fashion.

There are tutorials not only for tech in the game, but each character too, so you know the in's and out's of your character when going into a battle. The story mode is interesting and fun, even if it is short. It's kind of like Classic Mode in Smash, but if each character had an interesting-to-follow storyline to go with it. Abyss Mode is interesting, pitting you against endless waves of mini challenges, whether it's knocking out loads on enemies or destroying hexes in a short amount of time.

Now, on it's own, this is an amazing game. But the real fun starts when you go onto the Workshop.

The Workshop turns this game from great into amazing. There's geniuinely something for everyone, whether you want to play as the really well designed OC characters, characters from franchises you already know whether they're a recreation of Smash incarnation or they go a step further and try making original movesets (and either way are really fun), or hell, even meme characters like Ronald and 100% Accurate Fox, where they're clearly designed to be OP, but they still make for a great time none the less. There are also many custom stages on the workshop for you to mess around with, whether it's something as simple as Final Destination to full-out Boss Fights. 

My only problem with this game is that the Workshop kind of holds you back from progressing. When in the Workshop Beta, Aether coins aren't saved, Points toward achievements don't count (Even if you play as the default characters) and Story Mode won't save your ranking in each story. I kind of understand why it's like this, but on the other hand it kinda means you play one or the other instead of being able to do both at the same time. It is easy to switch between the Workshop beta and the current version, however to do this you must restart the game. I kind of wish they made it so you could still gain achievements in the Workshop Beta, but you have to be playing with Default Characters on a Default Stage, or at the very least so Aether coins save in both modes.

As a side note, I wish I could access Abyss Mode while in the Workshop beta. However with this one I fully understand why it's like this (Would be hard to program runes for Workshop Characters), but even then they could make it so you can't use the Workshop characters in that mode, similar to how you can turn them off in Vs. matches while still on the workshop beta. 

Overall, this game gets a solid 9/10 from me. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys fighting games (especially Smash) and those who love nights sitting on the couch with friends playing games such as Smash.

review: a very authentic smashlike which draws from a host of smash oriented design choices while conservatively implementing a host of its own unique mechanics. netcode is pretty decent for no rollback, coast-to-coast USA matches feel good over ethernet. if you have friends who are interested in this sort of game, or someone you want to get into fighting games, this is an excellent way to start them off, though a gamecube controller is recommended!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is very high quality. The sprite art is good and the gameplay is very solid. DLC isn't too expensive either, and if you get it all, the price is only around 55 or so dollars, which is cheaper than smash ultimate. Plus, workshop makes it so the roster is one of the most unique in any fighting roster. Custom skins are also really nice and can really make your main or secondary unique compared to other people. My only real gripes with the game is that finding players to fight online can be difficult. Hell, I haven't found a single person online. Though that's not really a problem due to the devs.

Over all, I would give this game a 9/10. Very, very solid.
