title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether has been in my sights for quite some time now, because I've been a long-time fan of SSB and other fighting games. I decided to give it a shot, and honestly...

The game is good. it is VERY. VERY GOOD.

but there's very little content. not even ten caracters to choose from, and the DLC honestly feel pretty extreme - I could buy whole new games for the price of a single character.

I hoped the Workshop content would still make it worthwhile.
it doesn't.

quality is all over the place, and even the more curated options just... don't seem to fit with the game.
There's also some more major grievances. the control setup options are atrocious to me, as I'm used to having more options as well as the ability to bind multiple actions to the same key, such as up and jump, allowing me to perform tilts, up-finishers, short-hops AND jumps... using only two keys, instead of a total or four. this results in massive frustration at knowing exactly what I want to do, knowing I normally could pull it off with a more effective keyboard setup scheme, but being foiled repeatedly because such options do not exist.

I'll stick to Super Smash Flash 2, a free game with three times the content, better response to controls and customization, which also includes online play. This is just not worth it, for me... Sorry.

But I won't deny it is extremely well put together everywhere else.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
An amazing platform fighter if you're willing to spend time with it. 
The movement and combat mechanics are fluid and reasonable for a new player to perform without extensive practice, the visuals are beautiful and recognizable, and the character design/balance is unmatched in the genre, even by the game series Rivals was inspired by. Plus, the workshop is the first to allow the community to easily create their own platform fighter, buddy, and stage concepts this easily.  Don't buy it if you don't want to dedicate time to learn the aforementioned movement and combat mechanics; all that will be left is the "Story Mode", which is just timed CPU battles with some nice pixel art, and the Abyss Mode, which gets incredibly repetitive. Do buy it if you want a refreshing competitive experience.

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Challenging, but a whole lot of fun. I obviously need to get better at it, but it's still an overall good game. 

Some downsides I can think of:

If you don't buy most of the DLC, you're kinda left with a small character roster and not too many stages. 

And that if you're more of a casual player and don't get competitive with these types of games too often, this might not be for you as I feel a lot of the characters moves and ideas lean more towards competitive play rather than general. That's not a bad thing, not at all. Just be prepared to deep dive into what competitive Smash players have been dealing with for years now.

But this is still a great game, and easily the best Smash clone out there right now.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Have you ever thought: why was I so much sexier 10 years ago?  If you're thinking, "but I was only 6 years old," this probably doesn't apply to you.  Time travel would be super duper, but Rivals of Aether is the next best thing.  Rivals of Aether might give the rest of you a chance to go back in time and crush the hopes and dreams out of anyone who thought they were pretty good at video games.  If you're like me, it gives you a chance to go back in time and try to git gud while juggling a full time job, school work, home ownership, and all the other stupid crap that gets in the way of devouring all the pixel sekts this game has to offer.

Look, I don't need 5,300 hours like the ding dong who gave Day Z a negative review.  This game makes me want to drop my online degree, and crush the upcoming generation of gamers.  More likely, in my advanced age, I'll just wish that I could create some pixel art that has a fraction of the quality.  Then, maybe after years of failing to create any kind of pixel art that doesn't make me sick, I'll realize that these guys have amazing animations and tight controls and I'll go back to enjoying the hell out of this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is absolutely fantastic. The characters are charming and the gameplay mechanics are smooth and satisfying. It's comparable to the likes of the Smash Bros series, but quicker and engineered with competitive gameplay in mind. The workshop mode is phenomenal, the possibilities are practically endless, with brilliantly crafted fan characters, some looking like they belong with the main cast. You can also play as beloved fictional characters, making this game potentially the biggest crossover event. Furry Smash Bros is all in all worth every penny, and will definitely stand the test of time, as we anticipate more workshop fighters, stages, and even an all new 3D model version of the game in a couple years. The only problems are the lack of grabs and shields, but its not detrimental to the game's overall quality.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is very good when it comes to style and art design. From the element inspired characters, to the lighting fast game play. Players can find themselves doing amazing combos to secure a KO or engaging in a intense neutral game with these fun and often exciting characters, fitting to most fighting styles. The balancing is very nice between characters so anyone you pick wont be hammered down by their level viability. Top this with a community workshop and you got a great game!

But this review is a No and here is why

I said in the good side of the review this game has lighting fast game play. That can be part of the problem for some players. the speed in which characters move can be a bit daunting for players new to this game. That in itself is not a bad thing but I will like for you to keep this in mind when  you keep reading.

another issue i have is the controls. in my opinion, they handle weird... For instance special moves. in order to do a special move (lets say we want to do a up special move) you must push in one direction and while holding that direction press the special button. what makes it weird is that you cannot press these at the same time. it has to be move then special. This results in a lot of players moving a bit before the do the input they meant to do.for new players it makes their movement quite clunky which is not bad....on the ground. when you get to the situations where you are in the air. it is a whole different story. that weird but normal input. becomes paramount to you getting back on a stage. and in a game where it is fast. one wrong input can spell death in a lot of cases. 

another point of for annoyance me and this game is the defensive options. You can see that the developers want players to engage with other players on the map but for me it really makes the game oppressive on players who want to play defense. I also said in the good side of review that characters are fitting to most fighting styles. But I feel like one of the styles that are kinda weak here are defensive ones. From the lack of shields to not being able to hold ledge even the size of the map and how small they are on average makes a defensive player really uncomfortable. I can imagine this being polarizing since no one wants to get "zoned" out on a big map. That also is not fun. I think this hurts the experience because there is not a lot of down time. to compare smash brothers and fighting games in general have blocking. this allows the player to relive some pressure when in a undesirable situation for a small moment the player has a time to breathe and get out of getting hit over and over. ledge grabbing the same thing. giving the player a second to get themselves together if only just a small bit. instead when you are on the defense you are left to DI. a tech that relies on you moving your character in a direction to  escape the combo or avoid the blast box. 

now do not get me wrong, there is defensive tools. but the problem is these you need to time it in order to work. and to replace ledge grabbing characters get a wall jump. this may seem cooler but now it  makes recovering harder. and  for the one who is defending you from grabbing the ledge it makes their job somewhat easy. this makes a very offensive environment. 

From the small stage, the odd input combination, fast game play and the lack of defensive option to relieve pressure. inexperience players will not feel as if this is game where they have a fighting chance. To put it simply- the skill floor is high and player will easily find themselves demoralized. 

when i played online ranked for the 1st time. i was a bit confused when I  saw a sort of striking system. but after a few seconds. I knew what kind of game this audience was catering to. This game feels like a more inherently competitive like say street fighter. but it has the mechanics of a platform fighter like smash brothers.

Now even though I do not recommend this game. I wont refund it. I am quite used to this competitiveness in games. But I do not write this as if I am experiencing  this i write it from someone who is new to this type of game. to put it simply the appeal will draw players in but the difficulty, weird input and speed of the game will draw some of the same players out. 

For those reasons I will not recommend this to most people. I just do not think it will up a lot of people's alley.

though i will say the workshop has been amusing to look at. Thanks for reading :)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I do want to hit "Yes" as I do think the game in it's skeleton is good - however looking at it from the point of view of enjoyable play, it's a no. Your character cannot grab ledges, there is no grab function at all actually and you can't tech in the air, only dodge. Once you are in a "combo" which is really just a mash of buttons from the opponent, you cannot escape. Although there is a tech and dodge feature, once you are locked in being hit, you cannot use them, they can only be used pre-hit. 

So basically if you are playing against someone who's perfected the timing of most of the basic moves you will be hit from 0% to death in one motion. This to me makes the game niche and kind of lame. It will limit the amount and type of players to only those willing to grind out the skills to time hits as there is little wiggle room for luck or just that hidden equilibrium of a fair fight. This is of course fairly true with most fighters so it's not like i'm trying to single this one out. If you like watching yourself get smashed around on a screen with little chance of getting to play the game, this ones for you. Otherwise the game is actually great.

*Pros 
- Graphics are great
- Gameplay is smooth
- Sounds and soundtrack are great
- Very small game, easy to download and very easy to get into a friends game or lobby
- You can make your own characters which is sweet but you'll need to do a little work in order to make them

*Cons
- There are a total of 8 characters that you can play unless you pay to unlock another 4 so a whopping 12 characters 
- You cannot tech in the air, you can't hold onto ledges and you can't grab. This in itself kind of limits the casual playability of the game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a technical platform fighter, with the kind of gameplay you might see in a tournament set of Super Smash Bros. Melee or the competitive Brawl-mod Project M. There are no random items in this game.

What I really like about Rivals of Aether is that instead of being some kind of blind copy of Melee's physics and quirks, it reimagines this technical fast-paced gameplay that's unique to Melee (and PM) as something intentional. Melee's competitive scene is a result of a decade's worth of discarding parts of the game that make the game a bad competitive game, finding ways to exploit the game's physics engine to do cool stuff, and grinding tech skill way past what the developers ever expected.

You have a game about two (or more) players fighting to knock each other off a small stage with some platforms, using only their character's unique moveset and their own skill. The game's physics, character controls, and hitboxes make it possible to move around the stage quickly and effectively, letting you chain attacks together to defeat the other player in a satisfying and rewarding way. But you also have the tools to escape combos and recover back on stage, and when you play another player you're always trying to get in each other's head. Melee's competitive play is unique and interesting, but it's not what the developers had in mind when they made the game.

Rivals of Aether on the other hand has this kind of competitive play as its vision, a reimagining where everything is designed from the ground up with intent and purpose. And it shows.
-Characters are constantly tweaked and the game was patched according to player feedback to keep the game balanced.
-The game's singleplayer offerings complement the multiplayer by teaching you how to play and building on your fundamentals. Getting good at Abyss, the most arcadey mode, still involves learning how to move your character quickly and learning the range of other characters' attacks.
-Inputs are streamlined, customizeable, and buffered. You don't have to do frame perfect hand-breaking button presses just to move around the stage and do what you want, and this makes the game a lot easier to get into at any level of play, and is one of the big reasons I play this instead of Melee. No l-cancels, wavelands feel great. The fact that you can use whatever controller you want and customize your controls helps, but the main factor is intentional design.
-You can play solo, play locally with friends, or play online. Though its ranked and random online modes aren't very active outside of the US, joining one of the discords lets you jump in and play another player online at any time through Steam. And trust me, the online is way better than Ultimate's.

RoA manages to preserve the genre's depth while rejecting the artificial difficulty you get from frame perfect button presses and unintentional game design, and I'm a big fan of that. If you ever watched Evo and thought "wow Melee looks cool, but there's no way I can play like that" then you really need to check this out. The fact that it's a lightweight indie game that you can purchase for a fraction of the price of an old nintendo console + old nintendo game controller + old nintendo game also helps.

Obviously this isn't just "Melee: the indie game" and I think there's a lot in this game that appeals to people who just can't relate to Melee's appeal, I just wrote this from a competitive Smash point of view.

Finally, I'd just like to say that the characters are cool and I like the art a lot and the music's really good too. Kragg is cute. That's all.

Edit: 
Matchmaking through discord is the most common way to find people to play. If you're considering picking up RoA I recommend joining one of the main RoA discords:

https://discord.gg/RoA Official Discord (main hub/NA focused)
https://discord.com/invite/0XU22LeXTgWhyZ6c EUcord (EU server)
http://discord.gg/smash (AU server)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Really fun to play both local and online. I enjoy fighting games where you can easily string together huge combos to deal tons of damage, as well as fast gameplay. One problem I have though, is that there are not buttons if you use a PlayStation controller, but that's not an important problem. My biggest problem is that characters like Sylvanos and Ori are extremely powerful, but they're DLC. This makes it a pseudo-pay2win but not by a lot. Also, this might just be me, but the online could use some optimization, big-time. When it works, it works perfectly. But when your opponent has only like 100 ping, you just lose connection immediately.
-
Overall, it's a great game. The inclusion of the Steam Workshop is also a very good thing about the game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's a great fighter with fun and colorful characters. If you enjoy Smash Bros, then you'll probably like this game. It's very inspired by Melee, so Melee players should feel pretty at home. 
The only negative I can say is that it's not quite as friendly to new players as Smash games, but the tutorials do a great job in giving new comers everything they need to take their game to the next step.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Game controls beautifully, has deep & different characters, and wears its inspirations from Smash with pride! Art style is gorgeous, customisable of controls & character designs are a welcome plus! Only downside is that you have to pay extra to unlock the best stages, and half the roster. title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I recommend this game for the workshop only. The game is alright but doesn't have the selling power of most platform fighters because of a lack of iconic characters other than the Shovel Knight DLC. The game itself is pretty fun, although it doesn't do a whole lot to innovate and is kind of basic in practice, I'd personally give it like a 7.8 or something for the appealing graphics.

However, the workshop totally turns this on it's head and brings it up to like a 9 for me because of the amount of community involvement and freedom that games like Smash Bros can't offer.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I love Smash bros. but don't have a switch and thought of finding a similar game when I came across Rivals. I initially took it as "Smash on PC" but this is honestly one of the most fun, challenging, and technical platform fighters out there. Each character has specific tech and characteristics they bring to the table and the diversity is solid. Do expect to run into high-level opponents when going online. I definitely recommend 10/10. 

P.S. Rollback for RoA pls

review: I bought this game because I wanted to play Smash as Ronald McDonald, Sans, and Untitled Goose, but once I finally got around to playing the game as the main roster, I realized that this game is still really fun even if you just play as its original characters- the gameplay is fast, the controls are tight, and it changes up the mechanics from Smash just enough to make it a unique experience while still feeling just familiar enough that anyone who has played a platform fighter before can jump right in.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is a really well crafted experience. It doesn't really do anything for casual players looking to play casually but it's awesome for beginners looking to get into what makes platform fighters so fun. It has useful tutorials and a great community on discord for learning as well as mechanics made with the user in mind.
    It doesn't have too many characters but they are all very unique. Almost all of them push the boundaries of what mechanics can work in a platform fighter as opposed to just being the same concepts with different numbers.
    If you have any interest in playing a smash-like that encourages you to git gud without being nearly as brutal as melee and for a very good price, I'd highly recommend.

review:
This game is un-ironically more fun than Smash Ultimate with all of the workshop characters, stages, etc... On top of that, the base roster and stage variety is also nice, and the DLC is worth buying, especially the characters, but the alt colours for characters are nice to have too. This game is stupid fun with your friends, especially with the workshop characters making my friends dreams come true with certain characters in smash... To an extent...

Overall, get this game! It's amazing!

review:
Smash but more aggressive. 

No shields, just parry. Only specific characters have grabs, and only as a special. No ledge grabbing but you have a wall jump, making recovery and off-stage fighting more technical. Takes the best tech from melee and leaves behind the stupid ones. 

In a lot of ways, I actually prefer Rivals over smash.

review: 10/10 gameplay. A really fun and fast-paced platform fighter, with as much complexity and depth as Melee, but more accessibility and more uniqueness to each character. I also found learning the game had a much less painful learning curve and was immediately more accessible, due partly to streamlined and/or redesigned mechanics (no shields, grabs, or edge-guarding, and instead extra frames on moves when you whiff them) and because of its tutorial and just great design.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: It feels like ultimate and to some degrees but less laggy, more balanced and with wavedashing and gimmicks or secodnary goals for each character to achieve to attain victory. It feels like a new game while taking inspiration from other games like melee. I love the moveset choices and combo potential of the characters, the fact that all characters can wall jump after a upward special/ up b recovery to allow them to recover once more is very interesting change to allow for the removal of traditional grabs and ledges to speed up the flow of the game. You can still airdodge in place spot dodge or roll. The game also has loads of cool things separate from melee, reminds me of brawl with the amount of character specific setups and tech. It also has an arcade mode style story but I think abyss mode is a more fun and challenging mode

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is a lot of fun. I'm a sucker for games with good movement options, and this game delivers. I've played the majority of smash games. Project M and Melee being the ones with my favorite game play (Ultimate definitely has the better roster though). But above all of those, Rivals just FEEEEEELS so good to play. Moving around feels so good and landing a spike on someone hits the G Spot of your brain. Plus, the community has put out some amazing characters with the added workshop support. Some of my favorites being Ronald McDonald, Master Chief, and Pac man. This game is easily worth the $14.99 price tag, and is a no brainer at a discount.

ALSO: All of the DLC Characters are going to become free with the release of the definitive version. Those who have already purchased them get some exclusive taunts. And they're adding a tether ball mode which looks pretty neat.

review: My brother asked me if I wanted to install a game he had heard about. As you may guess, it's Rivals Of Aether. Of course, I didn't want to lose my money on a game I didn't like, so I asked him to give me a description of the game. He said it's pixelated SSB, has custom characters, and some other stuff. I was sold. I had always loved SSB my whole life, and to see a pixelated one, with custom characters really gave me the refresher for games I play. I'm having tons of fun, learning characters, and getting more custom characters and, also learning them. 5 star game in my book :)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is just Smash Bros. if the creator actually gave a fuck about wanting to make a well balanced fighting game. The movement feels amazing, all characters have interesting and unique styles and gimmicks and the game features an in-depth tutorial that explains every single mechanic, from Wavedashing to DI, in painstaking detail.

The netplay has near unnoticable input delay if you play in same region, only downside at the moment is the matchmaker that can honestly barely be called a matchmaker as it chooses seemingly random, local play is a bliss however.

The roster is a bit small compared to most other fighting games but not a single character is a lazy copy of another, not even slightly. All 14 characters in this game are made to be as unique and distinct from one another as possible and learning to play each character feels like a comepletely new experience every time.

Also, the workshop is a gigantic clusterfuck of one stupid memefest, if you're into that sort of thing. And many people have and will continue to buy this game just for custom workshop characters, but if you happen to be one of those, I implore you, give the real game a chance while you're at it, you might end up loving it.

Though while we're at trying out. Biggest repulsor of this game is without a doubt the learning curve, which is so steep it might as well be a cliff wall. When you start this game and are still quite bad at it, you WILL get your bright red beaten ass handed to you. Learning how to net get combo'd by your opponent is something that takes a lot of practice and cannot be achieved by simple tricks and since the matchmaker is an unholy abomination (mostly because so few people play this game) you can't really help but be matched against people who will, mostly involuntarily, absolutely demolish you.
You can somewhat forego this issue by using the various Discord servers that the community has dedicated to helping you find opponents of your skill level and helping new players learn the game, which I sincerely recommend. The learning curve will still be just as steep but at least you got people throwing you some ropes instead if kicking you down.

Other than that, this game is a really solid, fun and competitive fighting game. It emulates what Smash could have been if Masahiro Sakurai dind't just want to create a party game and it succeeds flying colors.

Also the creator, Dan Fornace, has a really cute dog and keeps posting vids and pictures on twitter and is also a cool dude, go check it out.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I first got this game a while back thinking it was just your regular smash clone. I was hoping the game would be sorta like smash because I was into platform fighters. Dang was I surprised. I started off playing the game and doing the in-depth tutorials on movement, combat, and on each specific character. It started to feel better and better as I started progressing as a player. What I realized is that this game is heavily inspired off of Super Smash Bros Melee. Wave dashing, wave landing, dash attack canceled up smash (DACUS), you name it. All of that tech was taken from Melee and improved on. No ledge camping (or ledges at all) make for an even faster paced game. They even added some new tech to separate from Melee. The game is incredibly made and each and every character is unique and balanced (unlike smash). This game was built to be competitive and has been since day one. If you're a casual player who isn't really looking into the competitive part of Rivals, they even came up with workshop so you can play custom made characters from tons of people in the community. Overall it's an outstanding game and really shows what platform fighters are meant to be. The true rival of the smash bros series.


TL;DR Fantastic game play, better than smash, amazing competitive scene.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A must have game for anyone who has ever or WILL ever enjoy smash bros. The competitive elements of melee, combined with an engine that makes these inpputs much more accessible and practical. 14 specialized characters means there's a character that will click and feel fantastic. Stylized pixel art style means the game is fun to look and dosent suffer performance issues. The one caveat to this game is that in general, the ranked online system can be a bit hostile, in that the skill disparity can be quite steep, so make sure to pick this up with a friend if you can. I've played platformer fighters since the release of melee, and this is my favorite "Smash" game of all time.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Game is really good and i like how there is a workshop, but. It's really not fun playing against AI, Or at least in my opinion, My friend didn't like this game straight away after we played 3 rounds and refunded, i nearly had 2 hours on this game (1.8hrs) and so i had no one to play with, So i refunded it as well.

Game is good and all but really little content and there are custom characters who are too overmemed and too op

100/200% accurate fox
200% accurate cloud
ronald mcdonald

And espically golden ronald mcdonald
Ronald mcdonald or golden ronald mcdonald is way too op, He can instantly do another attack and the second he does his first attack when the round begins, you cannot do anything, he won't let you even land on the ground, he will be damaging you the entire time, therefore you can't do anything, You may be able to land a few hits on him, but he heals at inhuman speed, literally.

I don't want to feel bad about myself, so i give this game a good review, but there are 
too overmemed and op characters
a small amount of original characters
and many more negative things.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A lot of people have recently been buying the game solely for the workshop content Rivals of Aether features, and while the workshop content is great and absolutely a reason to buy this game, my review will go more into the vanilla content it has to offer. 
The big question: is this game worth getting, even when disregarding the workshop? Hell fucking yes. The gameplay alone is a reason to buy this game. It's definitely the best platform fighter in terms of movement (feels even better than Smash Ultimate), the combo system is incredibly satisfying to experiment with, and the characters don't really feel like a complete rip-off of existing Smash tropes. 
I will admit that the single-player content is a bit lacking at the moment, but the Definitive Edition (which is coming pretty soon at the time of this review) will hopefully improve the single-player experience.
Overall, great game. Definitely the best platform fighter that isn't Smash, and that's not even considering the Steam Workshop (which is obviously another plus to getting this game).

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a spiritual sequel to the Super Smash Bros. Melee competitive scene. It takes elements from the competitive Melee scene and expands upon them. In some cases, it removes certain aspects entirely, like the ledge for example, but it always adds something in return. In this example, for instance, every character can wall hop AND retain their jump after air dodging. Every character has more options to recovery than in Melee.

Wavedashing is there. Ledge teching is there. L-cancel is there in the form of "whiff lag" if you whiff moves in the air (with a reduction to end lag if you connect). You'll be right at home if you play competitive Melee in terms of how the game controls from your first game; only you'll be better because Rivals is designed for these mechanics to be streamlined.

The most important thing to know about RoA is that this game is extremely punish heavy. Meaning that every character in the game can zero to death you. DI is just as important in Melee, if not more, in RoA. If you like the combo game of Melee, you will like the combo game in RoA. However, if you're someone who is easily frustrated by getting hit many times in a row, you'll likely find RoA frustrating in that regard. I'm not going to claim any "git gud" excuses. While I don't think it's a fault of the game that new players tend to get beat extremely hard, I don't blame someone for not wanting to continue because of that either.

That being said, however, I think RoA, once you start to understand how to DI and combo game work, is extremely rewarding. It is very, very satisfying when you pull off a sick combo. Another huge plus is that the entire cast is viable. Yes, there are tier lists, but they ultimately do not matter. If you put enough time in, you can beat any character with any other character, it may just be a bit harder in certain matchups.

Overall if you enjoy competitive Melee, but want a more fresh experience, I think you'll really enjoy RoA. If you're not from the competitive Melee community, but you're interested in Rivals, I think you can still get a great experience out of the game (and grow as player playing it), though it may take some time to get to that point. I was trash when I started, my friend who was very experienced would beat me 25 games in a row without breaking a sweat. Now I win maybe 1 out of every 5 games we play, but the time and effort I put in to improve my skills was very satisfying and rewarding. I honestly enjoy this game more than Melee now. And there's my opinion, hope it helps you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is great,the best smash clone to be made,it's both familiar and new enough to stand on its own two feet as a game.

The game has a very small cast of characters each with charming designs to them.They are not as iconic as the smash characters for obvious reasons but they are effective and stand out from each other. they all play vastly different from one another,even though the game is very aggressive.They each have their own fun mechanic that only they have that makes them pop and stops them from just being like fox but a lion.The cast itself is also really well balanced more balanced than any other smash game beyond maybe "Project M" but that barely counts the whole cast is viable in this game.

Unlike smash bros there is no shield or grab,making offense key in winning and zoning limited.This can be jarring when starting out because it feels like you just eat damage but once you get used to it,then the gears start turning and the gameplay feels great.It's way more like "Melee" than "Smash 4"/ "Ultimate. Parrying feels great to do and it's not too hard to master.It also takes the best parts of melee and leaves out the the more painful taxiating stuff.There is no more "L" cancelling instead aerials are just fast landing lag,wave dashing is also way easier to do in this game.It has all the smart second by second thinking of "Melee without the extremely taxiating execution barrier.One thing I do love is the ability to test out characters in the character select it works wonders.

Customization in this game is great,you can change the controls, have little pets that just hang by you for fun.The best part is you can make your own custom colors for your character which is amazing.

My biggest problem with this game is the lack of content,now I don't mind the small cast it works well but most of them are dlc sadly.Also the single player mode sucks minus the "abyss mode." and the final boss the rest is real lazy and boring.I'd love to see break the targets especially and I'd let people make their own break the targets stages as well with the steam workshop.Also since the game lacks items it less appealing to more causal smash fans.

Presentation is great,the animations are real clean and nice and the music is catchy.Never had a problem with clutter at all.It all oozes charm and fun.

I give it 8/10

Now steam workshop I get a 10/10 fixes all the flaws of the game and makes a whole new experince.Now you have dozens of stages ranging from good clone of final destination with a nice aesthetic, a new competitive layout or remake of a smash stage,or just a memey mess.You also have infinite characters that range from garbage to play to complete god of the game and sometimes you get golden nuggets of a character that feels fresh and is balanced.This makes the game a lot more casual and silly,my only issues with this is that I wish there was a way to organize modded characters with folders or something,making the game just a 9/10.

I recommend this game to pretty much all smash fans if not for the solid base game do it for the steam workshop.

review:
I play this game for the steam workshop content. Rivals of Aether is a great platform fighting game, but I couldn't really get into it until they added workshop compatibility. Now it's incredible.

Watching the base characters of the game get absolutely DESTROYED by an overpowered laser-shooting Jigglypuff but at the same time Jigglypuff is losing to Waluigi who at the same time is getting creamed by Ronald McDonald - pure gold. I love it. 10/10, I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a little nonsensical fighting.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I am writing this review shortly before refunding the game, and thought it may be useful to know what, as a new player of smash-like games (not including Brawlhalla) I experienced.

Menuing is poor, can't use mouse (or WASD initially), button key is for Xbox/ Nintendo controllers. Playing the game with keyboard requires you to change control  scheme. Try playing a casual game and you'll get stomped, try playing a ranked game to play players of your skill group, you'll get stomped. Not a friendly game for new players of Smash-like games.

I discovered the game from a YT video by Akshon Esports and as a Brawlhalla player who enjoys Melee content I was excited to play a game which was more similar to Smash than Brawl was. However, the issue with the menuing as well as the difficulty with changing controls for keyboard, topped off with the incredible difficulty of online play for a new player, I was severely disappointed by the game.

-Brain melts after 2 hours. The game is about constantly going all in pressing all the buttons.
-DLC characters should be free/cheaper
-Not THAT many characters, not much variety.

9/10 its pretty fun

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1]The TL;DR[/h1]
[b]Chapter 1: I Can('t) Make You Move[/b]
If you're going to make a Smash clone, don't make something as simple as moving your character a chore, you idiot.

[b]Chapter 2: Character Design Do Not's[/b]
If you're going to make a Smash clone, don't make something as simple as looking at your character painful, you idiot.

[b]Chapter 3: All Video Games (but this one) Are Art[/b]
If you're going to make a Smash clone, don't make something as simple as having a consistent art style impossible, you idiot.

[h1]The Actual Review[/h1]
[b]Chapter 1: I Can('t) Make You Move[/b]
The most basic controls have been bastardized by an incompetent developer who think he's hot shit because he has the autism to sit through a Melee frame analysis video. You stop on a dime with no regard to the laws of inertia, barely nudging the joystick is an actual thing you HAVE to pay attention to in the tutorials, and the overall combat is clunky. Dan Fornace doesn't actually know how to make parrying mechanics, and I embarrassingly sat there as I timed my button presses, only to be punished for not waiting right before instead of right now. Go play with the Royalguard style in DMC3/4/5, it's so much more satisfying to do than parrying with whatever the hell this is. 

[b]Chapter 2: Character Design Do Not's[/b]
To say the official characters are nothing short of easy furbait is low-hanging fruit. "Furry" characters can be done right if you know what you're doing, which of course is the one requirement Danny-boy doesn't meet.
[u]Zetterburn?[/u]
He's literally just an anthro Pyroar (for reference, this game was released in 2017; Pokemon X/Y was four years old at that point).
[u]Forsburn?[/u]
The same as Zetterburn, except he looks like the female Pyroar instead. Like, really? You had ice and water, air and thunder, grass and earth, but you decide on fire and... fire. Not lava or embers, you wanker. [i]Fire.[/i] Again.
[u]Wrastor?[/u]
Falco, except annoying to look at.
[u]Absa?[/u]
Absa is peak furbait, and that's why I hate him so much. You take one look at him, and you know he caters to the fetish-y femboy look.
[u]Kragg?[/u]
Actually a very good character design. He's bulky, he's muscular, he's intimidating. He's the archetype you should see in fighting games.
[u]Maypul?[/u]
This character is just stupid. He hits people with leafs. Fucking leafs. Like, am I supposed to believe they're sharp leafs? It's just dumb as hell.
[u]Orcane?[/u]
Likable for the exact opposite reasons. In a game that obviously takes itself too seriously, Orcane is the breath of fresh air that can be both goofy and practical. He's a killer whale with legs, he's surely a scary thought.
[u]Etalus?[/u]
A good design. Big, intimidating; do you see the pattern yet? Big and intimidating designs are good designs because they take away from any sort of pandering for the furry audience. Any anthro character either looks hyper-masculine or like a bitchy, feminine bottom. If you're going to do that, give them clothes.
Oh, speaking of which, Zetterburn's loincloth isn't even visible in his sprites. GG Danny.

[b]Chapter 3: All Video Games (but this one) Are Art[/b]
Inconsistent art style was the biggest problem of this game. The backgrounds use a dozen colors and stray away from pure black. Why don't the characters do the same thing? They have mostly flat colors because they use, like, four to six colors in general. You can argue this is done to distinguish the characters, but you can also do that by making them more colorful in general. Maypul easily stands out using light mint greens in his own stage, which is more brown, lime, and dark green in color. Besides, the "stand out" rule is already out of the question thanks to custom palettes. Come on, even pre-3DS Pokemon can get this rule down, all of them are capable of carrying up to 16 shades of color in each sprite! The Aether sprites lack shadows, dithering, etc. and really take away any visual pleasure you might have. At the very least, they could stop using pure black outlines and add a little color into the lighter parts (again, like pre-3DS Pokemon would).

[b]Epilogue: Judgement[/b]
This game? Boo. I bought it because I thought it would have been fun to mess with the Workshop creations, but the controls are just garbage and take away any joy I would have doing that. It's not MUGEN, it's a shameless Smash clone that tries way too hard to be competitive despite how mediocre the gameplay is. Just go play Project M or something if you're desperate for a Smash fix from your PC, I don't fucking know.

At least it's not Slap City, I guess.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's really weird that none of these reviews mention the terrible peer to peer connection for matchmaking because that is definitely a pretty significant downside. The game is really fun to play with friends, but unless you are into the game enough to tolerate constantly playing against players with terrible connections that actively impact your own ability to play the game, I would avoid general online play. Also, the barrier to entry to even reasonably compete online is insane, but I guess that is to be expected with this kind of game. Prepare to get utterly destroyed over and over by players who choose to play this game all day in lieu of bathing or going outside. These are people with 1000+ hours in the game who are overjoyed at killing people who just installed a few hours ago to the point where they taunt after every single kill. I know that people who are more concerned with their ego than fostering a positive community is a ubiquitous problem in online gaming (if not the world in general), but I would be remiss in pretending like this game is any exception. If none of these things bother you and/or you are willing to put in a large amount of effort towards practicing so that you can stomp those degenerates into the dirt :D, you will enjoy this game thoroughly. I just not sure I care enough to do so at this point in my life, and if you are looking for a more relaxing, casual experience online, look elsewhere.

Edit: Alright... after playing the game a bit more, I don't think I can reasonably give this game a bad review. The issues I mentioned still stand, but they aren't enough for me to disservice this game with a thumbs down.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Just play this game, man. A great soundtrack and solid visuals are built on top of a fantastic foundation of entertaining and skillful gameplay.

This game can appeal to both the most competitive and most casual of video game fans, boasting solid mechanics and a plethora of well-constructed characters, both base-roster and downloaded from the workshop, as well as endlessly hilarious moments, both from ridiculous custom characters and delightful alternate game modes and stages. 

Overall, Rivals is well worth the purchase, even at full price. It works with Remote Play well, but for the most stable and smooth gameplay, I'd recommend each player use their own copy. Definitely pick this up if you're even remotely a fan of the Super Smash Brothers series!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
rivals of aether might be a clone of smash but the truth is that this game is a masterpiece, igf you like smash (especially melee) you won't be dissapointed, rivals of aether is a similar game to melee but with its own differences and mechanics, every character (except for 2) are really good and balanced with each one having a different playstyle, and if you dont want those lame old characters you have the workshop and can basically play melee in a new 2d engine, old pc's also handle this game very well and the controller options are smooth as heck, bad things about this games are, the wifi isntreally the best, it's hard to find other players that are the same level as you, 2 of the characters that are dlc btw are pretty unplayed (not played a lot), and we aren't getting a sequel till a few years, doh its pretty cool to actually be announced

if you like competitive games, smash or want a fun party game game with friends this is definitely the game for you, if your casual the game has loads of interesting mods in the workshop.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
the characters are unique and balanced, the mechanics are unique as well. It really extends the platform fighter formula to places that it just hadn't been before.
The only things I dislike are some of the early characters' sprite work (okay maybe its just Wrastor, and to a much lesser extent Orcane) just feels like a rough draft of a final version. However custom color schemes helps make them a bit more dynamic. Additionally, wall jumping in this game works differently than every other game I've played. Instead of flicking the stick in the direction you want to jump when wall jumping, you have to hold in towards stage to perform a wall jump the whole time. This is not too bad until you need to use your up special to recover because it will not read your wall jump input as a directional input, so you have to dramatically double tap the stick in the direction to angle your up special the way you want to go. A little inconvenient.
But these are extremely minor nitpicks in an otherwise wonderful game! I'd highly recommend it for people looking to get into the platform fighter genre.

Overall I enjoy playing everyone but Ranno is my favorite so far!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Coming into this game as a Smash 4/Ultimate veteran with some experience with Project M and a touch of Melee, this game was a breath of fresh air. Every character feels like they can actually do something and not be relegated to the abyss of irrelevancy. I'm super excited to see the sequel to this game come out, and I'm also very excited for the Definitive Edition.

Also, the color palette system for the skins is diverse enough to where I was able to recreate Excalibur. Yeah, got on this train late, and I don't have the special taunt, but hey, got get what you can get.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is a love letter to the greatest fighting game of all time, Super Smash Bros. Melee. It streamlines Melee's fluid and fast-paced gameplay by making advanced mechanics such as wavedashing/wavelanding, short hopping, and L-cancelling easier to perform, while also leaving its own mark on the gameplay with revamped recovery mechanics and replacing shielding with parrying. Rivals is perfect for when I am in the mood to play Melee but not necessarily in the mood to expend the mental energy required for it. Would highly recommend it for any other Smash players, and Melee players specifically.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'm just gonna say it. Rivals of Aether is one of my all time favorite games. I love everything about it, from it's gameplay, it's characters, it's workshop stuff, and even the stuff that isn't actually in the game yet like tether. I have followed this game on xbox since it went into early access, and bought all the DLC here, and on xbox. I love this game that I spent over $70 on a $15 game and I don't regret it a single bit. My only real gripes with this game are the story mode, and some of the DLC is unavailable because they were limited code releases from the smash.gg store, and now none of them can be bought.

Also nerf Wrastor and Etalus please.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This is a fantastic game that puts a great twist on the fighting genre. The workshop branch incorporates so many new fighters and stages from dozens of different franchises. I highly recommend this just for the variety and the satisfying, aesthetic style. One minute you could be playing as Sans from Undertale and the next you could be Ronald McDonald or Barack Obama! There are near infinite possibilities and matchups you could create in numerous different scenarios and that is why this is a wonderful game to play.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So at first, I'm sorry, you might like this game if you're a fan of Super Smash Bro's and if's you're new school.
But i am one of the very few who hates the controls. Feels very janky slippery, the characters do what they want, but not what you, the player, wants. 
Sure, you have to get used to the controls, i get that. 
I'm rather oldschool ok, i have a Xbox360 controller, so why is the jump on the Y-button as default ? Oh right, i can change it in the settings, so dumb of me, so why do i have to set the controls and change it again on the character selection screen ?
Oh that might be because i might have a friend over and we play together. Alright.
A few stumbling blocks at the beginning. My bad !

I hated Smash Bro's for its controls and i hate this for its controls. The rest is fine with me, really good even. 
But if you can't control a game properly and the characters do what they want, then the fun will be lacking, especially for me.
That's how i feel. I played it for half an hour and immediately requested a refund. 
Sorry i can't recommend it !

review: the base game is an incredibly tightly designed platform fighter with every character being interesting and unique. the workshop, however, is one of the greatest additions to a video game ever. the characters, stages, and modes that people have made are all so much fun, and the workshop is a way for people to express their passion for video games as a whole.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game excels in almost every regard. Every aspect of it feels razor polished from the immaculate balance to the heart of the game the unique creative and challenging characters. The game celebrates melee with its free-form combos, movement techniques and fast pace of gameplay but is more than a brilliant modernization. I have never played a video game I enjoyed more than rivals of aether. 10/10.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Every other character has moves that are just hitboxes that cover their entire sprite, the Solo mode is an absolute joke. The bots do the same exact thing to the point where you can end a round in 6 seconds after playing it 2-3 times. 

Casual online mode is just a bunch of sweats that are angry they keep getting killed by the other no-lifes in comp, so they bleed out into the casual mode online and you face off against tryhards who use nearly inescapable combo's nonstop and you can literally never learn anything in Furry Fight 2020 due to that. Within my first ten rounds I was put against a dude with a decorated banner under his name and a bunch of premium skin shit that proceeded to use an infinite inescapable quick combo that kept me just barely above the floor.

Don't buy it unless you're the type to play "Lovers Of Aether" or you have a dedicated group of friends to play it with (and you're fine with the fact the base game has some real issues with balancing/accessibility so after about an hour it will degenerate into playing admittedly hilarious meme mod characters for the rest of its time on your shelf).

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you're wanting a Smash Bros experience on the computer then you stopped by for the right type of game. Rivals of Aether is a well balanced, action packed game! It provides loads of fun for both a solo player and a party of friends. One of the best features is the ability to use Steam Remote Play so that your friends don't need a copy of the game to play. Beware that using this feature does take a sufficient amount of bandwidth and the more players you add the more the quality of gameplay will suffer. I have no issues hosting two other friends, but when we introduce a 4th player the game lags out on almost every map.

They also provide several character bundles for relatively cheap prices. Overall, they are definitely worth picking up when the DLC's go on sale, but for $5 you can't beat that. Buying the bundles also unlocks the maps associated with the characters, however, if you set your map selection to random you have the opportunity to play many of the maps that are DLC locked. You can also download additional characters and maps from the Steam Workshop. I haven't dabbled in that area of the game yet, but it's worth mentioning.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[b]Rivals of Aether is the closest thing to Smash I've played, but stands as a strong fighter on its own.[/b]
[list]
[*]The two of them are definitely similar, right down to the coins for unlocking goodies. You've got your stories to go through with the characters, Abyss Mode as something unique for survival, and online when you're ready to take on some players. You'll feel right at home if you've played anything like it.
[*]I was honestly surprised by the tutorials compared to Smash. They're a lot more than clips of how to play, going over things such as DI and tech skill. Each rival has a lesson of their own as well.
[*]Mod support in fighting games is cooler to me than any other genre. Bringing a character to life and creating matchups yourself is something great being able to do.
[/list]
Not owning a Nintendo console myself for some time, it's awesome having something that can take me back. [spoiler]And there's FURRIES![/spoiler]

review: Rivals of Aether is an excellent game. From the detailed lore put into every character to the extremely unique fighting style every character has to offer (with their little nods to the game it's inspired by), Rivals will have you hooked for a good amount of time. I quite literally have put 40 hours into the game over the span of two weeks. If the main game ever bores you, there's always Abyss Mode and Online Mode -- and if you're still bored, there's a bunch of new player-created content in the Workshop.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This is the best platform fighter out there, hands down. every character is fun, and there is representation of every character at the top level, there's a plethora of custom characters to play with on the workshop, and it's incredibly easy to play on other patches, including beta or old patches. WIth the definitive edition coming out soon, every character will be made available without having to purchase the DLC, so as soon as it goes on sale, pick this game up if you're even considering it a little bit. The community is a ton of fun, and there are people to play with at all skill levels, so if you're new don't be discouraged. There's a lot of information available and a ton of people willing to help you get to a comfortable place in the community discord. If that isn't enough to convince you to at the very least try out the game, then I don't know what would be enough.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
At first he game was a rather simple one for me. It wasn't too easy getting used to it, having so many losses in Casual Matches made me put the game down for a bit, due to me getting upset. Of course, this was before I got the hang of the game, and also before the Steam Workshop support came around.

Not only am I much better at this game now, I also enjoy the game much more. You don't have to be a master at this game to enjoy it, hell, you don't even have to be good. Not that being good is everything, but the point is this game can be fun for you regardless how well you play it, and with the Steam Workshop now out and running wild, you can play characters that you never expected to! The characters are great, some a bit more chaotic than others (coughcoughcosmicronaldcoughcoughultrainstinctfoxcoughcough) or just downright amazing with how much effort was put into them. If you're down for it, Rivals is a pretty nice alternative for Smash Bros., but I wouldn't say it's better. It has its flaws, but none which completely destroy the enjoyment of the game.

I recommend this as it is one game I can't help but come back to. Truly, it is great. You don't like it? That's your opinion. But this is mines, and I won't change it anytime soon.

However, one thing I would like to note: Please don't try to fight CPU Lv9 Cosmic Ronald. Don't say I didn't warn you!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
At its core its a great game, but you need to make it a part time job to get good enough to have fun. Even low-mid level play is full of spam and cookie-cutter combos that will just leave you feeling bored at best and frustrated at worst.

I always reinstall thinking I will have a good time getting back into it, but then instantly remember why this game never really got its legs.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The game itself is good to play against others, mechanics and movement is similar to Smash Melee but way easier to execute.
But I wouldn't recommend it to people that aren't willing to invest time into it and try to get better at the game.
Online matches are very tough, a new player will get destroyed constantly, and some people would just stop playing there and then out of frustration and because the game doesn't have a lot of single player content (Story Mode / Bots).
If you're up to the task, there are many resources and players of all skill levels on the official Discords.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I have been a long time Melee player at a semi-competitive levels (locals, regional tournaments mostly) and Rivals of Aether scratches the perfect itch for me. The characters are intelligently designed and all feel unique and strong enough to single main. The lack of an 'ledge grab' is something that I find really refreshing for me, in the smash games its implied in the game design that the center of the stage is supposed to be the strongest position to hold. However, character with good ledge dashes can practically eliminate the disadvantage by just grabbing ledge to gain invincibility (Hax has a great video about this), but characters like Peach have incredibly bad ledge games so it creates a big disadvantage to fighting near the ledge. Rivals has also had consistant updates for years, the DLC is actually worth it and not just cashing in, and they even implemented a fun singleplayer mode.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: While the gameplay is solidly enjoyable, the best part would definitely be the music. In my opinion, Flashygoodness is one of the best video game composers I've heard. The first thing you should do is unlock the Tower of Heaven stage, especially if you've played the Flash game beforehand.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: God, I wish people played this game. It's the best platform fighter experience I've had since Project M.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game feels like a spiritual successor to Super Smash Brothers Melee. It's fast, extremely tight, and the characters feel completely different from each other. The heavies even feel great! Almost everyone gets a zoning tool and the stages all have an option for what most would call "tournament legal." The music gets you pumped while playing it and the art is fantastic. Orcane is adorable. 

The tutorial system is a little rough around the edges if you've never played a smash game before, but even a novice friend of mine made her way through the basic tutorials and had a blast playing for hours on multiple occasions with myself and another smash vet. It's a great end to a DnD night.

No Shields. No Ledges. No Grabs. Everyone gets a Parry move. It's a brand new world and I'm in love with it. I've been sleeping on this title for a while but now that I'm getting time into it and checking out the pro scene I'm only getting more and more impressed. 

I can invite anyone I know to play for free. If you want to check it out hit me up.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: After playing way too many hours of Smash Bros. the last five years, Rivals of Aether offers a fresh, satisfying feeling to the genre.  The controls and the movement options are intuitive, the characters are well-designed with layers of depth and mastery, and the game is a blast to play both casually and competitively.  The online experience and interface both deserve high praise for sure.  The workshop beta is also loads of fun.  I've both played other people's characters and designed my own stage that I plan on releasing soon.  I honestly feel comfortable saying that I've had more joy playing this game for fifty hours than any Smash Bros. game has really offered me.  This game is totally worth the money spent, and I cannot recommend this game enough to all kinds of players!

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Honestly really solid platform fighter. If you are looking for a game like melee but a bit easier, and also fun, this is it. Each character is cleverly designed and tries not to be a melee clone, but rather it's own separate game entirely. The lack of features like grabs, ledges, and shields may seem off putting, but in turn it makes it its own unique game. You can get really creative with combos, often just being able to freestyle a lot of them. Shame this game isn't bigger than it is right now. Also if you are waiting for the definitive edition, if you get this game on steam, you'll get the definitive edition when it comes out as a free upgrade.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Brawlhalla is free and lets you earn characters for free but this game has workshop characters but BH also has full M&K support (something this community has been asking for for at least 4 years now I've seen) and I mean it's fun with a controller but for 15$ I would expect it to at LEAST have the same features if not more than a free version of the same thing. 

I rate it up moooooostly because I can play Mr. Game & Watch from ultimate but only against friends.. Would ALSO be cool to add an online mode that you can select approved characters from the workshop ((obviously stuff like the aimbot tf2 sniper is off the table or Satima etc.)) since only playing it against bots and the one other friend I have that owns this will get old, I'm only 3 hours into the game and about an hour of that is figuring out control setup and then how it plays (it's heavier than BH so be careful about going off those ledges in the beginning!)) 

It has so much MORE potential and I hope the devs see some of these things and implement them but with even no mouse input for over 4 years of asking to me spells trouble... We'll see and I'll change my review accordingly when I have more hours but for now it's at LEAST worth trying for the 2 hours that you can return it and see if it peeks your interest. (highly recommend figuring out how to set everything up BEFOREHAND so you aren't stuck figuring it out on the clock)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is dying. The amount of people playing is so short and it's rapidly declining by the day. It once held about 1,000 people playing a day. Now it is around 60, with a good number of those people playing local. Why are they playing local, you might ask? Because the only ones who play online are the ones who've played this game since release, and are typically looking for a combo gif clip to show off to their friends. At this point, there's just no real reason to play the game if you're new to it. If you even WANT to be SOMEWHAT good, get ready to literally waste hours upon hours constantly losing with barely any way to improve unless you get someone to teach you character-specific fundamentals before you can start winning a single game. 
Now, I managed to get a good number of wins in this game, as I previously played Melee and PM competitively, so my skills managed to transfer a bit into this game. Nonetheless, the game is still obnoxious with how insane and unwelcoming the skill gap is online—The community is dying, therefore only the hardest of players are playing, which only encourage new players to simply go away and find something else to play. In a way, the online system and community is killing its own playerbase with how massive the skill gap is, and how little people tolerate new players. And no, there is no matchmaking system, unless you play Ranked, which is more or less abandoned. I'd love to continue playing this game, but honestly with how irritating it is to play, and with how much hours is required just to simply HAVE FUN with the game, all I have to say is it just isn't worth it.
Also bear in mind: this game's community is honestly just very toxic. There's constant T-baggers, constant taunters, a MILLION people who tryhard on new players (and honestly, after being CONDITIONED for so long to fight at my absolute BEST without ONCE giving my opponent room to breath thanks to all these tryhards, I've ended up becoming one of them, and I feel terrible when I end up doing it to a new player), and a lot of people who lag switch to make you mess up your combo and neutral game (and just so HAPPEN to almost always be a zoner character...huh...)
Overall I really honestly think this game isn't worth it until there's a PROPER matchmaking mode and a more mature / open minded community, because right now literally everyone just says "go on discord lol that's where you'll be able to cherry pick the nice players from the toxic ones (trust me, most of them are sweaty homophobic conservative gamers who think playing fighting games is a personality, so you won't find many who aren't)."
No one should even have to do that. Not even melee net play or anther's ladder is this monotonous. Heck, smash ultimate's QUICKPLAY has better matchmaking than this, which is kinda sad.
All in all:
Melee has a better community. And that shit had someone throw a crab.
P.S.: This game is hella carried by the workshop community. It's basically just a paywall smash MUGEN.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So... Rivals of Aether. A 2D Super Smash Bros style fighting game with a cast of original characters of the anthro persuasion. Doesn't sound like the sort of thing I normally play? Yet here I am playing it.

Let's be honest, I got the game for the Ori DLC. And stayed for the workshop integration. Whilst the cast of official characters is tiny compared to Super Smash Bros, even with the DLCs, the fact that the game has workshop integration, and has a large array of well-balanced, well-drawn community-made characters, including well-known favourites from other franchises, really makes all the difference. I've seen the Knight from Hollow Knight. A host of Sonic the Hedgehog characters. Undertale and Deltarune characters... and plenty of custom stages to match.

Of course, the gameplay is great too, of course. The tutorials are a little on the frustrating side... even more frustrating than trying to do the tutorials for Soul Calibur III with a dodgy controller, but that's neither here nor there. Tutorials aside, the fighting is fast-paced combo-based fun with characters boasting specialisations that are of varying difficulty and host various playstyles. Zetterburn may work well for just getting in there and smashing your opponents to pieces with fire, but try that with Orcane and you might end up biting off more than you can chew. There is a story mode, a survival mode, versus mode... and online multiplayer. Local multiplayer is also possible too, as is RPT (I still haven't gotten around to trying RPT on any game on Steam, so I have no idea whether it works well enough for a game requiring these kinds of reflexes).

So yeah, I do recommend this game. I won't give it a rating out of 10, because I don't play this genre enough to have sufficient comparison.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Fans of melee will enjoy it. Keep in mind it is quite a bit different though. No ledge grabbing, shields, or grabs in general make the game extremely fast paced and combo focused (Even more so than melee imo) It controls extremely smoothly and you can use just about any controller with it. There are lots of comprehensive tutorials and an excellent training mode that will help newcomers. I also find this game to be a lot easier for newcomers to the genre (It's a lot less intimidating than melee, for example, I have a friend who's still getting the hang of wave dashing but he doesn't get absolutely murdered if he messes them up once in a while) The characters are awesome and the game is frequently updated to ensure a balanced meta. Sure, some characters are better than others on paper, but with enough practice and dedication you can really make anyone work. It's not like melee where certain low tiers (Bowser, G&W, etc.) are unplayable. Overall I think this is worth a shot whether you're new to platform fighters or just want to try something other than melee/Project M and you don't like the direction the new smash games are going.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
funny how everyone is trying to say this game is the next melee or successor to smash. In reality, the game is extremely flawed when it comes to casual and competitive match making. Input delay is an obvious problem, but is more game breaking in Rivals of Aether than Smash Ultimate - smash ultimate being connected through wireless connection vs Rivals of Aether being on ethernet. As much as everyone has hopes for this game, the game truly consists of being queued against players with 500+ hours even in casual. I beat lvl 9 bots (highest difficulty) around 10 times in a row, which should mean I am ready for online casual at least. This is completely false. I would not recommend playing casual online with under 100 hours put into this game. You will get put into casual games with people who have obvious hundreds of hours, not allowing you learn anything. After getting whiped and not being able to move for around 20 games, you will go offline to practice, only to beat extremely easy bots that don't teach you anything about how to actually play the game.

tl;dr - game is current state is trash in a sense that online casual is unplayable for new players - bots don't teach or prepare the player for online play. There is an obvious reason why smash ultimate is so much more popular than rivals of aether even as a PC platformer that came out 3 years before for 1/5th of the price. Wish I didn't put 5 hours into learning because I would like to refund - not worth spending hundreds of hours getting rolled in casual to learn basic mechanics

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I've had this game for only about 3 days, and almost all of my free time has gone in to it so far.

There are a few key differences between this game and the Smash Bros series.
The removal of grabs and shields make it so that you have to play aggressively to perform well, but you still have the ability of defense with a parry. There are also no ledges, but you get a single wall jump to make up for that. Even if you use all your normal jumps as well as your Up-Special, you can wall jump to get said Up-Special back. Each of the characters are unique and interesting in their own rights (8 Base game, 6 DLC). While I've only gotten a decent amount of experience with one of them for now, I am confident I that will put a great amount of time in each character in due time. The music is stellar, not much else to say on that topic.

And then there's the workshop. Where do I start? 

There are limitless possibilities in the workshop, both in creating characters, and playing others'. There are pages full of quality content for you to enjoy, both in terms of Meme and "Normal" fighters. It's the aspect that easily caught my attention on this game, as I'm sure that's the case for many others. But even without it, you're still left with a great game that has such a high skill ceiling.

If you're not keen on playing the online, there's still the Abyss mode. I see it as a sort of way to test how good you are as your character in different ways (Ariel control, ground movement, etc.). You can also spend tokens you earn while playing to buy "mods" that will change your character in one way or another. There's also local multiplayer if you have some friends/siblings who wanna play with you.

Also, you can play as Sans with a Gun if you're using the workshop, that makes this worth it alone.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: REALLY fun so far. I say that as a player who has never played a Smash-type fighting game before, so take my opinion with a grain of salt, but every character feels great to play. The tutorials are extremely detailed and there are character specific tutorials for every playable rival, not to mention movement, defense and offense tutorials for every stage of the game. (This is  really important to me in any game.) Movement is smooth. Attacks are solid. Mechanics are interesting. 10/10, although I have only played for 10 hours at this point. Matchmaking is kind of weird for beginners, so you'll probably want to ask the Discord server (invite is roa) about tips and such.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Awesome graphics, cool characters and fun to play. Also tutorial mode is great and very descriptive. 

Unfortunately though as a new player trying to get better at the game, there isn't much by means of doing that. The online mode is restrictive in that you cant casually play 4v4 (with this option like in brawlhalla the matchmaking is more likely to be somewhat even). Also on top of that you're likely to get absolutely destroyed by some very capable players (where are the other newbies?) and if that isn't enough there is also the issue of lag in the matches and Ping issues. (Yes, even within the correct local region)

Would be nice if the difficulty of the CPU could be increased to at least something like 15-20 (for fun but also training purposes) because against lvl 9 CPU on versus mode with less than 3 hours of gameplay I'm able to win with large margins, yet go online and run into almost competition ready players who are pros with the whole wavedashing, parrying, wavelanding, DACUS, edgeguarding + recovery - you get the point. 

Overall its a great game; fun to play, nice visuals and interesting characters. Would be nice to see an expanded story mode including all characters background stories. Also it'd be great if you could select a character to do the beginner intermediate and advanced tutorials so you could get a decent feel for the game with more characters than just Zetterburn. Also would be nice if you could customise the cpu actions is practice mode more ie getting them to spam certain moves like FSpecial to practice parrying etc

Update after some months playing:

This game is awesome and very underrated. The learning curve is a bit steep for those who have never played any platform fighters, and definitely isn't very forgiving to casual players. But if you're willing to put in some time to getting good at a game you will have a great time. VERY positive and helpful community and discord resources to help you improve too.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I think overall RoA is a good game, but it's definitely not for anyone. Once you understand the game the game flows well akin to melee or any good competitive smash game. I suck at the game and starting to understanding slowly (only 9 hour in so far), But i do see myself improving and starting to pull things together, despite getting my ass handed to me 95% if the time. However, climbing the mountain to be competent at this game is not gonna be easy, this is where the game not being for anyone comes into play. For starters, the tutorial isn't really robust, a lot of the time you will end up going into youtube to see how some of the mechanics are performed. Secondly, if you're new at this game 9 times out of 10 you will play someone who  is a veteran and won't let you play the game. What i mean by "won't let you play the game"... he will combo you to death and you won't know whats going on and won't land a hit. In other words you're gonna be someones highlight reel that  will probably be uploaded on youtube.  That said, why do i recommend it or even like the game? Well i played street fighter/smash growing up so I'm use to learning games through getting my ass beat and exploring the internet for how to perform tech. So for someone like me I recommend this game. I get satisfaction in finally taking a stock off someone better, performing a combo and successful edge guards. So assuming you're someone like me with patience and with a background in being a noob in fighting games and learning, you will like this game. The game has insane combo potential/creativity and nice diverse characters, on top of finding opponents quickly when you queue up. If you  wants to learn through playing people your level or new.. then i wouldn't recommend it. Nor would i blame you for disliking the game because of it, the game isn't really huge and composed of vets at this point which could be demoralizing if you just touched the game.
 
P.S  the art and soundtrack is awesome.
