title: Rivals of Aether
review:
*Edit* I HAVE DISCOVERED TILT STICK, so i will leave my old review below to kinda show how a player (myself) who isnt very familar with Smash bros i only have owned SSB Brawl and i didnt remember the controls for it and the Wii controles didnt translate over to my PS4 controler it has made things much simpler and im enjoying it alot more now

First off the perception of this game is that its not for casuals and on some level i agree with that but its not required to have fun with them game. I think the main problem is the lack of information and complicated terms given to you in the tutorial in other words.. THE TUTORIALS ARE GOD AWFUL if you want to learn the game i would look up people playing through the tutorial on youtube while your doing it because this is a BIG problem it give you no visuals, examples or anything besides text and they use terms that make understanding things way more complicated then it needs to i hope they make a new tutorial with this next update.

Now the tutorial is my only problem it made things seem complicated when they wernt this game is INCREDIBLE it just doesnt have enough information to new players and the default button settings i beilve are trying to replicate a gamecube controler witch is a very poor decision. For example on a PS4/Xbox controler the jump button is Triangle/Y and you can only use the analog stick to move witch i found is very inaccurate for me now i went in and changed everything till i found it enjoyable but this process of just figuring out the button layout along with the frustrating tutorial took me about a month because i didnt know what i was doing wrong i love learn complex games of all kind and i am very collected while learning but i need to know what im doing wrong to learn

All this seems like a negative review but i cannot ignore that after a couple months of trying to understand and learn after giving up multiple times im having a AMAZING TIME, The Steam Workshop Charaters can be a whole reasion in itself to buy this games you can play/create ANYONE you want and there are many helpful mods to help learning/experimenting in the Practice zone

Over all i reccomend this game highly but know that you will have to do a little external research right away to help learn the game but its honestly not that much or complicated, its just the reasons i stated above can be very frustrating right when you first boot up the game

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals has a lot going for it; it's a visual treat, the soundtrack is excellent, and there's a lot of discernible variety between the characters. If you've got a friend who wants to grind the game with you, then I'm sure you and this hypothetical person would have an excellent time. However, from the perspective of someone playing it on their own, there are a couple things that really soured me on the game as a whole. This review is not intended to flame or saltily justify quitting, just some gripes that I wish I had seen in more places before I invested some time in the game.

1) The online needs some work. Part of the trouble is the size of the community, but as far as I can tell the matchmaking could stand balancing out. Casual pits you against basically anyone, including the same person you just passed on three times because their PING was shit. The imbalance of casual is to be expected; of course you're going to run into a bunch of players who are better! Just mosey on over to Ranked and...get matched with Gold players as a Bronze. 

A number of folks will counter by mentioning the Rivals discord. Obviously this helps, but it also does not change the fact that the game's online is messy, nor is the discord an official part of the game, so thus not really germane to this review. I am sure that a great many games are improved by external resources; the existence of these resources does not make the game itself any less wonky. Speaking of online presence:

2) The online player-base is surprisingly mean-spirited (the surprise being, in my eyes, that these players are by no means a small minority) . A ton of folks will no doubt advocate a mindset of, "It's the internet, what did you expect?", but this toxicity is compounded by the aforementioned matchmaking troubles. It becomes, on some level, impossible to avoid or contend with these people, especially without a report function. Once more, many reviews for this game did not mention this element, so I would like to stress its relative prevalence.

3) The tutorials are very frustrating. While it is no doubt difficult to teach a player concepts like fastfalling and directional input in a tutorial setting, many times I would swear that I had performed the move despite the game not counting it. With two of them, it got so bad I even googled it to see what I was doing wrong, only to instead find steam threads detailing Rivals' inability to read these specific tutorial inputs correctly.

These might seem like nit-picks given that I've praised the game's roster and aesthetic elements, but the aforementioned issues create small annoyances that honestly just made the game less and less fun as time went by. If you enjoy this game, great! You have undeniably good taste and a level of tolerance that will serve you well in life. If you're looking to buy, the best advice I can give is that the game will annoy you frequently in small ways; it's your call if that makes you apprehensive or not.

review:
epic game that is like melee. movement is smooth, easy to learn hard to master, fun with friends, balanced roster, tourney support, and lots of new content coming soon im sure ill enjoy.

edit after 100 more hours:
Fun platform fighter that has smooth easy to learn hard to master game play, combos, and especially movement. has a lot of inspiration from smash melee featuring things like wave dashes but lacks ledges, shields, and staling which is my biggest complaint. Has a smaller roster of characters but each one of the fighters has vastly different gameplay and strategies. features 2 indie game characters ori and shovel knight which is great too bad that 6/14 characters are payed dlc until the ultimate edition releases. loads of fun with friends and online is pretty good. Even has a great local competetive scene but idk its kinda based by where you live.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is probably the best platform fighter to play competitively out there, having played Melee and PM for a loooong time I can say the speed, flow and feel of the game are extraordinary. The game is extremely well balanced and every character is very well-designed, bringing lots of creative aspects into the genre. I've been with it since early access and I can say the devs (formerly dev) are really dedicated.
For those that like playing casually, this game is also really fun. The game now has workshop support and there are lots of fun/meme characters you can download that make Rivals a blast to play without competitive focus. The controls are highly customizable and easy to pickup, especially if you played any Smash game or other platform fighters, such as Brawlhalla. There is also a free update coming with even more casual and single player content, such as alternate game modes and new additions to the old ones.
If you like fast, competitive platform fighters, get it. If you like fun, casual platform fighters, get it at a discount.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Please give this game a chance it's much more than a clone of Smash, every character (as few as there is) is completely unique (in this game, they are Smash archetypes). The flow of the game is nice and fast, adds a lot of depth to the combat, honestly prefer it to smash. Art and music are amazing, custom colors is really nice, practice mode has all features I could need, controller settings are really customisable. My only complaint is that it's mostly a competitive game, not a party game like Smash so it's a bit hard to find friends who want to play 1v1 ONLY all the time, 4 player is local only.

The workshop makes this a whole new game, you now have a limitless amount of content to play with in a well made platform fighter. Thank you Dan for making this game, hope you have more in store for us in the future.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I really want to recommend this game. Really really do. A smash bros style game on PC. Sounds great in practice, but it falls apart in 1 regard.
The controls, frankly, suck. I don't know what's wrong with them. I don't know what would need to be done to fix them. But I'm at over a hundred hours and most, yes MOST, of the actions I do in the game are not the inputs I want.
Git gud you say. Well I've been playing Smash Bros (the real game) for many, many years, never really had trouble missing inputs. Sure, sometimes I dash attack when I wanted to smash every now and again, but everyone does a bit of spaghetti sometimes. In Rivals, spaghetti is the only order of the day. I've put up with it for over a hundred hours now, hoping eventually something would "click" and I could start enjoying the game.
Well, after winning a single game in the past 2 hours online, I realized I was no longer interested in waiting. I'll probably come back to check out the Definitive edition when they release it, but in the meantime, well, I'll free up some hard drive space.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game... this game... I've followed this game ever since discovering the Lord of the Smash and Elementimals. Now, this platform fighter featuring antro Pokemon rip-offs fighting it out in an Avatar-style world with Ori and Shovel Knight as guest stars (Ragnir snuck in), along with a Workshop that gave everyone a chance to join the fight, is suddenly rising up the ranks to become one of my favorite PC games of all time. The solid-as-hell gameplay, the awesome retro graphics, the almost heavenly music, it is all amazing!

It has to be said: BUY THIS GAME! Why? Because this has to be one of the best platform fighters of all time, even threatening to rival my top 10 favorite games of all time. I salute you Dan Fornace, I salute you

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you like Smash Bros, then this game is worth a go, even if just to play that style of game with competent online matches. But even beyond that, Rivals has plenty of its own to offer, with most of the fighters adding interesting new mechanics to the genre. Even if you haven't played Smash, this is a great deep competitive fighting game that you ought to try.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
An amazing platform fighting game that that takes the best parts of other games and innovates on top of them while expanding the mechanics in meaningful ways. Each member of the roster has a fleshed out set of skills and mechanics. All satisfying to learn.

Only downside is unfortunately the ranked multiplayer mode is quite stagnant, not bolstering the player base it needs to keep the mode alive. You will often fight the same player multiple times or be unable to find a match with good ping. The official discord is the best place to go to find quality matches.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Um grande jogo, lembra muito Super Smash Bros, e é realmente gratificante de jogar.
Uma gameplay mais "rápida", sem shields por exemplo, e maior liberdade para customizar os controles.
O único "problema" é a baixa quantidade de personagens selecionáveis, mas que é contornado pela qualidade dos mesmos.
Outro ponto é que o jogo tem Workshop disponível, então você pode baixar ou fazer personagens do Workshop para utilizar com seus amigos ou alguém que você encontrar por ae no servidor do Discord.

Resumo: Ótimo jogo, vale a pena comprar. (E quem comprar antes de Junho + - vai receber todas as DLC'S de graça com o lançamento da Definitive Edition.)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So this is a mixed review. I liked the game from a conceptual standpoint but not quite on its own. If you're looking for a smash-like game that captures the frenzied high level tournament play of melee, go for this. If you're looking for a fun party game that feels more like brawl or the new smash games, try Slap City or Brawlout. I'd actually 100% recommend Super Smash Flash, which is 100% free, has over 20+ characters in base game, and feels exactly like the PC Smash Bros experience we all deserve.

PROS:
- Solid gameplay with fully customizable controls (you can ACTUALLY MAP THE SHORTHOP!!!!)
- Slick Digimon-esque character designs! (Renamon who?)
- an ENDLESS array of free expansions in the Steam Workshop, from characters and stages to skins and game modes! (SANS IS IN SMASH SANS IS IN SMASH SANS IS IN SMASH)
- A fully implemented and realized story mode with challenging gameplay. 

CONS
- No shields, no grabs. Perfect parry or die. 
- Very floaty, very slippery. Slide and perish. 
- Not a good game for anyone who is new to Smash-likes. tournament level competency is a prerequisite as there is no difficulty settings for younger/newer players. Git Gud or lose $14.
- You have to buy all the actual extra characters instead of having an option to unlock them through regular gameplay. Rather than giving us a fun challenge like the insane character unlock requirements in Smash, you are REQUIRED to pay more for content that should have been included at launch. Unless you only want to play with workshop characters in the beta builds, or the 8 characters that are included in the base game. 
- no items??? Why??? i want to beat up an anthropomorphized weasel with a giant crate! let me do that! lemme turn him tiny!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I absolutely love the mechanics and design of this game, and one of the best things about it is that there is such a skill gap between fresh installs and pros that it's nuts, this is a double-edged sword however. due to the relative unpopularity of this game, ranked is not even an option, making finding players at your level a fool's errand. the only concievable way to get better at this game as of right now, is to go through the process of getting destroyed over, and over, and over, and over again, until your on the cusp of uninstalling. as great as this game is, the most fun way for me and my friends to play is on the workshop beta, where no one cares about getting better or learning a new rival. just having a good laugh. the reason i chose to reccommend this game to other players is because the only real thing keeping this game back is the relatively low active player count. my estimate is that there are only ~10ish people on at a time, making the "new opponent" button completely defunct. so until this game has more than 10 people playing i will keep getting destroyed by people who have 1000+ hours on the game. I dont care about any of the other flaws of this game, such as the lacking story and pretty lackluster singleplayer modes, all that matters to me, and i think everyone else, is the fact that until you "git gud" you will be getting six stocked until your mind is on the verge of melting. everything about the mechanics and design of this game makes it fun to play and watch, so it deserves all the credit it can get. but you can only get so far off of just good design. I will continue to play this game, but. if you dont want to go through the feeling of not even wanting to launch the game because it will yield the same result, (getting six stocked.) then i suggest you ask yourself whether playing as obama and sans on the workshop beta is worth your money. if yes, great! if you actually wanted a serious platform fighter, i suggest you let this game sit on your wishlist until you get some kind of notice that people are actually playing the game. the growth of this game, is however, inevitable. no game this good flies under the radar for too long. 

also if you buy this game now you get all dlc characters when definitive update comes out so consider that.

NOOOOO! you cant just play weegee and obama on the workshop beta this game is a masterpiece and its mechanics are second to none!

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game was fun to play to begin with. From doing the story with all the characters to having a little fun in a 4 player battle royale. And now that they've allowed Remote Play, the game is even more fun since we can now properly play with our friends in a match of 4 real players. The game gets a little buggy with more than 2 players, but I can live with that. And now with the edition of workshop custom characters, I can now officially say this game is a MUST HAVE. I've never had more fun fighting different versions of Goku with Shantae. Or having a straight-up anime battle with Golden Ronald and Zetta. Definitely get this game if you have the spare money and/or just trying to figure out what game you want to get.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
9.5/10

Pros:
Really good gameplay.
Runs very well.
Controllers run perfectly with it.
Good soundtrack.
Extremely well balanced, every character is viable.
Small cast allows for better balancing.
Mechanics are great; there's so many movement options and clever ways to recover.
Spammers are almost nonexistent due to the mechanics this game has.
Next to no toxic players in online.
Airdodge mechanic is great; makes the Smash airdodge mechanics go to shame.
Workshop version with custom characters and custom stages.
Custom colors for your characters.
Good DLC characters.
Good devs.

Cons
Online Workshop can be pretty dang laggy.
Mindgames are a bit hard.
Rather high learning curve.
Vanilla version isn't very good for casual games since this game was build with competitive in mind.
Sometimes the hitsun can be a tad excessive.
Some things can be a total chore like the Opulent Rival, the Endless Abyss, and the Ardent Rival achievements.
Roster is pretty small so there's not as much variety.

Really good game overall. If I had to rank it among Smash games I'd rank it second behind Ultimate, with SSBU winning just because of the variety of characters and music, and more causal, and first if it's just gameplay.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is easily one of the best platform fighters I've ever played. I love Smash, and spend a lot of my time playing both Melee, and Project M, but Rivals just keeps bringing me back. They're always adding more content to the game. Whether it be fighters, stages, or even Steam Workshop support, allowing an endless trove of goofy, but also very creative and entertaining content. It feels natural to play right from the get-go by offering many of the same mechanics from Smash games, like wavedashing and DI, while also replacing some core concepts like with ledgegrabbing -> walljumping, and shielding -> parrying, giving Rivals a unique feel that's unlike any other game on the market. It's easy to pick up and play casually, while also offering a lot of depth, making it a great competitive game with a high skill-ceiling. Sorry if I sound like an infomercial, I just like to rate games positively when I feel like they deserve it, and the fact that I could appreciate a game to the extent that I feel I need to write a goddamn essay about it, that alone should tell you that it's worth the purchase. Thanks for reading!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Alright y'all, here is rivals of aether.

This game is literally a 2D smash bros game where you don't grab ledges, instead are given an extra wall jump. Giving different approaches and opportunities when it comes to combat. 

Instead of shield you are given a parry that can stun the opponent for a couple frames.

The cast of characters you are given is a good and well structured, but what makes this better is that this game adds workshop content that can virtually be any character. (Master Chief, Mario, Luigi, MR G & W, Sonic, Shadow, Talis, Etc.) And some of the effort creators have put into these characters, being workshop or not are quite awesome.

The combat overall is smooth and satisfying.

would buy this game if on the fence worth the $$

review: As a competitive fighting game, I would say its actually better than smash. The removal of ledges also removes ledgehogging and gives you more options when recovering. Parrying means that you can still punish obvious attacks but makes the game a lot less campy since you can't just sit in shield. Where the game really shines is workshop though. Come on, Ronald McDonald verses Melee fox is the matchup of dreams.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
games pretty fun, feels a bit empty, not a lot of characters without paying which is annoying, very creative and fun design, workshop definitely the reason i payed 15£ for this.
Edit:
after playing for a while i have a lot more to say, there are a lot of problems with this game and has definitely helped me shape my idea for MY OWN fighting game that i will develop one day.

Cons:
-Lack of Characters
-Online Is Nearly Dead: you have to go out of your way to guarantee a good match
-Dlc is right in your face and really depressing, if you have it you're disappointed at the lack of characters and if you don't you feel like you don't have the full game.
-They wont be adding anymore characters which suuucks
-They'll probably make a sequel that you have to rebuy

Pros:
-Fun, very fun.
-Interesting mechanics, 
-Workshop has infinite potential
-You will get the DLC for free this summer
-Nice (but limited) music
-Good Balancing
-Im Good at it

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I really want to like this game, but it is so difficult being that I am trying to get into it so late in the game.  It has been out for awhile, and it has such a small community.  I have just reached platinum rank, and it keeps matching me up against master rank players.  I am getting demolished, I can't even improve because It is so one sided.  I know it's because the community is so small, not many people play this, and those who do have lots of more hours and gametime compared to me.  I guess maybe I just started playing this too late, or the matchmaking isn't very good.  I just can't recommend it for a new player, you might as well wait for the switch version so you'll actually have fun playing people around your skill level.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a really fun platform fighter. If you played smash bros you know most of the basics but the devs changed some things up for the better there is no shields, grabs, or ledge grabbing instead there is parries and wall jumping. Each fighter is original however some moves the fighters have are references to some smash characters. The pixel art is beautiful and the animations are fluent. The soundtrack is fantastic with a track for each stage and then some. The price is reasonable with a lot of dlc to buy if you want all the dlc fighters you will be looking at at least $19.96 not including tax including the $14.99 for the base game. The devs also included a workshop which can be a bit of a crap shoot to find what you are looking for with guest characters from other franchises, characters from smash bros, joke and meme characters who are designed to be broken, and original characters which fit perfectly with the base game there are also stages, buddies, and experimental things such as new game modes. 
TLDR the game is fantastic and is a must by if you like games such as Smash Bros.

I will also probably increase that number once it is available on the nintendo switch. I am looking forward to all the new stuff this game has in store. As Always, I'm cow lord357, have a good noon, and stay TロSTY my friends.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is easily the best Smash clone out there. It basically takes Smash's core gameplay, and expands it much farther than Smash ever has. It has a lot of extremely good ideas that Smash wouldn't even dare implement.
For example, Forsburn's smoke and clone mechanics use deception as a strategy, something that has never been seen in a platform fighter, and even at low level play, this makes Forsburn fun as heck to play. Wrastor, on the other hand, has insane aerial combo potential, and can finish combos with little trouble thanks to the fact that he can use his strong attacks (smash attacks) in midair instead of on the ground.

I originally became interested in Rivals of Aether because of the Workshop, as I wanted to create something custom. I originally saw Rivals as Smash Bros but you could make any character you wanted. As a matter of fact, the reason why the vast majority of the Smash Bros. community plays the game in the first place is for the immense cast of characters coming from the four corners of the video game universe, and this interest in any characters I wanted in Smash being creatable for Rivals got me into the game. But as I played more and more, I started to see how a platform fighter didn't need recognizable characters in order to be fun, and the chaacters' mechanics, which go beyond Smash's simplicity, shone through.

Basically, Rivals of Aether is an amazing game, thanks to the characters having original and fun ideas which go beyond Smash Bros.' simplicity, and it doesn't need an infinity of recognizable characters to create a devoted fanbase. If you're a fan of the mechanics that made Smash Bros. great, give Rivals of Aether a try. You wno't be disappointed.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is one beautifully crafted game. In an alternate universe, this would've been the game that everyone played on their SNES.

Having started playing this at the same time as BH, I can safely say that this is the superior game. Far more technical, with a diverse set of characters with unique movesets. BH is much, much easier to play around with. RoA is clearly where the elite Smashers show off their combo skills in the PC realm.

Exploring each characters abilities in game takes you back to the early days of Smash on the N64, where you just wanted to see what everyone can do. The inclusion of Ori & Sein just opens the door for more characters as well down the line, which will keep me invested as time rolls on.

The effort that has gone into the characters, the world they live in, and the vibant fighting arenas should be appreciated by any fan of retro gaming, not just die-hards of the Smash community. My inner 10 year old can't get over how gorgeous the presentation is.

If you ever enjoyed Smash Bros. and wanted that same experience on PC in a new world with a new cast of characters, then this will bring you a lot of joy.

[EDIT: Had to buy all the other characters. Such variation on play styles. And Shovel Knight too! Hands down, one of the best local multiplayer games on Steam.]

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Great mechanics and character design. I had played this game only a little bit before a few days ago but had been interested and watched a size-able amount of content a while ago. This game had been in my steam wish list and with me getting back into playing games on steam fairly recently, seeing it go on sale for 50% off peaked my interest. I sat on it a little bit but bought it about 3 hours before the sale ended. I've had a lot of fun with the game so far, racking up a little over 16 hours I believe in the few days I've had it so far. That being said I wanted to make sure I was as good as I could be while just starting, I played through the full tutorial including some of the character specific tutorials. Not wanting to just assume I'd be decent at the game just because of all of the hours I've put into the Super Smash Bros. series. I've had my fair share of experiences with all of the titles in that series. I've gone to Melee tournaments a good number of times, no majors like EVO or Genesis, just locals. Although I considered trying to be a pro player for a while. Those ideas are long gone from my naive mind, closest thing to that I think i could become is a content creator in the fighting game community. Point is I'm in no way a god at fighting games but I've sunk hours and hours into Smash especially melee and i wouldn't consider myself a casual player or very awful. All that being said the tutorial was straight forward enough but doesn't really teach you how to utilize the tools it teaches you in a real scenario. I'd say I definitely learned some from the tutorial but I would hope as a new player the story mode at least if not the tutorial being more in depth would add a little more to learn. Like have the player have to do something specific to beat the other Rivals like implement parrying into counterattacking or something. I feel like they could have done a lot more than the bad CPUs that will just randomly kill themselves just cause sometimes. Also I know everyone who complains about this game complains that the story doesn't make sense, which it doesn't. All the characters backgrounds and themes are interesting enough but the way their paths cross in convoluted and frankly not explained well. I played through the whole story mode hoping that I'd get some more practice or learn some more before i just jumped into the online mode. I didn't really get that and my first few online matches at least I got destroyed. I feel like most new players to this game will be very put off by the learning curve of this game and how it doesn't help you too much along the way. Getting beat very badly over and over again can be very demoralizing I know there is a discord linked in the game for people who want to learn the game and I'm sure that is a very good resource for new and older players alike. I personally have not used it at least yet, maybe eventually I'll check it out and give it a try. The online connection can be bad sometimes and I know that in the definitive edition they plan to have region filtering and such which I'm glad for. Also I personally haven't bought any of the DLC characters even though Ranno looks very fun and I'd like to try playing with him. I've decided I'm not going to get any of the DLC and just wait for the definitive edition which thankfully will include all of the DLC characters and stages. I like this game a lot and I'm very excited to get definitive edition on my switch so I can even bring this game with me on the go. I'm hoping for a sooner than later in the summer release cause i just can't wait. Overall I'd give this game 4 out of 5 stars because I really like it a lot but I feel like it could have more for newer players to do to help them improve and not just get thrown into combo city with no idea how to deal with pressure or mixups or anything like that. I'm sure with definitive edition coming out it will bring a good amount of new players in as well as bringing back players that had stopped playing the game. I have my hopes up high but I could very well be disappointed with the results, we'll see. I play Kragg and Zetterburn by the way if anyone happened to be wondering. Hope this review helps anyone.

review:
Absolute fire, you can just style on people, although the ranked is filled with only the biggest of wieners so be prepared for a nice resizing. Boys house out of ten, top tier. 

Also abyss mode is an unnecessary grindfest that makes no sense for a fighting game.If you want to unlock FD you have to spend 20 hours in abyss mode running the same thing over and over again. It wouldve been fine had they considered the curve at which you gain experience and thus levels for the achievement that unlocks the stage. It simply isnt fun to grind the same scenarios again and again and again and again FOR EVERY BASE CHARACTER! Seriously the amount of time it takes is unholy and mightve been an outright troll by the devs.  Fortunately all stages are unlocked online but if you have IRL friends or family be prepared to sink an unholy amount of time into an unenjoyable grindfest just for a stage.The grind is so egregious I would have been less pissed off had they just charged five dollars to unlock it. Seriously they ought to patch it down by at least half and youll still be there awhile.

review: If you like smash, you will like this game, it is basically smash but built for competitive, with built-in stage striking, unique and balanced roster, and unique stages that all fit the competitive scene. Rivals has a very easy to play, hard to master concept that goes along with it, most of the tech like wavedashing and wall techs are easy to do. But the real skill shines within the mastery of neutral, punish, advantage, and disadvantage. Like I said at the beginning of this short review, if you like smash, there is no reason to not try this game, I really want to see this community flourish into something huge.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
One of the best fighting games on the market.  The movement feels amazing, with the buffer making said movement incredibly smooth.  Honestly that alone makes the game incredibly fun to play, it is probably the most fun fighting game to just move around in.  Combos are decently long and free-form, allowing you to string several moves together and adjust to how you opponent reacts to your combo.  Additionally, these combos for the most part aren't incredibly technical, allowing for the player to improvise combos on the fly.

The only real complaint I ever had was that there was a lack of casual play.  However, with the addition of workshop, that issue is completely solved.  There's plenty of fan-made characters that are a lot of fun to play, ranging from those who were created with balance in mind, all the way to the completely broken ones.  If you want to play Rivals and not worry too much, get a couple of friends and play those broken characters, it'll be a blast.

Overall, a great game to pick up.  Relatively inexpensive, even with all the DLC, and offers a lot of fun for the competitive or casual fighting game fan.  If you enjoy fighting games with good movement and good combo games, or you enjoy beating up your friends with silly characters, Rivals of Aether is the game for you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you are into competitive games just buy it. 
It is a very deep game, mechanics-wise, inspired by melee but different enough to be its own thing. If you are more into casual gameplay there's also the workshop (just check youtube) and solo game modes. Tutorials go over pretty much every mechanic in 3 levels of depth and every character has its own.
Every character has its own mechanics and no one feels a copy of any character in smash. They all feel unique. Also the balance in this game is just on point. There is not a non-viable pick or OP characters.
The artstyle is just beautiful, pixel art, music, animation, stages, HUD...
The only downside is the number of players at a time, it makes matchmaking sort of a lottery where you can be destroyed by a pro or play someone who has never touched the game.

Coming from smash brother games, this game might feel clunky. But once you learn how the controls differ, you will feel sharper than ever.
Coming from a traditional fighter, this game might feel overwhelming. But once you learn to take advantage of the space around you, you will feel swifter than ever. 
Rivals of Aether offers fast paced and snappy action, for those willing to learn how it operates. and once you do, the varied cast will guide you toward excelling at at every facet of the game. despite the small roster, you will find more variety here than in any other platform fighter. And if that isn't enough... Workshop.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'd been playing Smash Bros. since I was a kid back in the N64 days and enjoyed playing all the entries that followed. However, once I started playing on other consoles and eventually PC I no longer had access to Smash Bros. So I started looking for a good substitute. I tried Brawlhalla & Brawlout and neither really felt like a genuine Smash like game to me. 

Then I saw Rivals and decided to give it a shot too. I now look back at Smash Bros and wonder how much better Smash Bros. could've been if they'd tried implementing even half of the character moveset ideas that Rivals has. 

This game is in my eyes exactly where Smash should've ended up gameplay wise. It's faster, more creative, has a fantastic community, and some of the most exciting tournament matches I've seen in fighting games across the board.

Make sure you don't underestimate how great Rivals of Aether really is and give it a shot yourself

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you like Platform fighters such as Smash (any title), SSF2, SSB Crusade, Slap City, Icons, etc., then this game is for you. Period. This game is the most fun I've had in years, and offers a more competitive scene compared to smash without trying. For example, I personally am average in Smash, but with how intuitive Rivals is, I play like a pro. This game is amazing, the characters are unique and interesting, the stages are awesome, the music is banging, there are a ton of modes to play, single player or otherwise, and achievements are fun to obtain. And did I mention this game has workshop support? You can mod in any character you desire. Shrek vs Ronald Mcdonald vs Obama is FINALLY possible in this game. 11/10, can't stop coming back to this game. Buy it, play it, and have your life changed for the better.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Want a faster pace smash bros like game? Like a large diversity of play styles in characters despite a low playable character count? Then this game is for you!

Pro's: 
Good music
Fast and solid gameplay
Fairly friendly community willing to help improvement, or willing to goof off if thats what you prefer.

Cons:
Super steep difficulty curve online.
Very few choices of how to improve and practice outside of online play.

Cons that are likely to be fixed in the near future with definitive edition:
Wired internet connection is kind of required, and even then there is occasional unstable ping.
Limited to 1v1 multiplayer outside of local play, and steams couch play.

now for some joking character overviews:

(Seriously these are just jokes, don't dive into the salt mines.) 

Clairen: Future cat uses bubbles to hide from projectiles. Opponents find her sword stunning. They do not mean that positively.

Zetterburn: Fire makes fire, While also making it so that this lion can hit harder. WHY???

Forseburn: The most intense game of hide and seek I've ever seen. 

Wrastor: CAPTAIN LITERALLY A FALCON. 

Absa: Local goat kills everything with one very well-placed kick. 

Elliana: Essentially bowser jr. but interesting.

Sylvanos: I am anger salad. I speak for the trees, and the trees say F@#$ you.

Maypul: Gets one of the worst recovery moves in the game, so uses it to kill people instead.

Kragg: KRAGG THROW ROCK AT FACE. KRAGG THROW ROCK AT FACE. KRAG THROW ROCK AT FA-

Orcane: Adorable water dog kills people with his own ass. 

Etalus: (the magic school bus theme grows slowly louder as he slides towards you)

Ranno: Less damaging but harder to get rid of passive damage than zetterburn AND a more powerful stun mechanic than Clairen. Why was this even approved?

Ori: Dies at 70% but can kill you at 70%. Seems like a fair trade.

Shovelknight: Somehow can do bayonetta style combos... with a shovel?



Over all: A fast paced smash bros like game, with a huge update and even a switch version coming just around the corner. If that sounds like something you'd like then this is def the game for you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Fantastic game! Rivals has great movement and a diverse cast don't think this is "Just a Smash Bros clone" Rivals is so so much more. While it is inspired by Smash (especially Melee which isn't a bad thing) Rivals is very much it's own thing and definitely worth a shot. The movement is quick and snappy, the devs pour a lot into making getting into the competitive scene of it worth while, and it offers tutorials that teach the player everything in such a clean way to understand the game's fundamentals. Even for casual play this game is still easy to pick up and play and custom characters are a blast! This game is more then worth the 15 bucks and when it's on sale (usually around $7.49 in USD) it's an absolute steal!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I like this game, i really do, but i can't recomend it, if you have no friends to play local , don't even waste your money on this, the servers online are pratically non-existent since they use a player2player connection, if you get to play a match with a ping better than 200 or 100 you're blessed, because the input lag gets so terribly, and when playing with randons online, good luck getting someone on your skill level, most of times you will just get paired with a no-life with hundreds of hour which will just bash you in a matter of seconds ... if this game ever gets a decent server and matchmaking i might change this review, has for now, those are my complaints ...

Edit 1: I have dedicated a few more hours into playing Ranno which made the game more enjoyable to me, the complains about the lag stand still as a better conection other than p2p would be nice but oh well ... it's not fun to queue for a match for 10 minutes and people declining over and over .. other than that .. its ok i guess ..

Edit 2: Still no servers, get away from this game while you can, spend your money where it's worth

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is, in my opinion, the best platform fighter out there. The mechanics are much easier to pick up than Melee, and the characters are much more varied at the competitive level. The game gets updated frequently, so glaring balance issues aren't usually a problem for too long. If competitive stuff isn't your thing, the game still offers plenty of other stuff to do such as abyss mode or custom workshop characters. My biggest complaint is that the netcode isn't amazing, but it's supposed to be updated in the summer.
9/10 Would buy again on Switch

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I was hardcore into Smash Melee and RoA is now my favorite platform fighter and the closest thing we'll ever get to a melee sequel. The character design is sick. Colors are customizable, Controls are customizable.  The game just feels good even if you aren't fighting anyone. Movement is smooth and flowy. Characters feel balanced and well designed. No one is not fun to play. The level design is beautiful and well thought out. The game modes are fun. Online works great. Just like smash it's easy to jump into and fun right away but practice, and skill are still highly rewarded.

 The devs clearly care about keeping the game fun and adding new and exciting things. I can't recommend it enough if you like Smash Bros or any other platform fighter. This is the best one.

review: The game is honestly great. It runs nice and it has a wide and unique variety of characters. The workshop is especially fun! I do have a few problems with it, however. First off, I keep on getting paired with the same person over and over again on ranked online. I only have one Continent filtered out, and I know this game has a lot of players. Speaking of filters, that one continent I filtered out still gives me players from that area. I quadruple checked, and yet still the same player kept appearing. One more thing I want to be changed; the custom controls keep on resetting, and I wish they would save, even when you leave. Other than that its a fun game

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This is a very good platform-fighting game. Each character feels like a work of art, and very original. The gameplay has tons of depth if you like to play competitively, but if you don't like that as much, try workshop characters. You can just have fun messing around with a friend. Workshop characters add so much to this game. There is no limit to what you can create (if you're willing to put in the time and effort to actually program it). The in-game online may seem empty, but go on the discord servers and you'll be able to find someone in your region fairly quickly. Overall, this game is a work of art, original and fun, with few flaws.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: After playing this game for a while im kinda debating if i want to recommend it. First off this game looks great, the music in this game is amazing, and the game is overall fun. The bad part about this game is starting out, if you hop into matchmaking you will get destroyed, there is no point in playing that. Its like the people on this game have no mercy for new players. There is a discord server to find people around your skill level to play with but some people might not use discord or they might think it is tedious to hop on discord and wait for people to play with every time they want to play the game. If you want to improve fast, you need a coach, but that is something im not personally down to get. Basically this game is amazing, one of the best platform fighters ive ever played, but starting out is super hard and for someone that wants a more casual game to play this is not it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I would describe Rivals of Aether as Smash Melee lite, and feels very comfortable coming from Smash, there are some differences a la the lack of a shield, grabs, or a ledge, but they're very similar. While a very well put together, the tutorial is kind of boring, but is informative and the best place to start. As a disclaimer, this game has a small community and you'll be getting washed in online matches, this game is not friendly to casuals. You'll need to really learn the mechanics and neutral game before you'll be taking wins. Casual play is pretty limited, so I would not recommend it to someone who wants to play that way.

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
In my opinion, this is a very good game. But I'm kind of biased because I love fighting games such as Super Smash Bros, Brawlhalla, and other games. 
     This game is great because it has a story mode, online, and practice without being too involved in any specific game mode. I also like the the characters and physics in this game. The characters really remind me of Super Smash Bros 64, because its a little harder to string along a combo, and the main point is to have your opponent off the stage. The physics remind me of Super Smash Bros Melee, or Super Smash Bros Ultimate, because it's like "punching a balloon across the room." 
     Some downsides to this game it's really hard to start playing online, for your first time. For me, I would never be able to beat someone online because they combo me so much. Maybe I'm just bad. I still love the game though. 
     The community in my opinion is really nice compared to some other games I have played such as Geometry Dash, and Team Fortress 2. 
     Overall, i would have to give this game an 8/10 mainly taken down points for originality, and difficulty. I hope you enjoyed my review of Rivals of Aether and continue to/decide to play this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Having played many different platform fighters and all the smash games I can confidently say this is some of the tightest and most well tuned and engaging game play. The characters are all unique and balanced and the online is better than most other games in the genre. The only negatives are a bit of lack in single player content and having multiple payed DLC characters that in total cost more than the base game. This is at least partially excusable as the developers are always hard at work and the support goes along way unlike say  a company like Nintendo. The workshop has some super cool and insane characters and is a great way to introduce new players to the scene. This is well worth the price and would recommend this to anyone who likes smash or any other platform fighters or fighting games in general. 9/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
One of the best Indie games and Smash Bros. style game I've played in my life. Every character is extremely unique compared to Smash Bros. Ultimate's deal with literally copying off a character they already made like Zero Suit Samus to regular Samus or Ness to Lucas. The pixel art style with background, design, and sprites are extremely polished and flow smoothly. I like the fact you can even download mods for this game to further expand your experience to infinite possibilities. With that, you can pretty much make your own characters and stages if you know how to code and and draw pixel art or sprites. Because of that, I can even say that this game could blow Smash Bros. Ultimate off the market because of the fact you can create. I can even make as many league of legend modes for this game as I want. I highly recommend this game to all those creative minds out there and to those that enjoy fighting games in this style. 

Thank Fornace for making an incredible game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
EDIT 3/16/20: Bit late to the punch on this one, but my goodness the workshop content is incredible. It's only a matter of time before every fictional character is in this game. 1000% recommended.

EDIT 8/10/18: Shovel Knight was announced, which is cool. That likely brings the grand total of all the DLC's cost to $20 (excluding a possible sale of course). Coming from someone who has all current DLC and intends on buying the final DLC fighter, it's... kind of a bit much. It's not like the game is incomplete without them, but when you're playing with the same 8 fighters, it leaves a lot to be desired. Especially when you know that lot to be desired is THERE, just locked behind a price. That said, you probably shouldn't buy this game unless you're willing to fork out at LEAST 25 dollars instead of the up-front 15. That way you can either get 4 more original fighters or the 2 guest stars, or a combination of the two. That, or you could wait for a monstrous sale and get everything for less than the game's original pricetag.

That said, I love this game.
 

If you enjoyed the competitive aspects of any of the Super Smash Bros. series, you've got a high chance to enjoy this. It may take some getting used to, but the gameplay becomes very rewarding and satisfying as you learn to utilize many of the game's techniques. Especially once you get used to each character's unique mechanics, but, as with every fighting game, some tend to be more powerful than others. However, due to the relatively small roster size and the active team, you'll find that no character is particularly unfair to fight against (Except [i]maybe[/i] Ori and Sein, but they're supposedly being changed soon). Some things to note before you purchase, though:
[list]
[*] Not everything will be unlocked initially. You will have to play quite a bit to unlock everything.
[*] You will likely want a compatible controller. I've had someone refund the game because the keyboard controls were really hard to deal with.
[*] The price for non-cosmetic dlc that we know of (which is 3 characters and one stage) goes up to ten dollars. Only one character and one stage are available right now. There's more dlc on the way as well, so don't expect the full package with your initial $15 purchase.
[*] Singleplayer content may be a bit on the short side. There's no slough of extra gamemodes like Smash 4 has, but this does include a story mode, an Abyss Mode (think of an endless Multi-man smash, but with a lot of customization elements and some boss fights and unique challenges interwoven), online play, and, of course, a local versus mode (with AI if you don't have friends nearby)
[*] Currently, you can only play vanilla 1v1 on the stage hazzard-less versions of stages online. The developers said that the online mode will be expanded in the future, but just know that as of this date, it isn't quite complete yet.
[/list]

And as far as the gameplay itself compared to other Smash-esque games goes...
[list]
[*] No ledge grabbing.
[*] Airdodge is that of Melee's, but you don't go into freefall afterwards and it can be used to cancel some special moves.
[*] No basic grab (some characters do have command grabs)
[*] Shield is replaced with a Parry, which is essentially a counter that stuns the opponent briefly, even if they use a command grab. Has strict timing and the stun can be ignored entirely if it's triggered by an opposing jab (with an exception of the last hit)
[*] Every character can wall jump, and can do so even out of free fall or some special airborne state. Walljumping in these circumstances removes freefall too.
[/list]

Also, something else worth noting is that the game's music and artwork are beautiful and refreshing, despite following the infamous and in some cases boring pixel art style. In turn, due to the graphical style, you'll find that this game can run on just about anything at a smooth 60 fps. Your old computer, your laptop, your gameboy, your refrigerator, your couch, your soul, you name it. ...Okay, maybe not ALL of those things...

Overall, I recommend that any competitive Smash Brothers player try this game. Heck, maybe you'll enjoy if you like competitive games in general. It takes inspiration from the Smash Bros. series while providing many new and unique mechanics to keep it from being a clone. While the game is missing some things that will be added in the future, what it does currently have will keep you occupied for quite a while. If you have 15 dollars to spare, this game might be worth picking up if it's many high points intrigue you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's a great game, an incredibly mechanically solid smash clone with mostly original characters. This game also features a robust steam workshop with custom characters, stages and more, with some great additional characters and meme-y chaos as a result.

The standard online lobbies are rather hostile to casual players, but remote play and a number of Discord communities make it easy to find players of a similar skill level to jump in and have a blast with now and again.

The game's biggest weakness is a drought of good singleplayer content. The NPC AI is rather lacking compared to what can be found in similar fighting games and the solo story mode... needs an overhaul. Abyss mode is pretty fun, but it's nothing to write home about.

Overall, this game is great and the robust workshop support really elevates it. You need to put in some amount of effort to get much enjoyment here, but having a good time isn't only down to system mastery like some of the negative reviews would have you believe.

Overall, I give this game 8/10 arbitrary points. I think it needs better singleplayer content to ease peoples' frustrations, but it's still a very good game with a lot of fun to be had for all.

review:
This game's pretty fun, if you want to play the workshop version, follow these steps
1. buy this game (is simple XD)
2. get some characters from the workshop (You can't play as the costume characters without getting them)
3. right-click Rivals of Aether, click Properties and click Beta (Now this is when it starts)
4. click "Select the beta you would like to opt into" and scroll down until you see "Workshop Beta".
5. click cancel and enjoy playing.
If it works, your welcome.
if it didn't work, try to do 3 to 5 again. (Keep in mind the game's cover will change to Purple to Green)
That's all.
I'm out.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Short version: If you love Smash Bros or fighting game insanity, you're going to love this game.

Long version:
On its own, it's a very fun game! There are 8 base game characters and 6 DLC characters (Two characters per $5 pack, with an exception for some third party reps) as well as a story mode based around the 6 characters first introduced to the game, and an "Abyss" mode that tasks you with completing certain challenges one after another in a wave-like function. All of these features are great by themselves, but the game starts to get even crazier once you boot up the Workshop Beta.

The workshop for this game is pretty great! A ton of characters and stages to download and play with/on for yourself, whether it's as OP as Ronald McDonald or The Duane or as weak as Motivational Lizard (he tries his best though). There's something for every type of player on the workshop, and matches can become crazy if you get some friends and some workshop characters together. Unfortunately, as it's still in Beta, there are some issues. It's inevitable that your game could crash when playing a very demanding workshop character (such as Base Joker) and menu load times for workshop characters can be annoying. There are other things that annoy me slightly, like not being able to use Workshop characters online with friends or coins earned not saving, but those I can understand.

There's online play as well. Of course, you won't be able to play as any Workshop characters or stages online, which makes sense. There are many workshop characters that are stupidly powerful or underwhelmingly weak, and having those characters flood online matches wouldn't be that fun. I personally haven't tried many online matches, as I'm not as good with the base roster as I am with the workshop characters.

Overall, I enjoyed this game. It reminds me of games like Super Smash Flash which are PC friendly clones of Smash Bros. I think what makes this game more enjoyable than Smash Flash is because of how different it is compared to Smash. There's different characters, different mechanics, and different customization options, like making your own custom color. If you want a PC fighting game with similar mechanics to Smash Bros but still being different, Rivals of Aether has you covered!

You can build custom stages and even custom characters, which is part of why I love this game so much. The online community here is more intense (akin to Super Smash Bros. Mele) than other games of this type. This is one of my favorite games I have ever purchased. 10/10 would recommend!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Excellent platform fighter with super fun movement and tons of depth in every character. The things rivals changes about the genre makes for a fresh, great new experience.

Plus the workshop mods allows for tons of stupid fun, but also interesting well designed characters and stages.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: So the way I got into rivals is cause I was looking for a new platform fighter that felt smooth with great gameplay. I played a decent amount of brawlhalla and at first it was fun but then it became more tedious and boring the farther I climbed and with the new weapons ruining the game. Smash was fun but at the same time getting kinda old with Bayonetta. So my friend introduced me to rivals and I gave it a try at his place ever since then I was hooked. I never felt so much progress as I improved with smooth mechanics that allow for fun matches. A development team that ACTUALLY cares about its game and strives to improvement. Its getting a brand new netcode, something capcom wouldn't do. It has a fun workshop mode where you can download and make your own fighter. Plus Dan is one of the best top dogs I have ever seen working behind a game. So I highly recommend the game, soon it will have a Definitive Edition which will add more content.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A great successor to Super Smash Bros. The controls are great (though the default setting isn't the best in my opinion) and it runs very smoothly. The game is easy to pick up o and start playing, but it definitely takes a bit of  time and practice to master it. One thing I really like about this game is the workshop feature that was added to it. I would definitely check out the fighters section in the workshop for this particular game. My personal favorite OC characters are the ones featured in The Diamonds & The Rough, So much time and effort has been put into each of them. In my honest opinion, the characters in that set feel like they could easily be considered a part of the Rivals of Aether roster if someone was unfamiliar with the game. My overall rating for this game is 10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I can't believe ive left off reviewing  this game for as long as I have considering its one of my favorite games of all time, but you should know that this is the most enjoyable platform fighter ive ever played, including every smash brothers game. people say this game isnt for casuals, but I no longer agree with that. with the workshop the game brings in the potential audience of any casual, which is amazing to see. 

the workshop is amazing and all, but im not going to be talking much about that. when it comes down to it the base game and its dlc, are some of the most fleshed out, interesting characters ive ever played, focusing on quality over quantity to the highest degree. every character played super different, and super unique even if at first glance, they seem super basic. the fact that I enjoy playing as literally every single one of them is a huge achievement.

If you've ever seen competitive melee, you may be discouraged to get into it with how technical it is. however, this game tries to imitate the feeling of those games when you are really good, keeps its high skill ceiling, but gets rid of the barrier of entry. instead of L cancelling, there just isnt much lag, wavedashing is incredibly generous, and the knockback paired with the hitstun is incredibly combo based. 

offstage is the most fun that ive ever had in a platform fighter, if you just played offstage it would still be my favorite of the genre. in games like smash bros, you get a standard ledge that grants invincibility, which is where most edgeguarding takes place. however, in rivals there is no ledge, instead you get a walljump, in which grants you your up-b again. this allows offstage to be threatening, without being strictly a death trap like it is in games like ultimate.

other things that are drastically changed are the grabs, which dont exist, giving more emphasis toward using your regular moves to get the opponent where you want, instead of just grabbing to start a basic combo. The other change is to the shield, instead of a shield every character gets a parry, which acts like a standard counter, but if activated, stuns the opponent like when you get a shield break, which emphasizes true combos or aerial combos. if its not true or confusing to the opponent, they cant parry at the correct time, which allows you to keep a combo going

on the topic of combos, in games like smash ultimate particularly, combos are quick, done in a few moves, or highly technical. Take mario for example, marios notorious combo involves a shit ton of up airs, a few up tilts sometimes, a throw, and an up b, but mainly a shit ton of up airs. in rivals, I have never looked up any combos, seen any and tried them myself, or anything, but I came up with a bunch for myself. They happen almost subconsciously, its really something you have to play for yourself. just know that if you look up a combo video, they arent THAT hard to do. with a little practice you could probably do something very similar, be it worse or better.

People say that the singleplayer is horrible in this game, and for the most part I agree with them. however, abyss mode seems often overlooked. the ui is really confusing but if you find it, unlock it, and play it, its very fun. you use coins you get from playing the game to buy runes which change up your characters moveset in minor or major ways. you start with nothing, and you wont get farm but overtime, you get more gear and get better. another bonus is you can play it with friends which goes a long way.

you wont regret buying this game if you put the time in, its that good. definitive edition is on its way and I highly HIGHLY reccomend it. Im personally getting switch because I already have the regular pc version obviously, but on the topic of portability or workshop, go with pc first. workshop does add a lot to the game, but dont look over the main game, its a damn good time.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether first came off to me as a Smash clone. After recently playing it I can conclude it has the same percentage system from Smash, yet the game is so different! This game is mostly combo oriented, as hit stun midair is very long. The workshop characters are the icing and cherry on the cake, as the game can be fun without them but add much more fun to it. Local multiplayer with apps like Parsec or Steam's Remote Play make this a grand ol' time with friends, or even your mom!

Highly recommend it!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Such an amazing platform fighter. I'm really not good at this game at all, but it is challenging and fun when you do manage to land a combo. Plus the tutorials honestly served as a fun way of teaching me more complex mechanics I have never really understood.


Update:
Playing online is brutal. Not gonna lie, spending 4 hours of my free time when I don't have loads getting destroyed over and over not learning anything because Im just being repeatedly combod. Yeah that's not fun.

I still enjoy the game and art style, but how the hell are you meant to improve when you cant really interact vs the people online.

I would like to add that when you do find someone roughly as bad as you are though it feels great. The back and forth of a close fight can feel super intense and the thrill of finally managing to beat someone after getting bodied for hours is fantastic/

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I'm a fan of fighting games in general (Tekken, MK, Street Fighter, etc.) and my favorite has always been Super Smash Bros. When I came across this game, I honestly thought it was a Smash rip off, and wasn't gonna be worth it. A year later, I saw the game was actually doing well, so I decided to try it. I haven't put it down since. It's everything I love about Smash Brothers but it adds more speed, better abilities and a fluid combo system that makes the game feel like it's meant for competitive play.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Game is great, just not for me I guess. 

It plays beautifully and there's a huge ammount of depth in each character. Game is hard as balls and extremely frustrating though. Certain characters feel like their dominant strategy is extremely degen.

Parry is a bad and one dimensional mechanic and probably what drags the game down the most for me personally. 

DLC characters feel kinda wacky, especially elli, sk and ori. game got alot less fun when those lads joined the roster. 

Pick it up if you're interested in a really hard plat fighter with unconventioanl mechanics. Netplay is ass but is being worked on. If you're looking for a casual experience, stay far away, you might get extremely disapointed. if you're still interested wait for the defenetive edition which is supposedly coming in a couple of months.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
You like Smash Bros? you like when someone picks the game's formula and does changes that can make it's title stand on it's own while still being fun? you also like Anthro characters? also you want a Fighting game that allows you to use the workshop to download awesome stages and characters even if most of them are Meme fuel?

Rivals of Aether is The Game for you!

Positives:
+ The game has a really good art style
+ while the selection of characters is smaller than Smash, it does provide characters with unique moves, --personality and all things that makes a good fighting game character.
+ Gameplay is Easy to pick up, fun to play, but it's hard to master all mechanics in the game
+ Luckily it has a great Tutorial that will teach you from the Basics to the most advanced techniques
+ Soundtrack has a really good 16-bits vibe and it's always great to listen to it
+ It has Shovel Knight and Ori (as DLC) 
+ Online is really good and probably the mode you're probably gonna be spending the most time with

Negatives? sadly there is some
- 6 of the characters are DLC, even if they are cheap like 5 dollars 2 characters, 2 of them (Shovel Knight and Ori) are separate and cost the same ammount of money which is a bit of a bummer
- Single Player Content is lacking in many places
- It's probably not gonna be for everybody since it feels Heavily different from Smash in gameplay, like the lack of Grabbing Ledges, Guarding and actual Grabs

but despite some issues here and there, Rivals of Aether is a great game. i can't even call this a Smash clone because the game stands out on it's own and it feels really good to play! in fact parts of the gameplay i prefer it over Smash Ultimate (and i love that game). and now with the addition of Workshop this will make the game even more interesting and insane! i simply love this game~

9/10

review:
The game offers a highly streamlined control scheme with some of the most technical aspects of any fighting game I've ever played. The community is extremely welcoming and helpful, always willing to teach and tutor those who seek the help. The game is extremely competitive, but the game itself seems to have this energetic charge to it that helps to fuel that competition aspect. 
Extremely good game, underrated as far as I am concerned, should be talked about more

There aren't too many characters to start with (there is DLC) but the ones you have are extraordinarily well made and are all super fun to play. Whether you're an expert in fighting games or not, I'm sure anyone can enjoy Rivals Of Aether.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: rivals of aether is a game that despite being inspired by smash bros, feels like a vastly different game. it achieves this by taking the core gameplay of melee, then adding its own features like parries and removing grabs and shields to make it more offense-oriented, then having 12 unique characters and 15 original stages my only complaint is that the AI isn't quite strong enough to fully prepare you for the shap difficulty curve of fighting online. eight-point-five out of ten, would be well worth my money even if it costed twice as much for a unique and more competitive take on the smash bros formula.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: ROA does what nintenDONT because like honestly, this is just a mishmash of smash melee combined with ultimate, which makes for some incredibly entertaining matches.  Along with that, you now are able to get custom characters, even if they are broken, or too underpowered, its a lot of fun to play with characters that people have made, wheather they are pre-existing characters or even if they happen to just be OCs. Overall this game was surely worth the money, allowing characters to be made in this game makes this game way more popular and playable, its amazing honestly

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Damn how have i not given this a review? Rivals of Aether is honestly the best platform fighter out there(besides smash) The game's controls, style, characters and music are all very good. The team are very open and keep the game fairly balanced and mostly bug free while listening to the community.

And then you have the workshop...the unholy perfection that pushes this game to a whole new level. Everything from legit oc's to indie reps to memes....to ronald mc steal your girl donald. 
If you're a fan of smash or competitive fighting games to even just shitposts, you should check this game out!

review: In less than 2 hours of gameplay, this game and the content creators in the workshop have made characters that have made me hard wheeze laugh because of it being the dumbest and most unexpected shit I've ever seen. The thing that broke the camels back in terms of making me wheeze laugh was after hours of getting anal and mouth raped by Lvl 9 Ronald McDonald, was I picked Weegee and dodged mid-air and was completely caught off guard by the super Sayian teleport noise coupled with Weegee practically teleporting....Just buy it and go right to the workshop....all I need to say.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game has workshop support and custom characters. There's also Ronald Mcdonald as a playable character. He's fast, and he runs like he has to use the taco bell bathroom. Jojo references? Check. Memes? Check. Hamburgers? Check. Rugal's Genocide Cutter? Check. High quality rips? Check. This man is unstoppable. He will dunk you into the stratosphere and he will give you a value meal free of charge. Face him, and your going to eat it, he's got explosive milkshakes and apples and he's got a freaking ketchup death laser! Whatever you do, do not face Golden Ronald, because his power is stronger than any roast Wendy's has made on twitter and he will do anything to serve fast food and fast victories, even if it has some extra salt. Be prepared for the battle of a lifetime, because he is fueled by red bull and too much anime. If you face golden Ronald. Good luck, as I've been trying to win for over an hour now. I'm not going to quit though, because defeating gold Ronald is a gold experience.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game will forever be my favorite non-Smash platform fighting game. Its characters, stages, music, and menus all look super nice. This game feels like Melee but you can act out of your air-dodges immediately (and they don't put you in special fall), the ability to grab and ability to shield are intentionally gone, and there's parrying in place of shields. The parry ability replaces those buttons for shielding in the original control scheme too, so it's obviously intentional. If you are attacked in your parrying state, the opponent is frozen for about a second. I'm not good at explanations, so just... play the tutorial or something. The characters feel very nice and balanced, although Zetterburn still feels kinda broken, along with Absa and Etalus. The story mode is rather short, but still fun. I love this game, but it's definitely better with friends.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Do you like Smash Bros?  Then you're gonna love this game!

This is the closest thing we can get to playing Smash Bros. on PC.  And that's just fine because the characters are all well-designed and fun to play as.  I mean they have AN ORCA-CAT (ORCAT?) for Pete's sake!  And if for some bizarre reason you don't like any of them, you can just play as custom characters from steam workshop! (Sans and Ronald McDonald, anyone?)

As far as being a Smash Clone goes, this tries to provide more tournament-friendly play and thus has no items and has stages that are less gimmicky than many stages found in Smash.  So if your absolute favorite part of Smash is throwing around green shells and poke balls at each other, you may be a tad disappointed.

What you have you have here is a game that is not only perfect for serious play, but is a ton of fun to casually play with your friends & family.  And if you don't currently have anyone to play with in the same room, then you can play online Currently limited to 1v1 as of Feb-6-2019, but 3p & 4p online matches will be available this Summer with the upcoming Definitive Edition.

tl;dr  This is an amazing Smash Bros. style game you should totally play!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether....is a fun game. Despite what it may appear to be on the surface, this game is not a Smash clone. It may be a platform fighter just like Smash, and while the overall speed of the game may be more akin Smash Melee, the distinct lack of grabs, ledges, or shields make this game pretty unique mechanically. Not to mention the unique roster that Rivals brings to the table as well. Not to mention, Rivals is CONSIDERABLY much more balanced than Smash. The community is somewhat small, yet dedicated. Which makes this game not too appealing to casual fans, as there are likely dozens of players with thousands of hours in this game who have been playing since day 1, leading to a very frustrating cycle of getting beaten time and time again. Until suddenly, a miracle happens, and you start getting beaten less often. Even after 150+ hours in this game myself, I still often get beaten by players of higher skill level than me. So getting better at the game isn't something that just happens; it's something that you have to be dedicated to and work towards. Something that, more casual players who aren't interested in that kind of time-sink, may find off-putting.

If the game isn't very casual friendly by itself, then what is there left to do? Well, you can always try out "story" mode, with art that looks like it was drawn by a 4th grader and a "story" that makes Smash Brawl's 'Subspace Emissary' look like Homer's 'Odyssey'. Not to mention that for new players, the CPUs are hard. For players who have played the tutorials, the CPUs are nothing more than an obstacle between them and earning that second custom color option. But what about besides the story mode? Well, there's Abyss Mode. Where you can spend hours and hours doing the same easy thing over and over again, just so you can get special runes that just adds an extra helping of jank into the game. But only on local mode and only with the base 8 characters, not the DLC ones (more on that later). But besides the game modes, there is one last thing that makes this game appealing to casuals: [b] The Workshop [/b]. With the power of the workshop beta, you can play as an infinite amount of characters that have been lovingly made by dedicated and (mostly) creative members of the community. There are SO many great workshop characters, and lots of them have very unique ideas that haven't been seen before. Now, keep in mind, the Steam workshop beta is just that: a beta. It is prone to crashing online and workshop replays have had a tendency to cause crashes as well. But if you're able to look past that and instead see the sheer abundance of creativity radiating from the workshop, you're bound to fall in love with it. Not to mention the "modding" that uses the replacement of game files that helps in adding custom music, skins, and more.

Now let me address some of the other concerns new players may have, which is either related to or can be answered by the Definitive Edition releasing Summer 2020. Plenty of people will, and already have, questions about what this means for Rivals. Well, we don't know everything. But what we do know is that Rivals of Aether: Definitive Edition will replace current Rivals of Aether. And yes, this does mean that if you buy Rivals now, you will have to buy it later. I understand the feeling of frustration on hearing this, but that's just the way it is. [b] HOWEVER [/b], the developers have confirmed that if you buy the game and all of the DLC characters, you will NOT have to buy the game again. The devs have not made it known how this will work (because they don't know how either), but they have confirmed that it will happen one way or another.

Definitive Edition, while still replacing the current Rivals, will, bring along many new things with it. This includes:
-Better netcode (better online experience, however the game will still likely be P2P)
-All DLC characters added to the base game
-Abyss mode will be finalized along with runes for all DLC characters
-New cosmetics (stage skins, chracter skins, etc.)
-Some older characters will have updated sprites and animations
-Workshop support will hopefully be finalized and out of the beta status (will NOT be available on Switch)
-A new platform (i.e. Switch) (RIP Xbox. No, we have not heard word as to the exclusion of Xbox for Definitive)

[b] IN CONCLUSION [/b]: Rivals of Aether....is a fun game. It may take dozens of hours and lots of dedication in order to even get remotely good at the game, but personally, I think it's all worth it for the hundreds of fun experiences it's given me. If you have any questions or are looking for help in how to get better, you can always ask the Discord server. It's widely active, and there is surely to be someone there who can help you. Comments will also be on for this review, so you can ask me anything if you'd like. Thanks for reading.

[b] NINTENDO SWITCH, HERE WE COME!! [/b]
