title: Rivals of Aether
review: Coming from Smash Brothers here. I jumped into this game a week ago after thought of purchasing it for years. I finally bought it on sale, and bought all the DLC characters as well. I have been having a tough time transitioning to this game from Smash, but the more I play, the better I am getting. The game is crisp and fast. The size of the game is super small, so it only took me about one minute and thirty seconds to install. The in-game tutorials are absolutely amazing. They teach you everything IN-GAME, which many fighting games do not. The characters are amazing (except Shovel Knight right now, I personally hate his guts, but that's only because I don't have any answers to his item-shop purchases). The community on Discord is awesome. The RoA Academy is a great place for beginners. They treat you with respect! (Screw you, DotA) I will accept any criticism.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I don't have that much time in rivals but i do have a lot of time in other platform fighters like Smash Ultimate and Brawlhalla
and when i write this review it Isn't just me saying that this is a bad game, far from it, but it comes from frustration. I know platform fighters and I know that there comes a lot of frustration from them and the games feel unbalanced. But for some reason whenever I play aethers i feel like im getting combo'd into oblivion and nothing helps. 

I know for a 100% fact that my 6 hours of playtime means i have little experience and i don't know matchups. But i the Directional Influence in this game feels utterly useless and once you get hit by a certain move by one character it just feels like its over and lose the stock or get around 80% of damage on you. 

I'm mainly writing this review for help. Maybe some of my complaints are valid and maybe its the inexperience that I have so I am just a noob complaining. But the only thing that I can say that really makes me not want to play is when I play smash i feel like when im losing its my fault, when i miss its my fault, and when i do the wrong option its my fault. When i play Aethers i feel like i have no control.

Thanks for reading and try to help me out because i am utter TRASH at this game

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The best platform fighter I've ever played. I love this game more than smash, as it gets rid of a lot of the mechanics that i disliked about smash brothers;
Grabs, shields, and ledge-grabbing are completely removed. This means gameplay is faster and more kinetic than smash, and in place of shielding is a parry which takes a lot of work to master using correctly. there are still air dodges and rolls though, making the game more focused on spacing and aggression.

It also helps that every character feels entirely unique, with their own special mechanics and ways of being played; playstyles range from placing puddles or air currents to buff your character, to creating shadow clones or earning money to buy new special moves. there is a playstyle for every type of player here.

The game has a lot of optimisations to many types of play, such as turning off stage hazards or uneven level design. Sadly the online is missing a few features i would love, there is no way to make big lobbies for all your friends, which makes it a hard sell to my discord buddies.

Overall a fantastic multiplayer game and fighting game, and with a few small additions it could become something truly special.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Debatably the best take on a platform fighter.  If you like smash then you will likely love this game.  

Important things to note are:[list]
[*]No shields.  
  Instead you have a high-risk, high-reward option called a "parry" which if timed correctly will stun your opponent or reflect any projectiles depending on the move.
[*]No grabs.  
  No shields, no need for grabs which I find to be one of the lamest things to ever exist in any fighter.  You'll have to be a lot more creative with your combos/punishes that just grab down throw into aerial.
[*]No Ledges.
  With no ledge to grab onto you're forced to recover in a lot more creative and interesting way.  Because of this you're given more options offstage to help you get back onto stage.  For instance, you can air-dodge once before landing and you won't go into special fall.  Also, you can walljump from a special fall state so you can perform your up special, walljump cancel it and up special again.
[/list]
There's a lot more to it than just that but I want this review to be brief so if you're interested and want to learn more about the mechanics of Rivals of Aether than looking online is a great idea.  If you're the kind of person who likes to "learn as I go" then you'll really want to pay attention when playing because there's a lot you can get punished for not knowing.  DI is very important as is knowing when and how to tech and whether or not you can throw out your own move before your opponent's next one.

If you like playing aggressive and having a very high skill ceiling then this game is a must-have.  Also SHOVEL KNIGHT

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1] Honestly I Just Love the Workshop [/h1]

I don't have the same experience as other Rivals players or even the time and practice that comes with being a Smash fan and fan of games like it.  I only got into these games since Super Smash Bros. Brawl.  

However, I do think that the gameplay of Rivals feels really, really [i] nice. [/i]  Rivals of Aether has a fast, clean flow to its combat.  Leaping around with Zetterburn, burning the dude then chokeslamming them into the abyss.  Throwing chunks of earth with Kragg and bashing everybody into the same earth.  The gameplay of Rivals is so intense and speedy and it gives me a thrill that the newest Smash game just hasn't been able to replicate.  

But...I'd be lying if I said that I wasn't more thrilled by the user content.  Now, I understand that Rivals has a team that worked on the game, originally crafting this platform fighter to be as smooth and sleek and badass as possible.  However, since the workshop was created for this game back in 2019, I've been more hooked on the game's user content than nearly anything else.  

You have people making OCs that could fit into the Rivals of Aether universe very well.  You have people adding stages from games I haven't heard anyone talk about in...ever.  You have the most meme-like garbage I've ever seen that is something you know is gonna show up on YouTube.  But most importantly, you have some of the most fun and unique interpretations of existing characters in Rivals that Smash never has yet.  People implement Garou: Mark of the Wolves characters with mechanics from MOTW itself, you got mechanics from 3D platformer characters worked into their moveset that nod back to physics exploits from the game.  You got fighters who people have wanted in Smash fully playable in Rivals with their own movesets.  

God, the workshop content is so good.  I've had so much fun just being offline and testing out so much workshop nonsense, characters that are so broken or fun to use that you'd probably never see them in their own crossover game like this.  The guys in the workshop are really good at what they do.

It even has mod compatibility, so you can have stages and characters outside of the game in it! review: Rivals of Aether is a wonderfully fantastic game through and through. Mechanics and movement feel better than some official Smash Bros games and almost all fan games. Everything feels fast paced and hectic, leaving you always on your toes. The game feels decently balanced, with each character having their own unique gimmicks, like Orcane's water puddles, Forsburn's smoke and doubling, or Absa's cloud control. Everything feels beautifully polished. If you like platform fighters, this is probably the best one on the Steam market.

review: Although I didn't look into this game very much at first, after the workshop update and the publicity of such on YouTube by people like Alpharad, I love this game. It is like Super Smash Bros. Melee if you couldn't grab onto characters and ledges. However, that doesn't matter. The game, both vanilla and with workshop characters, is a blast to play. Characters like Shovel Knight and Ori bring the game to a whole new level of fun. If I wanted to, I could play as Sandbert 3.0 fighting an overpowered Master Chief or Steve on Final Destination. This game has so much to it, and I've had a blast with the game so far. I definitely recommend.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: The game itself is fresh while also very familiar to those who play smash; I love the graphics and music! Overall a very unique platform fighter. But what puts this over the edge is the custom characters; this is the best thing I have seen implemented in any game EVER. Once you sink your teeth into this game and all it has to offer, you wont be able to put it down.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Very good game, If you like Super Smash Bros, you will definitely enjoy this, all the basic gameplay features are the same so it is easy to get into the game if you are coming from Smash. The main differences to consider is that you get a parry mechanic rather than a shield, and there are no ledges to grab onto. Every character is unique and has their own special gimmicks that work well with their movesets, and the roster includes both Ori from Ori and the Blind Forest, and also Shovel Knight from, well, Shovel Knight, which are very cool additions and also very fun to use. 

The singleplayer content is sort of lacking but fighting games aren't known for their singleplayer content. The game has a story mode which just consists of a series of fights for each character and a cool final boss battle where all the characters act as your lives, similar to how it worked in the Subspace Emissary from Super Smash Bros Brawl. There is also an Abyss mode where you try to get past wave after wave of fights and minigames, which is fun every so often but gets repetitive quickly as the waves are not randomized so you do the same order of things every run. 

If you like customizable content in your game, this game has a lot of it. Playing Abyss Mode lets you unlock and use Abyss Runes, which change the way attacks and physics work for the characters, and they can be used in fights against other players as well locally. In the extras mode you can create your own custom colour palettes which can be used in local matches or online in casual matches. There is a collection of various buddies that can be equipped for a little bit of flair in a match. The game also recently added support for workshop content. This includes custom characters, buddies, and stages, adding a limitless amount of content and makes the game more than worth the price.

All in all, this is a good game and I highly recommend it.

review:
One of the best 2D fighters on the market, my friends introduced me one night and I immediately went home and bought a copy myself. I've played Melee for years now, so It definitely feels familiar but still completely new and refreshing, the parry mechanic is tight and all of the characters are enjoyable. The only thing i'm not a huge fan of is the DLCs, the roster isn't huge and the DLCs are a bit pricey, I will probably eventually break down and buy a few but that's only because i've enjoyed the game so much already and i'm irresponsible with my money, not because it's a deal. 

Art style 9/10
Mechanics 9/10
Soundtrack 9/10
Cute animals 10/10

review: Please describe what you liked or disliked about his product and whether you recommend it to others. Please remember to be polite and follow the Rules and Guidelines. A description is required to post your recommendation.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
man if you hate yourself this game's perfect for going online and getting your ass stomped. doing casual matches online is like playing the lottery in how badly you want to get whooped. for some reason a lot of really good players hang around in casual match mode? i personally am fine with it but totally understand the frustrations that other people have getting into the game. the learning curve on this game is so unbelievably high; you just have to pray that you get matched with someone who's only just slightly better than you instead of leagues ahead so you can learn something instead of get 0 to death'd three times in a row

that being said, after about 50-ish hours of playing, it feels nice to be able to stomp on some other people. i've played PM, Melee, and ult and probably have over 1000+ hours combined in those games so i think i was able to pick it up a little quicker since the mechanics mostly carry over aside from parrying/wall jumping/hitfall. i think the main thing i'd complain about is how awful ranked mode is; i'll sit there for like, five minutes and not get a match so it's just better to play roulette with casual mode and hope you have some amount of fun. i mean, at the very least, the netcode is better than ultimate's so learning how to play online is bearable

the game is super well-designed and each character has their own quirks/playstyle that really make them all feel unique. everyone's got a different combo game and different "objectives" to fulfill while playing; i really wish that there was an easier way to learn the game than getting stomped on but sadly that kind of seems like the main way to learn. gonna keep playing for now; if you're okay with losing a lot, this game's honestly really fun to learn and playing when both people are on even playing grounds feels so fair; never felt like i've lost due to a matchup. it's really just about how you play.

also, workshop is a riot and thank god it's here

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
RoA is a really good platform fighter. It is fun to play casually and at a high level. It is fast, colorful and unique.

RoA distinguishes itself from Smash by replacing ledge-grabbing with wall-jumping, removing grabbing and shielding, and adding a parry mechanic. Each character also has an environmental ability of some kind, such as Wrastor's ability to create a horizontal space which he can move more quickly in. These abilities add a lot of interest to the game. The stages were thoughtfully designed, and the player is free to switch between the gimmicky casual version and simplified competitive version of each stage as needed (unfortunately, the gimmicky stages cannot be used in online play, only local play). In general, the online play is as good as the connections on either end and the distance between the players will allow. Using a wired connection and playing with people in your region will help. This game will run on any machine.

All in all, I strongly recommend RoA. It is an excellent game, and after 60 hrs of playtime I enjoy it more than ever.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Game is good, but I can really only recommend it if you already have a group of friends who are willing to play it with you.

Daily players for this game average from 200 - 500 players. This isn't a completely unreasonable amount of players, but in my personal experience I was playing against the same person in matchmaking repeatedly who kept leaving due to not wanting rematches. When I wasn't getting the same person I got people who would take a couple rounds, then leave and leave me in queue for awhile.

Aside from that problem there's also the massive skill gap. The only way you're going to be getting 'gud' at this game is if you have a friend who is already experienced that is willing to teach you how to get there, because the absolutely gigantic skill gap between you and the people that have already been playing this game will be so insane that you will find yourself being frequently 3-stocked and styled on. Aside from that you can also bash your head against the wall of top tier players this game has to offer and hope that some of their skill will rub off on you.

Definitely recommend it more for casual gameplay as the environment that's in the game right now is certainly not enough to promote anyone climbing a skill-ladder, especially when the curve to getting there for most games of this style ends up being a ladder-based progression that lasts months to years.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'm writing this review after my two xbox360 controllers stopped functioning correctly for playing this game so much. This game is the closest thing to a proper platform fighter that you can get on steam with a relatively healthy playerbase. It's not a big community, but if you have too much ping playing with the built-in matchmaking system there is always the possibility to find players on discord servers that are always eager to teach and play with you. There's also a definitive edition coming out soon (tm), which should bring a much better netcode along with other features.

The game is simply phenomenal, from the music, to the tight, frenetic gameplay, but I'm going to be honest with you. If you are getting this game just because you saw that the characters are animals and you are a furry, don't. You will get destroyed over and over by the players who actually like the fighting aspect of the game and tore each other to pieces while learning. The game can still be great for playing casually, but if you don't have other casual friends to play with, you are probably going to get frustrated and leave after 10 hours like most people do. But of course, there's always the possibility of being a furry and also liking fighting games.

Rivals of Aether is a love letter to smash bros melee, you will see good players using wavedashes, wavelands, edge cancels, crouch cancels, multishining, etc., I hope that's enough to convince you to get the game if you like melee. If you come from other platform fighters tho, the game is still very accessible, as techs are not as hard to perform as in melee. While it's true that Rivals is very inspired by melee, the game still has very unique mechanics, like the parry replacing the classic shield, or the walljump replacing the ledge, which make Rivals a more aggressive game than Smash, and a much more intense game than the floaty and shallow brawlhalla.

As for customization, the game allows custom colors (free) and skins (mostly paid), which is awesome. The game also lets you play with a ton of different controllers, and all of them should be viable (xboxONE, xbox360, dualshock 2/3/4, gamecube, keyboard, switch pro controller, etc.)

I love this game and the friendships that I gained along my ~700 hours of playing, and I plan on playing it further after getting a replacement controller. Get this game if you like being competitive, and buy the dlc if you want to try new characters. Every character is viable, and you will surely find one that suits your playstyle. Recommended.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Update 1/3/2020:

Almost 4 years later and the online mode for this game is brutally incomplete still. For starters, matchmaking is especially rudimentary as there are extreme deviations between you and your opponent in ranking. This game thinks it can imitate Smash Bros without actually having the infrastructure to do so. Oh, and DLC has also effectively ruined this game as the best characters are available to those who have some extra cash available. Pay to win at its finest!
--------
I want to like this game, I really do. And that can happen if they make the necessary fixes to get this game back on track. Playing this game locally is very fun, and I have done so on many occasions with friends. However, the big issue I have with this game right now is with its ranking system online. If you're just an average player, you'll either be matched with someone who is ranked significantly lower than you are or you will be matched with someone who is ranked significantly higher. I have rarely been paired with another player whose ranking deviated from mine by 30 ELO points or less. So needless to say you'll either be bored playing someone who doesn't have a ranking comparable to yours or you'll be frustrated by getting destroyed by someone who is light years ahead of you in ranking and overall skill. Furthermore, the community is fairly small so don't count on getting a lot of lag-free matches if you're outside the U.S., especially if you live in Asia or Australia. 

The gameplay on its own is fantastic and takes me back to when I first got interested in Smash Bros. Melee. But there are just so many glaring issues with Online gameplay that I can't say that the game is worth it right now. If you aren't prepared to spend several hours a day getting better at this game, don't bother or wait until issues such as the ranking system have been fixed because the way ranking is structured now, newbies will be obliterated. The game may look bright and colorful and welcoming but to say that this game is newbie friendly (particularly online) is an absolute misnomer. Like all Early Access Games, proceed with caution on this one. Rivals of Aether has so much potential and I will change this review if it starts to live up to that potential, but right now I can't recommend it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you like platform fighters this really is the game for you. I've only sunken in 36 hours atm and I'm loving every minute. There's a lot of depth for those who are looking for a challenge, but if you just want a great casual experience, update your beta to the workshop version and you have endless content to enjoy with your friends. And downloading it just takes a few clicks. There's a pretty cool story mode, while not a full-fledged 40 hour experience, it's a fun little adventure. Also. there's a tutorial that will teach you every tech you need to know. And while the tech is kinda difficult, but nowhere near Melee levels of precision. It's compatible with any controller you have lying around the house, including Gamecube controllers, and I guarantee you can run this game at full speed no matter how shitty your pc/laptop is. It's 100% worth every penny.

review: This is an amazing platform fighter. The controls are incredibly clean, the movement is snappy, and the character designs are very creative. Veterans of the genre will feel at home, but it also has tutorials for beginners. The single-player modes are mainly just distractions, but they are fun for a bit. The real draw, however, is the multiplayer. It is incredible, and supports both local an online versus. And as the cherry on top, there is workshop support.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Some of the most fun i've had with a fighting game, the movement is very smooth, even if you haven't played many platform fighting games there's an amazing tutorial that explains everything you'd ever want to know in intuitive ways, from every mechanic there is to offer, to character specific tutorials, everything. My main gripes with the game come from the single player perspective, the story mode isn't too interesting and is over before you know it. There's a handful of side modes but mostly time wasters. Nothing is bad here, more then likely just not my cup of tea given what I personally play fighting games for, the VS modes. My fun came from playing against humans, mainly online which is smooth from my time playing. The games balance feels great, I've never felt like i've lost because of my character being bad, but rather I lost because I didn't understand my character or the matchup for my opponents character. Nothing feels impossible if you're willing to learn. This isn't even to mention the workshop support, where there's been simply amazing creations by fans that adds a whole new layer of reasons to come back. This game has been the most pleasant surprises in a long time, and I can't recommend it enough if you just want a fun time with friends/family.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Bloody 3kliksphilip makes fairer AI, and he's an amateur compared to the creators of this.

3.
KLIKS.
PHILIP.

Makes better AI, and he, along with Valve, understands that good AI does not equal good AI, because good AI, unless you're actively looking for a challenge, is not FUN.

The AI in story mode is too damn OP, it's like the creators didn't even test with fresh players and stuck to the same old playtesters, creating battle-hardened players that has no problem fighting against the AI. THIS IS BAD AND STUPID. It makes the game more frustrating for newer, or more casual players if they want to go through the story.


Basically, this game is pretty bad in story mode because the creators didn't bother to test the AI against newer players. 3kliksphilip is an amateur compared to this, yet he understood that and tested his games with different playtesters at different stages.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Fun game, but...

TLDR: If you can't get past the title screen go to the game properties and set it to build 1.0.1, had to figure that out myself cuz none of the developers attempted to help me.

Upon purchasing the game I booted it up, title screen says press menu. None of the buttons on my controller worked. disconnected the controller and restarted the game. none of the keyboard keys worked. went on google. people said press Z. still nothing. Validated my steam files, nothing. Uninstalled then reinstalled the game and same as before, nothing. Went to the official discord to ask for help but no one responded to my problem. Sent a private message to the official twitter account and also got nothing from them. A day later somebody on their discord finally told me to DM one of the developers, which they @'d in the message. I sent a message and guess what, no response for the entire day. After getting frustrated with the lack of support I went and figured it out all on my own. Dunno why the team never bothered to try to help me but at least I got it to work now.
I put it on build 1.0.1 and it started working. switched it back to the workshop beta and it continued to work.
weird and kinda stupid but hey I can at least play the game now.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'm just gonna copy and paste something I wrote up for a post on Reddit:

The game is a really fleshed out platform fighter that draws influences from Melee but puts it's own take on the genre and it has really good community behind it. There are quite a few platform fighter games (Brawlhalla, Brawlout, Slap City are ones that come to mind) but Rivals is arguably the best of the bunch.

The game has a really good competitive scene, showing up at tournaments along side Smash, though obviously without as much attention as Smash. It's also really fun as a causal game though they are some things to learn (no ledge grabbing, only wall jumps)

If you're looking for 1:1 Smash Bros, this isn't it (and you're never gonna get that.) If you want a smash-quese game, this is one of the best.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals is an incredible smooth, well built platform fighter, every character feels unique and fun. On top of that all the workshop material gives Rivals nearly infinite content. It's true that the workshop has a bunch of meme characters, but there's also a surprising amount of incredibly high quality serious characters, some of which almost feel like they aren't mods at all but full fledged rivals that were always part of the game. If you're a fan of Smash Bros, Rivals is 100% worth your time and money. On top of that, the visual style is beautiful, the soundtrack is comprised of 70% bangers, and unlike Smash Bros. the online play isn't a powerpoint presentation

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Fantastic game by dan 4nace and his team of smash fans. The art style flows very well and feels natural, and every character is totally something you wouldn't find from a smash game. The community is also very welcoming and kind.

I made this review in 2016 and I think it still holds up well, although there are some dickheads in the community, it's generally very cool and the game itself has only gotten better since I played in 2016. There's also steam workshop support now so we're MUGEN now I guess. If you like SSBM, absolutely pick this game up. Even if you're like me, and can't play Melee for shit, this game is so good that even if you just enjoy watching games like Melee, it's still worthwhile.

Praise Sunny

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is the best Platform Fighter available on non-nintendo consoles, to the point that i would probably consider dropping Smash from my rotation in favor of it. The only real issue i have against this game is the lack of local tournaments, as I live in the midwestern United States. So much about this game from the mechanics, to the spritework and animations, and sound design is so wonderfully on point, that i place it on par with Smash Bros as far as quality is concerned. Some players may be bothered by the roster, which does not compare well in scale to smash. Others yet might find the story mode lacking. I think these complaints only matter if you want extra entertainment on top of the full suite of entertainment offered by the versus mode. Even better, this game offers content comparable to 40 dollar pricetag games at less than half that. Do yourself a favor and buy this one before the meta is solved (which will probably take a decade or so, but still. No time like the present)

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I'm aware I have very little play time and don't know virtually anything about this game, so I won't leave a bad review. So I will be voicing my opinions as a new player picking up the game. I download the game and it only take 5 minutes. The game looked nice and I heard great things on youtube about it so I tried to pick it up. I new there was a tutorial and it took a little bit to find it. I completed all the tutorials with some difficulty, but I was just starting so who cares? I then have to preform a up light attack, then jump, then sair. I spent 7 minutes trying before I got fed up and quite. This was a game right? Lets get to the playing! So I go to local vs and fight a lvl5 bot. It was close and sloppy but I pulled off a victory. After two more fights I start looking for a real challenger and go to 1v1. after multiple people with high ping leave my lobby I finally get a opponent with good ping. I great them and ask to take it easy on me. They reply with "Let's go!" and the fight was on. for 2 minutes I get juggled from one end to another. I sometimes break through the ass whooping to do a little damage then quickly get thrown off the edge. The lion continuous shoots fire at me and knocking me back off before I can do anything. He taunts copiously then leaves right after the fight. Soon after I asked for a refund. I am well aware I need to "get good" but I have no desire to spend the next few weeks training to become the type of person I despise. I show off who taunts between every juggle, then leaves before I can be criticized. I get enough of that from the absolute radioactive cesspool Brawlhalla offers. I'm know Brawlhalla is different then Aether, just a comparison. This game has a dedicated following and I really don't get it. I'm sure many who play Aether feel the same way about Brawlhalla so who am I to judge? Recommendation? Maybe make the tutorial more practical. Chasing around a orb and dodging when the timer hit zero really didn't help with any of my fights. In fact, I could get the timing down at all when put up with a robot player, let alone a Aether god. Other then that, I don't think I'm qualified for any other recommendations, so I will leave it at that, Good game, not my cup of tea.

review: A very fresh addition to the platform fighter genre with all of the fun characters that casuals want, and all of the technical depth the pros want. With the addition of custom characters through the workshop (which are getting more polished and more distinguished each day), there's a bright future for this game, if new players can get past the huge barriers to entry that are the super technical tutorials and elite online playerbase.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: EPIC

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether...
It is good, but also not as good, and sometimes even bad.

By the time of this review the final omega ultra edition of Rivals is still in development (it's been more than half a year since the last straight update to the main game), so most of the problems will surely be solved in the future. Yes, there is a steam workshop beta out now! And you have to know how to code and make pixel-art to do any sort of custom character.

Gameplay is great. I mean the non-competitive one, with friends and family and the likes. If you go online after completing the story mode and tutorials, you will want your money back. The people there are grinding it; the moves, the techs and DIs, recovery and parries. If you don't have time to grind and train, if you don't have friends of somewhat similar skill level, like with any fighting game, you better not buy RIvals. AI here is also not that good, it just can't compare with the real player, too weak and too unsystematic, but maybe it will see some improvement later in 2020.

Music and Art Style are simply amazing. It is pixel art. Precise, thought-out, pleasing to the eyes and the soul fluid and expressive pixel-art animation. I would give the highest score to Rivals only for that. As a person who wants to become a pixel-artist, this game is a treasure. Ok, enough of nerding around, music here is amazing too, fitting, beautiful, energetic and a bit catchy, Flashy Goodness know their shit.

What deserves the praise more than anything about this game is the continuous (or I would say "unstoppable") support from the developers: balance patches, skins, holiday events, tournaments, both on- and offline. Although, most of the skins are only available through smash.gg, which sucks, and a lot of the coolest looking skins are sold limited time only, so... Nonetheless, I respect Dan Fornace LLC's pixel-artists, both former and current, since I realize how much work has to be put in for each and every skin and buddy.

There are a lot of modes you can play, but not online... While playing online, you can't have: Abyss Mode, Aether variants of Stages (the biggest downside, since it is the most fun factor thing, as I see it), Training. For now, free-for-all and online team-fights are only available at betas, Ranked games and ranking system are going to be revamped, and it is a welcome sign.

Community of Rivals is nice, if you want to improve, simply find the Rivals Dojo Discord server and that's it, go beat CakeAssault already. Daniel, please, let us buy all the skins in the Steam DLC section right here, it would only give you free money and cover more players who wish to support the continuous existence of this game :-)

Characters are all different. There is not much of them (especially if you don't plan to buy 4 separate DLCs), but they are certainly all different and almost flawless mechanically. Balance is nearly perfect, that's for you fighting games gamer guys out there.

I truly want Rivals to have a much bigger player base, but it is too unfriendly to the new players. Maybe, if there's a bunch of them online at once, they all can have fun?

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's not a game for everyone. If you hate games that are similar to others for that reason alone, then don't play this game. If you're willing to accept that, then you might want to try this out. The characters make it fresh and different from what I've seen, each trying to bring something new to the table.

That said, I am aware that I am making a review about a game where random wildlife is thrown into an arena to fight to the death. Amusing!

review:
I originally glossed over this and only really gave it a good look when it announced the workshop for user made characters and stages.

Even without the workshop, Rivals of Aether can and does stand on its own feet as a decently made platform fighter. Of the eight original characters, there can be a huge difference in play styles and mechanics. The graphics and crisp and clear and I find the music utterly amazing too.

The workshop's a bit rough at the time of writing as its rife with bugs and UI's a little spotty in places. But already there's a wide variety of characters and stages, in a wider range of quality.

review: Really fun and fast paced. Compared to SSBU, the window for performing a short-hop is much more generous. The tutorials, especially the advanced offense tutorial, can get very confusing to the point I had to do a quick search to see how I was supposed to do it. The characters you start with are all very unique, not many of them have much of anything in common with each other. I really enjoy playing Orcane, I find it's surprisingly easy to pick up, place a puddle, dash attack, up tilt, and up air are what I use most of the time.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Having very vague memories of my time with SSBM at my daycare, having played SSBB only a handful of times on an emulator that my friend had, and played SSB4 for a half decent amount of time on a friend's Wii U, I can really recommend this game for anyone who has little to no intention of getting a Nintendo console.

As of writing, I have 42 hours played, I main Orcane, and haven't played online (excluding friendlies). Sylvanos and Elliana have just been released and am starting to pick up Elliana out of the two. I am a player who knows what they're doing, but constantly messes up inputs on my own accord. Though the character list may be small in comparison to other platform-fighters, I think it works in the game's favor as they become more memorable. The art is great, the music is sick, and the gameplay is fun as heck, despite me being bad.

TL;DR
-Fun Platform-Fighter
-Appealing and Well Done Aesthetics
-Small, but Memorable Cast
-Play Water Pupper

PS
Make Elliana's steam rapidly disintegrate upon its destruction rather than it just dissapearing in an instant. Thanks Dan, have a nice day.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I decided to remake my review since I have a lot more experince under my belt.


Rivals of Aether is a Smash Bros styled game created by Dan Fornance (who is also the creator of Super Smash Land)


As a big fan of the Smash Bros. series, I love Rivals of Aether and bought it the game Day 1
of its release. Some of you might find it a little harder to get ease into but for someone who's played a lot of Project M, albeit casually, it wasn't too difficult to get into as I felt I was playing in familar territory unlike my expericene with Brawlhalla. 

Don't get me wrong, Brawlhalla is not a bad game, its rather enjoyable and it's free. It just didn't click with me on a personal level. It didn't give me that fluid feel that Rivals gave me (Again, the game is pretty good)


Speaking of familiar territory, while playing the game you might notice that some characters might have similar moves to other characters. Zetterburn is literally PM Wolf, Orcane is Vaporeon from Smash Land, Kragg has moves like Bowser and so on. 

I feel like the characters have enough diffrence to keep them original but enough for Veteran Smash players like myself to fit into. As a Bowser main, I warmed up to Kragg the quickest as he just felt good to play as. Always was a fan of Heavy-weights. 
While the Roster is small, if you're like me, it won't change a thing.


Speaking of familiar territory, most of the Melee/PM and Smash mechanics are here: you've got Dodging, Wavedashing, Dash-Dancing, erm... um... a lot of the other stuff?... Did I mention I play Smash casually?

However, not everything is the same. There is no edge-grabbing or no grabbing and the shield is replaced with a Parry. The Parry works is when your opponent hits you during the parry frames it will protect you and cause an increase of endland for your opponent. Think like 3rd strike but much... slower.

To be honest, The Parry is my least favourite part of ROA. It causes everything to come to a screeching halt before the flurry of attacks begin again. For a game so fast paced, it just feels out of place. 

It don't think they'll be changing it anytime soon though since they've had it from day one, even before the steam release. I just wish it was a bit more quicker like 3rd strike.


As for Online... Well, it's been a while since i've played and the amount of players have declined for the moment so finding a game is a bit hard. Though it might be because I'm Australian. From what I can remember it's pretty ok, it can vary but not nearly as bad as my expericences with For Glory in Sm4sh... oh god the lag was really off-putting.


Anyway. At the moment of the publishing of this, Dan and his team still have a lot more to give us in the future and it looks great.

If you're usually a bit sceptical of Early Access games due to how it can be a quick buck for something unfinished, Don't. We've seen what Dan and his team have given us and what they are capable of. They care about this game and it shows. They won't be trying to run off with your money anytime soon.

If you play a lot of online with these kind of games... erm I'm not sure. I haven't seen a lot but I think you'll still find enjoyment in this title.


I'm hyped for the future of Rivals of Aether and hope it keeps going strong for years to come.

review:
Simply one of the best platform fighters out there, and if you don't trust my opinion then you can't argue with the smooth movement, exceptional balance, unparalleled quality of life features, and active developer support. If you enjoy platform fighters for fun movement, the fulfillment of personal growth, and a varied cast of tournament viable characters, then this is a game for you.

Also, one of the dev team members is a TO for most major Rivals tournaments and the game's creator regularly competes in these events. When is the last time you got to play a game with the game's creator and ask them anything you want? They have done a phenomenal job of creating a great game and a great community, and we love them.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1]In short[/h1]

Like the Melee / PM type of smash but actually kinda redesigned so it's even more combo heavy and has less defensive options, making attacking, stringing moves and zoning even more important compared to these aformentioned games; reminds me of a mix between PM/Melee fastness and Smash 64 comboing, but with its own original things in it as well. If you have a rather aggressive playstyle, it will be fantastic to play. For begginners, it's actually not bad either, and has a tutorial that explains and trains you for advanced stuff like wavedashing and DI. There is a workshop branch that makes custom character, stages and modes possible which leads to cool or goofy stuff (or both!)

[h1]In Details[/h1]

The games controls are similar to smash with a few things removed, like shielding; grabbing; or edgegrabbing. It's usually replaced with another option (parring; jabs that can resist parries; and walljump in freefall that resets up special). A few notable things that may influence how you will like it (if you know Smash technical stuff) are : 
[list]
 [*]Long hitsuns
 [*]landing lag (no need for L-cancel) and plenty of autocancelled moves.
 [*]No airdodge on damage fall and no momentum canceling.
 [*]There is DI and Drifting (taught in the advanced tutorial).
 [*]There is also wavedash and waveland (also taught in the tutorial, thank god for new players).
 [*]Something that might be worth pointing, you can't (AFAIK) flick stick + attack to do heavy (smash) attacks. You must use a dedicated button or the right stick on controller. Thankfully, they are less used than in Smash due to comboing with ligther and air attacks being more present.
[/list]
The physics are on the fast and heavy style, but air combos are still easy, if you know you character. A number of things like jumpsquat duration is universified, so it's easier to learn.

You can feel the polish in every part of this game, wether in gameplay feel, sound design, music and animations. The pixel-art is pretty and smooth, the music is very good, the hits pack a punch.

I can't comment on balance yet as I am a relatively new player who mostly played agaginst bots, who are not really that good. Nothing really surprising.

Note that unlike most other platformer fighters, there is not option for random items, or items at all. This is a less wacky game that might not click with the more casual players, but the tradeoff is a fantastic feeling competitive experience. It can still be played 4-player free-for-all for a little "what the hell is going on" feel.

The characters have some Smash Bros. inspiration, but none of them are copy-pasted, and have plenty of unique moves or attributes.

In the Betas, there is a workshop branch, and the community have made some amazing characters, stages and mods (thanks to the companion system); original creations or stuff brought from other games, some even from Smash Bros. You can honk your oppoennt to death with the untitled goose, add back shield and grabs, play some aetherball (kinda like custom stage soccer/basketball from smash). It's goofy, I like it. Might attract people looking to just wank around.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you're a Smash fan, and especially a Melee fan, this game should be right up your alley. Melee-style gameplay, fast paced, with wavedashing and great combo potential, but with plenty of differences that set the game apart from Melee. When I heard that the game didn't have shield, throws or ledge grabbing I thought this wouldn't work, but boy was I wrong. Parrying is a fantastic replacement for shielding, and it doesn't require ridiculously tight timing, which, added to the lack of L-cancelling (for those who don't know, in Super Smash Bros. Melee you can reduce landing lag from an aerial attack by pressing one of the triggers) and being able to act after an air dodge makes the game more accesible, or maybe I should say "not as daunting as Melee" to beginners/newcomers. 

Tutorials for all levels of skill are pretty damn good, along character-specific tutorials. Character movesets are pretty cool overall. Plenty of moves are taken from Melee and other Smash games, sure, but there are some pretty interesting specials in some characters that you don't really see in Smash. Visually, the character designs are good, but not memorable. There are only 8 characters, but if you feel that's a low number don't worry, more will come in the future. Also, if you want to play with a Gamecube controller, you absolutely can! Full support for them, plus customizable controls, and one of its coolest features: being able to playtest characters ON CHARACTER SELECT SCREEN.

On Early Access it already had a fully implemented online mode, with exhibitions and ranked mode with leaderboards. Being from the region I am (South America) I admit it was tough to find matches with good ping. But playing at 180-190 ping it felt pretty good. Not ideal, but very much playable. With the upcoming full release we get a full ladder reset, alongside the single player modes it was lacking and more stages.

Accompanied by a TOP NOTCH soundtrack, this game is definitely recommendable for fans of Smash/platform fighters, and if you've never played a game like this, it's a good place to start.

UPDATE: This game has Workshop support and Shovel Knight. Play it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Sound cue problems: dodge sound plays even when dodge was interrupted prior to sound beginning. Some characters share the same skill effect noises, making it sound dumb when you fight each other and use different skills with the same noises. (I noticed it in ori v wrastor)

Visual cue problems: many arbitrary rules in this game suffer from a lack of visual cues. Fast-down is one example where there's an arbitrary period you can press down after reaching the apex of your jump that has no visual indication whatsoever. This means you're stuck doing guess-and-check until you get a feel for when it can be done. Lazy design.

Consistency problems: the devs keep changing the game balance because they can't get it right. Why bother mastering this game if the rules (hitboxes, skill reach, etc) are going to change every patch?

Sprite problems: the training room shows off how terribly disjointed the actual damage boxes are from the character sprites. The devs don't routinely update the sprites to reflect all the skill / hit box changes. 

Community problems: they'll make fun of you for not using their old smash-based terminology if you come from a different game and aren't familiar with what they call things.

Online problems: the devs didn't bother setting up servers, so player IPs are exposed to toxic brawlers via p2p connections. Unfortunately the network performance is still awful and often times you'll be paired with players that are so laggy you have to play in slow motion. It feels like slower characters with more punishable moves are stronger online as a result of the slow-down. (That's why there's so many Craggs online if I had to guess?)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
TL:DR 
Amazing smash-like, cheaper and with a great community, many good players willing to help, cool pixel graphics and great music, cool devs.
If you are a fan of smash bros and want a fast and "easier to play" version of melee then give this game a try!


full version:

Rivals of Aether is a great way to get into smash-like games if you don't want to pay so much for the smash bros games.
Its fast paced, has a great community and most of the tech is easy to do but hard to master which gives it a nice learning curve.

At this point, most of the people playing the game are veteran players with a lot of practice in the game, but in my opinion this is not a negative thing since you have so many people who can help you get better!
The people I have met through the Rivals of Aether Europe group are always up for helping anyone with any problem they might have about the game. We also have weekly tournements for people who are interested in testing themselves.
The pixel graphics work really well and the music is really cool. ( + if you don`t like it we have mods ;)

Right now we have the full roster of 14 characters, 8 of which are fully available and 6 of which are DLC, however you are allowed to test all characters before you buy them in the games tutorial mode. There the game teaches you all the mechanics of the game, how to use them and a separate tutorial for each characters abilities.

Over the 3 years from early access to now the game has only grown and gotten better!
I would highly recommend this game both to any fan of the smash series and anyone interested in getting into it. 
Because of the great tutorial and the easily executable mechanics, Rivals of Aether is a great starting point if you have never played a smash game before!

So come join us and enjoy a competitive smash-like with tons of potential ^^

title: Rivals of Aether
review: For me, Rivals of Aether has been by far my favorite platform fighter of all time. It's not just a game I play to fill the lack of Smash on PC. The movement feels superb, the combos are intuitive and fun, and the community has been wonderful throughout the three and a half years I've been a part of it. And then they added Workshop support, and now I spend more time coding new moves and new abilities than I do actually playing. I highly recommend Rivals of Aether to any fans of platform fighters like Super Smash Bros., and I'm sure I'll more than double my hours before I ever stop playing it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like smash bros melee you will probably like this game.  It feel like melee a fast-paced style.  You are able to wavedash, there is no shield or edge so you have to parry and wall tech after a up+b if you want to recover. The tutorial in this game show everything you need to know about this game with specific character combo.

This game have awsome soundtrack with nice neutral stage. The online doesnt feel laggy at all and I rate this game above smash ultimate!

The downside is you have to pay a extra $20 for the full roster for a total of 14 characters but the characters are all unique and special in their own way.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Its a platform fighter that doesn't try hard to be Smash Bros. and that's why it works so well. Strips away some aspects of platform fighters that were introduced by Smash Bros. in favor of a parry-based system that flows really well with the combat. Now with the introduction of workshop characters, buddies, stages, and more, the game's replayability has gone even farther up than it was before. My only major complaint isn't even to do with the game, rather the community. It can feel like wading through shit just to find a handful of decent modded characters, and even then half of them have an art style that doesn't fit in remotely.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like Smash, you'll like this game. It's kinda a no-brainer. All the characters are different from each other and each have their own little piece of originality. For example, Zetterburn can set people on fire. When he does a strong attack towards someone on fire, it's more powerful. Wraster can't strong attack on the ground but can in the air. 

I'd also recommend the DLC too if you really like the game. All of the DLC characters are great.

The game's made even better by the recently added workshop. You can play anyone from Ronald McDonald, Sans, a rat, or Obama. It's pretty cool.

Overall, I'd recommend this game to anyone looking for a cool fighting game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a game similar to Super Smash Brothers, but with far less characters, no items, and yet is still loads of fun. I started playing as Zetterburn, but as I played the game more and more, I found myself gravitating toward Absa and Shovel Knight. After an hour or so of practicing the controls, I gave ranked matches a try and wow, the difficulty curve is there. A lot of players play as a very niche set of characters, specifically Zetterburn and Etalus, but primarily play as Clairen and Sylvanos, both DLC fighters. What I noticed about the game was that Zetterburn, Clairen, and Sylvanos are all extremely powerful with attacks I can best describe as extremely unbalanced. You can tell me to "git gud" all you want, but there's no arguing the size of these hitboxes. In the case of Clairen, the most used fighter online, her attacks stun players, making the tutorial on damage influence absolutely worthless on top of her energy field attack making recovery impossible while making damaging those that try trivial. It's not even a technique that needs practicing like parrying. It's just a standard attack. For Sylvanos, his attacks are massively disjointed and hard to counter. Quite frankly, I'm not a fan of attacks that can reach two Sylvanoses away and sweet spot at the tip. It's not cool. Also, his recovery is absolutely broken. While everyone else has to walljump and use up specials, he just touches a wall and makes it back to the stage. This makes spikes like Shovel Knight's down special less powerful. Then Zetterburn. A lot of his attacks have a sort of flair (Flare?) animation indicating a sweetspot. I feel the placement for this sweetspot is in an unfair position as even things like a dash attack do around 30% of damage and deal knockback like a strong. Additionally, his playstyle relies heavily on projectile spam, similar to Simon and Richter from Smash Ultimate and anyone who's played against them knows how that feels. 

In conclusion, while I like this game, I would not recommend it. I wouldn't recommend it until it receives an update balancing these characters. When that happens, I will gladly revise my review.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: One of the coolest and cleanest platform-fighter games inspired by the legendary Super Smash Bros. Series. Although getting into the competitive scene of this game is definitely a challenge, there is still of ton to be had in the game's single-player experience. I've recently had a lot of fun with the new beta workshop build where people can submit pretty much anything as a playable fighter with enough effort. The workshop beta sort of renders any Super Smash Bros. Flash game obsolete in my opinion. It's a ton of though and like I said there's other things to enjoy besides that too, including the campaign. Okay- I'm done buy it now k thanks

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Fantastic 2D sprite fighting game. Yeah sure people complain that this just "copies Smash Bros" but I think this is a game that's worth giving a shot. Modding the game even makes it loads better. But that's probably because ya know... their mods. Music is amazing, Character Selection Screen music got me pumping, moves are done nicely and controls feel very fledged out and well done. Only criticism I will give is that whenever I edit the rules after I edited them previously and then press start to go to the stage selection menu, the game crashes for some reason. Also after completing a match I for some reason cannot choose P4's character which would have to bring me back to the menu and restart the whole character selection again. But overall, very nice game. I'm glad I had two of my friends show me this and I was very pleased with my purchase.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: At first, it may seem like a clone of Super Smash Bros., but Rivals of Aether changes enough mechanics to carve out its own identity in a world of platform fighters. The roster is small, but each character is designed with an incredible attention to detail, and no two characters feel the same. From a competitive standpoint, Rivals is one of the best balanced games I've seen, with no reliable tier list existing, due to how close in strength every character is. The addition of Steam Workshop characters allows for endless shenanigans, and has expanded the lifespan of Rivals of Aether several times over. I'm incredibly excited to see what this game's future holds, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to fans of platform fighters anywhere.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I've loved this game since I started playing 2 years ago, and I still love it now! Ever get tired of playing Smash Bros.? Play this game! Love Smash Bros. but want something different? This game is right for you! Definitely worth the price, and the DLC characters are amazing! The workshop also has amazing creations that I just can't stop playing! I absolutely love Guadua, Mollo, and even Sans Undertale and Pyukumuku! These are all amazing creations, as well as many others and I can't be happier playing a video game! Thanks Dan Fornace and the wonderful creators on the workshop!

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is not an ordinary Smash Bros. clone, it takes the ambitions and techniques discovered and utilized by pioneering Melee players and fleshes them out to create a different kind of platform fighter experience. Grabs and shields have been swapped out with parries, technically simplifying the formula. However, the characters create another layer of depth into the game play. Each 'Rival' has a special gimmick that makes them bar-none separate from one another. Zetterburn sets people on fire and deals more damage against them when they ARE on fire, Orcane can teleport to puddles that he makes on the stage, and Wrastor's aerials are smash attacks that can be charged. In addition, this game's workshop access has spawned one of the most amazing communities on Steam. Basically, you can create an entire character and play as them in the game. It is absolutely wonderful to play as characters created by the fans, and to see eager game coders, artists, and aspired developers get their feet wet in this already wonderful little game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is mental and balanced at the same time! So fun to play and all the characters have really unique mechanics (Wrastor's ability to use smash attacks in the air, Etalus being able to create ice and use certain attacks with more momentum, Orcane's ability to create water puddles to teleport to etc) and is just overall a very stable and fun game. Never had any issues with the game and also the custom character feature makes the game infinitely playable with constant new characters. Love this game! As a fighting game fan since my childhood with smash brawl I give this game a 9/10!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A Fighting Game that, while inspired by Smash, definitely has it's own identity with every Character being extremely unique.

... Is what would've been RoA's main selling point before the workshop update...

But, now that it's here, this game is so much more! While still retaining the aspects I mentioned above, it now has the potential to have a fan-improved copy of basically every fighting game character you can think of. It isn't even limited to fighting game characters:
ANY Character you can think of, fictional or non-fictional, could soon be made into a custom RoA character, or if you don't wanna rely on others, jut DIY! ...Allthough you'd probably have to be good at animating and coding to do so...

Anyway, even in the short time in which the workshop has been online now, you can already have a 1v1 brawl against Obama as the Annoying Dog from Undertale, while Big Yoshi and Lego Yoda watch the both of you from a distance.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: For those saying "Its just a shittier smash" dont seem to know what Rivals is meant to be. Rivals is supposed to be a high skill fast paced game. Much like Melee, higher skilled players WILL shit on you but that stands true for any skill based game. Im not very good but it has some nice controls. There is a button for "Smash" attacks and another button for tilts. In smash, the A button is used to smash and to tilt so for a shitter like me, i end up with smash attacks 99% of the time. The online however is another story. Ive mostly played against my other shitter friends an have rarely touched the online so far but the few times i did i did roughly 2% my first game. This is a high skill floor and skill ceiling game. If you are good at these games or are just looking to mess around with some friends. HIGH recommendation, if you dont have friends to play it with and are mediocre or lower, just dont touch the online

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who has enjoyed super smash bros.
Yes this game doesn't have a lot of people playing and it is not a very beginner level type game, and it will be difficult to play online because of the community being really good.
But it does have some amazing features like the newest update to the game STEAM WORKSHOP!! (download my character ;) please). But maybe workshop character are not your thing. Well there is an functional online with AN FANTASTIC net code that far surpasses ultimate's net code. Nintendo's official game...

So, I will give this game a 9/10, I chose a 9/10 because it has almost everything that a good platforming fighting game needs like amazing characters, fantastic mechanics and the fact that this game has become a  smash bros mugen. But i did have to knock down a point for being a bit too hard for the new casual gamers to the mix of this type of genre of game and the fact that it is hard to find people online. But these are kind of minor things in my opinion, I have had a blast with this game and I bet so will you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is bar none the best Smash-like that isn't Smash itself [or a Smash fangame, but meh, semantics].

The gameplay is easily some of the most solid i've seen for an indie game, an indie fighter especially, with tight, responsive movement and some of the best midair control I've seen in platform fighter- even a complete novice like me can hit combos half-decently and predict movement relatively well.
Everything feels satisfying to hit, from combos to strong attacks to parries, it's all super satisfying.
The inclusion of a MUCH more indepth tutorial is absolutely amazing as well, though i wasn't able to finish some of the higher end stuff. For those that could though, this makes it an EXCELLENT introduction to some of the deeper mechanics in some of these games [it'll help particularly well in carrying over to Melee, which this game was heavily inspired by].

The creative side is absolutely amazing too, with an excellent soundtrack, and amazing character designs with hands-down some of the best spritework i have ever seen.

A lot of passion and work went into Rivals of Aether, and it really does show.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Why are the menu controls and most of the controls so confusing? instead of using WASD to move and using the arrow keys for directional attacks and "e" or "q" for specials\strong attacks, they have all the bindings in such an awkward placement. In the menus, "enter" works to select game modes but not to go back or select your character???? also why cant you select stuff in the menu with your mouse? why is there so much delay when I go to dash and all the characters feel incredibly heavy to play? I honestly don't know but the wacky controls stopped me from playing this game. I can tell controller-use was the only playstyle in mind when they developed this game because the game tutorial dialog mentions the controller buttons and analog sticks rather than the ones my keyboard is bound to (while displaying the actual key bindings in the bottom left). title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is Smash that advocates offensive play.

The gameplay is fast, thrilling, and precise, with each combo string or move you bust out feeling very good and powerful. There's no shield, instead having it be replaced by a parry that reflects projectiles and stuns your opponent when used with good timing. There are also no grabs (save for some characters with a command grab like Clairen), which makes the focus of the game stay strictly upon combos. The ledge grab has also been replaced with a wall jump, which allows characters to use their recovery move again after the initial jump.. All of these things make Rivals of Aether satisfying to play, not to mention that there's an extraneous amount of tutorials you can go through in order to learn the ins and outs of each character, as well as sharpening up your DI and learning mechanics you may not have known about before.

The music within the game is breathtaking, too. While some tracks are somewhat short, they're all incredibly ear-catching. I find myself getting lost to [i]The Forest Floor[/i] whenever I need to focus, and I can always enjoy [i]Full Steam VENGEANCE!![/i] when I want to be up and about when going around. [i]Sorrow[/i] is a touching tune that can jerk tears from my eyes, and [i]Formless Onslaught[/i] lets me know that I'm in for the fight of my life when I start playing Abyss Mode.

Don't even get me started on the Workshop for this game, either. Whenever I meet up with some of my college friends, we all get together and see who'd win in a fight: Obama, or Squidward? That being said, some of the original characters on the workshop, such as Ash, Guadua, and Mollo, are genuinely exciting and fun to play. It's also neat to see your favorite characters come to life. I quite enjoy playing as Kirby and as Emerl, personally, and I can't wait to see if people'll start doing commissions for custom characters! I'd pay a pretty penny to put someone through the workshop.

This being said, if you love platform fighters and want a good, free-flowing game, pick up Rivals of Aether. It won't be a mistake.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Solid game. Come for the Smash Bros, stay for the 100% custom characters. Import your own images, import your own sound effects, and even code your own moveset. It actually doesn't get more custom than this when it comes to character creation. Big plus.

I'm actually concerned because I hope this doesn't become the next fighting shitpost engine (aka MUGEN), but it's shaping up to have little restrictions in place to PREVENT that from happening. As I mentioned, can import you own images and even code your own characters and frame-data. All you'd have to do is KOs other players in 1 hit with an oversized hitbox, you can see how this level of flexibility is both a blessing and a curse.

From the visual side of things, there is an abundance of amazing pixel/sprite animations covering this game. The only complaint I have with the visuals is the teeny tiny resolution that all the sprites are made from. I truly wish the sprites were about twice the size they are now-- but even like this, the game is undeniably stylish.

If you're a furry, you're liable to feel right at home with this game. if you hate furries with a burning passion, stay away. EVERY character seems to be an animal of some kind.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I adore this game. Comparisons to smash are obvious, but the changes it does make, make all the difference, on top of having characters and mechanics that are generally more inventive. I will say I prefer this to any smash game I have played, but can understand how others disagree. I find it to be  much more inventive with those mechanics, more willing to branch out. And it's a bit of a small thing, but it plays with launch angles more, which really helps characters feel distinct as the same inputs can do very different things, even on normals.
It's gooooooood.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
8/10 I really like this game... BUT

The Good
I like the fighting and how they made most characters balanced, I also liked the story mode even if its a little under whelming due to very little content there but non the less its only really used as a sort of getting used to some of the characters, the DLC is cool adding shovel knight and Ori which is one of my favorite games, the other single player stuff is also fine, the online almost never slows unless my internet starts to act up, and the music is AMAZING.

The Bad
The matchmaking in this game is ok but sometimes feels unfair due to me being put up next to pros who have been playing this game or melee and perfected everything. This next thing annoys me a little but isn't much of a problem which is how much all the DLC costs, now I don't expect a whole lot but I think paying $56 for all the DLC should get you some other things except new some cosmetics and a few new fighters, like maybe adding to the story mode or extra single player stuff but thats just my idea.

The Worst
Now I said that almost all the fighters are balanced which is mostly true except for the most know fighter which is Zetterburn. Now lets dissect his move set, up first is his jabs and ground attacks, all seem ok but noting to bad, his left/right tilt attack is powerful but it makes sense. Next is his air attacks which all seem very generic but are fine, his up air can be annoying but all fine. Now here is where it gets a little unfair, his specials, his neutral special isn't all too bad, it adds the fire defect which makes sense since its very close range, his down special is kinda op with it having a lot of knockback and leaving an area where the fire defect but its not too bad once again, his up special is just fox's/falco's up special from the ssb games which is a very good move but not too bad again. Now his side special this is why all Zetterburn mains almost always win, what it does is shoot a burning projectile that gives the enemy the fire debuff, this doesn't sound bad until you realize that it can be used over and over again, takes no thinking compaired to the other projectiles and, and as said before causes the fire debuff which if you didn't know causes all smash attacks to kill on lower percentages, this wouldn't be a problem if we could shield but we can't and even when we reflect it they already could've shot another one... Oh yeah an his smash attacks aren't much different from the other ones but do more damage with the fire debuff. So in total Zetterburn is a mixture between melee fox's fast moves, ness's annoying projectiles, and ultimate ganadorf heavy smash attacks and weight but buffed because no shields. So in total please nerf a little








Oh yeah and also workshop is pretty cool:)

No shields and no grabs, bitch. Only parry.

The only bad thing is that almost half of the characters are DLCs, with 8 on normal and 6 by DLC, and only 2 of them are guest appearences (Ori and Shovel Knight, both of which I haven't bought yet), but that's all, really.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game started out ok, and I also considered this the true "Indie" Smash Bros. game. But ever since the release of Steam Workshops, this game became nothing more but an attraction to memes and annoying communities created by very annoying players. Because of this, I cannot take this game as seriously as I use to before, even thou it was never my favourite game to begin with. I never liked the game that much, and since the introduction of Steam Workshops, I now begin to hate the game a lot more. Overall, this game is cringy and annoying, which makes sense seeing that the creator of this game is an annoying Smash Bros. fan, and the "Smash Community" is nothing more but a community full of hate, insults and discrimination against casual players as well as certain characters which they see as weak or uninteresting. I love Smash Bros. but the community is one of the worst ones I've seen. I love the series, but I hate the fans. Another side note to add is that the Steam Workshop concept in Rivals of Aether is similar to the Stage Builder concept in Super Smash Bros. Ultimate. Both are full of annoying creations, memes and annoying communities made by the most annoying people of all time. I hated the Stage Builder concept in Smash Bros. Ultimate, and I certainly feel the same for the Steam Workshop concept in this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you wanna play rivals of aether:
Try playing smash 64 competitively, learning that hitstun is a major way of dealing damage.

Besides that, if you live anywhere outside of North America or Europe, you might think, "Hey, the lag might be insane, considering I can barely play smash 4/ultimate.  All matches are always laggy-
No.  Even when matches have 250 ping, they run surprisngly smooth, as if you're couch playing against someone, it is unreal how internet lag barely affects this game.

Having said that, you will encounter a couple of problems, incluiding:
The fact that everyone is better than you, and unless you have much much training, you can't exactly say you had a proper match before, considering you'll get raped nearly every second you're alive
Just that.  If you don't mind getting your ass handed over to anyone you fight online, then this game is for you.

This review was made by a furry faggot

((also devs, sorry for pirating your amazing game, but I bought it later :) ))

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A nostalgia train like no other, it slams together SNES\Genesis\16-bit with the fast pace of Smash Bros Melee. The exception however, is that because RoA is built from the ground up with this intention, it creates a far more consistent gameplay. The customization of controls is extremely in depth, affording players complete analog sensitivity adjustments, button mapping(including my personal fave - assign short hop to a certain button = perfect wave dash every time) amongst several others. The bottom line here is - if you are looking for a PC game that offers the most polished Melee feels, or are just looking for a fast paced 2D platform fighter, Rivals of Aether is by far, the most obvious choice.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I barely started playing platform fighters outside of Smash recently and Rivals is my favorite one. 

TL;DR - If you love Melee I think this game is worth a pickup with dlc, and if you don't play Smash maybe wait until the ultimate edition is released with all the dlc. 

For me personally I like it more than Smash 4, PM, and Brawl for sure. The movement feels so fluid and all characters feel really fluid. It's gameplay changes enough to not feel like a Smash clone but still feeling similar enough where if you love Melee you'll fit right in. Speaking of the characters, I love so many of these guys that I don't really have one definite main, I just really enjoy playing maybe 4 or 5 of them. The pixel art can be so beautiful and the music adds so much to the polish and feel of the game. Definitely worth a pickup for any fighting game fan or Smash fan.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The complete lack of keyboard integration for a PC EXCLUSIVE is appalling. Why put make a PC game that is nigh-impossible to play with a keyboard?
That aside, the gameplay is quite clearly a Super Smash Brothers Melee clone. Good on you if you like that, but I personally never understood the obsession with Melee, and as such, the game as a whole seems rather contrived.
The menus are very counter-intuitive and wonky to figure your way through. The pick-and-ban system for maps seems completely pointless considering the lack of any real difference between the maps; it ends up with you and your friend just spam-clicking any map they can just to get past that pointless system that only seems to waste time.
Speaking of friends, I tried this game with two other friends of mine and we could never figure out how to play all together. It seems the only way to play this game is 1v1. You can't have more than two players in a game, which I find extremely dissapointing.
All in all, I found trying to play this game a very frustrating and unenjoyable experience.
