title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Every negative review I've read is either that the DLC is handled poorly or that the community has too much smash autism.(the latter is a positive as far as I'm concerned)

Let me level with you. This game actually properly captures Melee autism but with no game ignorant tech spam or pinkie jank.

No character can regurgitate a 7 input pattern to insta-win the neutral game, nor can they chuck turnips, spam back air and fish down B's, or bait an infinite grab combo.

Imagine if melee was made so that every character was within a 20% viability range of eachother, and every single one had to engage with the physics system in a meaningful way to perform well. That, and each one had an interesting macro strategy to bait aggressive play.

The only actual problem with this game is that it is slightly too combo heavy. In that hitstun lingers longer than in other games. 

So in melee, if someone performs a sloppy overlong/loose combo, you can just hit A or dodge out of it and punish them.

In this game, that is an impossibility. I don't know their reasoning behind it other than stroking semipro boners, but any competent player upon landing a hit can combo unavoidably to 80% until the opponents increased knockback peels them away from chase long enough to permit them to act again. When struck, you need to wiggle that goddamn control stick and wiggle it well. Anything else is death, and also strokes the opponents ego as they tickle your anus from nothing into the void.

Certain mistakes can be teched out of, and not all moves lead to this situation, sure. But I've played casual and ranked a fair bit, and both me and my opponents opening combos lead to one step from lethal typically. In smash terms, two neutral state wins is a kill, almost always, like clockwork. This is a tad strange, and takes some getting used to. Managing to land the first hit of a jab shouldn't mean 60+% more damage regardless of how good I or the opponent are at predicting left-right waggle. But I digress.

This game is tightly and excellently woven in a unique way that cuts the fat and flaws from other platform fighters.

Despite what I said, and my likely 10000+ hours of melee, I consider this to be the most perfect iteration of the genre I've encountered. 

It's lively enough as of this review that you will always find players to match with, and further, they have an 80% chance of inverting your anus. Which is what you want if you are interested in this type of game. 

The music is good, the art is good, the degeneracy has been expunged, and the melee autist community has been explicitly and effectively pandered to. I consider myself blessed to have experienced this game, and anyone whose fingers twitch with the fever dreams of smash inputs ought to buy it. It is a game engineered to please you, and you owe it to yourself to experience what that particularity of constructed gameplay feels like. 

It's better than a breath of fresh air, that's for people who don't know what they want, and have choked on staleness only to find momentary relief in the obscure or eccentric. This is a game for men who know what goodness is, and would recognize it immediately when they see it. 

It's as if God cut excellence into a shimmering diamond and punched it into your heart, forcing you to recognize its brilliance or die.

Buy it, you coward.

i played this and it amazes me. the characters, the story mode, the stages, the music. 10/10

if you dont own a nintendo console (but if you're on steam i can only assume you do) this is an amazing pseudo "Super Smash Brothers". top it off with a hint of indie charm and a dash of furry animals and you got this game. (not all the fighters are furry. so if you're into that, its cool)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a good game but it has some problems.                                                                                                                                                      


Pros:
- Very good art style 
- Amazing sound track
- Its a good smash like fighting game that does the core mechanics of smash really well
- A lot of game modes and fun features in the game
-Every character is unique

Cons:
- Very difficult for new players
- The tutorial doesn't teach you much
- The players are very sweaty
- The game costs 15 euros and then you have to pay more for the characters
- Small roster with only 8 characters and 6 more you have to pay for
- No one plays ranked or team match so you just have to play casual against all the sweats 
- Characters are not balanced. Some of them are broken (Wrastor and Ranno) and some of them are trash (Elliana and Forsburn)

Conclusion: The devs need to put all the characters for free because the game is expensive enough already.
The devs need to put a system in the game so new players don't get matched against gods.
I would recommend Brawlhalla if you are looking for a smash like game on steam because its free and all 45+ characters are free.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
While in it's current state, Rivals of Aether does not provide a lot of content for casual players. This will mostly like be less of a problem in the final version, with the addition of more players online and different ways to play. If you're looking for a good competitive platform fighting game, though, Rivals of Aether is an excellent choice. It has a somewhat active matchmaking, as well a extremely welcoming and helpful community on Reddit/Discord.

Personally, it's my favorite platform fighter of all time, and if you're looking for something worth getting good at, I have to recommend it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is a solid game, great art style, good sound track, cool story mode, diverse characters with different characteristics, shovel knight, trading cards, cheap at $15, and has a solid community and competitive scene. There are a couple problems, the roster is on the smaller side with only 14 characters, 6 of which are dlc. If you don't buy any dlc for this game, you are limited to only 8 characters. Also, the dedicated community, are very established and are good at the game. If you are new you need to play a lot and often in order to get better, and be very patient, as you will find people destroying you with 0-60 % combos, however, this can happen in ANY fighting game.
Overall solid game, I reccomend

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Fantastic game, it takes similar gameplay format to smash but puts its own unique and aggressive spin on it culminating in a fun, fast paced game with a lot of creativity put in, now while the game is rather inaccessible to new players and borrows a lot of moves from smash, the way they work and are used is often very different, the characters to an extent also borrow from smash but even then the game manages to feel unique, it also has a level of outward simplicity only matched by smash 64 making the game feel a lot cleaner and more polished as a result it also doesn’t suffer from issues melee has either like having to practice wave dashes for ages to get perfect wavedashes done or break your hands trying to learn say fox, so even though new players may struggle to understand its gameplay at the start due to being more geared to the more hardcore members of the pfgc it doesnt at all push people who want casual fun away, each mechanic in the game still allows for people not looking for anything serious to pick it up and play it with friends even if online randoms will often times beat them. Now while I said it borrows moves and whatnot from smash, every character is still rather unique and designed in a way that would never occur in smash. To finish I should mention stage design, spritework and sound design were all very well crafted and designed, it adds atmosphere to the game and adds to the experience ultimately and there is single player content to be had that give it lots of value, I myself have no real nitpicks about the game it’s self yet but I very much do recommend the game

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
An updated review after logging almost 30 hours on this game.

To start, the gameplay is fast paced and fun, and the art and character designs are very good. The story could use a little work but the characters themselves are enjoyable and memorable.

However.

The online is actually terrible. The connection is very bad and lag is almost a constant throughout every match. Ranked is dead and no one ever goes on there, and on casual you're not up for a casual match. Everyone on casual is ridiculously skilled and you will not learn. There isn't a way to get a hang of the game without putting extensive amounts of time into it.

These things could be fixed with a few patches in the future, and I hope to see this game improve because it has so, so much potential.

So buy only If you are veteran smash player of furry/weebo inclination from US. Oh and you will need a controller. 

Dont get me wrong the gameplay is solid but you need more than that for game to be a good experience.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is a good alternative to smash. Art style is very pleasing to look at and the ability to make custom color swaps is a really awesome capability to have. The community is a small depending on where you live but it's very tightly knit and even the best players feel real because of how mundane it is to run into the big names in this game's competitive scene. The community is also very mature and welcoming unlike many other similar games can be *cough* smash bros *cough* the roster is a bit small containing only 14 characters including dlc but that is to be expected from a $15 indie game they can't just pull together hundreds of staff members to make a game with over 70 characters in a year's time and even despite the small roster size it leads to a much more balanced game and much less possibility for cheese due to lack of character knowledge. The game has tutorials to cover everything you need to know to learn the game and even start tutorials for specific characters that detail their specific mechanics. This game also has a story mode and an arcade mode both of which are fun when you need a break from the base game, as well as developer mode access so you can edit how character work to create your own wacky gameplay modifications. Highly reccomended 10/10 game

title: Rivals of Aether
review: First of all, if you're not good at getting used to new, almost alien controls, avoid this game like the plague. If you're good with the controls being hard, this game is for you! Beautiful pixel art and fun, fast paced (when you're not locked in a 10 minute combo by someone better than you) gameplay. Just be warned, 6 of the 14 character and several of the maps being locked behind DLC. If you want the full experience, you will have to pay more than the original game's price in DLC. This was a big turn off for me, but I quickly learned I can barely handle the current characters and maps, let alone the DLC ones. Also, if you hit random when selecting maps, sometimes the game will let you play on premium stages for free, although this does not work for characters (from what I have tested). The music is really good, and they have a custom colour creation tool for every character! Oh yeah, and this game is complicated. *Really* complicated. There are 3 different attack buttons, that all do different thing depending on whether you're running, walking, standing still, holding up, holding down, and then all of *those* do different things if you're in the air. If you dash as you jump you do a small dash without the invincibility frames(I think?), if you dash in the air you can dash in any direction, you can wall jump, dash without moving to parry and stun the opponent of you time it properly, and the list goes on. They have really handy and useful tutorials built in but it's still a hell of a lot to remember. Still, if you're coming from SSB you'll probably be fine with everything I just mentioned. Recommend to people smarter than me, but I still find it fun, even being stupid.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The Rivals of Aether community ain't big, but it's got a lot of heart and passion. Like any fighting game, it's going to take a while until you see good results. When that happens, however, you'll realize that this game can get fast and intense as Super Smash Brothers Melee with a whole new twist on the genre. 

Each character has something unique about them that players can use to push them to the limit. Etalus is a big and slow boi, but with his ice he can zoom around the stage. Shovel Knight doesn't start with much, but as he accumulates treasure he'll buy relics to become a threat on the battlefield. 

Mechanically, Rivals of Aether is a smooth and deep platform fighter that pushes players to the limit. I wouldn't have played for this long if I didn't enjoy it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This is the best Smash Clone that i've ever played... period. This game takes from its source material and pushes a more competitive playstyle. It's fun for everyone but it's even more fun in a competitive playstyle. Long story short i love this game, i even own the Xbox One version aswell. If you love Smash you'll love this, if you love Melee you'll really love this.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
As of writing this, I've been playing this game for 10 hours, tried out a bunch of the different modes (I think most if not all). I had seen stuff about this game in videos every now and then and I was always interested but a bit unsure. After having plaid it, however, I've had the time of my life with it and will probably continue on with it for quite a while. This is a very easy recommendation, a fantastic party game that really is more than just a Smash clone, and plenty of fun on your own too.

PROS:
This game has some beautiful artwork throughout, beautiful music, nice clear usable menus, and slick controls that seem to almost always work as you expect them to. The 8 base characters - all I've used as of writing this - are very distinct in play styles, and it can be a bit difficult to get used to multiple at once, but they are all extremely fun to play with, and are all effective with enough practice. The only one I've had significant difficulty with so far is Absa, and I can easily chalk that up to it just not being something for the way I think and play.

Online play works pretty well, out of around 30 or so casual matches I only had significant problems with lag during a match once. There are some troubles with the online systems I'll get into, though. Most of my cons are about online, so don't mind the fact that the cons section is longer than this one.

Local multiplayer is the best way to play this game. So far I've played with my brother, and while I think this definitely works best with controllers, keyboard controls work well too. That said, the best way to play this has to be with 4 controllers and a bunch of your mates huddled up on the same couch. It'll be endless fun.

CONS:
The ratio of base-game characters to paid DLC characters seems pretty large at 8/6. The roster does feel pretty small generally, and even smaller when half the board is grayed out (I do plan on getting some of the DLC fighters though). This is more of a personal thing, I certainly don't see it as pay-to-win, as none of the Clairens or Oris I fought online seemed too unbalanced or anything. Every character seems to have some one or few thing(s) that seem way overpowered at first but all have reasonable counterplays.

Actually finding an online matchup is extremely difficult. If you want to play online, you best have friends that already play as well, because the random lobbies are pretty harsh. Having tried at (all times in EST) around 8 PM, 12 AM, 3 AM, 10 AM and 1 PM, I haven't come across the right time where people are playing and I'm not waiting for ages for someone to connect. Then, often when someone does connect, they end up disconnecting for whatever reason very soon after. When you get a match, cherish it - no matter how easy your opponent is, or no matter how hard you're getting bodied, just stick with it, because you're gonna have a wait before you can find another player (and you might just end up with the same player again anyway).

I saw a couple of reviews that said basically something along the lines of 'git gud before going online' and I can agree with that testament. I'm not sure, but the reason may have something to do with the fact that it's impossible to get a match on ranked. I tried this at several different times of day as well, and I only got one pairing which promptly disconnected. There are some really good players just playing casual possibly because that's just what's available most of the time.

The stages are all good if none of them are truly great or innovative, at least in Basic mode. My experience with Aether stages, however, is that the stage hazards need some consideration. In a lot of stages the hazards are just way too intrusive and far too decisive in actual gameplay, with some just killing you instantly without any real way to do anything about it (that treetop place).

BUY IF: You're looking for a fun platform fighter that is both a great cheaper PC alternative to Smash, but also its own unique experience with its own quirks and skills associated. This is great if you just want something to kill free time, or if you want a good party game to play with two to four friends on a couch.

AVOID IF: You're looking for a Smash clone - this simply isn't it, it has a lot of inspiration from Smash, but it is a completely different animal playing this game. Also avoid if your intent was just to play online or, in particular, ranked.

There are some things I didn't talk about here but they're kinda just side stuff that isn't really the core of a game like this - Story Mode, for example, is pretty fun and does help to ease the learning curve of the six fighters available in it (Etalus and Absa are not part of this mode); and Abyss Mode still gives me mixed feelings, as it kind of just felt like I was turning my brain off for a lot of it. Overall I think this game at its core is well worth the asking price, and during the summer sale it's an absolute steal for a super entertaining game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
An extremely solid platform fighter built on the competitive basis of Melee. Has a very small cast of fighters, but each has an incredibly unique playstyle to work with, making no two characters feel alike. Most if not all movesets have some way to incorporate working with the environment around them, adding extra mechanics that feel perfect in this subgenre, where environment is a key component in how you play. The game plays incredibly smoothly and has a nice set of gamemodes alongside normal play.

One of the most notable features, though, is a robust set of tutorials rivaled basically only Skullgirls. For a beginner, they're incredibly helpful. Definitely pick this game up if competitive platform fighters interest you.

review: After 60ish hours I feel confident that I can say that this game is awesome and well worth anybody's time who is into platform fighters. There isn't a huge amount of characters in the game but they are all good and play very different from each other. The game feels so smooth to play and the flow of movement options in and out of combat feels real slick. The lack of shield (there is a timed parry mechanic) and lack of grabs make it so every match is constant action. Overall I would say, good game is good and is worth your time if you're willing to put in some time to get good at it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Great Game. Long Time Melee fan here. 
I've been looking for another game similar aside from Melee to invest time into. Somewhat chiller or different experience in the same genre
I played a lot of games, and even mods: 
[list]
    [*]All Smash games (64, melee, brawl, wiiu, ultimate)
    [*]Project M, Legacy, Super Smash Flash 2, Brawlhalla 
[/list]
and yet it was Rivals Of Aether which was my favorite to have in addition to melee.
It's a great game. It's amazing. It's as if they took melee, said the wanted to make a "lite" version of it and while they were at it fixed a lot of bugs and issues.

My [b]only[/b] gripes are that the online could be tweaked to feel better and the minor little glitch. I personally prefer servers and lists, but I can see they wanted to go for a cleaner "It Just Works" kinda feel. very plug n play.
That and I have a bug/glitch where trying to access the CEO Ring skin brings a prompt to their website. if I click yes, the game deletes the executable and requires me to reinstall the game and then reboot my computer. odd, but i can live without that skin. doesn't bother me too much.

review: Amazing mechanics and flexible combos, fast paced gameplay. This game is nearly everything you could want out of a competitive platform fighter, and even playing casually. This game is incredible, and up there as one of my favorites.

review: One of the best 2D platform fighter games that isn't Smash Bros. The soundtrack is amazing and the art style is nice, but the mechanics and the characters are what make this game one of my favorites. Every character has their own gimmick, whether it be controlling the stage, spacing, or rushing; There's not one character that's says "pick this and win," because the roster is just that balanced. The learning curve for any character is extremely steep and the tools that they have create an insanely high skill ceiling. There's only one way to learn, just like in any game: hop in an online match and get your ass kicked a couple times.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
There's only a small handful of games that have a control scheme that feels consistent and intuitive, and Smash invented a genre just to flex on literally every other developer at the time, and with the internet's rise, sharing games and concepts never have been easier.
Rivals of Aether is a love-letter to every competitive Smash player. It takes a classic formula and streamlines the learning curve by adding in-game tutorials and removing any unnecessary depth, leaving a genuinely addicting and easy to pick up game for smash veterans and beginners alike.

If Smash flexed by creating a genre, Rivals of Aether flexed by perfecting it for a fraction of the price.

review: This game is sick. Got this game less than a week ago and I have been having so much fun with it. Would recommend if coming from Super Smash Bros. since it has the same end goal and damage system. What sets it apart from Smash, is the several different characters, each with respective traits that define them. For example, rather than using strong attacks on the ground, a character named Wrastor uses their strong attacks in the air. Also, in Rivals of Aether, some of the actions you could do in Super Smash Bros. are absent such as grabbing and shielding (though in some instances there are command grabs, such as Clairen's neutral special). Overall, I think this is an extremely fun and enjoyable game; and I would definitely recommend it.

review: Overall very fun. It's clearly a platform fighter inspired by Smash Bros, but it does enough to stand out that I can reccomend this if you already own Smash. The fighters are all fun, and while short the story mode is a good time-killer. My two biggest complaints are 1) The DLC, since the lineup is so small it feels cheap to make almost half the characters Paywall, even for a relatively inexpensive indie game, and 2) the online. title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is an absolutely fantastic smash-like fighter, but don't be fooled by its similarities to melee - it's a unique and entertaining experience. Every character is distinct and fun, there is a near-infinite skill ceiling, a passionate community with tournaments, minimal but consistent activity on ranked ladder, and multiple helpful and friendly discord communities to join with. 

Now if you come from smash, you'll have to adjust. DI is different in some ways, ESPECIALLY if you come from ultimate, and the change in how recoveries work is fresh and fun but takes a little getting used to. Once you've got a half hour under your belt though, you should be good to go and able to adjust and have fundamentals carry over. Seriously, get this game!

If you're also looking at DLC characters to try, my personal recommendations are as follows:
Ranno/Clairen - I love swordies, and if you do as well you'll like Clairen. If you don't, Ranno is a lot of fun and has some serious potential. IMO, easy first purchase for DLC
Sylvanos/Elliana - Neither character is the *most* beginner friendly, but they have really unique mechanics and movesets that freshen up the game and allow you to change the pace a bit. Probably not an auto-buy, but it's two unique and fun characters for 5 (2.50 if on sale) so not a bad idea at all
Orio and Sein - If you're an Ori fan, you're probably gonna buy this anyways, but be warned these two can be a lot to handle early on. However, if you're not new to platformer fighting games you may find these guys the combo fiend you've been itching to play. Easy pickup for experienced players, less so for new ones.
Shovel Knight - this one is... weird. Not bad, don't get me wrong, but weird. Like Ori, if you like Shovel Knight as a game you should buy this as well, but if you aren't a fan already I think this is the most skippable DLC pack of the four. Still a really fun character with potential and interesting mechanics and options, but ultimately is one that I would urge you to decide you really like the game before picking it up over either of the packs with two characters in it.

tl;dr buy this game and ranno/clairen and play, it's smash bros but fresh and fun

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I've been playing since day 1 of Early Access and was watching the game even before then. I played Super Smash Bros. Melee in my local scene for a couple years before I picked this game up and I fell in love as soon as I saw this game for the first time. 

I definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes playing Super Smash Bros or similar platform fighters. It's a very fast-paced game with lots of depth to the gameplay (such as wavedashing, wavelanding, auto cancels, directional influence, etc.), unique character designs, a wide variety of competitive stages, cool pixel graphic design, and a lot of cool features. Not to mention a very nice, welcoming community/playerbase with lots of local and online tournaments.

This was built up for competitive players with the best tutorials in any smash clone I've seen, play testing in the character select screen and a community that is more than willing to hone your skills if you're willing to lose and try again. I'm not saying to drop your favorite platform fighter to play Rivals, but if you give Dan and the team a real chance you'll find a game that is a more aggressive yet balanced answer to today's Smash.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Amongst its competitors for a PC Title of Super Smash Brothers: Lethal League, Brawlhalla, Gang Beasts and others, Rivals of Aether is the title I have spent the most time and for good reasons.

The soundtrack is INCREDIBLE. If you've ever touched a Super Nintendo you'll instantly be reminded of it. By God it is only comparable to Lethal League in its quality.

Gameplay is FANTASTIC. It's everything you'd expect from Super Smash Brothers except for some minute differences, which, I'd challenge you, are better than Brawlhalla and you're going to have a whale of a time with it if you give it a chance.

Multiplayer is DECE. It's a local multiplayer game. Regrettable that we as PC Master Race denizens cannot overcome networking for online multiplayer. However, in a title as cheap as what Dan Formace is offering, alas we shall look forward to the future.

PLAY THIS GAME. ALL THE CHARACTERS ARE UNIQUE. AND AWESOME.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether on the surface it looks like another platform fighter inspired by smash bros because they want to show there love for the game when you play the story mode and survival mode, but once you go online it's a giant boulder of a skill gap between you and the players that are high ranking people who played for years. If you think that playing casual will be fun then stick to the story and the  survival, but if you wanna be someone who can survive the people who play this game like it's smash bros melee then you have found the game for you. I really love the characters and there move sets, it's a fresh breath of air to see characters that re not copy and pastes in the game. (unless your talking about the star fox hybrid mettaburn) I think my only problem is that there is too big of a skill gap for those who want to just enjoy the game and fight people online, I know people are gonna say stuff like "oh this game was meant to play like the hardcore side of melee so get good noob" but there are those who love to just have fun with a game and it's hard for people new to the platform fighter games to play this when the high skills beat you into the ground and take your money in bet matches. So here is what I say unless your gonna play this game and become a hardcore player like the rest of the community.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's alright.

Maps are pretty cookie-cutter and most of the roster rips pieces from Smash Bros. fighters, but it's still fun.

Additions to the game take a while and cost too much for what they're worth (like some DLC are literally $25 plushies just for a taunt buddy like wtf)

Their original fighters are pretty boring to look at but they got Ori and Shovel Knight to compensate for that (even though Ori's menu sprites are ugly af).

Some characters have unique gimmicks, like Wrastor can only use his strong attacks in air, and Ori becomes more powerful the closer he is to Sein. This creates a more unique identity for the game, and makes mastering certain characters more individualized.

You can also personalize the game by easily replacing music in the files with your own, given that you can make OGG files. You can also find a mod installer that lets you rip and replace sprites in the game (I've only been playing again because I replaced Ori's bad sprites with good ones).

Anyway, it's ok. I think what it needs the most is better maps: they're all laid out really similarly and their gimmicks kinda suck. Everyone says the game needs more fighters, but that's neglecting the fact that Smash 64 had just 12 fighters and is just as fun as its later installments. Make the maps bigger and more interesting.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
TL;DR. If you like fighting games get it. If you like plat fighters you should already have it. 9.5/10

Where to even begin, This is the game that has taken over my life more than any other. 
It is highly competitive so tutorials are a must. Good thing they are incredibly well done and are updated throughout patches. Do not assume another player is as easy as a level 9 opponent. If you find yourself losing often online try redoing tutorials for your character, and also see how others use the tools that character has. Do not forget the wall jump as this game has no ledge, and be aware that aerials are much easier to punish do to the parry instead of the shield of smash. If all this fails then pick up Kragg. I wish I was joking. 

Awesome characters / Great Balance / Various Modes / Custom Colors / Insane amount of Controller Support / Great Music
A must have for the competitive Platform Fighter.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game has no business being as successful as it is, considering it's stepping into the ring with one of the most popular series in the history of games with Smash, but it's awesome to see it carve out a niche.  The game looks and sounds great and it plays even better.  It's such a fun interpretation in the genre with a lot of fresh ideas and character design that packs a huge amount of depth.

It takes a lot of queues from a game like Melee, but is also remarkably different in how it approaches concepts like defensive play or directional influence.  It's an great game from top to bottom and absolutely the best non-smash platform fighter available.  Well done, Dan and team!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Coming from Smash Bros. Melee, I have to say:
1. I love SSBM
2. I love RoA just as much, if not a little more
3. What makes RoA shine, is the fact that it maintains almost all of the iconic and game-shaping "mechanics" of SSBM, and refines them. What I mean by that, is that the most important things in SSBM, like wavesdahes, techs, float cancels, turnarounds, DI, are essentially glitches/bugs that can be abused. The best example of this is the wavedash, which is not necessarily a glitch, but rather an unintended mechanic of SSBM. As it is unintended, it is super inconsistent and completely unrefined, making it unnecessarily difficult to consistently pull of perfect wave dashes. RoA maintains this (incredibly fun) unintentional mechanic, and instead turns it into an ACTUAL game-mechanic. Because of this, it's much easier to consistently do, never fails you because your input was pixel perfect, or just straight up messes with your head.

RoA is like taking all that makes competitive SSBM so inaccessible and changes it around into an accesible, beautifully pixelated, awesomely composed and well-designed masterpiece. If you like SSBM, I don't see why you wouldn't love this game. 10/10 I am in love with it tbh.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I friggin' love platform fighters. And I love the Smash Bros. series. But this game is really special to me, for some reason.

It's difficult to explain, but most platform fighters don't always respond to my inputs the way I expect them to, and I'm forced to adapt and evolve in ways I wouldn't have to otherwise if the game initially responded the way I expected. This is the only platform fighter that fully responds the way I want it to, 100% of the time. I try to do something, and if I'm capable of it, it happens. I try to make a certain combo happen, and if I'm capable of it, it happens. There are no ands, ifs, or buts; the game just does what you want, and doesn't restrict you in arbitrary ways. It just feels amazing to play. And if you need a rundown on gameplay mechanics, the ingame tutorials do a great job teaching you.

And it doesn't hurt that the graphics and sound are beautifully done, too. With amazing pixel art and a jaw-dropping, mind-blowing, awesome and catchy as hell soundtrack, there's not much in this package to complain about.. The online is a bit hit or miss, but for the most part, it works as intended and it's due for an update in the future. In fact, multiple things are due for an update in the future. The developers are constantly updating this game to make it better. 
For more info, check out:
https://www.rivalsofaether.com
https://medium.com/@fornace/rivals-of-aether-2018-developer-recap-2019-developer-preview-92850686d8dc

Give this one a chance. I know that platform fighters outside of the Smash Bros. series have had a bad reputation in terms of quality, but this one is something else. Something well crafted and thought out. Unique and fun.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Another unnecessarily difficult and clunky melee/64 clone designed to emulate the worst features of both games. There's no balance, no logic to the priority of attacks vs other attacks, nothing intuitive at all, and there is WAY too much hitstun. Everything is either hard on purpose, or so ""deep"" that it's convoluted and not fun to play. People have said you just need to master every character to be good at the game, but honestly who has that kind of time? Good design is a character you can just pick up and play, and there are none of those in this game. I'm not sure how anyone could enjoy a game where you're in hitstun 50% of the time, completely unable to perform any action whatsoever. And worst of all, it takes so long just to figure out how to play, that by the time you play against a real person it's too late to return it. Absolute waste of money

Simply take a look at the top players and you will see that they're sad & depressing losers who don't know how to take care of their physical appaerances, similarly to the top players in Smash 4 and Ultimate. (It is likely they smell equally as bad as their smash contemporaries)

They and their asskissers will refuse to rematch or play casual matches with you on the basis of their superiority and delusionally believe this game will ever be taken seriously competetively (at least to a wide audience). As consequence if you're a new player you will not have any fun online; unless you're the type that will willingly subject themself to "online" tournaments simply to have the privelege of playing with people who only practice amongst their own kind. 

The official discord, "academy" discord and all the individual character discords are trash & will hardly benefit you in any way; insignificantly if at all. And you will not find good players in them who will be willing to play with you despite they having you added on their friend list & being currently in-game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A very well made Smash-esque game that really seems like a great alternative for fans of Melee. I've never played Melee myself, but many did say it does give that Melee feel.

---

[b]Upsides[/b]

+[u]Very unique roster of characters[/u]
Although some moves may appear similar to the original moves in characters of Smash, they always keep a separate mechanic or certain move set that makes them really stand out from the rest. 
Unlike in Smash were you usually got your guy with sword, heavy-weight guy, speedy combo guy, small/light guy, projectile guy, all-around guy, or slow brute guy, there really is no such way you can categorize a set of characters aside from their type of region. They all got their own separate moves and mechanics. Even the DLC characters appear to keep a good separate feel when playing them.

+[u]Great retro soundtrack[/u]
Always feel adventuring and keeps you at the edge of battle. Also may get you into humming, whistling or singing along while you're at it.

+[u]Balanced and unique stages[/u]
I think they did a pretty good job with this one. If you want casual play and enjoy hazards, obstacles, and sudden movements in stages, then play the stages in Aether mode, but if you want a good competitive play and no hazards, you can play the basic mode in stages. The best part about these stages is that they're all unique even if you're playing competitively without hazards. The stages will feel just as unique and balanced no matter what mode you put it on.
Unlike with Smash, where almost everyone likes to play the same old Form/Final Destination stages, Battlefield stages, or Animal Crossing stages which usually feels the same. Mostly just because it's how "the championship plays it" with no "banned" stages. Which really ruins the uniqueness that each stage carries. 
There's also given info about the Stages' and fall hazard sizes if you want a stage that suits your sense of fun.

+[u]Staying in with the Smash lingo[/u]
This one might be a weird one, but it is great for the people that's been with competitive Smash players. The game does call such types of moves for what they are, the tilts, the specials, the aerials, and other such. There's even such things like money match requests in some online games. (For those who don't know a money match is when someone starts betting cash on a single match or best of 3. That's right, some kids, teens and young adults will attempt to gamble with this game) But instead of actual money, you are bidding in-game currency so it is all safe. 
For newcomers of Smash, the game is happy to explain the lingo.

+[u]Tutorials[/u]
Now this is great for the new beginners. Especially for people that had never experienced Smash themselves.
Not only does it tell the basics like tilts, specials, and strong attacks, as well as a few combos, but it also give tutorials on each individual character. This is a huge benefit for trying to find a main, or learning what a character is capable of in certain situations. For example, I didn't know Maypul could tether a marked opponent by holding her UpSpecial or that Wrastor's strong attacks can only work in the air. Not without seeing their tutorials that is.
Also this is something that not just Smash, but all fighting games should actually have. A tutorial mainly based on the individual character. It is much easier and better for someone to learn a bit more about the character they play rather than just throw 'em into battle with nothing but a move/combo list and/or [i]a few bits of info at a 3-5 second loading screen.[/i] *ahem* [i]Smash...[/i]
While some may like the discovery of finding the different movesets or different benefits a move can have, I think it's better for the discovery of the combos one can learn in their movesets.

+[u]Good and easily adjustable controls[/u]
The controls are very similar to Wii pro controllers, but only with an added [i]smash[/i] button. That way you can easily separate a strong attack from a tilt attack. You can also adjust flicking up to jump or flicking the joystick for strong attacks as they are options you can switch on or off.
Joystick sensitivity is also adjustable as well as the joystick flicks which is a huge benefit for trying to separate a strong attack from a tilt, an UpTilt from a jump, or a walk to a run. Overall the controls are easy to adjust and easy to get used to.

+[u]Story[/u]
Now this is a [b]HUGE[/b] thing for me. Especially in appealing characters like these. An actual story mode for these array of characters. A story that actually gives the emphasis and interactions between each character in the roster. Smash does seem to do this but recently hadn't done a very good job of it and tend to struggle at it. World of Light does less character interaction, relations, and emphasis and rather just throw them all into a shocking situation and straight into a sudden environment. That's about it. No emphasis on the characters, why they're there, and how they came together. In fact we don't get much interaction with the characters after saving them. Just one big baddie, everyone's together and that's it. That's already 90% of actual story you'll get from there
Also, Smash isn't the only one guilty for this.



[b]Downsides[/b]

-[u]Unbalanced DLC pricing[/u]
Now I find the DLC to be excellent and reasonable, but what isn't reasonable is the prices for the DLC. For each character it's about $6 and that is more reasonable when it's only the DLCs with 2 characters in one. When I'm buying a single third-party DLC character why would I buy it at the same price of two DLC characters?
The DLC skins/recolors are also ridiculous in their pricing. For something as small as getting a recolor, why would I spend about $4-$2 for something as simple as a pixelized recolor/skin? For something as little as that, the prices should be no more greater than $1.

-[u]DLC characters have no Story Mode[/u]
Now this one might be a minor complaint and I know that they've already given some story within' their reveal trailers, but I would still like it a lot more if they allowed us to take part of it and be the ones to continue it. Even the Third-party guests if they can.
After all they've given them their own individual tutorial, their own stage, why not give them their part of the story too? 

-[u]No Free-For-All online matches[/u]
This one might be a minor one as well. Now I know we got 1 on 1 and team battles which most do play, but really? No classic online Free-For-All? I would at least appreciate it if friend battles would at least add this gamemode.  



[b]Mid-sides[/b]
(this can be interpreted both up and down sides, depending on what preferences is to your liking)

=[u]No shield/grabs[/u]
Now this can be both good and bad. Bad due to the fact there's no blocking, but then again good by the fact that they've added their own original mechanic when playing defensively.
Instead of any blocks, there are now parries. Which is kinda like a well-timed block that allows you to stun an opponent and be able to quickly strike another hit. However, this doesn't work all the time since it's all in the timing. Personally I really love this separate mechanic because it encourages every player to move around in combat instead of just standing there, waiting to block and counter almost every attack.
It's still got its rolls and airdodges, and again I like the way it is encouraging others to move around instead of standing in one place.

=[u]DLC[/u]
I know I've stated about the prices, but now it's time for the DLC itself. I'm fine with it having DLC. After all it is just a $15 game and not a $60 game with another $60 worth of DLC or more. Plus if you add up the DLC with the game's price so far, it should add up to about the average price of a new game.
But yes, there's DLC. So don't expect spending just the game's price if you want to check out other mechanics and characters.

---

For me I'd definitely recommend this game to my friends and other people.

title: Rivals of Aether

Inspired by the Super Smash Bros. series, Rivals of Aether is a unique take on the platform fighting genre. In Rivals of Aether, each character has unique properties that brilliantly distinguish themselves from each other while maintaining fast and aggressive gameplay. The tutorials are executed perfectly, giving both casual and competitive players the same basic mechanics to work with. This game is straight up fun no matter the player, and I respect the gorgeous pixel art.

I absolutely recommend this game for anyone fond of fighting games.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
RoA is a great game. This is probably one of 2 games that can literally replace Smash as your platform fighter of choice. It has great characters, good adventure mode, ranked, in-game tutorials, great stages, advanced melee mechanics, tight and in-depth gameplay.
This game is pretty good, I definitely do have fun whenever I play this game.

But I can't recommend this game.
Why? You may be asking if I have great things to say about the game. I'm not denying anything good I have said. 1 thing. Well 2 technically, but 1 major thing prevents me from recommendation. 

I'm getting it out of the way now but my first one is relatively small:
No Grabs and no shields. This really only bothers only me specifically but I feel like I should mention in case it would help in deciding in your purchase. Since there is no shield or grabbing, there is parrying and dodging only. Parrying is like a spot-dodge and a perfect shield. If someone hits you, they get stunned depending how damaging it was, allowing for some really sick reads. Its a great mechanic, but I just do not like it. Yeah I know git gud, its great, yadda yadda. It is a great mechanic I know it is.
But I don't like this mechanic, and that's it. It sounds weird I know, but its just one of those things we come across that we will just not like. It's like when you meet another person and they're really cool and what not, but you just can't seem to like them.

Now for the real main issue here.
DLC.
Not just any DLC here. Character DLC. 
This is a massive issue with fighting games, not just RoA. 
I hate character DLC. Why? Its rarely ever done right. Take a look at Ultra Street Fighter 4. That is the best way to add characters. "But Krayken! How will this company earn money? They need to feed families and whatnot" A relatively obvious way of doing this is selling skins. Don't tell me skins do not sell because this is a way brawlhalla makes their money. This is how Fortnite makes their money. This is how League makes some of their money.  DLC skins are the best way DLC should be sold. "Well its only 5 bucks!" So what? The price doesn't matter if the skin is well made and is a reasonable price then it will sell. Yes some will get more skin treatment than others because it will make them more money, but skins aren't required in the first place. "Well smash has DLC characters individually" That is true, but here's the thing. Compare the amount of characters in smash ultimate without DLC to the amount of characters without DLC in RoA. 8 characters in RoA, 76 Fighters in the base game if we count echo fighters as part of that, otherwise 69. At the time of this review, Piranha Plant and joker are the only 2 DLC characters we have right now. 6 DLC fighter in RoA thats nearly half the roster!!! I very much do not like this form of DLC. 

It is for this major reason that I cannot recommend this game. DLC characters are not meant to abuse your wallet, they should be instead used for skins or when you have plenty of character content to back up and justify the creation of character DLC.

As a side note if you're still reading I hear they're in works of a definitive edition for this game with character bundled in apparently, this is what you should spend you money on. Not the character DLC. Save your money for the upgraded edition.

Super Smash Bros Melee inspired, and a decent attempt at recreating some of the cool and interesting aspects of Melee as a fighting game. The game keeps the fast aerial combos, wavelanding, but removes some of the better aspects of melee such as the shield mechanic,  (although it is replaced with a tech similar to what Ultimate has, parrying), and the ledge. When you get good at the game, you can feel it, very fast combos, a lot of very interesting movesets. 
8/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
(I'm gonna be editing this review because I really wanna give this game a chance)
Rivals of Aether really needs to fix the servers. Why are the servers so bad? If I were to play Brawlhalla (bad game), I wouldn't lag nearly as hard. I have 100Mbps+ download speed yet my ping is practically 300 every game. The sad thing is that the bad players will have bad connection while the people that sweat on casual have good connection. The matchmaking on casual is also a problem. As I said, the sweaters have good connection so the moment I see less than 100 on ping, I'm expecting to get destroyed. Why can't they fix the matchmaking? It's so bad. The final problem is that some characters are just plain better than others. Zetterburn has stupid dumb strongs that easily kill that low percentages (70 min) just by spamming side special and Clairen basically has enough range to abuse most of the roster. So annoying.

I love the design, lore, story mode, pretty much everything about this game apart from online, which is a vast majority of playing time because of other people's trash connection and terrible matchmaking. You can say I get good but won't against fucking diamonds will it? Still better than Brawlhalla but I have to leave negative for now until I feel like they improve online and I can have a better experience.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I've played quite a few of Super Smash Bros. clones such as Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Smash Up (Yes I'm aware that Game Arts made both SSBB and TMNT:SU), PlayStation All-Stars Battle Royale, and Brawlout. None of which captured the same charm and what made the SSB series an awesome franchise. But there's one game that is an indie answer and what makes Super Smash Bros. an awesome series, and that is Rivals of Aether. The game is by far the best SSB clone ever made. It controls, plays, and feels a lot like SSB. The sprite graphics are absolutely fantastic, this game has an amazing soundtrack (I swear to god that there's themes in this game that would fit in games like Mega Man, Chrono Trigger, Final Fantasy, Duck Tales, Kirby (Especially Kirby Air Ride), Hyperzone, etc, and has characters that have their own variety of moves and no clone bs. I highly recommend this game on so many levels, so much that I wish it came out on more platforms such as the PS4 and Nintendo Switch, because this game deserves it. :D

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I want to say I LOVE fighting games... I work really hard at them and this one is a MUST HAVE for me. This game is up there with SSB (Super Smash Bros) because there are so many combos to learn to help you build your own play style which is so cool to think about. I have to think like my opponent to try and figure out their next move and for me it was crazy getting into it but now I can't get out of it (it's so fun). Fighting my friends is crazy fun because we talk trash to each other and then find a way to duel it out. I recommend this game if you want a FIGHT and establish your own style to help you beat that ONE friend that always wins at SSB.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
For better or worse, its not melee.
Rivals took the idea of melee, and brought it to the modern day. Rivals is a unique game with constant development, active balancing from a dev team that listens to the community, and a thriving competitive scene. There is almost always someone in your skill range online, and trying to push story mode times on the leaderboards can be a fun, although extremely frustrating, challenge.
This game is a competitive fighting game at heart. If you are looking for something calming or have a predisposition to controller throwing, you might want to look elsewhere.
All in all amazing game for the right audience; it's not for everyone, but if platform fighters are your type of game, you'll love it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you like super smash brothers and don’t really know much about this game, just think of it as a combination of melee and smash 4 with pixel graphics. I really enjoy it since it’s not as technical as melee, but still really past paced. And if your worried about it just being a cheap knock off of smash brothers don’t be. The game is really well developed, constantly getting new patches, and each character is very unique with there own individual gimmick.  The only downside I see is the smaller character cast, but I personally see that as an opportunity to achieve mastery with all the characters easier.  So if you enjoy super smash brothers but still want to try something new, this is the game for you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The game is fun, the characters are pretty well balanced. If you play online, you will see pretty much any character being used by some players to ultimately play super quickly in order to destroy their opponents.

You get used to the fact that there is no grabbing characters or ledges. Multiplayer online is sadly limited to just 1 v 1's or I have heard 2v2's. 

I believe the game could be improved though by adding a free for all online mode where more than just two friends can fight against each other, similar to Smash Bros or Slap City. Other than that, the game is definitely something I would recommend.

Update:
Adding more of a story and more maps would also be a bonus for this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Coming from a long time fan of the Smash Bros series, I genuinely have more fun playing Rivals than some of the actual Smash games. The gameplay is fluid, the inputs feel incredibly responsive, and every character has their own personal charm. That's not even mentioning the clean graphics and UI alongside an absolutely incredible soundtrack. Loading times are also near-instant which makes it easy to find yourself playing game after game without wanting to stop. Overall this is by far one of my favorite purchases I've made on here and I shall support this game until the day I die. If you are a fan of Smash Bros or fighting games in general, please give Rivals a chance if you haven't already. I can't recommend it enough!

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Ive had alot of fun with this game! The graphics and feel of the game are superb. Every playable character feels very polished in its own way and very balanced. Though, having said that, the game doesn't allow you to play your PAID DLC characters in all of the other solo modes available. If someone pays for a character, I believe it is fair to allow that person to experience the whole of a character in all of the available modes. Hoping to see some online free-for-all type modes in the near future. I’m sure many people miss the feeling of playing against all of their friends online at once. Overall, decent game that need some more work on the content available for the steep price.  7/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Easily the best Smash Bros-like game not made by Nintendo. The combat feels smooth and fun. Characters control pretty well with a gamepad.

I only have 2 (minor) gripes with it:

1) You have to press a face button to jump, instead of just hitting "up" on the gamepad. There's an option to change this in the settings, but for some reason it keeps forgetting that I changed the setting on the next time I run the game. It's not saving the new setting for some reason.

2) No mod support?? Please please add Steam Workshop and mod support. I guarantee this game would have a MUCH larger playerbase if people could create their own stages and fighters, and easily download new ones from the Steam workshop. I know the developer probably doesn't want to do this because then they won't be able to sell new ones as DLC. But with mod support, the base game would instantly have a ton more value, which would convince many more people to buy it. I'll tell you right now though, I ain't buying any of those DLC characters. But if the game got mod support, I'd convince everyone on my friend list to buy the game.

Despite these two issues, I still recommend this game. It's the closest thing you'll find to Smash Bros on Steam!

review:
A lot of people say that this is like smash bros for pc, or this is like smash bros but less characters or whatever. a lot of smash bros players are just coming to this game because they need something fresh or different, and if you ask them what they like more they would pick smash bros. not me. I played smash bros my whole life and this game makes me hate it. this is not some downgraded smash bros, this is better then smash bros. 

The story mode is like 20 minutes long and no replayablity.
The 4 player is pretty bad
There is no four player online.
this game is only good for competitive 1v1s

Comparing to smah bros 

Pros
-no ledge grabbing
-no shield
-every caracter can parry(counter)
-better characters
-better maps
-better combos
-tutorials that teach you everything
-easier to read
-better balanced

Cons
-price and dlc price
-Graphics
-roster size
-less casual modes
-less players
-small maps only

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a really fun game but there is many bad things about it. Each of the characters in the game is very unique and uses different options to approach and have different optional goals to do, which if they complete get rewarded with new options/kill setups. The downside of this is the small roster. Another thing about this game is that most people NEED a controller to play well or to even have fun in the game although this can easily be solved by simply finding a random gamecube, xbox, or even ps4 controller.  Even with a controller this game is not incredibly easy to play and it had a very steep learning curve with no real OP character for lesser skilled players to play. The story mode in this game is lacking but at least it's there. All in all I do recommend this game as it is very enjoyable to play with by yourself or with friends.

P.S: Anyone have a free code for shine zetterburn that I can have :)

Pros:

Unique and Fun characters
More Legal Stages than Ultimate
Shovel Knight and Ori

Cons
14 Characters
Very Few defensive options

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game plays absolutely fantastic. I honestly like its gameplay a lot more than Smash proper, since the comparison is inevitable. It feels a lot tighter than Smash ever has and all characters feel good and unique to play as. It's fast paced and honestly addictive once you get into it. Parries (which replace shielding) are a fantastic mechanic. It just plays really fucking fantastic. I'm too sleep deprived to put that any other way. I played it one day for like 4-5 hours in a session with my sister because we both were just fucking hooked to it, and the vast majority of those matches were using the same characters for both of us. I think that tells how damn good it plays.

It also embraces the competitive Smash mechanics, giving the game extra depth, but it also embraces the silly gimmicky side of Smash with its Aether stages, though there's also Basic stages for the more competitive-minded (or the not-getting-fucked-by-troupple-king-minded, when Troupple Pond comes up). Bonus points for the basic stages not just being Final Destination/Battlefield, they all remain unique just without hazards or gimmicks. 

The game also has great graphics, with lovely colorful spritework with really good animations, nice UI. The music is also fantastic and the sound effects are great.

So the flaws? This game's one flaw is probably its lack of content. The base game only has 8 characters. Granted, they're all quite unique and fun to play as. There's also only 14 stages, I believe, though each with their Aether and Basic variations (though a couple few are identical in both Aether and Basic, but I think it's only 2 like that). A few of the stages have to be unlocked, too.

As for modes, there isn't much either. You have your local versus, a story mode, abyss mode and online modes (ranked/casual/friend). Oh and a fairly meaty tutorial too, in which you can learn even character-specific things or try out the DLC characters before buying them, so that's pretty good. Story mode might sound meaty but it takes like half an hour to complete.

In story, you pick one of 6 of the base characters and fight a series of 5 matches with cutscenes telling a story in between. The matches sometimes are completely random and nothing to do with what the story is, either. Then lastly there's an epilogue which is some cutscenes and one boss fight. Then you unlock Abyss mode, which is a fun survival-ish kind of mode with some RPG elements, but sadly you can't use the DLC characters in it (yet) so I haven't touched it much since I main a DLC character.

Now, the DLC. The DLC is in my opinion quite fantastic, but I bought it all at half price. Gotta say, though, the characters are definitely worth it at half price, at least, though I dunno if I would personally pay full price for them. They're all incredibly fun, I personally enjoy them more than the base game characters. As Shovel Knight fan, I ended up maining him, too. Of course, whether you like the characters or not is a more personal thing, but I think they're all fantastic unique additions to the roster.

The DLC in total adds another 6 characters, 2 of which are from other indie games (Ori and Shovel Knight), along with another 6 stages again with 2 of those stages being from Ori & The Blind Forest and Shovel Knight. Also the Aether version of the Shovel Knight stage is fucking garbage because the hazard is incredibly harassing so you can't properly fight in it, but the Basic version is great at least. 

So with DLC, you have 12 characters and 20 stages, though I think the DLC stages can be played online even if you don't buy them. At 5 bucks per pack, it's a total of 20 bucks of DLC and 15 for the base game. I got it all (game + character DLC packs) for a total of about $14 on sale. So if the game's lack of content bothers you, wait on a sale. Though you could just try out characters in the tutorial and only get the packs you want, also.

I've barely touched the online modes yet, because my internet is only good enough really late. When I did, though, it was really good, using delay-based netcode. Though the player I fought against was an absolute scrublord and disconnected during the 2nd round of our matches, sadly, then I couldn't find any more matches. Most of my play time has been local multiplayer.

So anyway, this has gone on longer than I wanted to, and I feel it sounds more negative than positive, but I gotta say once again that the game plays absolutely fucking fantastic and is the most fun I've had with a platform fighter. It just lacks content and is best bought on a sale unless you're the kind of competitive player to really sink the time into it. But it's an easy YES recommendation, because what IS there is all pretty fantastic.

Edit: forgot to mention the AI is kinda dumb as bricks so yeah, this is a multiplayer-focused game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A Super Smash Bros style fighting game. I'm still a beginner, but it is very fun! Good music, gameplay and pixel art. Too bad that I don't really care about the original characters in this game. They are all based on animals and their designs feel very boring to me. The game only has 8 characters and other 6 characters are behind a DLC paywall. One of those DLC characters is Shovel Knight, and I will admit, he was a big reason that made me buy this game. Still, I'm glad that I did!

If you are a PC player who wants a Smash style game, this is a good choice.

The game also has online, which is a very good thing. It seems to work fine, as long as the other player is not too far away. When the ping gets high, the game will be unplayable, so avoid playing against people who are from another continent.

By the way, there is one thing where this game beats Super Smash Bros. in every way possible: TUTORIALS! Actual Smash games are pretty bad at teaching beginners to play. This game has very good tutorials, and even seperate tutorials for each character! The developers did a good job with this, and it's just a little weird that this indie game does this while the actual Smash Bros doesn't even try!

+ Fun gameplay
+ Good pixel art
+ Music is great
+ Shovel Knight
+ Easy to learn, hard to master
+ Good tutorials for beginners
- Original character designs
- Many characters are DLC
- Online play will often match you against players who are living too far away

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
PSA to anyone playing this game online: THE NETCODE IS BRILLIANT.
This game plays fantastically with almost no input delay online even over 100 ping. Don't be afraid of those high ping values!

To everyone else: Now that this game is out of Early Access, it is a STEAL for $15. Honestly, it's my new favorite fighting game on Steam. I'm a bit biased since I've been playing Smash Bros. competitively for a couple years now and have been playing since near day one of Early Access, but considering you get nearly the same amount of content for $15 as Street Fighter V gets for $60, this game is well worth the money I spent on it. Also if you're worried about buying a game for which the community might be dead, don't be. The game's community is incredibly active, and I've never had a time where I just couldn't find a match.

TL;DR - This game is INSANELY fun, whether you enjoy fighting online, or just want to play some solo modes like story or survival modes. I HIGHLY recommend you join our wonderful RoA community.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Fantastic game! I enjoy it so much, I purchased a copy both here on Steam and on my Xbox One.  Def reminds me of Smash Bros. Melee back on the Nintendo GameCube. Solid seamless movement, great character control, excellent combo potential, and a high ceiling just begging for constant player improvement. And it's not just all hard-core comopetitive; there are other modes like Story and Abyss, that are great for a more relaxed experience, not to mention online 1v1 and other such options. Couple that with a great tutorial and an individual character 'dojo' style training mode and you have yourself a true and complete fighting/platformer package. If you enjoyed Smash Bros. Melee or really like fighters and don't mind a retro swag, give this one a go!

Rivals of Aether is without a doubt, the best online fighting game on steam. It has balanced gameplay, a high skill cap, and a constant stream of fun opponents to face off against. Also, it is the perfect game to play on a laptop. If you like smash, you will like this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Pros: I came to this game from melee after I'd been playing semi-competitively for about 10 months. after over 100 hours on RoA, I can safely say that I enjoy it much more than any smash game I've ever played. It removes unnecessary tech checks such as Lcanceling and perfect wave dashing as well as adding input buffering, while still retaining many of the varied neutral options available in the likes of melee and PM. In addition, it removes irritating mechanics such as ledge invulnerability and flowchart chain grabs while also encouraging aggression with the replacement of shields with a parry. This game is a joy to just move around in and I would highly recommend it to anybody interested in fighting games.

Cons: Online play needs much more work put into it. There is no way to search for a minimum ping, and when you inevitably find the common >75 ping game in casual, there is no way to decline so you must exit matchmaking and renenter, after which there is no way to guarantee that you won't be matched with the same player over and over. However, this IS getting fixed by the devs soon as a netcode rewrite is underway.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a Super Smash Bros. esque fighting game with a bigger emphasis on speed and tech skill (similar to Melee) while still not compromising what makes platform fighters so fun and accessible. Aether was created by a team that clearly understands what people want, and care immensely about the community. Easily the best platform fighter available on PC, and it's not because others haven't put up a good fight for the title. 

Pros: 

-A cast of characters that, while seemingly small, are all incredibly unique. Not one character plays remotely the same, and each is as fun and deep as the last.

-Gorgeous art and animation. This game looks as good as it plays.

-A comprehensive tutorial mode that goes over some of the more complex aspects of the game as well as a series of character specific tutorials. 

-Excellent online options with a recently revamped (for the better) Ranked mode, a casual exhibition mode, and of course online friend matches. Each mode has stage striking and counterpicking.

-Incredible OST. Seriously, every track is just glorious. 

-Amazing community. With a dedicated discord server and a few community run servers for player help and improvement (and of course matchmaking), you're never left alone as to how to improve.

Cons:

-Limited single player options. There's a short story mode and an endless gauntlet mode with a bunch of fun gimmicks, but ultimately nothing exceptional. 

-Can't play teams with a friend over the internet. I'm not sure if this is just a limitation that doesn't really have a way for them to implement it, but it is rather sad. 

-Can't play with more than 1 friend at a time over the internet. Yet again, still not sure if it's a limitation or not, but a bit dissapointing. 

-Fast movement options allow for insane combos. The game is exhilarating to play.

Final Thoughts:

If you enjoy fighting games like Smash and want something with a unique aesthetic as well as deep gameplay, you're in the right place. I would recommend you wait for one of the frequent sales though, as you can rather often get the game + all the DLC for a massive discount. The DLC characters are so much fun to play as, so I do recommend picking them up. Also, an "Ultimate Edition" is planned, but as of now no info has been shared on it. I believe it's assumed that all existing owners will be given an upgrade option, so I would say it's still a safe purchase.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[b]What I liked:[/b]

I have 45+ hours logged into Brawlhalla, and based on that I can say that I like the gameplay of Rivals of Aether a bit more.

Rivals offers less characters in total (and half of them are paid DLC), but I feel these characters are more "fleshed out" than the characters in Brawlhalla.

That is to say, the fighters in Rivals have more intricacies - more things (like different types of moves) that make them different from each other. In contrast, to me, the characters in Brawlhalla tend to feel more "samey".

Overall, the controls are pretty tight, and the overall gameplay feels pretty good to me. I enjoy the pixelart, and I didn't expect the music to be so GOOD! I wish they added the OST as "buyable" DLC.

The beginner tutorials, the Story more, and the Abyss mode are pretty good. Oh, and the advanced tutorials are a nightmare, so prepare to become frustrated :)


[b]What I didn't like:[/b]

Once I'm done reaching level 10 with all characters in Abyss mode, I'll probably never touch this great game again, except for playing with friends.

As of right now, Rivals doesn't offer casual 4-player online matches - only 1 v 1 or 2 v 2.

And the people you play against, even in casual matches, tend to be god-tier good, so... as some other have mentioned, this game isn't "online casual" friendly, so to speak.

This is something Brawlhalla does well (I think), as I was able to win many 4-player casual online matches (and lost a lot more, of course) with only average skill.


[b]Conclusion:[/b] If you enjoy this genre of fighting games (brawler, platform fighter, etc.), either get it on sale, or maybe wait for a supposed Definitive Edition to come out in the future.

If you have friends to play with, even better! If not, you'll probably play this game regularly only if you want to become competitive.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
To be honest i've not playedm uch, i've watched it, tested it out very well from a friend's account, but I wasn't sure how I felt seeing as I was playing brawlhalla. 

Overall, it's awesome. It's coded in an older game making program that still does great today and I personally love it (GM2 still getting into it). Combat i fluid, very smash like, and you really do have the skill to push to make it like that. The roster of 13 is small but it has Shovel Knight and Ori, great to see guests but would love to see more.

IMPORTANT: There is a definative version coming out. From what I'm understanding from topics, anyone whom owns the game and the DLC is getting this version free. Hopefully some new chracters will come as this can easily be one of the best smash clones if the levels are better and more characters added, needs at least double the roster and this takes time. 

So, because of this, and it's on sale BUY ALL OF IT. The game will hopefully keep going and you got a great indie fighter for cheap and a new version free. This is awesome. Brawlhalla is still my favorite but it's just because the roster is so packed. This game is much better in both combat and execution of controls. You cando a lot. Things like grabs and edge grabbing is missing, but wave dash is here, so hope these things can be added. I would say for the cost, it's expensive for what you get but Indies really need funding, so buy it at the discount at least and we may get a very healthy new contender in the smash style gaming scene for PC. This has pretty much all you need. Brawhalla is still beating it but it also beats your wallet for skins and stuff you want ha. I bought the 100 supporter pack twice, my wife and I, so this wasn't a big deal, but overall for me, it's an 8/10, for the cost and on average a 6/10 for content. But hoping this dev really pushes this series, it can become something great. Maybe a non pixel graphic style one day, but it still looks and feel great. I just think the levels in both mmentioned games (comparison) are sort of meh, very little to do, smash has so much interactive levels, many things to compete over, and crazy areas to really bounce people around. Here it's barebones levels but so is Brawhalla. And Brawhalla has no excuse, they made a ton. I don't know what the dev here made but i'd suppor this first if they make good to their consumer and themselves and beef this up, it would be the go to smash game even without grabs and other mechanics, just needs better maps.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I have nominated this game for "Labor of Love" because there is not a single game I played in 2018 that fits that category more snugly than Rivals of Aether. With a team comprised of only a handful professionals including himself, Dan Fornace (having previously worked on season 1 of Killer Instinct and a bevy of small independent releases) has created a phenomenal fighting game built on the foundation of Super Smash Bros. Melee, but one that expands its boundaries and pushes its mechanics into a new and exciting territory, heralding the birth of the "Platform Fighter" genre. Rivals of Aether has grown a rabid Early Access following into a tremendous sleeper hit, a thriving playerbase and a common fixture at national tournaments alongside Super Smash Bros for Wii U and Melee.
