title: Rivals of Aether
review:
First of all, i love it when a certain friend beats me up in this game.
Second of all, i love this game.
It's basically [h1] Pixel Melee. [/h1] The game currently has a decent amount of characters.
August 10 (2018) The final guest character will be revealed, im pretty hyped for it.
But, yeah. Enough r a m b l i n g, Let's get into the new- Let's get into the review..?

The Story Mode: I'm gonna be honest 
What is this? Nothing made sense AT ALL.
Basically, you play as all original Rivals (Zetterburn, Orcane, Forsburn, Kragg, Maypul, Wrastor.)
Through different locations, against other Characters.
Why do you fight them?
no idea.                                           !Spoiler Warning Below, btw!
[spoiler] At the end, there's a boss battle. (when you beat all story modes.) 
Choose your Rival of choice, and beat up...two eye things. [/spoiler]

Gameplay: This game is basically [h1] PIXEL MELEE [/h1] 
Not like that's a bad thing, Alot of Advanced Techs are present, for example Moonwalking, Wavedashing. This game is pretty easy to learn, Once you play it for abit, You start remembering the controls and stuff. Basically, Imagine Smash Flash 2. Combined with Melee
Has a different graphics style, and removes all Nintendo Characters, and makes new ones instead (Apart from Ori he's from "Ori and the Blind Forest.")

Is the Game worth full price?: Depends on who you are.
In my opinion, Yes.
If otherwise, Wait for a sale, i guess.

DLC: The DLC'S pretty cheap. There's also additional Recolors for characters you can buy.
Though, if you're gonna buy any of those...B U Y A M E R I C A N W RA S T O R.
Is Ori worth it? Yes.
Are Ranno and Clairen recommended? Only if you like MARTH and a Frog who does Vore.
Are Elliana and Sylvanos recommended? if you like heavies, yes.

Online: Pretty good, when i fight one of my friends, we only really have Input Lag.
alsoifyou'renewdonotgoonlineasyouwillgetbodied

Conclusion: Rivals of Aether is a GREAT game. i recommend it 100%, 10/10.
you must like platform fighters though.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is the best "smash bros clone" imo. The movement is crisp and the game is very fast paced (which I like a lot). Each character is slightly similar to Smash Bros. characters but not exactly like them, which makes it pretty interesting if you're coming from Smash to Rivals. Every character is viable and there are no unwinnable matchups. No matchup exceeds 60-40 favoring either. Rivals is probably the most balanced platform fighter out there. DLC can be slightly overwhelming at times, but not much to complain about, really.
This game also has a very in-depth tutorial that you don't see in most games. It covers essential fundamentals and explains them properly, like good DI, wavedashing, edgeguarding, etc. Playing this game for so long helped me develop a proper neutral and DI. It's very useful for building your fundamentals in any of the other platform fighters. 

With relatively low defensive options, Rivals of Aether keeps you on your toes. Every decision counts because combos are VERY long in this game. Combine hitfalling and the opponent's bad DI and you've got yourself a nifty 0-death. It's hype AF. DI is VERY influential in this game, as it changes your angle by 18 degrees. 
Parry and dash dancing (just outside the opponent's area of influence) are the only true universal defensive options, so be careful in neutral, Smashers. 

There are no grabs (only command grabs) and no ledges to grab. Since there are no ledges, you walljump and recover again (you can walljump out of freefall). This teaches you to save your jump and airdodge for when you need it. 

The community is absolutely WONDERFUL. There are a lot of nice people who are super supportive of their favorite players and friends. Lots of us are also willing to help others learn the game and improve. There are crews and learning groups out there and plenty of great resources like the RoA Academy and character-specific discord servers. We're always welcome to new players and you'll feel right at home with us :D

The only issues with the game (as of 11/2018) is the increased input lag and frame drops due to GMS2. Hopefully that will be fixed soon, as it affects both online and offline. 

Hopefully you enjoy the game as much as I do. I quit Smash entirely for this (minus Ultimate if it proves to be as great as I hope). 
-Spyker, Forsburn main

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I've been encouraged to play Smash Brothers but I've always been put off by the huge balance differences between the characters, the huge roster and rubbish Nintendo online services. I feel that Rivals is a much friendlier introduction into the platform fighter genre and is a great place to learn fundementals. It's got a great and small (but not too small) roster with interesting characters and mechanics. I'd recommend it to anyone who wants to get into the platform fighter genre. My only gripe is that multiplayer is not very populated, For ranked games I usually have to wait a good few minutes and I often get matched with US players, as I'm in the EU this leads to very high ping. The game is solid though and is continually being worked on and improved apart from the low player count online it's great.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
First off, let me mention the one glaringly negative thing that I can't really argue with: the matchmaking.

I haven't tried online myself too often, but I do hear a lot of people complain about it. From what I can tell, it really is quite difficult to find players similar to your level of skill, especially ones with stable ping. This goes doubly so if you're a newer players. If you don't have anyone else to play this and intend to get this just for the online games, you might want to avoid this if you're not a veteran in this genre.

That said, locally or playing with friends, this game is close to flawless in my opinion. Combos flow naturally into each other without giving your hands all sorts of diseases, asthethic and sound are great, character designs are mostly unique (Some characters do have some smash attacks, but I can appreciate the familiarity), and distinguished animations make it easy to recognize attacks. I like the flow of this game a lot more than any other platform fighter I've played, though I honestly can't quite pinpoint why.

An issue people frequently seem to complain about is the DLC. First off, no, the DLC characters are not stronger. They all have their unique playstyle to them and do take practice to counter them properly, so if you haven't faced them too often, it may seem like they just have better alternatives. And yes, they are pretty pricy, but the base game comes with 8 characters playable, which I think is fair enough.

I've bought most of the DLC, and though that totals up to 35€ already, I've had over 75 hours of fun so far, and I don't see myself dropping the game any time soon. I'd say that's wel worth it..

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Competitive oriented platform fighter.
Very fast pace (comparable to melee), but techs are easier to execute
Some moves are very reminiscent of melee, but new spiced up moves allow for thematical gimmicks that spice things up and make every character truly unique. 
Kragg spawns his own platform
Orcane can set a puddle trap and burst or teleport to it
Forsburn can lay smoke to hide or inhale to charge a megashine
The bird can jump

The whole roster receives frequent balance patches and all characters are viable.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
What I had said in my early access review pretty much stays true. (I'll keep what I wrote at the end. You may want to read that first.)

The developers have added a few single player options, like story mode and Abyss mode. Story mode is you're traditional arcade mode where you fight a series of opponents. Abyss mode is a more unique gamemode, where you complete a variety of tasks as your chosen character. Your character can level up if you play as them enough in Abyss mode, in order to open up slots to equip runes which alter your stats and abilities.

I think at the moment, these two single player modes are not enough to engage a casual player. It's day 1 of full launch and it seems as though there aren't too many new players, it's still a lot of veterans, so it'll be a while until newbies get into the swing of things. Hopefully this will change.  

The game is still fun, and a must have from Smash Bros./platform fighter fans, but I was really hoping this game would not become a niche competitive game. It's picking up steam in the Smash cicuits, but if you start looking at the stats, games far more inferior to Rivals like Brawlhalla always have thousands playing. Rivals on average has hundreds.

The game is realatively cheap and can still only expand in content. I personally recommend, but I'd be sure the experience is really for you before you buy.

EARLY ACCESS
Rivals of Aether is a platform fighter in the vain of Super Smash Bros. Melee, that has a strong focus on competitive viability. The game does act as a great jumping off point for those who wish to up their game in Smash, as well as stand alone as it's own platform fighter. Just by changing a few core mechanics, the game is new and it's exciting. Though with all this said, the game is not without flaw, and all the issues I have will be covered later in this reveiw. 

If you are unaware of what a platform fighter is, I recommend you do some research first as I will not be explaining every detail. To start, a big departure from games like Smash is the lack of grabbable ledges. The games recovery meta revolves around wall jumping and heavily mixing up your approach back on stage. This game also replaces sheilds with the ability to parry. If timed correctly, parrying an opponents attack will freeze them for a short period of time. These two changes alter not only the core mechanics of platform fighters, but also up the pace of the game. Games are blood pumpingly quick.

The game makes heavy tech skills in Smash like wave dashing and L-Canceling much simpler. The timing for the former is much more forgiving, and everyones wavedash is quite large making it quite versitile. All ariels, with a few exceptions, automatically cancel making for huge combo potential. With all this said, what's easier for you will also be easier for your opponent. Although most pro players stick to ranked mode, you will still get bodied by those who are even more comfortable with the easier controls elsewhere.

The general meta of the game has it's flaws. Most character's tool kits have a very potent dash attack, making it a viable option in almost all combos.I find some characters can get away with dash attack after dash attack at low percents. Not only are they good in combos, but also amazing for starting combos. In Smash, dash attacks are very situational with plenty of ending lag, leaving you open for major punishes if wiffed. Since RoA doesn't have a sheild option, it's much harder to counter a dash attacking opponent (especially online where lag is a factor). To mention one more smaller gripe, the games art style, although very good, makes it difficult to know when to tech.

Rivals of Aether is a step in the right direction when it comes to putting platform fighters on the map. The game is fun, vibrant and captures the style and hype of the genre perfectly. The game does lack features for the casual gamer, but the game is still in Early Access. Rivals still has plenty of time to grow both in balance changes and in features, and I hope we as a community will support it in it's growth.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
As much as I get bodied in this game, to give it a negative review because of the difficulty leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

In short, Rivals is a great platform fighter that has a unique blend of mechanics that I actually prefer to any of the other platform fighters out atm (including all Smash games).

-DIRA (Directional air-dodging) is back, allowing for wavedashing, wavelanding, etc. from Melee
-Speed of the game matches Melee/PM
-More balanced roster than any of the Smash games (excluding DLC characters for some time after their release)
(Most low-tiers in this game tend to be less fun and therefore have less advanced tech and high-level players to boost their prestiege. This is what makes them low tiered, as opposed to them being completely useless like Smash's bottom and low tiers)
-No ledges, removing all of Melee's busted ledge options (luigi fuck off) and Sm4sh's magnet hands that nerfed edgeguarding

In short, if you are a competent competitive player of Melee or PM, you will like this game. Hell, you may even love it. Even if you're a competitive Sm4sh player, you will probably like this game.

However, for everyone else, you will probably not enjoy yourself. Like most fighting games, the community quickly becomes stratified into new players and everyone else. No one online is going to be at your level, as most new players get bodied and leave, just as you will once you buy it.

With friends, it's a hoot. I love playing locally and online with friends and that removes the only downside to this game.

Conclusion:

For the discerning Smash player who likes playing competitive rulesets but isn't very good at Smash, get a friend or get out. For competitive players, this is the best other platform fighter for you, and the only one to rival Smash in terms of genuine competitive spirit and design.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals is a fantastic competitive fighting game but in its current state, unfortunately I cannot recommend it. While it was built from the ground up to be a serious and tournament-ready fighting game, this comes at the sacrifice of newcomers. With a very tight-knit playerbase, rarely exceeding 300 concurrent players, Rivals effectively alienates newcomers to the game by forcing the utilization of advanced tech and extremely high APM for even the simplest of movements. Combine this with the reletively high average level of play that Rivals operates at, and the extereme toxicity of the tight-knit community, and the environment becomes unfun very quickly; with matches ending up 90% of the time in a stomp in either direction. Players spam taunt, tea-bag, mirror your character picks, and challenge you to 9999 coin money matches after they stomp you, and insta-switch to Zetterburn in pure rage when they lose. Rivals also has no dedicated servers, meaning the entire experence happens on a shaky and most often weak connection to your opponent that makes the controls feel more like suggestions to your character. If you are looking for a high-APM competitive fighting game to become truly invested in, Melee has a far, far greater following; and if you're looking for a fun and entertaining casual experence, unfortunately, you're looking in the wrong place.

REVISED REVIEW: Developers are Listening to Feedback!

After my previous review, it appears that the Developers have addressed all of my concerns - adding 4 Player Online Modes and a sizable roster of characters.

Pros:
- All Characters are very interesting to play - Vast and Diverse Move Sets!
- Closest thing to Super Smash Bros - Improved Mechanics!
- Competitive mode is challenging and Intense!
- 4 Player Mode - 2v2 or FFA!
- Developer continues to release more characters and improve upon gameplay!

Cons:
- DLC is a little pricey, although I don't mind contributing to the Developers because they show much promise.

Thoughts:
- I would like to see more character releases in the future - I enjoy all of the current characters and would love to see a lot more!
- It would be cool to see a 6 or 8 player mode.

Made with love. That's the best way to describe this game. You can tell that the developer took great care to make this a great PC port of SSB while incorperating their own features, and style of gameplay to set it apart from the clones out there.

The gameplay is instense, and highly technical. You quickly forget that you're playing with pixel graphics.
The community around this game is very passionate about it. I'd say it has a following just as deticated as SSB.
You really have to play it to truly appreciate what has been accomplished here. If you're looking to get your SSB thirst quenched on PC then look no further. Great graphics, amazing sound effects, a soundtrack that will get stuck in your head, and last but not least, gameplay that will keep you coming back for more.

Example. I have SSB Project M Legacy TE, and XP, and I showed this game to my friends, and they ask to play this instead, every time.  9.5/10 only because the lack of ledge grab as killed me more times than I am comfortable admiting.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
WARNING!: This is all subjective, as this is purely my opinion, and nowhere close to "hard facts", as this is just a review written by some idiot who doesn't know how to play melee, but loves smash, so don't go getting your hair in a knot alright? Ok? Good, let'sa go.

This game. OOOOOOOHHHHH this game. This, right here, is how you make a smash-inspired platform fighter, THAT ACTUALLY HAS DIFFERENCES, AND IS GOOD. It's combat is very melee-inspired, to put it bluntly, however, Rivals of Aether does many things differently than melee did in order to stand out. For starters, this game is very beginner friendly, and by that I mean it has tutorials for pretty much every basic action and many more. It has tutorials on movement, combos, sweet spots, and even character specfic tutorials for any character you may want to main. The tutorials helped me out a lot when trying to learn, and I know how to play mostly because of these. They are clear, concise, and best of all, effective. 

Enough of that stuff though, let's get into why this game is so good that Super Smash Brothers Ultimate may have some competition (I'm partially kidding), THE GAMEPLAY. This games gameplay is put as simply as can be, super fast, and high stakes-high reward. It offers many similar traits to melee, but changes up many aspects, for instance, the abscence of shielding and grabbing. Rather than a shield, every character now has a parry, in which, when pulled of successfully, can completely stun the opponent once their move is finished, leaving them open to a combo. Due to, well, not having a shield, grabbing is not in this game. I see you SSB4 Mario mains, outta here with them grabby fingers (Joking, I love you guys). However, one thing that truly makes this game unique is the status effects (that's what I call them anyway) that many characters can inflict on themselves or the enemy. Every status effect is different, whether it be Zetterburn's flames that slowly damage you and make you go even further by his strong attacks, to the speed boost that Wrastor gets in a certain area after using side-b, there are so many status effects that they shake up each and every matchup, and none of them are necessarily overpowered, of course, some are better than others, but nothing's perfect. Another reason why this game's gameplay is so great is that there is A LOT of hitstun, allowing for hype, long, strong, or just outright ridiculous combos. However, to balance this, most moves do less damage percentage than the average Smash Bros move, which was a simply brilliant move by the developers (seriously, good on you dudes!).

My next point is a short one, but a powerful one. The soundtrack of this game is simply spectacular, with plenty of memorable tunes throughout (my personal favorite being the newest smashville-styled stage's theme). Nothing much to be said here, just some fantastic music all around.

The graphics are spectacular too, featuring phenomenal pixel art animations, stages, and character art, surely a very pretty sight to set your eyes on. The game also features custom colors, so you can color your character whatever you want! Though, it can't be used on ranked.

Alas, no game is perfect, and Rivals is no exception. The roster size is very small, consisting at only about 14 characters, with 6 of them being paid DLC. However, the original eight are still great options and plenty of variety. This is more of a personal nitpick, but having almost half the cast be DLC just doesn't seem too great, but I'll let it slide. The legal stages are pretty much ripped right from Smash, but there are still some very cool and beautiful stages, and there are still plenty of stages to play on casually.

So, final verdict? This game gets a 9.5/10 from me. A simply fantastic platform-fighter I would reccommend to anyone,
with fantastic gameplay and music, a gorgeous artstyle, and plenty of tutorials and help provided from the get-go. Thank you for reading this review. See you next time!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Looking for Super Smash Bros? Well... it's not in Steam.

BUT, for those who are looking for something similar in gameplay and fun, stay and check out both this review and game! Rivals of Aether is an interesting take on the Platforming Fighter in how it closely compares itself to Super Smash Bros Melee. A decently sized character roster, multiple skins, DLC characters, and a quick and fun story mode make this game feel more than its original counterpart. The graphics of this game manage to feel deep and beautiful with its seemingly hand-drawn backgrounds and well-detailed pixelated arenas and characters. Finally, the music is definitely a soundtrack worth listening to during a tense and fighting-filled moment. I would recommend it to those who like the original series and wants to see what others have managed to make out of love for the franchise, especially for multiplayer.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether - Smash Melee made by Dan Fornace; not Nintendo.

Got to say, it was hard learning this game's mechanics, but because I love Smash Bros. so much, I still learnt all the mechanics of the game. This made me love the game more. So much, in fact, that I went to buy all the DLCs (except Shovel Knight). I main Ori and Sein, which I was surprised to find it in when I first heard about the DLC characters.

Now, if you want a fast-paced platformer fighting game, then you should check this out, especially if you play a lot of Smash Bros. The stages are simple to manuever, characters are a bit overpowered even with today (and future) nerfs/buffs but, with enough time, can be dealt with, the pixel art design is splendid, and the music is great too.
Despite this being an Indie Game, I say otherwise because it is so competitive because, again, it's fast-paced.

Which is good.

The gameplay is fast and fluid carrying many things from the Smash Bros. series (mostly Melee). I think it's the best Smash Bros. fan game but to be honest I think it's even something more than that. However, this game is not perfect. 

This game has DLC characters, 6 in fact. The thing is, not only is the roster already pretty small, they aren't cheap either. For 15 dollars it's not that bad but if you want DLC expect to pay over 30 dollars. 

Now that wouldn't be so bad if the DLC characters weren't notably better than the main 8 characters. I'm not gonna lie, I'm not amazing. I don't win every game I play, but I think I'm good enough to realize that the DLC characters feel way better than everyone else. It adds an unfortunate P2W aspect as in some cases it can make you win games (An example is someone who is obviously better than me beating me, but then I play Clairen and win 2-1 online)

Even though the DLCs are a little better, I wouldn't call any character bad. Which is another good thing, in this game you can play as anyone and win due to the developers' constant care and updates of the game. 

For this reason, I can't say I wouldn't reccomend it but at the same time I wouldn't reccommend it to someone who doesn't want to spend too much. I like the game though and if you like Super Smash Bros. (or SSF2), try this out. It's fun.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: RIvals of Aether is my favorite platform fighter over Smash, but you must put in the hours to get good. The story mode is fun and challenging, and the characters are all unique. If you want a good time, I'd suggest you get this game. The pixel graphics also allow it to run fairly well on potato PC's so it's a very easy game to run. You start with 8 characters, and there are DLC characters you can buy in packs of 2 with Steam currency/real money. The only problem is queueing for games online, and you may constantly get disconnected from an online match lobby. But other than that, this is a very solid game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
In the past I gave this game a negative review saying it was a good game in a bad state. Now it's a good game in a good state. I like that.

If you're here for good single player content then you may as well just give up now, if one thing remains from my previous review is that the story mode feels tacked on and lazy and the abyss endless mode hasn't even been updated for the new DLC characters.

Now the gameplay. That's where the real fun is, fast paced, little to no defensive options aside from zoning and each character has their own little gimmick to them that makes them different from each other like how zetterburn can light his opponents on fire with his specials and while they're on fire, if you attack them with a strong attack they go flying really damn far. 

The online of the game has improved dramatically as well and there really isn't much to say about it. Character balance is pretty good right now too. Go have fun.

It's fun, not too slow paced, has balanced mechanics, and despite it being somewhat of a smash clone, similar to Brawlhalla, it still retains its own charm. One issue I have found is that sometimes the controls will swap themselves out whenever the game is restarted. For example, I set my jump button to the Spacebar, and when I restarted the game after a crash, it was set to Z. My dodge was then set to S after I set it to L. Minor bug, I'm sure, but it can be fairly annoying. As for content though, It seems pretty consistent with the characters and skins. Also it's fairly relieving that Clairen is a literal copy and paste of Melee Marth. So I can still seem like I'm good at the game even though I'm not.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Game is not meant for casual play. This game will literally drag to through the mud if you don't bother playing competitively to enjoy the online experience. If you like to play competitive games and dedicate months to it, then by all means, go ahead. 
 The story mode doesn't really make sense and is something you the person have to put together yourself for it to make sense.
 The most worth while mentions for the game is giving the characters their own seprate identities in terms of gameplay and design as none of them seem similar at all. Along with offering the ability to make your own custom colors and see other people's ping online before playing them so you aren't forced to play through a laggy match if you don't have to. The combo system is too important to skip out on and heavily punishes the newer players and cheap strats. The game does offer tutorial mode that teachs you all the advanced tech and try out the dlc characters before purchasing them but I feel like if you don't put in the work to be a good player, then you will get smoked. Even by the bots, and everyone online will disrespect you if you aren't good.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's hard to put my finger on why this game makes me rage so much while Smash remains one of my all-time favorite games. I think there's something about the length of time that your character remains unresponsive after being hit. Rivals seems to ignore inputs long after you'd regain control of your character in Smash. The result of this is a fair bit of frustration as you try to attack, jump, or air-dodge in response to the enemy's next attack, but the game just ignores you and you get hit again and again. Each time you are hit, the timer is reset, so the game ignores you even longer. So, if your enemy is any good, they just juggle you across the stage for multiple seconds while you can't do anything. This feels really unfair when it happens.

If the online matchmaking were better, I could forgive this. Rivals is a fun game when two opponents are equally matched—I've had some enjoyable matches. But as far as I can tell, matchmaking makes no effort to pair opponents at a similar skill level. So you will play noobs and pros alike. 

(Well, I say that, but if you're against a pro, you won't actually be allowed to play as they juggle you into oblivion...)

Anyway, I probably just need to git gud and learn2play, but I can't think of any time I didn't feel in full control of my character in Smash, yet I feel that all the time in Rivals. That's why I can't recommend it.

review: Really good! Even as someone who never really played Melee or Project M, the roster is really well balanced, and the skill curve is steep but fair. title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is awesome.  Grabbed it when it was on sale, had a blast within the first hour of play and decided to grab all of the DLC characters to date.   

This game is reminiscent of Super Smash Bros (mostly Melee) if you couldn't tell by watching a few videos.  The game is fast paced, very responsive, the online feels smooth with very little delay at 200 ping using a wired connection (I played opponents/friends around the globe and once we got into matches things felt smooth).  I wish free for all was available for online play instead of just 2v2 and 1v1.  

Anyways, the main highlight of this game is how unique the play styles are in comparison to Smash Bros, and the fact that the game takes the Smash Bros concept and makes some very nice changes to differentiate itself on the fundamental level with its highly offensive/engaging play with the lack of ledges, no shield, and varied recovery methods.  The amount of depth each character has is like looking at earlier iterations of Street Fighter 2 and then looking at how unique Blazblue or Guilty Gear characters play.  

As far as content goes, there are a few stages to unlock, a tutorial for characters and the game itself,  custom moves/parameters, abyss mode (a survival mode with extra victory conditions for bonuses and surviving), story mode (a n arcade style setup with random opponents, but same final opponent each time, and extra colors; local versus modes are here too of course with aether stages (stages with hazards on) and basic stages (hazards off).   

For the price I paid for it on sale, this game is an amazing package and a wonderful to play hidden gem.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Bought this game back in 2015 when even Absa wasnt even known yet. This game is fantastic. It took Smash Bros and got rid of the annoying parts of the game and replaced it with a new recovery and parrying system. Defencive play in this game is discouraged, which makes it a really fun fighting game. Instead of shielding, you can parry, where, when you time it right, stuns your opponent and makes you invulnerable for a short time where you can quickly punish them. Ledge grabbing is also gone, instead, every character can walljump off the stage to restore their recovery. Other features, such as not having your moves get staled, no rage mechanic from Sm4sh, no need for L-cancelling, easier wavedashing, and being able to go into a smash attack while sprinting really adds to this game. The only thing that all of Smash really has over this game is their roster, as you know, all of their liscensed characters are there. But even Rivals beats Smash int heir competitively viable stages (at the time being, before Smash Ultimate comes out), as all of their stages are tournament legal when put on basic mode, and even ShoovelKnight is in this game now. They even hav a wolf clone, Zetterburn.
Buy this game. It really is worth way more than what it costs.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a 2D Pixlated Platform Fighting Game, the game is a smash like game, but is one of the greatest smash like games out there, than Brawlout.

NOTE: This is before the Definitive Edition
Pros:
-Graphics wised is awesome, the art style, sprites, animations, and effects are done very well with such a 2D Pixelated game.
-Super Fast Paced Gameplay
-Game is more balanced on the characters
-Plots in the story is interesting and the player fighting other Rivals doesn't even matter, it gets intertesting over time. You can even get a better time for each character's story
-DLC is worth buying with 5 bucks for each DLC Character, not only more characters but stages and a EA Access skin for the DLC character if you buy the early access version of the game.
-Online is perfect and works really well, there is even a ping displayed that tells whether or not your opponent has a good connection and the Ranked is really fun for experienced players.
-Abyss Mode is really fun with abyss runes being way fun and overpowered than custom moves from Smash 4. Abyss Endless is the greatest, you play wave to wave and every wave it gets harder and harder with some challenges. 
-Tutorial mode gives players a good way of how to be good with Movement, Offense, Defense strategies and even some Tips, Tricks, and Techniques that are for beginners and advanced players.
-The Achievements are also a fun task to do and or some things to be unlocked, you would have to do some achievements to unlock them like the Aetheral Gates or a Second Slot for a second custom color slot.
-Custom Colors are really fun to make because you can make your own OC or a skins made by you.
-The Replay system is fantastic, you can disable the HUD, look at DI lines, hitboxes, number of frames, restart the whole match, or sped up to skip each part of the match.

Cons:
-The online Team match sounds dead that it seems outdated. No 4 players free for all. No Aether versions. And no Abyss runes online.
-No DLC characters playable in Abyss mode.
-Ranked Mode needs some attention for more players.

Rivals of Aether- 9.7/10

I recommend buying this game, its really worth it if you don't a really powerful PC or you don't have the money to get Smash. :D

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I have played Super Smash Brothers all of my life, and I instantly fell in love with this game after seeing some gameplay. After Smash 4 came out, I haven't really played anything else on my console (currently 700 hours in ((update: 2000 hours in)), and I am sure I'll play this a whole lot too. An aggresive smash-like game with no shields, infinte combos and a very interesting way of edgue guarding. All characters are unique, and have something special to them. This game is amazing.

Here are my Pros and Cons.

Pros:
+Smooth gameplay
+All characters play completely different, and have their own side objectives
+Beautiful art
+Balanced
+Next to no bugs, which is a huge plus for an early access game
+Endless possibilities. You can basically combo anything into anything
+Unique features, which makes you play completely diffeent from Smash Bros 
+Shovel knight

Cons:
-Online rooms (both private and public) only support 2 players
-No team mode online (I'd love to be able to play 2v2s)
-REALLY hard to find matches if you're in Europe. Play with friends or use online chat rooms



I am sure most of my cons will be gone after a couple of updates, but until then they're staying. And to end off this review:

lol m2k

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Good god this game is fun. Having only played this casually without having touched online mode, this game is lot like Smash in that its barrier of entry is really low. You don't have to go online to enjoy this game - beating up level 9 bots and vsing local friends is still pretty damn fun. Also great for competitive players since the skill ceiling is pretty high. There's also a good tutorial on not only the basic actions but also character specific tutorials and tutorials on the more advanced techniques that can be performed in the game like Wavedashing (which is a lot easier to do here than in melee.)

For single player, there's a story mode but its pretty lacking. But there's also an good endless abyss mode which lets you level up the characters, unlock skills and progress further into an 'endless abyss'. There's an achievement for getting all characters to level 10 which is probably *the* achievement that will take you the longest to do. It's a fun mode to sink a lot of time into.  

If you're looking to pick this game up, you are going to want to decide whether you want to pick this up as a party game to play amongst friends or if you want to go competitive and look online for opponents. There's not really a middle ground. 

Also the music is badass. 

All in all, can recommend pretty well for any Smash fan.

9/10 I hope my friends pick up this game to play with me.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Yes

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'll be honest here. I wasn't expecting much out of this game. I remember hearing about RoA thanks to RelaxAlax and Alpharad posting videos about this this game and it definitley had my interest. So I bought the game early access. I believe it was version 0.0.5 and spent a good 4 hours into the game learning the mechanics, fighters and so on. As the game progressed with development with balancing, adding Absa and Etalus, and confirmation of DLC, I think Rivals was in a good place. I even bought the Xbox One version because I loved how fluid the game was becoming. I thought to myself, this would never replace Smash Bros. for me obviously, but Rivals set out to do something new. It did its own take on what we know as the platform fighter genre that new ideas can differ the game from similar platform fighters. Rivals of Aether has a huge softspot for me on how much fun I had with this game with friends and even learning the competitive mechanics. Currently I bought all of the main DLC (yes that means ALL fighters and Steam skins. I would say same for Xbone but...) because I wanted to support this game further. I'm so glad this game turned out to be amazing to me.

*The version of RoA is 1.4.0. Will represent balances, fighters, content, etc. in that state.
*Note: This isn't too in depth as this based on my experience for the game.

Story: The world of Rivals has a neat concept. Elements of fire, wind, water, and earth along with subsidiary elements exist. The games story mode details six of each Rivals occupation, their conflict and of course the resolution at the end. This isn't a deep story by no means it's very simple but I think it's simple enough to pass as an actual story. Sure, it's not the main focus, though I kinda want to see the lore build up upon the next game whenever that comes.

Presentation: Rivals goes for a 2D sprite presentation which, to the games credit, looks great. The stages are nicely detailed, fighter sprites are big enough to see them and very fluid I might add. Looking back at Early access, the sprites flet a bit stilted (i.e. Kragg) to where it still needed some work. Now, All the fighter sprites are very smooth which I really like. When studying frame data that's pretty essential. Also, I love how attacks pop when they connect. It gives a satisfying feel that, when you hit, looks like it hurts. Listen, when you get hit offstage or hit at high percent and see that colored aura just explode out it feels good. Plus the new stages like The Forest Floor and Julesvale are very well animated. My favorite stage, The Burning Capitol, has this awesome heat effect with the flame sparks. Feels so majestic. Also, the promotional skins for Rivals I love. Each of them has say, a particle effect or lighting, that makes a fighter stand out. When you see Genesis Forsburn and that lighted flames gives a cool vibe. The soundtrack for this game is just awesome. Flashygoodness once again makes really upbeat, energetic music for the OST and is definitley worth a listen. My favorite track The Earthern Division has a nice build up that lead to what I consider an iconic tune. Though I will say, there was one track that left me unsatisfied. Lightning Pandemonium to me feels like it's missing something. Incredible build up then halfway through the track it loops. I was honestly expecting something epic but I lost it when it did. Otherwise the rest of OST of definitley worth a listen. Also, custom colors. GENIUS!!! Oh and, thank you.

Gameplay: Then one thing I was worried when going into this game was its gameplay. I was afraid that this will copy what Smash fans love and basically Melee for PC. I was so glad I was wrong. All fighters have their own original movesets, bringing forward fresh, new ideas to the platform figher genre. I'd say most unique goes to both Sylvannos and Eliana. Both fighters have unique passives (grass, steam gauge.) that really change the course of a match. I've been trying out Shovel Knight and really like the idea for his passive (treasure hunter). Overall the whole passive abilities for every Rival is very creative. As for overall control is what they nailed so great. Each Rival has their own weight to them, feeling different from one another. If there's something I look into a platfrom fighter is control. Not too much floatiness, doesn't feel stilted. I can easily do wavelanding, wavedashing, RAR. I'm in complete control. As an Ori/Kragg main, I wanna make sure my speed is kept and confuse my opponents. Sure, the game does crash sometimes for me but that's what hotfixes are for. Abyss mode is loads of fun. I love the challenges it brings. The pace is constant, when I die it's fair, and the custom moves really help out. I would say something bad about this game but most issues have been fixed thanks to updated and hotfixes. Though if you do want me to complain online can sometimes choke but playing with friends and others had mostly good connections on my part. That and the occasional connection error. 

Conclusion: Rivals of Aether is a platform fighter that isn't afraid to try something new. Most of the roster is unique, stages, presentation. This game prides itself for being a Smash Bros. inspiration and not imitation. While I still wish for stable internet matches, online Abyss mode and more options for online, that's what the upcoming definitive version is for right? But as one last harah from and early access member, Dan Fornace, I'm looking forward to whatever you do next with Rivals 2. Rivals of Aether I would absolutley recommend for someone who wants a fresh take on the platform fighter genre.

review: It's great. Some people say it's a smash clone but they have to understand platformer fighter is a genre not something only smash does. I played both Smash and Rivals and it holds up realy well I especially like the physics engine in other platformer fighters besides Smash like Brawlhalla feels wierd to jump and change directions in mid air but its perfect here. You should get it if you can it's a growing community. It has a learning curve but once you can play efficiently it is a lot of fun.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is easily one of my favorite Steam games. While it clearly draws inspiration from Super Smash Brothers, specifically Melee, each character is original and offers a different experience from Smash. The game is easy to learn, but has a very high skill ceiling. To help players with this, there are comprehensive tutorials which explain not only how to play, but also other essential skills such as wavedashing and directional influence. The gameplay is fluid, the roster is quite well balanced, the artwork is great, and the soundtrack has several phenomenal pieces. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the platform fighter genre.

title: Rivals of Aether

Such a great platform fighter. All the characters are extremely unique and play very different from one another. 

The only thing this game needs is better online experience. But the game is still worth a buy.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: When I first played I thought meh.  But then I picked it up later and when I started to learn the combat system, I really started enjoying this game.  The recovery works different than smash bros, theres no grabs, instead of shield you have parry's, and attacks can be strung into long combos.  The characters have really unique abilities, and the game gets new content frequently.  Really love this game.  Get it!

title: Rivals of Aether

A really good indy smash-like fighter.
Interesting characters that are really original with their own movesets.
Has a colour editor for every character allowing you to have your own custom skin for a character.
Lots of great premium skins for supporting RoA's tournaments.
Just a high quality indy game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I've seen alot of people compare this game to SSBM and it's not the same at all! The only thing that is remotely close to Melee is the wavedashing (which is super easy to do in RoA).
But the game is one of it's own kind so it's not necessarily BAD but It could use some work when it comes to combos and hitboxes cause they're super easy to hit and feel off when you hit them.
Characters are fun and unique, unlike Icons who blatantly copied Melee characters, these guys made unique characters!
Wavedashing really doesn't serve a purpose in this game if I'm gonna be honest, though it quickens the game, it doesn't support combos at all due to the easy hitboxes making it quite useless since you'd be better off just standing still and spamming (Basically half of the players I met online)
Pros:
- Fun/Unique characters
- Nice design

Cons:
- GC Support is a bit off, you have to download a program for it to work so it doesn't work immediately.
- Useless mechanics
- Peer to Peer Online
- OP DLC Characters..

Don't expect something like Melee if you buy this, however, if you want a unique fighter game with pixel graphics; this game takes it!

If you're not a fan of platform fighters, you still need to get this game, it will make you a fan.

CONS:

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is my second review of this game since it was in early access in 2016. 

Rivals of Aether is an incredibly fun game. It's fast, complex, and is a spectacle to watch. The depth this game has makes me want to never stop playing, which is something I can never shame a game for. It's just so fun. The gameplay is similar to Super Smash Bros, specifically the Gamecube iteration, Super Smash Bros. Melee. It's a bit more simple, making things like wavedashing easier, and the complete removal of L-Cancelling. It makes it so that you can do sick combos and master movement a lot easier and worry about that less at a top level of play. 
I think that Rivals of Aether is either my favorite platform fighter, or second to Melee. Its characters are unique, the music is fantastic, and the gameplay is solid. I'm gonna keep playing for years to come. If you don't have the game, it's on sale for half off this week (as of the time of writing this) and you should definitely pick it up. I hope you enjoy it as much as I do.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I really like platform fighters, though this one just doesn't feel right to me. I feel like the controls aren't really intuitive, and the characters don't really feel that good to play in my opinion. I've messed with the custom controls and none of it feels right. This is the main reason I can't recommend this game. 

 Plus, the full game costs $30 as of right now if you want all the characters. Plus another $5 for the upcoming Shovel Knight, so $15 for the base game and $20 for the rest.

I think if you're interested in this game or platform fighters in general, you should also check out Roof Rage. It's cheaper and I think it feels more natural to play; really is the definition of easy to learn and hard to master.  I'm pretty sure there are more maps and distinct characters too, with more free stuff on the way.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is amazing.
I got into this game after watching numerous videos on it, and I decided to give it a shot. This is an extremely fun game based off of Super Smash Brothers Melee, and has gained much support in a short time, adding characters from other franchises, being added to the elite few featured in tournaments, and gathering a huge fanbase.
HOWEVER, this game is designed with the competitive side in mind. If you're going to keep it casual, then you should mainly limit it to playing with friends you know. Attempting to play against other people online without any training at a high level will simply lead to you getting bodied. 
That being said, this is a very fun Smash Bros style game. If you have the time and the money to buy it, I suggest you do so.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The simplest thing I can say about Rivals is that it cuts the bull. This is not just the best platform fighter I've ever played, but I'll take this over just any fighter. Period.
 
Defensive options that promote sluggish, campy, obnoxious habits are removed for a more aggressive, fast, and frantic fighting experience. You get a parry with 3 frame startup and 20 frame end lag that cannot be spammed and a very predictable roll. That's it, but the parry is very satisfying, skillful and rewards you for parrying medium and higher attacks with some i-frames and a stun on the opponent. And no ledge so goodbye BS ledge hogging or planking. You're forced to get creative with recovery which the game really lets you do.

This game is HARD. But it's wholly fair and somehow still accessible. I never feel cheesed out. The balance is just right that you don't need staling or dumb cop out comeback mechanics like rage. If you're good at the game, you can get very creative with conversions and combos but it's very easy to get out of bad situations. The game is quite flexible.
The base mechanics aren't needlessly difficult to do and there's some minor input buffering so you don't need to have the mechanical dexterity of a factory robot. It's a very human game that just lets you get immediately to understanding *concepts* instead of spending time worrying if you're even hitting the buttons properly. Rivals is simple. That's the whole point of the platform fighter genre. Simplicity. Everything just works as it appears like it should.

The movesets are just incredible. Characters just have amazingly wild and inventive options of approaching, zoning, and recovering. 
I often see folks say that the game pulls too much from Smash Bros in terms of moves. And that's just not fair to the game's main draw in that every character has some elemental based variant on stage control/pressure. It's just brilliant and along with the perfectly implemented parry, this acts as your bread&butter keep away and defensive tools. They require extensive experimentation and understanding of a character to utilize efficiently. It also lends itself well to the slight stigma the game has of being "furry Melee" or "Smash for furries". 
The art style is great. I can't really think of anything more perfectly fitting than an anthro cast for fighters focused on such creative elemental abilities...despite Shovel Knight being in the game now. But maybe he's a fox or rabbit under that armor. Who knows?

On the note of art, the graphics are just right. Another unfair criticism to this game was it's pixel art which I personally find beautiful and inspiring. I love the crisp, GameBoy Advance graphics. The characters are so cute and simple on screen with minimal detail. Certain frames look questionable, but in motion, these animations are just incredible for what they are. They're about as fluent as Third Strike and it makes for a visual fidelity that is very legible and easy on the eyes. Everything is crystal clear and lines up sensibly with hitboxes. You won't say "that actually hit??" in this game. And the backgrounds are just as beautiful. I love them, they make me yearn for simpler handheld times on the GBA playing classics like Advance Wars, Minish Cap, and Gradius.
There isn't a lot of extra fluff either. The pixel graphics allow for a mostly fixed camera that doesn't pan and zoom and rumble so fervently. The contrast of the characters and their attacks on the backgrounds of the stages are perfect. There aren't any needless effects to attacks or stages (even on Aether mode) either. I can focus. I don't get a headache due to eyestrain playing this game as best as I can.

This review is getting too long so I'm gonna wrap up with bullet points because there's too much to praise, and I do have a few kinda-sorta cons at the end...

Additional Pros:

+The music is fire. Very fresh, lively, consistent soundtrack that doesn't feel like it's trying to be something else or generic (*cough* Icons: Combat Arena *cough*)

+It had some of the best Early Access. The game was just clean from day one. Consistently. Even had online play immediately that didn't DC on you like mad. Though it could stand for some more options. Lobbies like Slap City would be welcome.

+DLC is cheap. If you're complaining about the characters not being free, you're being unfair. These were made from scratch and fighting game characters are not an easy task. The art, animations, movesets, trailers, balancing, QA, and everything else is worth the asking price. People have bills to pay. $2.50 or in the case of Ori $5 per character is wholly justifed. 

+Custom. Character. Colors. GOD yes.

+Great extensive training mode. Frame by frame, DI lines, extended CPU behavior options, hitbox visualization. The works.

+Playtest right on the menu. Wanna test a new control setup or just pass the time waiting for a player to connect? Even lets you beat up each other.

+All aerials auto cancel. It just makes sense.

+Basic mode did what Smash 4 failed to do with Omega stages. You actually get fun and different stages layouts that are more than just aesthetic differences but are still competitive.

+GREAT spectator game. The speed and depth of the game makes tournaments hype as Hell and exciting. And the visual clarity I outlined earlier makes things extremely easy to follow even at top level. Seriously, go to VGBootCamp and look up some CakeAssault or FullStream VoDs. It's great!

Cons:

-Playing randoms online needs work. No matter what time of day or what day it is, I often just find myself running into the exact same people multiple times in a row. This has been the consistent biggest issue I've had since early access even during big events for the game where it's popularity got a spike. This game isn't huge, but it's not THAT unpopular. I've never played another online game that does this so I think it's something server side as opposed to the number of players. You really have to join a Rivals Discord if you want to play online with different people.

-Single player content is a bit weak. I know this game was competitive multiplayer first, but if you're going to add SP to a game, I feel like it should have the same kind of polish for people who like it. It is *fun*, but just not lasting. The story mode is just way too sparse and not that engaging. And until Rivals Definitive, Abyss mode only lets you play the base 8 roster which is kinda lame. And there's nothing else beside those. :c
(The cutscene art could also be better, but that's so minor.)

-I feel like the original 8 characters are due for slight design tweaks. They're a bit lacking compared to the DLC characters.

But all in all, this game is outstanding. Would buy again...and I will next year.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Easily one of the best platform fighters around. Has a lot of the movement and tech that made games like Smash Bros Melee great, but also has a refreshing spin on defense, where instead of shielding or grabbing, spacing, parrying, and punishing your opponent are fundamental. Many of the characters are easy to pick up, but it is still challenging to get good, with techniques that take practice to master and the high skill level of much of the game's community. 

Nine furries out of ten. The only reason I'm not giving a perfect score is because Car from Rocket League should have been the final DLC character instead of Shovel Knight. What were you thinking, devs?

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of aether is an incredible love letter to smash bros. It takes all of its conventions and actually improves upon many of them. The micro-managing and more spacing oriented gameplay feels more strategic than smash. The only thing holding this game back now is a lack of content, it sorely needs story mode etc. would highly recommend for any fan of smash, especially competitive smash.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A very fun platform fighting game. It has mechanics like wavedashing and you can pull off long and flashy combos. The characters are well balanced compared to many other games and each character has unique and interesting mechanics to control the stage. This game is competitive focused, so it may not be the best game for casual players (no items / final smashes). Also, this game features a comprehensive Dev Mode that can be used to alter character variables for playing with friends, which is a lot of fun if you want to try to balance the game yourself.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A fun game that borrows some aspects of Super Smash Bros., while having its own twist and flavor that gives it a different identity. I cannot comment on online multiplayer as I have yet to try that feature, but local battles are a blast to say the least. 

It is like Smash but not. Instead of shielding, there is a parrying mechanic that demands good timing. If performed correctly, your victim will be dropped to one knee, completely at your mercy for the next whole secod or so. Instead of ledge-grabbing, there is a wall-jump mechanic used to recover(That I still find myself having difficulty pulling off). The game lends itself to a more aggressive, more offense-oriented type of gameplay that can be fast, frenetic, and satisfying when you land those combos and meaty hits. 

I highly recommend trying the tutorials, and each character-specific tutorial to learn the characters. They've been a huge help to me learning to use Clairen and Ori more effectively. 

A fun game! A most fun game. A good fun game indeed.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I don't want to say it, but if you're a fan of competitive platform fighting games such as Super Smash Bros. series, this is the way to go! 

Gameplay-wise, it is similar to Melee's, but has interesting mechanics like parrying and wall jump. Also all of its characters are pretty balanced. Sure there's a Tier List, however it doesn't punish you for using a bottom tier character against a top tier one.

It clearly rewards skill, but is also because of this that the game is not for everyone. Nevertheless, this is a game that you should try if you like fighting game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: The story mode is bland and boring. This is soley a multiplayer fighting game, unlike Smash bro's which doubles as a party game as well. Unless you have friends who are also interested in the game, DO NOT BUY. The skill cap is really high, and the online players are mostly salt inducing, taunting jerks.(Like FG). Your best bet is finding locals or friends to play with you in a more respectful environment... and good luck with that.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Really fun characters, really great art, really great music, cool new mechanics not found in any other platform fighter, non-predatory DLC made worth it by the level of effort clearly put into it.

BUT

I really can't recommend this game if you want to actually h ave fun playing it. Unless you're goal is to become the eSports ledgend of your hometown, this game is not for you. There is zero casual or low-level play available without having to use outside resources, and even then there's zero guarantee the people you'll find elsewhere also won't frame-perfect combo you to death over and over again. 

Fantastic game, awful community with zero non-competitive growth possible in it's current state.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you like Smash Bros., you might like this. It's a platform fighter with 12 original characters (and guest character Ori) and movesets sort of inspired by Smash characters but with plenty of their own twists. It's very much a more offense oriented game, there's no shielding or grabbing the ledge and campier stages like Temple don't exist. Right now the online modes are rather limited and only support 1v1 and 2v2(with a team of two playing on the same machine), but it's plenty to keep competitive players interested.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you're a fan of Super Smash Brothers...then I'd recommend you just stick with that game instead.

The thing is that this game tries to be Smash Brothers, but decided to try and do a few things of it's own. While that wouldn't be bad (because then you'd just be a clone), it ends up failing in actually trying to be both things.

For one, a few of the characters are very blatantly copying commonly used Smash characters (Zetterburn is Fox and Wrester is Falco), so much so that they even borrow some of their signature special moves. The second problem is that when they try to implement their own ideas into the game, it just seems like odd choices. Like are Kragg has the move to create a giant pillar to save themselves. Or how Absa's basic side-attack is able to reach all the way across the stage and could be done repeatedly with little chance of escaping. Or how Forsburn has the ability to cover large portions of the screen with smoke, obscuring both your vision and your opponent's.

There's just so many questionable design choices that went into this game that it just becomes annoying to even continue playing. I bought this game while it was on sale for around $5, but even then, it's not worth it. I can't imagine why it would even be worth it to buy it for it's full $15 price point. Along with the DLC characters being so few and not even worth buying...and including Ori as well (how and why they got the okay to put Ori in the game is still a mystery to me). I know some will argue that the mechanics presented are just part of the experience and I just need to "get gud", but no. I will not abide your crappy behavoir in giving shit game mechanics a pass just because you can find a way to work with them. They're still shit, regardless.

In short, don't buy this game. Buy a Switch and wait for Smash Ultimate to come out. Better to spend $360 in total to buy a system to play a game you'll at least have fun with than paying $15 for a game that you'll just spend maybe 4 hours at most with before putting it down and forgetting you bought it in the first place.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you're a person that gets salty at fighting games. Don't get this game. Rivals of Aether is a little over a year old at this point and boasts one of the most dedicated communities of melee fans I've ever seen, and they're all better than you. 

There's nothing actually wrong with the game itself and I think it's a quality product, but I deeply regret purchasing it, never realizing that I could never hope to be able to commit as much time to mastering the game as literally everyone else that plays. For some reason all the extremely good people just stay in exhibition mode.

I know losing is supposed to be a learning experience, but the absolute skill gap between a casual and a pro at this game is nothing less than [b]immense.[/b] Even after learning about DI, wavedashing and mix-ups, there's always more to learn, there's always more to improve on. Even as I type this salty review my left thumb aches with the dull sting of uselessly trying to escape combos. I don't even want my money back anymore, I wish I could just give the game away. [i]Preferrably to someone I hate.[/i] I live in the Eastern Time zone and the matchups I get at night are against people who outclass me in ways that could only be described as [i]sadistic.[/i] I now know how a mook in a Gundam series feels.

[url=https://youtu.be/P4iNaCc8TSg]If you don't know what you're doing this will happen to you, even the people getting bodied in the video are good at the game too.[/url]

It's like every game is Guts vs Griffith at the eclipse.
I'm a casual, I accept it, git gud, etc.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Quite honestly: Every review i could write could possibly still miss some facetes this game still has.

So... to be short then: This is the most awesome "Smash clone" i've ever played, to that extend, that it's not even a clone anymore, hence the quotation marks.

But it's not even the fast paced action or the fact, that even the dlc characters can be defeated in a 1v1 matchup.
Sure, they are a bit stronger, but what would be the reason for purchasing them be if they wouldnt be? :smirk:
Despite that, some of the original 8 or even 4 can be really op too...

But not only is the gameplay super comfortable, but also the presentation couldnt be better.
The crisp graphics, the catchy music, but also the outside-of-the-game presentation, that peaked with the rivals direct this april, when they put up a whole april fools not-nin***do direct, making everybody expecting nothing, but then suddenly referencing the smash ultimate reveal when showing of elliana in an awesome, never seen beast of a trailer.

It's been a blast and an honor to be a part of this comunity up until now, even for the huge amount of months i kept following this games stuff before finally buying it.

This is one of my favourite games of all time, gets a BIG recommendation to buy EVERYTHING it has to offer and i hope i wont be let down when the last character will be announced.

Thank you Dad Fornace ;D

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If I wanted to play Melee, I would just play Melee, but I play this because I want to play Rivals. It's similar but I don't play this game as a substitute for Smash, but more alongside it. The mechanics lend themselves to super offensive and aggresive play, which is easily how I like my games. Super combo heavy but not to the point where combos are free and with one hit a stock is lost. The amount of mind games that go into reading an opponents DI and knowing what will follow up with itself is insane. For me, Melee will always be on top but this is a breath of fresh air and I hope the community stays active for years to come.
TL;DR: Like Melee but with easier tech skill and more aggresive play.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I think this game is great, but for a certain audience, for some who liked the less competitive engines of brawl and SSB4, this will be a hard sell, though not impossible through tutorials. without the basics of this game mastrered you pretty much cant get the full experience and enjoyment out of the game, nor can you just hop straight into an online match. BUT, the stereotypical melee fan will not be disappointed, but that isnt the only demo catered to. This is a platform fighter made for the competitive audience but not accidentally like melee, the characters are well made (except elliana imo, although the idea behind her is great). You have to come into this game with the intentions of AT LEAST mastering the basics, but if you don't enjoy the competitive aspects of pro smash whether it be melee or 4,this game is a hard sell, though nerdy and elitist mechanics such as wavedashing are made easier for it not to have as great of a skill wall as melee does. Overall this game is made for pro smash fans (specifically melee), mastered to a T, but if you aren't as into it through time and dedication you'll find as much enjoyment as thy will.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
To start off, I am an extreme fan of smash brothers, and I am very happy to play a fighting game with the same style, using all the techniques of literally all the smash games combined, for example, wave dashing is so fluent and amazing, saying thatI love it is an understatement.

Now on to the actual game. The story mode is eh, but the gameplay is still fun. Some backgrounds for the Rivals are strange, especially Kragg, which is just "I go around wall, wall broke, must kill wall breaker." But seeing how this game was more centered toward the actual gameplay, I can understand the lack of character development, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. With the introduction of DLC, I'm sure things can be explained more clearly. 

After beating the main story, the abyss mode is unlocked. I'm just gonna come and say it: This mode is clearly better than the story mode itself. I enjoy every single challenge and miniscule thing I have to do. It's obviously inspired by all the smash minigames, like multiman smash and the like, but done in a unique way in that it's somewhat all combined. I also enjoy the alternate abilities or "Runes" you can unlock to make the mode easier. I would honestly like to see a mode online where you can activate these runes and play against your friends. I think it would make up for a very chaotic and fun expierence. 

Another thing I am very happy to see is the tutorial mode. It is by far one of the best tutorial modes I have experienced in any game I've played (although, I am guilty of not completing it). First of all, you can CHOOSE whether you want to do it. And the fact that it teaches new players advanced mechanics is amazing. Smash on the other hand, only shows a video of "how to play" during the title sequence, which is helpful, but fails to help new players in that it's not interactive at all. The one small gripe I have about it is the edge guarding tutorial. For some reason, I cannot, for the life of me, complete it. I can't seem to  get the damn Zetter off the damn stage but whatever. But that's the whole point right? To do it until you do it right. So I guess I can't really complain.

Next are graphics. They're good ,what can I say? Sure it's pixelated, but where it really shines is the effects, like Zetterburn's double damage smash attacks and what not. Seriously, graphics don't make a game, and this is a prime example. 

Finally, my one main problem with this game, MY ONE ISSUE. The recovery. I am a huge HUGE HUGE fan of how wall jumping gets you out of free fall, HOWEVER... The lack of ledges really hurt me. I've come to the conclusion that once you go off the stage, it's literally over if your opponent knows how to edge guard well. And I am aware of Orcane and Sylvanos' recovery, that automatically put them on the stage, but Rivals like Zetterburn and Eliana are done once they're taken off the stage. I honestly think that ledges could fix these issues, so that people could air dodge into them, and have an option to get back onto the stage.

In conclusion, this is slowly becoming one of my favorite games. I can see myself putting many hours into it, like I have in smash 4. Playing a new fighting game of this genre is really refreshing. It makes it even better that I don't have to deal Bayonetta mains, which seriously puts a smile on my face. If this game every gets an HD remake with 3D graphics, I will buy it in a heartbeat, you mark my words. 

P.S. The music is great, but some of the music on the stages can get kind of repetitive. 


(also eliana is bad pls buff)

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Let me preface by saying I love this game. Straight up, if you like Super Smash, Brawlhalla, etc., buy this. I personally can't decide whether or not I prefer this game to smash (and its obviously better than brawlhalla). The game plays and feels a lot better than smash, and the pace is much faster due to the lack of grabs and sheild. 
In all my time playing, I have encountered a single bug in this game (a small graphical error with custom skins against a friend online), that had no effect on the gameplay. In Smash 4, for instance, glitches are strangely common (Especially since I main Dedede who is glitchy af). 
There is, however, a downside to this game. That is the fact that every new character so far is DLC. Don't get me wrong, I bought them ASAP, and will continue to do so, but with such a small roster compared to other games of the same style and genre, having so many of them as DLC is counterproductive if you want to keep the playerbase growing, and keep them playing. In terms of gameplay, I feel this game is superior to Smash 4. Even the characters are better. Each character is very intricate and complex, with many of each characters moves having several effects, uses, and combinations with other moves. Each character is more fleshed out than in smash. Not to mention, smash has characters like Lucina, which is just bad Marth. The characters take more practice, and are just hands down better than those in Smash. 
The game is also much more balanced than smash when it comes to tier lists, with little difference from the bottom-most character to the top-most, and with all characters being viable competetively. But, I am a smash fanboy, and that makes me biased when it comes to saying that this game is better. 
I would rate them as equals, but any way I slice it, ROA seems to come out as being better. I highly recommend. One thing to know beforehand, this game is not for casuals, and FFA games are impossible online due to their matchmaking system. The only way to play FFA is locally, and it doesn't run very well compared to 1v1 matches.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Kragg. The rock is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of theoretical physics most of the potential will go over a typical Kragg main's head. There's also Kraggs pilar recovery, which is deftly woven into his style and overall gameplay mechanics - his playstyle philosophy draws heavily from jank setups and pure salt, for instance. The Kragg masters understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these mechanics, to realize that they're not just high skill outplays- they say something deep about KRAGG AS A CHARACTER. As a consequence people who dislike Kragg are truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humour in Kraggs existencial taunt **C R U N C H**, which itself is a cryptic reference to Dan Fornace's Russian epic Kraggs and Sons I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Dan Fornace's genius unfolds itself on their computer monitors. What fools... how I gimp them. 😂 And yes by the way, I DO have a Kragg tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the Kragg pro's eyes only- And even they have to demonstrate that they're within 300 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand.
