title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is an excellent indie platform fighting game specifically catered toward any player that has a competitive drive for a Super Smash Bros. like fighter.  It boasts a serviceable story mode, a great training mode, as well as an outstanding tutorial mode for any player trying to break into the competitive arena.  The story mode for this game is very typical for fightings games.  It serves as a decent way to get to know the backstory and playstyle of half the roster of characters this game offers.  The only drawback to this mode is that not all the characters are included in it (...Nor are the developers willing to include the other characters in the future).  Only six characters have a route in story mode.  This game is fairly fun casually however it won't last all that long without people to play.  The tutorial mode that this game offers is a great way for newcomers to learn the mechanics of the game.  If you want to play the game competitively, then you would have to complete at least the novice and intermediate portions of this mode to even stand a chance online.  This tutorial mode will show newcomers how to perform multiple super smash bros-like mechanics that fit into the game seamlessly (wavedashing, teching..etc.).  It is really neat how this game has a replay mode, Statistics data sheet, and a custom color mode for each of the characters this game offers.  These modes all really help to give the players all the tools they need to be successful at playing the game. 

        Each of the character designs look fairly detailed and interesting to look at (albeit the DLC characters have alot more effort put into them than the others).  All the characters have their own unique moveset and playstyle.  I would say the roster in general is very well balanced.  Any character is viable competitively in this game (unlike most fighting games).  Some characters are played alot more than others (Be prepared to experience alot of Zetterburn, Clairen, and Ranno play online).  The main draw to this game though is the multiplayer (like Super Smash Bros.).  The online modes are made up of competitive ranked 1vs1, exhibition 1vs1, team match, and free-for-all modes.  My main problem with this game is how inactive the casual team match / free-for-all modes are.  Nobody online plays these modes!  Having casual play would definitely add to this game by giving it more playability and fun factor.  So, if you really like casual play, you're not going to like this game all that much and would need to invite some personal friends over to your place for local matches.  However, the games makes up for the lack of casual modes with the 1vs1 modes.  These modes are absolutely thrilling and incredibly competitive!  

       Online the connection is very dependent on how well you're lag matches up to your opponents'.  When it comes to online matches, you will experience a wide range of ping.  The green ping means that the match has great connectivity, while the yellow means that the lag will somewhat dodgy occasionally but steady.  The red ping generally means that the connection will be very bad.  The online connection for this game is just decent.  Usually, one would be wise to avoid the lag that a red ping connection would give you and play the opponents with the green and yellow.  However, I have had experiences where the red ping players would give me more steadier connections than those with green and yellow strangely enough (vice versa too).  It is always a good idea to just wake up whenever you're side of the world is awake and get on.  Usually, I have more good connections than bad.  Still, the game may have multiple moments where the connection will play smoothly only to be totally interrupted and dropped later on.  With the community as active as is, the online scene will keep the game alive for hundreds upon hundreds of hours in the next few years.  This game has a fairly high learning curve (if you go online, you'll encounter many players who have placed many more hours into the game than you).  You can play on those modes for many, many hours and still not be very good at playing the game!  Keep in mind, this motivates someone like me to learn more about the characters and their matchups.  I highly recommend that newer players who are interested in playing the game competitively interact with the Rivals of Aether community as soon as possible.  The community is fairly friendly and helpful.  You will get better more quickly.  In general, this is a game that is definitely created with mainly the competitive aspect in mind.  If you don't like that, then you likely won't have as fun with the casual modes the game offers...  I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes competitive platform fighting games.   Sorry for the long wall of text.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Ridiculously fast paced and competitive. SSBM players will feel right at home, as there's finally a game for them available worthy of actual competition. The problems that prevent Melee from being a true competitive game on the level of something like Starcraft or Quake don't exist here. The characters are patched, the meta is shifting, and there are ten playable characters instead of 3 (lol).

I cannot recommend this game enough, for LOCAL play. Endless hours of laughs and enjoyment.

HOWEVER: The thing keeping this game from gaining any sort of playerbase is the absolutely horrendous online support. It feels like Rivals of Aether is trapped in a 1991 linux machine, with a dial up connection and adware galore. The online play is absolutely crippling. Every match lags horridly, with constant spikes. Just for frame of refernce, I'm on a Fiber Optic Gigabit connection (1000 GBps up and down). The issue is whenever you connect to another player, if they don't ALSO have very robust internet, it stutters non-stop. It's essentially unplayable.

Buy it if you want a wonderful game to play with friends locally. Don't buy it if you expect to play it online.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
First off, I want to commend the pixel graphics in this game, they're simple and charming. While there is beauty in realism, and you can see the love poured into every frame of Cuphead, there is just something lovely about seeing pixels pulling off the actions unique to this game, and having a unique feel despite it obviously being inspired by Super Smash Bros. I have a soft spot for pixel art in games with enough difficulty to make you sweat, like Hyper Light Drifter, so the moment I saw the style I immediately took a shot with it, and I was NOT dissapointed. 

Secondly, I did not come here making an review because I am super excellent at the crazy combos you can manage to pull off, or because I'm great at competitive. I come writing a review because this game seriously made me fall in love with the platform fighting genre. It drew me in with the characters and graphics, and it's kept me hooked, even though I most certainly get bodied every time I even attempt competitive. So, even if I am what you would call a casual player, I most certainly would recommend it, because there's joy to be found in taking time to learn the techniques, so that someday, you can go toe to toe with the best of em.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Fun fighter/brawler game - it's a 2d fighting game heavily influenced by the Smash Brothers series (though 2D, and with pixel art). While the game introduces you to Smash Brothers style fighting and lingo through some extensive tutorials, I can't say how faithful it is to the formula, because I've played almost no smash brothers.

I can say that throwing rocks at someone's face as the earth turtle Kragg, having it rebound, and then punching the rock in midair to shower the enemy with shards of the rock that just hit their face is great fun, as is jumping backwards through the air as the fire lion Zetterburn, only to kick behind myself into the enemy. All the characters have cool, unique and fun moves.

I've mostly just played singleplayer - the AI isn't super great, I'm a terrible player with old man reflexes and can beat it pretty much every time, but the single player game is still challenging because of time attack goals and endless mode.

The one multiplayer game I played tells me the netcode is rock solid - my current internet is utterly horrible, with lag spikes, packetloss, and all the bad stuff, but the match was still playable. I look forward to playing more multiplayer once I no longer have horrible internet.

The one thing I most wish for in the game is the ability to skip the tutorial parts I can't do, so I can see if there are any moves I should be aware of afterward. I also thought the story mode could have done a better job providing context for its fights.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Note that I have played both this game and Smash 4 competitively.
My humble review of Super Smash Bros Melee... with furries.

Visuals:
The graphics arent the best and are stylized towards a pixely look. This isnt a bad thing because it doesnt take a very good computer to run this game. When I was watching this game I thought the graphocs were to simple for me to figure out what was going on and what move the players were doing, but this never ended up being a problem.

Music:
The music is fantastic. Thats all I really have to say. If you dont like the music though, you can add custom music to the game.

Sound design:
The sound design in this game is fantastic! When Maupul does her strong attacks the whiping sound is clear; when Ranno  hits his sweet spot forward air there is a satisfing thud; and when sylvanos gets his tipper up strong you hear a very deep thump. All of the sounds in this game make it satisfying to do what you are supposed to and help a lot in terms of helping the player differentiate some parts of moves from the other.

Gameplay:
(Im gonna break this down into multiple sections)
-Character balance:
all of the characters are relatively balanced. Sometimes the tier list will rear its ugly head but any character has a good chance against another.
-Movement:
coming from smash 4 (where there was no advanced movement) I was scared that things like wavedashing and wavelanding would be too hard to learn and implement into my gamplay. But it wasnt that hard to learn what i needed to.
-Characters:
this game has the best designed characters out of ANY fighting game ive played! I remember that it was crazy in smash 4 when Mega Man had a projectile for his jab. Well the characters in this game have so much depth and are so unique that it puts any other fighting game to shame. In other games I cant stand playing any character other than my main or secondary. But in this game (I main Maypul) I love (not like, LOVE) playing Maypul, Slvanos, Forsburn, Ranno, Wrastor and Clairen. And Those are the only characters Ive tried out in my 72 hours pf playing and I am looking to try out more. And learning all of these characters arent hard because of the amazing indepth guides that are in the game.
-Flow:
the flow of the game is a lot more fast paced than other games and I like that. Its flashy and satisfying to pull of a cool combo.

I would 100% give this game a yes to anyone I ever meet.
PS - you dont need a controller to be good at this game :)

The community are actually really cool and teach newcomers how to play. Even the tutorial mode is robust and does a awesome job explaining things. Overall a great fighting game I'd recommend fully.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is an amazing Smash Bros.-esque platform-fighter which changes the formula a little bit. The best way I can describe it is a faster-paced Melee with no shielding, grabbing (though command grabs do exist), or ledges. Instead, Rivals replaces shielding with a mechanic called parrying, basically a counter from the Smash series, which puts the opponent in a stun state. This single mechanic makes the game far more agressive than Melee and gives the game a flare of its own. It has competitive tournaments, both online and local, and has both online and local multiplayer, though right now online is only 1 v. 1 which will be changed to 4 player online play somtime in the future, hopefully. The game is constantly being balanced to make sure that every character is viable in a tournament setting. If you like platform fighters, the Smash Bros. series, or are just looking for a game to play with you friends, I recommend you play this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Great Game. Unique mechanics, like the parrying system. Blocking is too overrated and is in too much games. I beat a guy called Dragon Splicer so hard he wrote a negative review. title: Rivals of Aether
review:
You can clap on the haters with Wrastor. 10/10

--Serious bit--
Really good game! There are a lot of similarites to Super Smash Bros. but this game is no way a clone. Each character has their own ability (ie. Wrastor has a slip stream that increases his speed and Zetterburn's fire increases knockback by 2x (plz nerf)). Each character can also perform a parry attack by perfect guarding an attack. Depending on the attack, the opponent is either left unable to move for a short period of time or the attack is reflected back at them. There are still a lot of balancing issues, such as Zetterburn's fire as it can result in a KO at ~50% - 60% from the center of multiple maps. Other than that, this is a fantastic game that should be given a try.

TL;DR
9/10 - Great game, needs more balance patches

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
What can I say about Rivals of Aether ... It has taken up a key role in my circle of friends replacing smash 4 after the newness wore off but we didn't want to go back to playing melee.  500+ hours and 1000's and 1000's of local matches later I don't see it going away any time soon. It has lived through the rise and fall of many other fighting games during its tenure in my game room.   

+  fast:  We love it because the action is fast, its fun to spectate, and the game favors aggressive strategies
+  balanced:  There is a meta, but the characters are so close in balance that I wouldn't say anyone is the "worst", at least at the level we are capable of playing the game at.
+  community:  The developers and players are a tight knit community, often raising money to sponsor tournaments or to help their own.  This has always been something that seems to really shine about the platform fighter genre.
-  engine:  The game is built on game maker which leaves a little bit to be desired. the controls have improved immensely since launch, but the net code is iffy.  Even playing netplay with people that live in the same city as me is hit or miss.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is super fun! I came into it with basically no experience with platform fighters (I just like furry characters, aha), but I was able to pick it up pretty quickly! The tutorials do a fantastic job of teaching you just about everything you need to know when it comes to playing the game, down to more advanced techniques that are pretty vital if you decide to venture into online matches.

A few pros:
-If you like a story mode, it's got one! It does a good job of giving you a taste of each of the featured characters' personalities.
-You'll get a lot of playtime out of trying to complete all the single player stuff, if that's your sort of thing.
-You can set a custom palette for each fighter (and a second if you unlock it) meaning you'll never run into an exact duplicate online, or be forced to choose a different color from your favorite one.
-The community is pretty friendly, and welcoming to new players! There's even a group dedicated to helping them improve.

A few cons:
-The aforementioned story mode is pretty basic, and only covers 6 of the full 13-character roster. It mostly exists as a sort of time trial with some story bits mixed in.
-Even though the single player options will take you a while to finish, there's really only two of them. Three if you count versus mode against an AI, but-
-The AI isn't really that good, even at max level. It's VERY good at parrying and teching, but not so much at anything else.
-As with all fighting games, it can be hard to find someone online in random matches who isn't insanely better than you when you're starting out. With this, and the above point, it's really recommended you play this with a friend for a while, or look into the group I mentioned earlier.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game has the potential to be good but the biggest problem thats driving me away is the lag online. Even on a green bar, if you're lucky evough to find someone on green bar, it freezes and/or frame skips. The characters are unique and are fun experimenting with on practice mode but when you hop online you're met with lagging games that are impossible to play. Its hard for a new player like myself to learn the game and its mechanics when I'm being juggled in the air all game be a low connection wrastor. I think this game on local multiplayer will be a lot of fun and the games won't be as irritating. So if you're looking for a SSBM like game to play locally with friends I recommend this but the online play is too bad right now to suggest buying it for online play.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like the competitive aspect of Smash, you might wanna squat over the toilet before you play this game because your naughty bits are about to resemble Gullfoss.
</bad_joke>

Rivals Of Aether is an exceptionally well-made platform brawler that, on the surface, resembles Smash very much. But it has its key, game-changing differences that make it stand out as its own thing. 

Shields and spot-dodging are replaced with a parry system, ledge grabbing is replaced with a wall jump system that allows you to use your recovery twice and still manages to not be broken, Smash attacks are relegated to their own button and grabbing is done away with entirely. Keep in staples such as Melee style air dodging and wave dashing, throw in interesting new character designs with a unique playstyle for each one, and you have a fantastic and different entry in a genre of game that sorely needs more original content. 

I picked up the core game during a sale and bought all the DLC when it was on a later sale for the release of the latest DLC, which I paid for full price. That's aproximately $17.50. I feel like this is a good value. Compare this to $35 for just the DLC characters in Smash 4, not including the $60 or $40 base game depending on what system you buy it on.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Full disclosure: I was part of the early beta testing period before the game went into Early Access. Take that for what you will.

Rivals of Aether is arguably the best platform fighter that wasn't made by Nintendo. Dan Fornace and his team have a clear understanding of what the competitive Smash Bros. community enjoys about platform fighters while making the game more accessible to newcomers. While most of the playable characters are amalgamations of pre-existing Smash Bros. characters, they at least have some unique mechanics in their move-sets that help them stand out. My favorite characters thus far are the ones that are wholly unique to this game. There's a reason why Orcane is the de facto mascot. 

Having said that, the single player content is a bit lacking. The story mode was clearly an afterthought, with each of the characters' individual chapters consisting of five quick matches before you get to the final boss. Kragg and Wrastor's campaigns in particular feel like what would normally be one scene in any other video game being stretched out and padded over several cutscenes.

Abyss Mode is where all the single-player effort went into. It's essentially all the bonus challenges in previous Smash Bros games mashed into a gauntlet-style challenge mode. You earn experience to level up your character and unlock various abilities with the coins you obtain from playing the game in general. Unfortunately, it's a huge grind to max out a single character's level and unlock all their runes if you do this by yourself. You can speed this up through local multiplayer, but I hardly have anyone to test that out with. A form of online multiplayer would've been neat.

Overall, if you want the taste of Smash Bros but you can't/won't get a Nintendo console, this will satisfy your cravings.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game rocks. It takes what made Smash Bros Melee great, and refines them to make a great competitive fighting game (Not saying that Melee isn't a good competitive game, but it wasn't intentionally designed that way is what I mean). The characters are all unique from each other and are well balanced to boot, and it's just a good time all around. It's hard to master, but very satisfying to play.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A perfect game for both casual and competitive Super Smash Bros. players. The graphics may not seem as detailed as the Smash Bros. games on consoles, but the art and alternative color schemes are awesome. For game play, many techniques from Melee incorporated into Rivals of Aether, there is a smooth transition between those games. Balance is relatively equal, and combos are fun. Not the biggest fan of Tempest Peak as a map though. But the rest of the maps have nice varying blast zones that some might want to know for competitive play. Overall, this game is super fun, and it supports the Smash Bros. scene. Would recommend to anyone looking for a new or familiar type of 2D fighting game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
While I can't say much for the playerbase, as it seems far and few between, I can say that the design, mechanics, and quality of the game are that of someone who deeply cares for this genre. I absolutely loved playing through the story mode, though I wish the final level wasn't as confusing. If you like Super Smash, Brawlhalla, or any fighting game for that matter, then you will love this game. Just, make sure you get yourself a controller as the keyboard doesn't quite do the game justice. That being said, using the keyboard isn't any less smooth. Truly a game worth your time and for a cheap price, if you're willing to play with only the base characters. The unlockable characters are purchased through DLC, and that's my only beef with the game.

If you wish to hear more, I'll tell you my experience of the game when I first started playing. I saw a YouTuber playing it and thought it looked pretty fun, and to my surprise it was even more fun than I expected. I started in multiplayer, which was a bit of a mistake because I knew none of the mechanics, I figured my Super Smash knowledge would suffice, but there are quite a few differences that really polish this game. So I decided I would try my hand at the story mode, just to get a feel for the characters, and that's exactly what it is designed for. The story mode will prove challenging enough for the first-timer but get easier between levels as you learn the moves of the character. There is also no penalty aside from adding a minute to your timer when you die. You can even compete with others through the story's time trials. Once I learned the characters, I hopped into multiplayer again and did much better, but still got my ass kicked. It wasn't frustrating, though, as those people have been playing for a while I imagine. I just kept at it and eventually learned how to do a lot more. There are times it feels like bullshit, but you just have to keep trying and you'll learn how to combat it. At no point did I ever feel like quitting. I wanted to keep rematching the same person over and over again so I could improve. There are not many games that can do that to me.

If I were to rate the game, I'd give it a solid 9/10. The only problems I faced were ping issues from people in my region, but there was luckily a setting to change the region, so I was able to keep playing with other people who didn't have such a bad ping. The other problem is the issue of DLC. I don't like that I have to pay $5 per character unlock. I can understand where the developer is coming from, they have to make their money somehow, but I don't personally want to spend the money. I wish the in-game coins could be used with the option of the DLC adding certain skins, that would make the game more enjoyable in my opinion. That way I could play all of the characters. Also, those characters aren't available for practice if you don't own the DLC, just to test them out, and there is no story mode with them as far as I can tell, but I haven't purchased them, so I can't say with 100% confidence that that is the case. It might just be something I can't see until I buy the DLC. Either way, I don't like that you have to pay $5 for a character unlock. I would pay that for only skins if anything. But those are really minor issues that don't affect the overall enjoyment of the game. You can easily play with someone who has around 150 ping, anything higher and you'll notice the lag a lot, but again you can just switch regions to play with people who have better ping. Really, a truly amazing game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is a great indie fighting game. Dan Fornace took the machanics from SSBM and amplified their competitive feel, making exploits into mechanics (alla the wavedash) and making certain techniques that seemed impossible to concistently pull off much easier. The game also is much better optimized for competitive play. The smash bros games were always made to be party games. This makes the competitive scene in any game very wonky, with a roster of unbalanced characters and movement exploits that will give you carpel tunnel when you try to pull them off (despite being basic parts of high-level play). Dan Fornace takes this formula and enhances it greatly. Every character is given a moveset inspired by various top teir characters from SSBM, with each character having a different feel and playstyle. Also, each character has the potential to win high-level tournaments (In each smash game, there are only a select few characters that have this potential). The competitive scene is much more accessible compared to SSBM while still having the same feel and rhythm. I think this game is a great fighting game and deserves  all the love it gets.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
To be fair, this game is awesome. The pixel art is amazing. The fighting system is fun and the natural progression of skill is very satisfying.

Now we get to the reason I wouldn't recommend this game. The community. If you didn't know, fighting game communities are easily the most difficult to get into. The playerbase is more often than not negligible in its size, so only the most seasoned tryhard veterans remain, and believe me, they do not hold back. No type of fighting game is more guilty of this than the "Smash-like", and RoE is about as close to Smash as you can get on PC. The playerbase is so small that the best matchmaking system possible wouldn't help in the slightest (not that there is one in this game), so unless you are one of those seasoned Smash veterans or you are planning on playing almost exclusively with friends, this game will fill you with nothing but salt.

Otherwise 10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Ya like Jazz? This game is in many ways Smash but more Close quarters action and in my opinon, much easier to pick up as a new player. As a long time fan of smash im sure you will be all to familiar with shielding to defend yourself from attacks. In this game however its replaced with a parry that stuns the opponent for a short time based on how powerful the attack was. I hated it at first but now its very rewarding to time the parry just right and then finish them off with a smash attack. The game truly shines in its small linear maps with excellent opportunities to combo your opponent. The characters all have different play styles with different kinds of abilities that feel very unique. This includes, traps, stuns, bleeds, teleporting, Ice armor, suspending foes in a bubble and much much more. Rivals of Aether takes what makes smash so addicting and fun and makes it even more Lets get stoned and play some smaaasshh. I have 60 hours in the game so far and I bet by the next time i revisit this review ill have 100+. 
                                        

                                           Overall: 9/10     Would highly reccomend.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like Smash Bros, then you will enjoy this game as well.
The characters are all very different; their movesets are unique and fun to explore.
The game has a great combo system that (at first) takes some getting used to but it feels very satisfying when you land them.
Don't get discouraged if you get bodied in online matches. There are enough single player and/or local co-op modes to have you entertained as well.
Rivals of Aether has great music, solid gameplay and is a fantastic 'love letter' to the Smash games.
Highly recommended for fans of this genre.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Heard about this by chance. Boy am I glad I did. Because at this point, I realized it's better than Super Smash Brothers - y'know, the big indie platform fighting game that really got the genre going.

The roster is small, but creative and fairly balanced. The art style is simple but lovely. The music is to die for (ty Flashy Goodness!) It's easy enough to learn but hard to master. Tutorials are there for the game in general and each character (even if you haven't purchased them!) Story mode is lacking, but was a requested feature the devs honored. Abysss mode adds a fun way to practice, as well as challenge, custom moves, and general replayablillty, even in a crazy/casual matches.

Quick, high-skill movement (wave-dashing) is made accessable to players like me at a relatively low learning curve. I know I'm not that good, especially agaisnt any skillled people, but I can still feel rather good at the game in general. It's an amazing experience.

Also, normal modes and hazard modes of stages is toggleable - play only with combatants and the ground provided, or around dangerous (but fair!) world hazards. Custom colors for characters is a great addition. And if you're interested in supporting the developers, fancy skins like American Wraster are available for cheap too.

It lacks some polish here and there, most notably with limited multiplayer options online, but I'm sure that as the game continues to be supported that concern can be addressed as well. I've bought all DLC and one skin, bought the game for two friends (including some DLC), and convinced another to buy it. I hope I've helped convince you as well.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1] Rivals of Aether pixel art fighting game which is fun to play and hard to master. This game has many fun modes to keep you going for hours and an online mode to prove your skill against people around the world [/h1]

[b] Graphics and system requirements [/b]
This games  style is amazing with fluid animations. Every cutscene, menu and movement has animation which makes the game very immersive and fun. This game has very low requirements so anybody can boot it up on any system.

[b] Difficulty [/b]
Just as all fighting games. The difficulty completaly relies on what you do. The game is fun and easy if you are playing the singleplayer but you can easily go herdcore and try to face people in competetibe battles.

[b] Game length [/b]
The main story in this game is max 2 hours but considering the story is like 1% of any fighting game, this game is endless. You can spend hundreds to tens of thousands of hours to become the best or just spend a little bit unlocking some characters and get destroyed the second you go online.

[b] Bugs/ glitches [/b]
There are no bugs or glitches which I have come across which is good.

[b] Extra content [/b]
This game has lots of extra content with tuns of maps and characters but the bad part is every character is over $1 and there are no bundles. But i'm not complaining since $1 for a whole new character to master is really cheap.

[b] Overall [/b]
Overall this game is amazing and I recommend it to anyone who likes fighting games.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
[table]
    [tr]
        [td]content[/td]
        [td]7/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]graphics[/td]
        [td]8/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]replayability[/td]
        [td]7/10[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]
and my final score is
[b] 7.3/10 [/b]

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1]~REVIEW~[/h1]

I adore this game. Smash is what got me into the fighting genre and I hold that game dear. It helped me branch out into SF, Tekken, BB, GG, UNIEL, Skullgirls, etc. I picked this game up in early access around 2015 if I'm not mistaken and played with it a little, but at the time I was very heavy into SM4SH, Melee, and Project M, so I let it sit around. With the announcement of Smash for Switch, I got the urge to play some Smash/Smashish games and looked through my list. I remembered I had this and installed it alongside brawlhalla, Melee, PM, and a few others. I booted this up, setup my mayflash GC adapter and off we went. 

I haven't gotten this much enjoyment out of a game in a very, very long time. I happened to pick it up again around the time of Sylvanos and Elliana launched and it couldnt have been timed any better. The game feels polished, fast, easily played on all systems just about, and has something thats been lacking in a lot of recent games imo which is fun and hype. 

[h1]~PROS~[/h1]

[list]
[*] Super fun characters
[*] Custom skins
[*] Hype combat
[*] Uses Smash techs. (Wavedashing + etc)
[*] Platform fighter
[*] Pretty Balanced
[*] Melee Like
[*] Awesome pixel art
[*] Great soundtrack
[*] Incredibly fun to play online and off
[*] Easy to pick up, hard to master
[*] All characters can parry
[*] Awesome technical combos if you're willing to invest the time
[/list]

[h1]~CONS~[/h1]

[list]
[*] 13 Characters as of [4/14/18], this is more of a want than a con. The characters in game are flushed out and great as is.
[*] Cannot get a lot of custom DLC costumes if purchased recently or missed previous opportunities. Excalibur Akin/Shine Skin/Genesis Skin/etc.
[/list]

[h1]~CLOSING~[/h1]

It has the hype and pacing of melee while being its own unique fighter with epic characters and a great design. The only con I have is I wish there was more! This game could really keep up with smash if it got a bit of a bigger roster and a fleshed out story. (No slight at all against the small dev team, they are talented ballers as far as I'm concerned.) Good platform fighters are rare... we pretty much wait on Nintendo. It would be awesome for RoA to fill the gap that Nintendo refuses to fill, such as Melee style tech in newer games and competitive competition at the core of the game. This is a fantastic competitive game as well and I really hope to see a RoA 2, or hell make another edition with some upgrades in the future, either way, I need more RoA in my life. 

I honestly wish I would have played this game seriously sooner.

~ Really tho, its a great drinking game and fun as hell to play with friends or solo online.~

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is a very Super Smash Melee feeling game with a lot of unique charaters and interesting mechanics.
You can find a lot of enjoyment and from the online casual macthes and the net code is not bad in my opinion at all. I do have some gripes but every game has something here or there that could be improved on and may already be being worked on.
-PROS-
~Fast paced
~Fun Game play
~Familiar controls to Melee players
~Satisfying combos and kill moves
~Beautiful pixel art from head to toe
~Very smooth

-Cons-
~Roaster is a bit lacking but they are releasing even more characters.
~People can select whatever region online they want making for cross world connection. AKA Laggy at times.
~Not Super beginner friendly. (Do not let that one deter you though! Come newbies!)
~Besides 8 characters there are pay walls to get the others.

Overall. 
Game play- 9/10
Art style- 10/10
Net code- 7/10

Final - 8.5/10 I would recommend this!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
At the time of writing this review, i have only had 5 hours on this game, and already im having a blast playing it. Yes. The game IS a smash bros-like game, however it doesnt feel like it is anything like smash brothers. 

Each character has got a really unique ability, and while there are very little characters to play as, new characters always has some new interesting specials, or a really cool ability.
Some examples are:
Zetterburn can do more damage with his strong attacks if the enemy has been burned by his attacks.
Wrastor can only use his strong attacks in mid air, which honestly balances out any characters that have >2 jumps.
Elliana has a machine that needs to cool down, and as you use it and it starts to overheat, you can shoot steam, to cool it down.
Clairen has a tipper effect similar to Marth's, but this time she stuns the opponent for a bit. 
Ranno has a poison effect, pretty sure it causes ranno to do more damage? (not sure)
Maypul can recover to any character which has been affected by one of her attacks, similar to burn, but no damage overtime. 


While the game does have a really unique cast, as the game stands, its way too overpriced. 
The main reason is because there arent many characters, so for the moment the game is overpriced honestly. Also, even though the games initial price is overpriced, the devs still decide to add new characters, that you have to pay £4 to get. Most of the time it is 2 characters though but honestly, i think you should be able to atleast buy them for an unreasonable amount of coins in game anyways, so then:
1. Players will try to play for longer just to get the character
2. Players won't be let down for not being able to play any of the DLC characters.

However im sure that in the future when there will be much more characters, aside from the default 8 characters, there will be a rotation where you can play 2 characters for a week.

Overall the game is really unique, the characters dont feel the same when you play them and each character is fun. However not worth the money though so i recommend to wait for a discount.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Loved the game at first. Played through story mode quite a bit and it was great, but there are a few things I can't get over.

1. Not a huge deal, but a ranking system would be great. The competitive community around this game is a barrier to entry for new players. Not noob friendly at all. Matchmaking needs work.

2. Here's where you lost me: the new characters are behind a pay wall. Each one is $5.00, so if you want the full experience, the price of the game is doubled at this point. I did the training mode and really liked the gameplay of Ori and Sein, and what's that? I have to pay for the newest update I've been anxiously waiting for? Nice tease, but I'm out.

It pains me to say I can't reccommend this game. I loved it at first, but there are some things that really bug me, and a fighting game that has new characters come out for $5 a pop is one of them. I'm the guy that buys games a year later because I want the complete edition. I do NOT like the feeling of paying for something and not getting the full experience. Look, I get it, it's only $30 altogether, but it's a matter or principle.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is absolutely astounding! Constant updating, developers know what they're doing, and great fun. If you've ever played smash bros., You'll like it. If you've enjoyed competitive Melee, you'll love it. If you've enjoyed competitive melee but felt all the hidden tech and exhausting inputs were scary or would take too long to master, you'll adore it and sacrifice Brawl discs in its name. Even if you've never played a smash-style fighting game, this is a great way to start.

Pros

easy on the eye graphics
incredibly responsive controller support
All the things you loved from smash, with the "bad" things removed and replaced with even better things
a competitive game that is still friendly to newcomers and casuals while helping and appreciating the veterans and devoted
compotent online systems and interface
characters are carefully optimized and constructed for balanced, unique, and riveting gameplay
new mechanics for smash veterans to adapt to, while still being familiar
characters combine classic characters from smash while introducing new "Gimmicks" that change the way you play entirely
You can play online or with friends. Local play with friends turns into a ritualistic pastime. Playing online helps you gauge how good you are, and there's always practice mode to figure out confirms and interesting tricks. Don't be afraid to buy this if you can't play with others locally, practice with the coms till you have a good grasp (don't forget the tutorial that is equally informative to complete newcomers and Melee gods), then go online and test yourself.
A new base game that will have you discovering new things well after 100 hours
Dan Fornace is very active in the community and is responsive to criticism and, as mentioned, applies input into frequent updates
cool "Make your own outfit" option I never saw coming
After playing through the turorials and getting a hang on how the game works, hidden tech and mechanics come very organically and a frame display in practice mode will teach you anything you didn't learn otherwise.
Awesome music (especially the airships)
great stages with a sort of "Omega" switch that makes them more tourney-legal, and base stages with fun and wacky active factors.

Cons

Graphics can be described as simplistic and certain frames during animations can look pretty wierd
DLC is necessary for a little less than half the cast
because it's this type of game, regular keyboard controls are probably foreign and confusing (Although I've only used keyboard maybe once or twice, so I'm not even sure on that)
Although it is much better than earlier versions, there is still just enough lag in some matches that can trip up your inputs and cost you the game, but still better than sm4sh's average online experience.
Some say the game can be a bit scary to newcomers and is really meant for smash players looking for a new game or migratory melee players. I don't believe so myself, but I've been playing smash my whole life so I may have a bias.

This game deserves a lot more attention and praise. Truly a game that is easy to pick up, but difficult to master. The Pros vastly outweigh the cons, not to mention all these cons may be removed with the constant updates the game gets. I beg everyone to pick this game up, and if you like it, spread it as much as possible. There is a community, but mostly people that have played from the game's start on early access. Spread this game as much as possible to all gamers!

P.S.:  Not exculsively for furries

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Honestly,i don't know what i expected from a game that looks 1990ish.
Apart from the, almost 8bit graphics, you get a soundtrack that is...cutlery with...eggs that are being fried in the oil? Honestly, i am not kidding.

The combat, oh boy. Wanna play with controller as any good'ol brawlers? Well, good luck, cause this is NOT that game.
The combat focuses heavily on timing and button presses, and honestly, keyboard feels more satisfying than controller. 

Secondly, there is not much explained about combat. I got to the Intermediate "tutorial" where i need to stop an NPC, to reach the platform.The game gives you a hint: you need to hit him hard down. Well, problem is, you cannot. The guy channels his special, gets a flame shield around him, and, lands on the platform. And, that's all, you get to see it repeat that, over and over and over.

Story wise, there are, 5maps with 5 stages, if i remember correctly. And 1 map is basicly the "mega boss", But, it's kinda a clusterfuck (sorry for expression), since you basicly need to avoid laser beams, missiles and constant dark heroes that spawn. At some point, the eyes start exploding the whole platform you are on, and they can be surrounded by some dark spooky energy, that basicly deals too much dmg to deal with. Oh, at some point i had like, 4 enemies on the map. I had no idea where the hell i was. (Did i mention that it also deals a MASSIVE BLAST on the whole platform, instakilling you?)

Multiplayer: Internet:1v1
                   Lan:up to 4 players
That's......that's it. 


The game feels rushed and it feels like it should be in beta version still.
I will keep an eye on it, since i really like one of the characters, and i do hope that in the future, i will change my review.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Ever wanted to play smash, but also have fun? Welp, here it is! Honestly such a great game and does the platform fighting formula RIGHT!. =] 10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
10/10

I remember the first time I heard of Rivals of Aether. I wrote it off as an attempt to cash in on the hype with Smash, and I thought to myself "Those pixel graphics looks awful"

Boy was I ever wrong. I absolutely adore this game. Even more so than it's inspiration at this point. I love the characters, I love the lore, I love the music, and I especially love the gameplay. Rivals of Aether does so much with so little. It took what made Smash Bros great and added a layer of techincality and aesthetic that absolutely works to the game's advantage. Every character is unique, fun to play, and great to look at. The music gets you excited, and fits their respective characters and stages very well. I love the music to the point where I actually bought the OST. The stages are all designed to be tournament legal, and the "gimicks" provided in the casual version of the stages make for interesting casual play. I have never played a fighting game and felt like I don't have a main, but this is the first time that I feel like I can't decide on a character because they're all so fun to play. Every time you think you've figured out a character you find new tech, or some sort of creative way to use their moveset. 

The developers and community are wonderful as well. Dan makes an active effort to communicate with the community over timeframes of upcoming content, The devs constantly post art on twitter and are very active within the competitive scene. For the skill required for this game, I've never come across a sour community member on twitter, reddit, etc. 

Even the skins are cool. Every single premium skin released is great to look at, and adds a unique taunt. The plushies sold award gold skins and are cool to look at. I even used the Orcane plushie to help teach a lesson about volume to elementary schoolers. The only real complaint I have about skins is that some are hard to come by, such as Twitch Absa and Excalibur Zetterburn, and in the case of the Gameboy Early Access skins, no longer available to get.

Rivals of Aether is the first indie game I've ever bought. Ever. While the learning curve is steep, the game feels very rewarding to play with others and is a shining example of what indie developers should aspire towards. Thanks to Dan and the Team for making one of the best fighting games I've ever played.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A very good game. I enjoy the music on it, I've been a fan of Flashygoodness since Tower of Heaven. In terms of gameplay, I call it a good "test the waters" for Smash Bros since not everyone will dish out cash for an old console and game just to try it out. If you wanna try out the genre, this is a good place to do it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you're into platform fighters like Super Smash Bros, you should definitely check this game out-and even not, you might just have a blast. The characters are rather creative, and follow an almost Arcsys-esque design concept philosophy. However, players that are more familiar to the Smash series may discover difficulties in adapting to the game's more offensive playstyle, which takes away the shield and grab mechanics for a parry system, and the ledge mechanics for a complex walljump-based recovery game. But, if you're willing to put the effort into it, or if you're just picking up the game to chill out with your friends, you'll still have a blast.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game, in the limited time i've played it, has given me a great impression. Everything just 'fits in', the art and animations, the characters, and all related to that. However, the mechanics are unique in such a way that they feel quite clunky until you get used to them.

Unfortunately, one thing that stuck out so very much to me was the community. The way newbie players are matched with people with hundreds of hours. This is an issue with some other games, and usually ended up with an extremely limited community that has a toxicity equivalent to or greater than League Of Legends and are all exceptionally skilled to the point where new players are immediately turned off. (See titanfall 2.)

There are some neat solo modes though, they're pretty fun. AI is a bit wonky but it's pretty good without being too easy or too difficult.

DLC characters seem a bit more capable of extremely destructive combos, but that might just be that i'm bad. Also i'd like to express my dislike of gameplay elements costing money, i'd personally be more interested and willing to buy cosmetics.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
My experience with this game:

First time: Some friends turned it on during out weekly Smash Bros night. They completely destroyed me and I had no idea what I was doing. Thought it was really hard and my pride was wounded.

Second time: Downloaded a demo on Xbox and played with a different friend who'd never played it. He beat me almost every time. Pride wounded even more.

In the meantime: Purchased and played through Ori and the Blind Forest (10/10 by the way, beautiful game and a must-have)

Third time: Friends decided to turn it on again for Smash Bros night. I chose Ori and started wiping the floor with KO's and actually won a few times. Turns out they did a freakishly good job of replicating Ori's playstyle in this game. I think I succesfully performed more spikes in those three hours than I think I've ever done in my entire Smash Bros career in the same amount of time played. I was good enough that my friend, who leads the weekly event, told me he's not sure that Clairen is his main anymore after going up against me as Ori and that I'm officially a contender for the crown with Rivals of Aether.

On my third time playing it. 

Ever.

All because I played Ori and the Blind Forest between games. That's how good the devs did with her.

10/10 would suprise the h*ck out of my friends again with this surprisngly well-made game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is worth your money. If you like smash you owe it to yourself to give Rivals a chance. In some ways I actually prefer the mechanics in Rivals over smash. You cannot grab (couple of the characters have unique moves which act as a grab) or sheild and wavedashing is incredibly easy. These changes really speed up the pace of matches. At first the game will feel a bit stiff in your hands, but once you see how much control you have over the characters you'll be landing crazy combos in no time. I have many hours on the xbox one version and many more on friends computers. If you have a friend who loves Smash, pick this game up. 

To be clear, this game won't replace Smash. It is a solid addition to the genre. If Smash is Dark Souls, Rivals is Bloodborne. A little faster and no sheilds.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I've tried some fighter type games in the past but realized I didn't want to invest so much time in memorizing arbitrary button combos. If you know anything about this game, you know it's more like smash, all characters have some specials that function differently, but if you know any of the characters you know the basics of how to play them all. Attacks "combo" into one another in the sense that "oh hey, it makes sense to punch up after I hit him with my dash and it knocks him into the air a little" etc. but there's never any just memorizing a random string of buttons.

The tutorials on this game are great too, they explicity explain the mechanics of the game, basic tutorials, and in depth character by character tutorials. You can pick this game up and know how to play it in 5 minutes, yet there's a depth to the mechanics that will take you a long time to master.

Expect a learning curve if you want to get competetive online, but the solo modes are fun to play too. Just grab a friend and convince them to play if you want a noobie on your level to spar with.

I'd looked into the game before getting it, and saw the normal complaints of "this game is dead/imbalanced/etc." The fact is, these guys are still very much supporting the game. There was just a patch and two new characters. I've never had trouble getting online matches either.

TL;DR - I'm new, and getting my ass handed to me online, but the game is so well made, and the business model is respectable/reasonable/straight forward enough that I'm happy to support these guys and invest some time to "get good".

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Update: The roster expands. My point about the roster is now rather irrelevant.

So I've been meaning to pick this game up for a while, finally got around to it. It's pretty damn good.

At this point, you probably know what it is. It's a Smash-Like game with some nice pixel art, catchy
music, and elemental animal-like characters instead of guest characters like Smash.

What's good?
-It looks awesome.
-The music is pretty catchy.
-All the characters are fun and interesting to play, and feel relatively well balanced.
-Gameplay is enough like Smash to feel familiar, but unique enough to feel refreshing.
The combos in this particular game are very fun and solid feeling to string together, and
there's a good enough balance between power and speed to make each character feel like
they have a good variety of options. Plus, there are a few major differences to Smash, namely,
no blocking, but instead you can parry, to temporarily slow your enemy for counter attacks.
-Though it's nothing major, there's a little story for each character with some nice artwork to boot,
an Abyss mode to challenge for fun that you can do with a friend, and local multiplayer of course
is always a blast with a good friend or two.
-Nice little features such as custom colour palettes for each character.

What's eh?
-The roster is not huge like the recent Smash titles. At present, we see 8 playable characters, which is fine, because it means each character has a good variety of ways to play and there isn't many balance issues from a normal players perspective. However, for those who like large character
rosters, this isn't the title, even with two more characters coming.
-The story mode won't last you long (I beat the entire thing casually in around half an hour), and the Abyss Mode gets stale after a bit because it's a lot of the same repeated challenges. These
aside, you have your standard normal and online matches, which are fun, but not particularly deep for those looking for variety.
-For whatever reason, you now need to buy non-base characters with an easy to obtain in-game
currency. This presents no challenge as the money comes from practically every mode and is plentiful, but it seems unneccessary, and some of the alternate stages you can buy feel unneccessarily barred.
-Online play is kinda hit or miss. To my understanding, it's a p2p connection, so sometimes it's great, other times it's terrible, and apperantely it's hard to find matches sometimes with just random searches.
Overall?
An awesome game, in my opinion, the best Smash like game on PC emulation. It's an absolute blast
to play once you get the hang of it, with satisfying combos and cool characters. It's best played with friends locally, and though the single player isn't particularly big, it's a bit of fun for a short while.
Overall, 8.3/10, very solid and fun game, can't wait to play Greninja. I mean Zenyatta. I mean FROGGO

Concerning RoA as a whole, it has provided me with 70+ hours of fun with friends and my twin brother. The characters are amazing, balanced and viable. The game is fast-paced, but it doesn`t overwhelm you like melee has often done for me, and it makes you feel amazing when you string the cool combos you have practiced in a match. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Already posted under the new DLC, but I really want this to get to the team.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

These are really fun characters, and yes, even though we just got them, these characters have a lot of potential. They seem to be real game changers and their gimmicks feel really fun and worth using. Also, these characters have some amazing character designs, showing you how much the team has really improved since the very beginning, and how much heart they pour into it. Dan, Ellian, Ranno, Flashy and the rest of the team, awesome job! You guys really nailed every aspect of this game, and I can assure you guys I will continue to have a lot of fun with RoA in the future. 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

THANK YOU!

review: Honestly the best Smash-a-like platform fighter I've ever played. It's clear the creators of the game truly care about the gameplay and listen to the community.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is like Super Smash Bros, except the majority of the character designs(except Ori as a guest) are made from the ground up to be a unique fighter with an interesting moveset. There are only two things that are very different from Smash Bros, first is the lack of ledge-grabbing. You cannot grab a ledge, but you do get one wall jump(if that stage has a wall to grab underneath). There is also no shielding, only parrying. The shield button used in smash is a parry button that, when timed out correctly to an opponent's attacks, will stun the opposing player for a brief time. 

You can play versus mode locally with environmental damage from maps and up to 4 players going nuts, but this game really excels at that 1v1 smash style with no gimmicky maps. If that's what you like about Smash Bros, this game will be very fun for you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is an amazing Smash Bros. alternative. I would highly recommend. 

+PROS
+ Good music
+ still getting updates
+ it has very good stages 
+ most if not all the characters are completely original
+ A competetive Smash Bros. for PC
+ has a great community 
+ Developers are still listening to our feedback and doing community livestreams every week 
+ custom skins and dlc if you want to buy it
+ runs very well and rarely any frame drops 
+ has a story mode 
+ The graphics are quite good for a pixelated game
+ Really balanced

-CONS
- Has only a few characters for the base game 
- only a few stages 
- Not too much content for the very casual players
- Skill ceiling is not the highest but better players will still win
- DlC can get kind of expensive 
- achievements can be EXTREMELY difficult to get (I had to get top 500 in story mode leaderboards to get an achievement)
- A too small of community 

Overall I think this game deserves way more players then it has been recieving. I think this game could use a bigger team to push the rollback netcode in and this game would be perfect. I would still recommend this to anyone who has a decent PC and that has played or enjoyed smash style games.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
When I first picked up this game, I played Smash 4 and Melee before it, and I had almost no idea what to expect. Now that I have logged over 100 hours, and played every Smash game, I can safely say that I prefer this game to Smash. This game has a lot of things going for it.  It's tutorial is good enough for most people to understand the mechanics of the game, whether you are a veteran to Smash, or if you just started playing. The gameplay is easy to understand and fun to play. It's in the perfect level where it has more technicality than Smash 4, but is easy to pick up without spending hours upon hours playing like you do in Melee. All of the characters are unique and have their own things going for them, and one character doesn't really shine past the others in my opinion. Not only are all of the characters evenly balanced, but all of them can be played in maky ways, increasing the posibilities even more. And with DLC characters still coming out, the roster just keeps growing. 

Overall, I think this game is easily worth it if you are into Smash games, or if you want to get into Smash games. I would even recommend this game if you are new to fighting games, since it is that good.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
TLDR: Game is fun and worth the buy, but make sure you have a friend to play with if you're new.

The game's really fun and all the characters are supprisingly unique.  I think all the characters are balanced in their own respect.  The graphics are beautiful and easy to run.  I do wish, however, that the game would (when queueing in casual) allow you to turn on/off selective match making.  For example you could check a box off on whether or not you want players to be around your skill level or not.  And this could be rather difficult to do unless you're playing ranked but the game can be hard on new players if they do not have a friend to pratice with because it is very likely that you're put into a game with extremely varying skill level players.  Overall the game is great.  But unless you intend to play with friends, I dont think this game is all that great of an enviroment for casual players.  I haven't really had a problem with lag also, which is great.  Thats always a good sign.  Overall the game is reccomended.  I'm going to have fun racking up hours on this game. :)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether has been on my radar for a long time and when i finally got around to trying it, it didn't disappoint. A mixup of technical skill and gameplay similar to the Super Smash Brothers series is what really brought this game home. Wave dashing, Directional influence, Teching, and Fast falling are all found in Rivals and it gives the game an even higher learning curve than other fighters. Althought this is true, Rivals lacks a deep defensive game found in other fighters, in favor of a more combo heavy and offensive based game. This forces newer players to figure out what their opponents want to do in the neutral before they get run down by better and more experienced players. It also means that newer players will have a lot more games where they get smashed 2-0'd before they even get a single victory. This maybe frustrating, but in the end it is worth it because when they finally connect the dots and become more experienced players they will be able to see through a players strategy and counter effectively.

Theres a great cast of characters each with their own unique mechanics and it really brings the game together. My favorite character is Clairen (DLC CHARACTER), A sword wielding panther, whose unique mechanic is a tipper edge on her sword. Similar to Marth from the super smash brother series, Clairen uses great spacing in order to land her tipper attacks which lead into an insane combo game. Whenever her tipper lands the opponent recieves heavy hit stun allowing Clairen to combo into moves that wouldn't have landed if she hit with a weaker part of her sword. The range of her attacks forces enemies to find other ways to approach and it is Clairen's job to punish those alternate approaches. She counters ranged approaches with her down special, a counter that activates a force field which blocks all projectiles thrown into it.

The problems with the game lie in its' single player modes. The story lacks depth and is really short in comparison to games like Brawl's Sub Space Emissary. Although it does show the player the relationship between each region and the characters that come from them, but even that is short clips and pictures of one thing that each character manages to figure out as they fight their way to the final boss. The final boss is pretty cool but its un clear why he attacks the people of the aether and the ending is rather abrupt as they just roll the credits right after.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I only have about 10 minutes of experience on this game so take it with a grain of salt. This is not a bad game, in fact I would argue its on the right track. But there are a few issues with it. First off the controls for a Keyboard player are god awful. Its like they only thought players with a controller would play it (and thats what you should play it with). Instead of having the controls be user freindly like (I know these are two different genres of games) a First Person Shooter, FPS, this games wants the keyboard player to strain their brain and their hands to remember the controls. A simple way to fix this would to map the movement controls to the left hand, it would look something like this:

A=Move right
D= Move left
S= Duck/ crouch
W= jump
R= Run
E= Dodge

So on and so forthe. The devs could also map some controls to the mouse as well to make the gaming even easier and less confusing to a keyboard player. it could look something like this (use these along with the controls above):

Left click= Attack
Right click= Secondary attack
Mouse movement= Looking in that direction

The game devs should take this into consideration and hopefully make this a more enjoyable game. 
Now just because the controls aren't the greatest does not mean its a bad game. In fact the music is catchy and frankly it sounds pretty great. The charcter sprite are well crafted but some work can be done. The tutorial was well made, but perhaps the AI in the Defense and Offense sections of the tutorial could be a little easier to fight. The player has about 2 seconds to respond before being blasted into another dimension.

With all of this in mind its important to remember that new comers wont have a controler, wether its a gamecube, X-box, PS4, or any other hodge bodge thing a player can use. 

Sincerly- A noob

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I played a lot of different Smash games growing up and while I never made the jump to competive play on any of those titles, Smash Bros will always hold a special place in my heart. In more recent years I've started watching more competitive smash and have also gotten into Rivals of Aether, and I can unequivocally say, Rivals is the best competive platform fighter I've ever played or watched played.


PROS:

- Once you put in a little time, gameplay feels amazing.

- The pixel art is GORGEOUS. Plus the simple style makes all of the info on screen really clean and easy to interpret

- Sick soundtrack

- Great tutorial and supportive community can help you get past the initiation phase, where everyone online rocks ur socks.

- The devs are super supportive / active in the community and have worked really hard to add a lot of nice touches to the game.

- Tech skill is more accessible to beginners than any of the actual smash titles (because in the actual smash games, tech skills, ie. wavedashing, L-cancelling, etc., are things that players have figured out how to do but were never really intended by the devs, whereas in rivals, tech skills are baked into the design and have much clearer animations and inputs)

- At the same time, high-level play in rivals is so much more varied and fun to watch than traditional smash games. Part of this is probably the fact that the Rivals meta is still underdeveloped, so people haven't figured out what the optimal strategy for each character is. But at the same time, the game is designed to give each character a lot of options so it could be years and years until the meta really cements in any significant way.

- Characters have really intentional moveset designs, where all abilities work together to create a kit that can be played in a lot of different ways. In standard smash games, a lot of character designs feel similar and a lot of moves are either useless at a competitive level or are just a variation on "wind up and do a big hit".

- Smaller roster means that each character feels super unique and powerful in their own way. No real dead-weight, low-tier characters like you have in other smash games.


CONS:

- If you're actively looking for a non-competitive experience then this probably isn't for you. Although I wasn't looking for a competive experience when I started playing and I ended up finding one that I love.

- Initial learning curve is rough (but keep playing, do the tutorials and check out the community on discord / reddit and you'll be fine)


TL;DR: If you're into any Smash game or other Smash-like: get this instead, it's better. If you're more interested in watching competitive Smash than playing it, start watching Rivals :)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a Smash clone that accurately replicates its core mechanics while making some alterations that still sets it apart from its predecessors. This review covers the game from the perspective of a semi-competent Smash player.

Movement is integral to any fighting game and Rivals has been able to take what made Melee's movement great and use it for itself. It's fluid and responsive and retains tech like dash-dancing and wavedashing which increase the skill ceiling. It gives the player snappy control over their character and doesn't have an excess of turn animations like Smash 4 which give the movement a sluggish feel at times. Those who enjoy Melee's movement should find Rivals to be to their tastes.

Combat at its core is the same as Smash aside from two main changes: the replacement of shields with a parry and the removal of the ledge mechanic. These changes are not necessarily bad but simply alter how the game is played. The roster while small is varied and each has their own playstyle with some familiar moves returning from Smash. The character balance is well done with no character feeling unviable unlike what often occurs in Smash titles. This is due to each character having a balanced kit with none having a crippling weakness such as being completely outclassed in frame data or range. Perhaps an advantage of a small roster is that there is enough space to have different feeling characters without resorting to gimmicks to differentiate new characters. 

The game's singleplayer content features an arcade mode style story which is I believe is fine considering most players will be looking for a competitive experience rather than story. It also features Abyss mode which pits the player against waves of weak enemies. More importantly, the game includes a tutorial that will teach players important tech skill in the game. Despite Smash's reputation as a casual game that is easy to pick up, many players are actually unaware of its deeper mechanics. The game features remappable controls along with other general quality of life features such as forcing results screen skip. Bots are available to the player at various levels of competency, however like most games, these bots don't play like humans do and are prone to taking unrealistic actions which can lead to developing bad habits which only work against bots and not human players.

The game supports up to four players but only in specific configurations online due to how the P2P connection works only allowing communication between two systems. Full four player FFA and teams works offline as expected but online is either 1v1 or 2v2 with two players at each system. Finally, online matchmaking. I live in Australia and have never connected with someone that has less than 250ms ping making matchmaking practically impossible. If you live in a low population area, be prepared to drag your friends over into the game if you don't want to be stuck playing against bots.

Rivals of Aether is a great option for someone looking for a competitive Smash experience but cannot or doesn't want to play Smash for any reason. The game is well polished and plays excellently. Just keep in mind that this is a still a small game with a limited playerbase.

review:
Very fun, but the online "friendly" multiplayer mode where you play with your friends is only 1v1. The local multiplayer can be four players, any kind of game. So if you're looking to play with more than one friend through steam, you're out of luck. You can always play ranked matches and online 1v1s but the best way to play this game in my opinion is with 4 people playing on the same screen, in the same place. Of course there's ranked matches and other things but that has never interested me. For my purposes console version is just as good as the steam version.

Fun, but needs 4 player online multiplayer.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: this game is really just a game to play online for me but i have a number of complaints that can easily be fixed and some are very nitpicky and that i can easily overcome. my first complaint is the bloody controls, the controls for controller are very awkward especially for probably the many that are coming into this from brawlhalla. (yeah we exist) and another problem i have is the connection issues that ive seen everyone i know face with this game, its truly a problem. the gameplay is relatively slow and the recovery frames from anything isnt helping. the learning curve is as steep as a wall and the story difficulty scaling isnt exactly a handle. but ive played this game for about 15 minutes if not less so take my review with a spoonful of salt. ill probably make another review when i "git gud" at technical fighters and remap my buttons and try the controls to their default state.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: It's honestly a great game. It's very fun, and a nice one to play. I only have 3 real complaints, 2 of which are small. For one, it's very possible to be good at this game with a keyboard, but there's a threshold for keyboard users that cannot be passed and hinders gameplay. Once you hit a certain skill level, a controller is almost mandatory. Another is that for some reason--even though I'm sure my opponent and I both have good internet--I can rarely find a match with less than 100 ping, and it only happens in this game (yes, we're in the same region). My biggest complaint is that this game can be far too competitive. Even in exhibition matches, I can't ever find someone on par with me, it's always someone way better. While it doesn't bother me that much, and I know I'll most likely one day become one of those "tryhards", I can see how it can ruin the experience for a newer player like me. However, overall it's a good game, and if you're willing to get your ass handed to you for your first hundred matches before you get better, I'd say go for it!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Hi welcome to a bad players review of Rivals of Aether. TlDr:Good game not everyone made for "competitive players" with fast reflexs and good ping.

Pros:
1) Can be alot more rewarding and interesting to do combos.
2) A pretty big community of people who play.
3) Interesting characters and movesets with some background Lore.
4) Custom Colors and a couple of Skins free and not.

Cons:
1) As with most fighters hard to get into takes alot of time and mental skill to have fun expect playing for about 200 hours+.
2) Peer to Peer can make or break a game in this case its break because alot of people wont play past 120 ping as it affects the viability of specific characters.
3) This one hurts me to say as I left Bh cause of this but unfortunatly quite a bit of the community is toxic and unaware of it or simply doesnt care all fighters apply to this really but it goes a bit like: in judging others they became as toxic as the people they were judging for it. *im going to get hate for this one ;)*
4) Rivals of Aether is not really a good game to play with friends due to the skillgap and ping to be able to play.
5) The last point segways into without friends this game can be torture really when no ones nice enough to play games with a inexperienced player.
6) Questionable balance I am aware that its "fair" at top level play but what of the future? well some characters really make getting into this game awful for a player without friends for example i usually make it a rule to never leave in a fighting game but I honestly cant stand Rannos bubble/Tongue it kills the games pace completely and is more of a 1 sided move. another example is zetterburn which is a noob stomper I can actually deal with him since he just KOs early but I could easily see zetterburn being the reason this game wont get much bigger due to how traumatising he can be.

Overall: I really did want to rate this positive but the games flaws overshadow the game to much and before you tell me a mentor can fix the bad player problem it really doesn't just like how school does not mean everyone graduates and gets a nice job theres bound to be people who simple wont get better by being told how to play and thats where mentoring fails it only gets positive reviews never negative because the negative have allready quit the game also seems the paid dlc is imploding the community truthfully paying for characters could be much worse so theres that I think paid characters is fine. Also at the time of writing game does not support any more then 1 vs 1 online which kills it for our group.

Update:
1)Character Wise this was written around the time Slyvanos is announced.
2)Gameplay Wise I still am play Rivals to confirm this review and still convinced this game is just not good for getting into when all that happens is a demoralising loss in game and of time hoping to get better when it never happens reasonably.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
As a smash player, I gotta say that the fast-paced nature of this game is a huge plus! The combo potential of every character makes every match feel new and enjoyable. The dunks and spikes are satisfying, and the game is updated frequently to maintain balance between characters. Online rarely lags badly and the DLC characters are worth the price. Custom colors and bonus features including an "endless mode" give the game a bit more charm.

The story isn't all too great. This game's strength certainly comes from the local and online multiplayer that the game offers.

If you play smash, this game will probably help improve your smash skills and vice versa as it did for me.
