title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Like melee but with parries and every character being able to walljump instead of grabs, ledges, and shields while basically having auto l-cancel and easier wavedash inputs

also ori and ranno are too fun and you should buy the game just to play as them even though they're dlc, it's super worth

If you like melee and are looking for a game that is basically melee for you to play when you're not playing melee, or if you like melee and just can't get all the advanced tech of a character like fox down, this is definitely a game to look at. The game even has full tutorials that are 100% optional and a story mode to teach you all of the inner mechanics and workings of the game. Very accessible, easy to pick up, and although some characters are locked as DLC I feel as though $5 for a full character that deepens the game by possibly giving some weaker characters favorable matchups or being one of the few characters able to knock top tiers off their throne, hell even as far as just making a solid character with no real favorable matchups while still not being too weak to anything, is completely fine. With more characters like Sylvanos just being revealed at Genesis 5 two days ago at the time of writing this.

Coming from a melee scrub who mains Falco and secondaries Sheik, if you are coming into this game from Smash here are some recommendations I have for characters to start with based on your main:

Zetterburn - Fox/Wolf/Falco
Wrastor - Jigglypuff/Luigi/Meta Knight/Captain Falcon/MAYBE Falco
Absa - Pikachu/Mewtwo/Ness/Lucas/Zelda
Etalus - Bowser
Forsburn - Link/Ice Climbers/Bowser Jr/Captain Falcon/Wario
Kragg - Donkey Kong/King Dedede/Pac-Man/Robin
Orcane - Squirtle/Ivysaur/Duck Hunt/Mega Man
Maypul - Yoshi/Zero Suit Samus/Bayonetta/Fox/Sheik
Ranno - Sheik/Greninja/Falco/Captain Falcon/Wii Fit Trainer
Clairen - Marth/Roy/Lucina
Ori - Rosalina/Ice Climbers

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is my favorite platform fighter that isn't Smash Bros. itself.

Do consider this game has more of a competitive aspect to it, and that may make people shy away from it. All that being said, this is a very mechanically fluid game. Another thing that is a plus is that every character feels like they're great in some way, although some would argue that there are better characters than others. I personally never felt like this was the case.

The pixel asthetic is fantastic, and really reminds me of the GBA days. The music is incredible, with every song being memorable in their own way. This game even comes with a mode that allows you to customize the color of your favorite characters, which is something I wish more games did. 

If you're looking for a casual game, it does have a story mode and abyss mode (which pits you against back to back mini challenges like beat 15 weak opponents and destroy certain objects.) Outside of that, I wouldn't necessarily recommend this game to one that wants to play it casually. However, if you want a game that plays a lot like Super Smash Bros. Melee that has an incredible community and a great dev team updating the game, I definitely recommend this game. It's so much fun to play.

10/10 Etalus' uair will never stop being satisfying.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Do you like Smash Bros? You'll probably like this.
Don't like Smash Bros? Try it anyways, you might like it anyways.

Rivals of Aether is a fighting game similar to Smash in many ways, although different in enough ways to create an experience that's subjectively better than it's inspiration.

While the roster is fairly small, the characters that are there fall under a lot of the major playstyles that people tend to use. There's Wrastor, and aerial acrobat with a quadruple jump and air-based moves and smash attacks, Orcane, a wily waterbeast with the ability to create puddles and use them to teleport or power up his smashes, Kragg, a rolling rock-monster with the ability to create barriers and throw rocks at his enemies, and a whole bunch of other creative characters.

As I'm not a real connoisseur of the fighting game genre, I can't really give specifics on why it's fun or what makes it a great title, but what I can say is that I most certainly enjoyed it, and it's a great game to play with your friends. I hope this helps you with your purchasing decision.

Not for people who want to pick something up instantly.

Edit: After only137 ish hours, I am a very good non-beta tester

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
For anyone interested in this game i say buy it if your a competative smash player that loves games were you can master the control style and compete in the online game modes. If you played Super Smash Brothers Melee, and played it online countless of times with really skilled players this game is for you.


But for anyone in the casual side, the ones who loved playing Smash Brothers Brawl, even for all of its flaws, this game is not for you. I know this cause i am one of those people. This game personaly i did not like , but i can understand why people love it. In any case i canot recoment this game at all sadly because i am quite unhappy with its lack of extras.

The game features a story mode , a single player endless arena, and a ofline mode with stage hazards. This is all in single player curently. But in the multiplayer there is 2 game modes to choose from , Play for rank, Or play for practicing to get good at getting a higher rank. This is what bothered me , I went into this game expecting a mode so i can play against 4 people online and let the stage just screw us over or some strange item to all get us killed, But there wasent. For the community (witch seems to be strictly competative) they love that theres nothing more than fight for glory and nothing else. But for me I find this more tedious and borring the more i try to master these mechanics but fail due to my incompidence. 

I cant recomend this game because it fails to meet my expectations of just having fun, but this is probably cause i wasent the target audience, for anyone else that loves this style of game, this is for you and i know youll enjoy it. But if you liked playing casualy and dont like anything really competative, dont buy this game , insted just go find a Dolphin emulator, get a rom for brawl, and just turn off your brain and enjoy the fun game modes once again.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[Bought during Winter Sale at a discounted price. Though I'd take that into consideration, Id say normal price is worth it as well].

Scratches that Melee / Smash itch on PC in a very defined, unique, and beautiful way. Roster as far as free characters go seem really well balanced so picking a main really came down to preference [Go absa <3]. The stages are varied, and the custom colors let you add your own personal flair to your cast. Cuts out some of the more monotonous tech in melee [L cancels and the like], and adds more emphasis to other tech like DI and general combo game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I adore this game, but it's not perfect. The biggest issue I have is that, although there is a lot original about this game despite its obvious influences (namely Super Smash Bros. Melee), there are a few times were they might as well have copied and pasted certain moves, animations, or even entire characters into the game. A few times is great, but to the level of this game, this borders on plagiarism. Again, I love this game. It's well polished, has a great soundtrack and animation style, and is balanced and easy to understand while still being competitively viable. I even plan on getting most or all of the paid DLC at some point. I recommend this game to anyone who loves Smash clones or the Smash series, especially Melee, though as someone who mostly plays Sm4sh, it's one of my favorite games.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game was not a good experience for me. I knew going in that there were some limitations and things to look out for. Examples of this are characters locked behind a paywall or 1v1 over internet with the only option for 4 players being local play. What I was not prepared for were the poorly implemented mechanics. Good implementation of mechanics in todays market results in a player being able to intuitively figure out the basic mechanics through observation and gameplay. This game does not accomplish that. It wants to create the PC version of smash bros. The problem it has is that Smash Bros achieves this intuitive understanding of the character's abilities. I still have no idea what the ferret character's leaf attack did. It took me a while but I got that the bird characters tornado sped him up. What does the cat-whale's puddle do?  How do you confur the sheep lady's electricity to her cloud? It was a frustrating experience that killed the fun I could have had with this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Having put in over 100 hours now, I can safely say that this game is definitely worth the $15 it is advertised at. It's like Smash, yes, but more like Melee made easy. The controls are fantastic, and the characters and meta are constantly evolving, and if you're willing to put in the time, you can make any character you want the best.

That being said, this game is engineered for competitive play, and thus if you live in a region with no weeklies or monthlies and have a poor internet connection, you'll have a hard time finding people to play.

If you're into Melee / Smash in general, give this a go, and I can guarantee you will have a good time

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So far so good.  Doing the tutorials; seems pretty fun.

One thing I would like to point out though so other players may avoid such when they play:

In the Intermediate Tutorial there is a segment on doing the tech-rolling (recovery move that allows you to roll before hitting the ground from an enemy attack).  I had the unfortunate luck of jumping right under the drone, which put me in an infinite loop of knockback, with no room for tech-rolling or any move whatsoever.  I suggest all avoid doing such as I did when you come to that segment.

Great Game though.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'm not a super competitive player, but between various Smash games and Brawlout, I have well over 500 hours in the genre. That being said, Rivals is really hard. I don't really know how to describe it other than that. Another thing that makes it hard: The ranked mode doesn't start at the bottom. It puts you in at 100 ELO and I've had to drop almost 200 winning I think one game. Other queues are even worse. It's just not fun to get dumpstered 20 times in a row.
Also, it's a bit pay to win DLC characters existing in fighting games really decreases accessibility and doesn't let you learn matchups, and just kinda sucks.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: An amazing game, I would highly recommend playing this game!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
When the reviews say that it's almost 100% like melee, they really do mean it. The game has a few twists that make it unique, but it really likes to take the juicy technical part of melee while mixing it up with fast paced unique combat. Seriously, try it out, $7.50 was a STEAL for this gem, and I'd pay $15 for it if I had to. 

You can also hook up your Gamecube controller with a Mayflash adapter, and at that point, it's literally plug-and-play, just check gamepad settings in game to make sure everything is okay.

If you ever have your doubts about this game, you could always refund it I guess? 2 hours is a lot of time to get the basic feel for this game, and you should easily be able to determine whether is "Melee-like" to your liking or not. Believe me, I didn't buy this game thinking it would be even close to what people said it was, but it feels SOOOO good.

96/100

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Long story short:

Pros:
- Great concept
- Similar to another game "Brawlhalla" but somewhat different in terms of core mechanics
- Very Original, even thou based on Super Smash Bros Melee
- Huge Potential if they can lower the price a bit.
- Very much any computer with good network should be able to handle this game w/o problem.

Cons:
- Online games need improvements, I get 200+ms players connecting
- Option menu improvements needed, mostly around the visual tabs

Overall: 6.5/10
Must-Solve Problem: Server connection makes the whole game feel like trash, this game requires certain level of timing accuracy and the network just put it into the garbage truck and let it run away (Mine is AS server, others should be fine).

Edit: And after half a year, two days after my birthday, it's still the same deal, they haven't fixed connection problem.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A fast, deep, and well-balanced platformer-fighting game with interesting departures from the mainstays of the genre. Character design is top-notch and all the character feel unique and fun. There is enjoyable single-player content, but the game shines in its multiplayer. The online services feel a bit lacking, and there is some noticeable lag that occurs regularly, leading me to believe that there are issues with the netcode or servers rather than both players connection speeds. Local multiplayer however is truly an amazing experience and I see myself playing this game with friends for years to come.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is definitely not a BAD game, I just wouldn't recommend it. Online is really hard to play not because of the game's complexity (You can definitely play Melee on Netplay and the complexity is kinda the same) but because it's really hard to find a match outside a big region, so you can't actually enjoy the competition this game is trying to create unless you're from said big regions. Singleplayer has barely any content, that added to the fact the roster is pretty small and getting the DLC characters is super close to buying the game again, and before you say it's pretty cheap and complaining about this means you're broke, think there are more countries and realities than US/EU.

And before you say my opinion sucks because I only invested 8.6hrs into the game, I'll say I've invested way more time in the game this is based on (Melee, another game that I wouldn't recommend unless you have people to play with) and I didn't feel the same motivation to keep investing time, specially with characters behind a paywall (idc if they're not "top tier", it's still matchups you have to learn and understand otherwise you'll get cheesed) which also was one of the reasons I grew tired of Smash 4. I'll now just add my personal impression here when it comes to mechanics, I completely dislike the way the game limits your defensive options (parry instead of shield, I know they had to deviate from Smash in some way but try parrying something consistently with +160ms) and some mechanics just feel off for me (no ledge grab + being able to use another recovery special after touching the wall). Also I find some character design to be pretty questionable, but that's an opinion so personal it doesn't weigh on the review that much as the other points.

Can this game be fun?
Under certain circumstances, sure it can be. But if for any reason you can't meet them, you'll probably be in disadvantages and the game can get boring fast.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I can't recommend a game that litterally asks for $10 just to get 3 more characters after paying $15 to get the game in general. Does this game already think its in league with Smash Bros?

The controls are fine, not horrible. And I find the little campaign to be... okay, but they could add to it with other character stories; such as the icebear or goat characters. I mean, give us more than just the character and a stage out of that $5. 

You earn in-game currency but don't worry, you only have to buy 2 characters in game, the other 3 are DLC. I'm okay with Ori costing $5 because Ori is a character from a well known game but we just got 8 characters, which feels kinda small. One gripe I kinda do want to point out is that the stages feel small. 

This game is great for those who want to play something competitive and it has a good few characters. The best I can compare this game to is the OG Smash for the Nintendo 64, which this game surpasses in a great way when it comes to balance. But, at the least the first game gave us 12 characters (four you get from playing the game). 

I had fun with the solo campaign, and wish that they would continue it. 

(Also,remember that regaurdless of what I write as a review, I did buy the game.)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Great platform fighting game, good online play, fun story and alternative modes. Custom colors for characters are awesome! Hella sick music and aesthetic!

Originally, I did not think I would like this game. As a melee player since 2010, I figured it would just be another game that is ok but that would just leave me wanting to play melee. After playing it and giving it a chance my skepticism was completely washed away. I love the way the game has unique stage control options (related to the chartacters element) which really makes the game unique and adds depth to gameplay and gives Rivals its own feel and soul to make it stand out from other games in the genre (namely Melee). It ties for the best tutorials I have seen in a fighting game (tieing with GGXRD). It has everything a casual and competitive player needs, though I wish the individial character tutorials and advanced tutorials were more specific sometimes or would say what common incorrect inputs would look like so you know if you need to slow down or speed up the time in between your inputs. 

Rivals has a great and helpful community on discord (search rivals academy) and competitive online tournaments.

My only complaints are that I wish they would add the dlc characters to abyss mode and have online co-op abyss mode with friends.

Absolutely 10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I really enjoy the gameplay esp with others since it carries overs some of the mechanics from smash melee. although i do have a big problem with the pause menu navigation. I use a Gamecube controller with the wii u adapter, and despite installing all the necessary drivers; whenever i pause the game to restart the level i have to put a lot of force just to move the selection up and down. I have to do that AND slam the A Button multiple times just to get a confirmation. Maybe its just my controller but this is really frustrating and makes me want to play it less. I also feel as if the "speedy rival" achievement is excessively hard to achieve as you need to be (what feels like) perfect on every story mode fight just to get a second custom color scheme. Maybe i just need to "Git Gud" as the kids say but at least make the amount of time needed to get a gold medal larger because 1:30 is very hard to achieve in this games story mode.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I've been hearing a lot of people downvoting the game because of the paid DLC characters. DLC is optional, you don't have to buy them if you don't want them. Anyways back to the review. This game is awesome, The story has an interest history for each character. Every character has unique abilities and style. The gameplay is very fluid and fast kind of like Smash Bros. The netcode is very good in the game, the only time that they are bad is depending where anyone lives like far away. The downsides that your controls don't save. This is bad because I prefer to have tap jump on the joystick. I set the tap jump to the controls and enjoy. The next time I booted the game and go to online, I was wondering why I can't jump. So I went back and restarted to default. It's not good that the fact they always restart you controls everytime you start up the game, and always have to remember to change it before you go online. Also, the game only supports 2 players locally (unless if it's in teams) is not good. Sometimes, you wanna play with your friends and beat them up in a 4 player free for all, you cannot do that in Rivals of Aether, if you want a 4 player match, you have to go in teams. It would be nice if the game supports 4 player local fully. Despite all the cons in the games, this is a really good Smash clone for $15. If you really like Smash Bros and fighting games, I would recommend playing Rivals of Aether.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is amazing, I love it a lot. But there are too many problems with it for me to reccomend it. Let's start with the pros.

PROS
+ (MOSTLY) Balanced character roster
+ Beautiful stage design
+ Very good controls
+ Satisfying to play

However, here starts a long list of cons with the game that I REALLY hope the devs fix.

CONS
- Roughly a quarter of the characters are locked behind a paywall. (AND THERE ARE STILL MORE TO COME TO A POINT WHERE NEARLY HALF THE CHARACTERS ARE)
- Clairen (One of these said DLC characters) is far too good. (However a couple of nerfs did happen, we will see how that goes)
- Cannot access Aether Mode (Essentially Non-Omega stages) stages in friendly matches.
- Cannot invite more than 1 person into a match.
- Story is extremely short
- Connection to games is awful
- Matchmaking is awful
- Customisation for keyboard controls are very limited

This game has amazing potential of being fantastic, but there are too many problems weighing it down. If the developers started actually fixing their game and stop making paid dlc characters, then this game will be absolutely incredible. But in it's current state, do not buy this game unless if you want to pay an extra $10 for the rest of the roster and only play locally with your friends.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you loved Melee, or enjoyed the competitive nature of any of the other Smash games, then you will most likely love Rivals of Aether.  Anti-campy mechanics, a distinguished cast, and a skill-rewarding combo system really sets this game apart from other Smash clones.  That and its surprisingly pleasing, spritey art-style along with its superb soundtrack really support the backbone of this game and flesh it out.  If I had to say anything negative about this game, it would be the DLC fighters(although this weekend is the first free weekend to play those fighters, besides third-party Ori).  This isn't because I don't think the devs deserve extra money for creating new content, or feel entitled because I purchased this game long before its official release.  Rather in a 2d platformer fighting game, or in any fighting game, I believe that all characters should be playable upon purchase (whether that changes the price of this game, which it most likely would, doesn't matter to me), so all players have the same set of characters to choose from when playing in an online competitive system and don't feel forced to spend money to get a character who is significantly stronger, but locked behind a monetary wall.  Regardless of your opinion on the game itself, I feel that Overwatch's system of free content and  micro transactions for skins is the best way to handle things (although loot boxes aren't necessary, just let people buy the skins).  If you are a die-hard Smash fan, and DLC fighters don't bother you, then you should purchase this game with no second thoughts.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a love letter to Super Smash Bros. Melee. It has almost entirely the same tech with a few changes to keep things fresh and balanced. Shielding is replaced with parrying, and grabbing and the ledge are gone. The controls are smoother than ever, and even wavedashing feels consistent. With its roster of unique and interesting yet balanced characters that complement a wide array of playstyles, we can all finally DI, tech and walljump our way to 20XX.

I highly recommend this game to any fan of Melee!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you're like me, then you found this game because you wanted to play a fighting game that's similar to Smash. Well ya found it. The only game in my opinion (and to my knowledge) that recreates the platform fighter formula and executes it well, so well. The mechanics are more leaning towards Melee in terms of frame data and tech (ie wavedashing) but if your familiar with Smash games in general then Rivals will definitely feel natural to you after the first couple matches. The terminology is also very similar like when playing through the tutorial, it will explain arials as Up-Air, F-air, Down-Air etc

The only gripe I have with the gameplay is that there is no shielding/blocking. It's instead been replaced with the mechanic of Parrying. Pretty much a counter. I understand the reason behind that switch which is to reduce camping and speed up gameplay/matches, which is okay. I respect it.

So if you want to play a more balanced game similar to Smash Bros. Then this is definitely the game for you. Not to mention that the developers constantly update the game to keep characters balanced and op at the same time. <3

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a platform fighter, much like Super Smash Brothers or Brawlhalla(among others). If you enjoy those games, especially if you enjoy the high skill ceiling they have, pick up Rivals. It's made by a small, dedicated team of individuals who continually update their game, and are incredibly involved with their community, both in the casual, and the competitive scenes. Below are my thoughts specifically on Rivals of Aether and what makes it stand out from its ilk. 

Super Smash Brothers has a sort of 'character triangle' when it comes to top-of-casual or low-competitive play. It is most evident in the newest entry of Super Smash Brothers, for the Wii U/3DS. The basic logic is such: 

Reflector > Ranged > Counter > Reflector...

This logic has basis in low-competitive levels ONLY, and is not applicable to higher levels of play. Low-competitive is essentially what you would see in the For Glory mode of this game, generally. Counter-Based characters are beaten out by Ranged as their specials are all but useless when they are being ranged out, but those projectiles are useless against a Reflector-based character. But as Reflector-based characters generally have no or very slow projectiles, they can easily be killed by counter-based characters. Obviously this does not hold true for all characters(Mewtwo, for example, is for all intents and purposes Ranged and Reflector in equal parts), but is a general rule when counterpicking(the act of picking a character more suited to beating your opponent) is concerned. 

Rivals of Aether does not have the same triangle. Every character is every single type, except for a few exceptions. Every character but Clairen and Forsburn have ranged attacks, but the parry(used the same way a spot-dodge is in Smash Brothers, or just by dodging with no directional input on the ground) is both a reflector and a counter, as it stops the enemy if you are hit with a melee attack up close and makes them vulnerable to a strong attack, or sends projectiles back to where they came from if used to block those, while alos granting a small amount of invincibility to help you close the gap and get in a quick hit. There are still metrics for the characters(as Dan Fornace himself put it, there are characters more geared towards rushdown tactics as opposed to spacing, and vice versa), but every character is viable and every character has no obvious counterpicks. This makes Rivals infinitely more interesting to the low-competitive player, and puts an emphasis on predicting your opponents' next move(commonly called 'reading').

Rivals also has much larger amounts of hitstun(the moment when you cannot move or take an action after being hit and launched into the air) than Smash Brothers, allowing for a more fluid and forgiving combo game that values that first hit even more, and not what comes after it as much. As long as you know what direction your opponent will DI(move away after they are hit), you can easily land a follow-up. 

In closing, Rivals of Aether is a heaven for people tired of Super Smash Brothers' limited combo game, tired 'true' combos, and restrictive character balancing. It is much more fluid, fast, and relies more on the players' strength when it comes to reads, as well as creativity in mixing up their approaches and attacks to keep their enemies on their toes. It's made damn well and runs like a dream, and has a lot of Quality-of-life improvements over other fighting games(such as the ability to see how good your connection is with another player exactly BEFORE you enter a match with them. 

Also, Dan Fornace's twitter is amazing. Seriously, look it up. 

Overall: Complaints on my profile about Ori/10.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a game for fans of smash style fighters.
But this game has its focus on the competitive aspect.
And on an competitive level this game is the best one out there.

It trumps with:

- airtight and intuitive controls
- vastly different and original fighters which still are all very balanced
- no randomness or other things outside your influence
- great tutorial
     (They have a server on Discord where you can request a teacher)
- you can customize your characters look to make it unique


BUT BE WARNED! This game demands you to:

- have great and stable internet
- be willing sit down and learn
- git gud.

The fun of the game is to train and improve.
Get yourself a sparring partner or two.
It's a competitive game, so go out and COMPETE.


The only downside I can find is that the story of the characters is a bit poopy at the time.
These are new characters and we barely understand their character and their world.
But thats really not the point of this game, so don't be discouraged.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
One of my favorite Smash-inspired fighting games of all time. Even though it isn't a crossover like Smash it makes it up for interesting characters, like for example: Orcane can create puddles by using his N-Special, D-Special, and ground U-Special. Or Etalus being able to wear armor once he uses his N-Special on ice. The list goes on and on! My favorite characters to play is Orcane, Zetterburn, Forsburn, Etalus, and Kragg. All 5 of those characters are all fun to play as. The other ones I don't main, like Wrastor, Maypul, and Absa. I don't like to play as them, but that doesn't mean I hate them, infact I kinda like them. (well that can't really said to Absa, :T) 

Moving on from the characters, why not I talk about the controls? The controls are well made, easy to understand, and feels comfortable for me. (I use the keyboard and PS4 controller) nothing much to say about the controls, other than that there great.

I honestly think that the modes are the strongest features (along with the characters) a Smash-Inspired game has ever had, this one has a lot and there all pretty good. Abyss mode is basically multiman brawl, but also a bit of the WarioWare stage? Except it won't time you for 5 seconds. Pratice mode is training mode but this time you can pause, turn on visable hitboxes, etc.

Overrall, this game is just so amazing, and I'm happy that I got this game. Plus I'm so excited to play as Ori tomorrow!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I haven't spent too much time with it, but I wanna give you my two cents anyway. 
Bear in mind, this is early access and right now there is not that much to do. Story mode and other things are coming though. Might redo this review as time passes.

But for now this is a fun fighting game and deliberately reminiscent of Super Smash Bros., but has some mentionable differences. Most noticeable for me, theres no Block/Shield. You do have a parry though, which does lock your opponent for a moment if timed properly, but this is only rarely doable online, because right now you have to handle lag and thus input delay. That sucks for a fighting game, but might change in the future

As for the mechanics themselves: The characters feel good and pretty distinguished. Every fighter has his very own style of moving, fighting and using their special attacks. Controls are, mostly, Smash-Bros-ish. There is DI, there is Aerial Dodge and there even is wavedashing, if your into it. Racking up combos does require some skill, but feels very rewarding so far. This game seems to be supposed to be competitive. No items, only a few environmental hazards and skill oriented gameplay. This might turn out to be a great game in the future, if the updates keep coming and the network-issues get resolved.

Up to this point it is a fairly fun game to kill time with a lot of potential.

PLAY IT.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I've followed Dan's games ever since he released Super Smash Land - Suddenly this little gem understood the fun of Sakurai's game, and even added new characters to showcase potential.

Here we are now - Gone are nintendo's characters, replaced by new mechanics, new characters, that don't feel like forced versions of characters in other games, even if some share a similar recovery to a smash character, no other character feels like Forsburn or Ranno, for example.

Rivals of Aether is a masterpiece for your wallet, and for every smash fan who wants something new to play. Kudos.

The game plays similar to something like PM/Melee as you can wavedash/land etc. There are no ledges or shields so you have to edgegaurd and approach/defend differently. Each character has their own "gimic" to make them unique and offers a different playstyle. Orcane and Forsburn are my favorites. Would recomend this game to anybody who enjoys the platform fighter genre!

*Edit* Clairen is now my main

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This just feels like wasted potential in its current state, and that's a heckin shame. The biggest issue with the game is its not mechanically deep enough to leave improvement for players. With the removal of things from Smash such as ledge grabs, normal grabs, and shield you'd think they'd add some other mechanics to fill in those very important holes. Instead the game, unfortunately, did little to nothing to replace these mechanics. The game quickly made me, as well as all of my friends who have purchased this game, lose interest after the first month or so. It really just ends feeling like an easier version of Melee with none of the mechanical depth that makes people enjoy the game enough to stick around. I wish I could like this game as a Smash title on steam would be stellar, but this title only came so close.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Really fun game with a lot of polish, tight controls, awesome soundtrack, extremely varied and cool cast of playable characters, etc. If you like Smash gameplay, it's basically that minus the items. Dang shame that 80% of your fights online will be against Clairen, and it's really, REALLY not fun to play against her (you know it's bad when the devs get on twitter and tweet about how fair and balanced she is and that players should stop complaining about her lmao). Pick it up on sale, it really is a fun game and hopefully in a few patches the rest of the characters will regain their popularity.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A platformer that's just fun. Challenging? Yes. For a casual gamer? Maybe. It is a highly competitive game with characters that when learn't, can be really good. My advice is do the tutorials and story mode before attempting the multiplayer as this is a game where practice makes perfect. The DLC characters are also challenging and may seem OP at first but have patience, learn their attacks and then you can counter them. This applies to any other character to. 

I don't agree with the price of the DLC's as I think they offer to little. As for the game I can see people thinking it's a bit too expensive but I would recommend it if you love platformers.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: For someone who has played about 40 minutes of smash, I cannot give a comparison. Go and look at a diferent review for that. But this is coming from a filthy casual when it comes to fighting games. I have not played much of the online as it can have sup-par connections and people not accepting the game. But I have played it with friends online and it still does have some connection issues. Personally I find it quite fun, I like to just jump on it for about 30-60 minutes and just fight against level 9 bots or play with a friend. Only one friend because the online only supports 1 v 1, there is a free for all and team mode for up to 4 players but at the time of writing this review, it is LAN only. The main thing I do not like about this game is the fact that for a small game it is £10.99 and the 3 DLC characters are all payed for with real life money. One cotains 2 characters and cost £3.99 and the other which I think is a cross over with Ori and the blind forest also cost the same amount but only contains 1 character. I would choose the first one because it gives you more content for the price. The thing I like the most about this game is the uniqueness of every character. I bought it on sale and currently I would recommend it on sale, maybe full price if you are fighting game player.

Well youre dreams came true because now he has hitstun that doesnt give a shit if you di or not beacuse you sit there until youre hit with a follow up. Every other character is fun to play as and against and I dont even mind getting bodied by them but jesus. that character is so gamebreakingly not fun. pay $5 to win. Id still reccomend the game because its legitimately a good time when it doesnt involve marth having a taser.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
While yes, the game is very fun, I gave it a negtaive score due to online play.

1. Clarien

I hate the term "____ is pay to win." But this is the only instance where this term gets a pass. Clarien is OP. Not because she does lot's of damage, not because she has a tip hit stun, here specials is what suck. You can't look me straight into the eye and say a energy shield that does damage when going out and that you can summon at any time is not OP. She can also punish anything. Miss jab=combo, miss aerial=combo, miss anything=combo.

2. Ping

The ping in most games is so bad. For some reason this game has great ping when playing with a friend miles and miles away, but can't handle someone who may be like 1 mile away. Just why? Most of the matches are unplayable if your ping is bad. 

3. Stereotypes

Now what I mean by this is you'll have this group of people you mostly encounter in online, this includes...
Clarien
Etalus players who make ice platforms and slide across all the time
Books to read
Players who use one combo and only one combo
People who are kinda good with a non-DLC charecter
People who are trying to get better
And finally, people who can't play the game cause of there awful ping... you won't see them often, but I am one so...

Conclusion:
This game is good in play style, creativity, and charecters. But those can't balance out the problems of online play Now you may say to yourself, "Why not just play offline?" Because it is so easy to start up combos and there just no fun. Fix Clarien, fix ping, balance out every charecter, and buff Maypul, he just can't stand his own ground anymore.

If you wanna buy it, go ahead. But don't say I didn't warn ya.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: It was November 21st of 2001, Super Smash Bros. Melee was released. The smash bros. game that ruled them all in the competitive scene. There were a crap ton of tech skill involved. 16 years later a game called Rivals of Aether was released and was inspired by Melee, It had wavedashes, techs (or breakfalls) and instead of well known Nintendo characters, (Apart from Roy, Nobody knew who he was back then.) They had original characters. Some downloadable content was also introduced like, Ori as a playable character. Rivals of Aether is a fun game to play with friends, you can give yourself a fun time destroying or being destroyed by friends! You have to knock each other of the stage by getting the opponents some percentage. To get percentage, all you have to do is hit them until their percentage is high and then SMASH!!!!!! Altogether the game is fun with an indie vibe, the retro graphics fit the game well and looks like it was made for the NES/SNES!!! I give it 10 buttslaps out of 10 buttslaps.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether’s greatest success was speaking to the young, imaginative child I once was. I recall fondly many instances in my youth when I was brimming with love for and inspiration from wild characters I would see in cartoons or video games. Many afternoons were spent playing pretend, as I embodied a righteous warrior of some kind with spectacular abilities only my youthful and energetic brain could visualize.

This game’s roster feels like an extension of that creativity, as if I, as a young child, were asked to come up with ideas for new and inventive characters. To what source of inspiration would I have defaulted? Clearly I would have put animals and the very elements of nature themselves together into a brawl so epic only I could truly appreciate the awesomeness and majesty of this clash.

Thankfully, Rivals of Aether had more care and work go into making it a good game, rather than smashing two cool ideas together and calling it a day. Of note is how each character finds a successful balance between feeling both fresh and familiar. I can liken certain moves to SSB characters and see their implementation in my mind’s eye, as I’ve seen and performed them myself countless times. But the way these abilities and character designs are remixed give this game a life all its own.

As a fighting game, Rivals of Aether’s endgame is the quest to achieve mastery of the game’s system or a particular character. So while I did not achieve mastery of any character, I did try out all of the game’s available modes. I have played a healthy amount of time as each and every character on the roster, both in the required sections of the story mode and in both local and online multiplayer. When I tried playing online, I got my ass kicked, hard. However, I think that goes to show more how technical this game can be, offering pros and newbies alike an experience that can be enjoyable, whether your goal is to play casually or competitively.

As a game trying to use SSB as a jumping off point, I think Rivals of Aether succeeds fairly well. Although I am constantly aware that I am playing what is tantamount to a “smash clone”, the uniqueness of this game’s roster and willingness to cultivate precise and fun systems shows that it has potential as more than just a SSB style game. The inclusion of in-game training tools also shows that the developer is willing to take a good idea and sharpen it to its perfect form.

For anyone with a SSB itch on the PC or console, I highly recommend this game. Rivals of Aether has provided me with a strong replacement for SSB4, allowing me to enjoy the platform fighter genre with a system that is responsive and available anywhere I have a PC.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game has become one of my favorite games of all time.  While the online is brutal to newcomers, the sense of achievement when you can take your first win online is immense.  The game is fine tuned, fast paced, and well polished.  With some extra dlc the game has a decent size roster that will be expanding even more in the future.  The game has a great tutorial mode to learn the game and the specific characters.  On top of that there is a community dedicated to helping newcomers learn and become better.

The sprite animation in this game is beautiful and shows a great attention to detail.  This is shown best in the more recent characters.  Even though some of the early animations had looked a bit rough in the past most of those have been re-animated and now look pretty great!

I would rate this game 5/5 and would recommend to anyone who likes platformers or pixel art!

title: Rivals of Aether
review: furry super smash bros. just kidding, that's just super smash bros. but no really, this game is cool. i like playing the whale. i dislike heracross, because my friend plays him and always beats me. there aren't enough smash-like fighters out there and a lot of the ones that are made attempt to copy the structure of melee outright and inevitably fail because melee is a difficult game to capture twice. Rivals of Aether avoids that by deviating from its source material and attempting to make improvements, such as the focus on an offensive combo-focused style. although this game's target audience has ensured much of the current player base is made up of experienced super smash bros. players, the game's mechanics and engines feel so intrinsically smooth and natural that the game feels fun to play at any level of skill. that's the true spirit of melee. the adorable, colorful sprites and excellent game boy-inspired music keep you feeling good while you get your butt kicked.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: It used to be a great game. Then, the developer released dlc for 1/3 of the games price. I strongly recommend that anyone reading this review after the DLC has been released to not buy the game, as you are supporting shady practices. Definitely do not buy the DLC, or this kind of thing will keep happening. One of the DLC's is a special character from another game, Ori and the blind forest, fair enough, expensive but that is something from another game and usually that kind of thing would be dlc since it doesn't fit with everything else. But then, they released Ranmo and Clairen, two completely broken characters  that are more annoying to beat than the others (for good reason, they want money) for $5. You may think "Well, that's $5 and it enables you to win games easier" and that is precisely my point. That thinking is how people like Dan Fornace make 1.33x the revenue on a game that should still be getting free content. After all, the last 8 characters had all been free. There was no reason other than being a money whore to make this DLC.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game has great potential, but I'm worried about their current business model.  That direction being releasing new characters as paid DLC when they only have a roster of 8 characters.  Super Smash Bros. on the other hand has a full roster of 47 characters already in the base game plus 7 DLC characters.  I give Ori a pass as a DLC as he is from another property and I love the original game, but realeasing two new original characters as paid DLC when your roster hasn't even broken ten characters yet is a bad business model.  Don't become like the AAA studios where they release a shell of a game and demand more money to get the full product, which is what you're doing here.  I view this game as the SSB people go to if they don't want to buy a wii u plus the game, but with the direction you're going Dan Fornance, I think the wii u will become the cheaper option.  Anyway, those are my words of warning.  

If you want my opinion on this game so far, it's great, if you play at 10-20 minute intervals vs. the AI.  Only played pvp a few times because server lag was terrible (dedicate more RAM to your servers, always helps).  However, I do like the game's art-style and soundtrack as it gives the game a retro feel to it.  Each character has a distinct personality to them.  Story mode... needs a bit of work.  One, have a rivial fight someone with purpose, not just dressing each story with fights in-between character's back stories.  Two, cut the one liners, yes I'm looking at you Wrastor.  I just spent an entire fight only to get one line of story before going to the next fight.  Introduce your characters more so they have more impact when you develop the story more. Anyway, keep up the good work, in it's current state I'll give the game a 6/10, which is a bit above average. You have the fighting down, now fix up the story mode a bit and stop releasing new original characters as paid DLC's if you want anyone to come back to your game.  Also fix your servers.  I can see you guys are a talented nine man team, don't become a AAA company.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a Smash-esque fighting game that takes the same winning simple-but-deep systems of the game it's inspired by (Super Smash Bros. Melee) and refines them so they're both more accessible to newcomers and more integral to gameplay.

Seriously--have you tried wavedashing reliably in Smash Bros. Melee? It's pretty frigging hard! You have to practice, practice, practice, for hours or days to perform that technique reliably. Rivals walks into the room and says, "Screw that, such an integral tech shouldn't be impossible. Here's a tutorial, here are the inputs, bam. You're wavedashing. Congrats."

That's not to say the game doesn't have depth, though. Heck no. The character-specific tech in this game was lovingly built in by developers who clearly know how to make characters that are balanced and varied without sacrificing fun. The characters are so unique and their mechanics are so cool that I can't even begin to express how awesome it is to slowly delve into each one, learning their intricate details and realizing just how much attention was put into every aspect. They all play fluidly and feel powerful.

tl;dr -- It's just the best. The developers of this game have made a fighting game experience that is built for competitive play, but remains simple and appealing enough that just about anyone who's handled a controller before can hop in and start learning without feeling overwhelmed.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is pretty much PC Melee with easier tech, but that doesn't mean it's a cheap clone. In fact, there are many things that set this game apart.

For example:
- No shielding, instead you parry, which almost is like more forgiving perfect shielding
- No ledges, instead you wall jump to reset your recovery
- Airdodging out of specials
- Unique character mechanics, such as Orcane's traps or Etalus' ice
- Constant balance updates that make every character more or less viable at the highest level of play
- Great netplay

This game is an easy recommendation to Melee players/fans and casual gamers looking to get into a Smash-esque game as it is very easy to pick up but very hard to master.

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is, quite literally, the poor man's Super Smash Bros Melee.

PROS
-lots of nice animations
-pixel art is incredible
-good variety of mechanics and playstyles in the available cast
-great music
-has enough original design to make it more than just a clone of smash bros the (the lack of ledge-grabbing in particular is refreshing)
-features a number of options that the smash bros series is sorely lacking, such as custom colors and random character select

CONS
-the game feels terrible when playing online, ie most likely the only time you're playing against other people
-single player modes are very bare
-the parry system is dumb
-with the amount of patches and characters that have yet to be added, the game is essentially still in Early Access
-DLC is overpriced; this is especially apparent when you compared the base game ($15 for 8 characters) to the total cost of each $5 DLC pack for characters that have been released and have yet to be released ($20 for 6 more characters)

Rivals of Aether's overall design is a platform fighter that's trying to be like Melee. It has fewer characters, less polish, a smaller community, and a much, much lower skill ceiling. However, even at a final cost of $35 for 14 characters, it certainly is a lot cheaper than tracking down a physical copy of Super Smash Bros Melee.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Melee remains the best competitive smash game, but its mechanics lack quality-of-life tuning that make it (to some) not feel fun to play.

Smash 4 feels a bit slow with the lack of attack-canceling mechanics and generally longer end-lag on many actions.

For a time, Project M (a competitive brawl mod) was similar to melee but a bit more well-rounded and more fun for your average player. A C&D letter from Nintendo's lawyers shut down development.

So enter Rivals of Aether: an original smash game with a vaguely pokemon/digimon esque cast of characters. RoA strikes a fantastic balance of "fun to play" and "competitive", with the general speed and mechanical demand being high, but not stiff/awkward like melee. It features a smaller cast of characters (8 main+3 DLC so far), but each has extremely unique characteristics which make them feel more distinct from one another than characters in the smash series.

The game is developed by a smash fan for smash fans, and it has been pretty well balanced since even the start of early access. The pixel art has been steadily improving, and if you're the sort of person turned off by pixel art, I think you'll come to appreciate it in time; pixel art makes the readability of frame data, hit boxes, and everything else massively more clear than what you get in 3D fighting games.

The game is totally worth it at full price and a steal if it's on sale.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you're a fan of Super Smash Bros... then this game is NOT for you.

This game lacks ledge grabbing and smash directional influence, and it really shows.

Edit: The game does have normal DI, but SDI as it is In Brawl/Smash4 lets you move all over the place when hit by a smartbomb, but while fighting this game's boss and getting hit by its similar multi-hit black hole attack, I was only able to very slightly inch a pixel at a time. Overall it felt like I had no control.

If you're not sure what I mean by SDI, skip to 2:41
https://youtu.be/UIdyVK1aDtg?t=2m41s

The existence of this kind of quirky movement helps you feel like you have more control over what's happening, even if it's not doing much, this is part of the game feel in being able to wiggle around even while in hitstun.

In any case, weak SDI isn't the worst problem here - there's no ledge grabbing and many of the up-specials (the ones that general are your main recovery tool in SSB games) are rather bad for recovery.

I'm constantly frustrated by scenarios I keep expecting to survive, [b]which overall makes this game feel inferior to real smash games.[/b]

In other words, you'll die to a lot of situations where it feels you've lost complete control of your character.

Don't think it's important? Going for a more "competitive" or "pro" fighting design?

Skip to 1:57
https://youtu.be/IwdekoJb3I8

In this case, the game has double jump, but the lack of ledge grab just has you dying in lots of stupid ways you could be recovering from if you were playing Smash 4 instead.

On top of that, a lot of the recovery abilities (equivalents of up-specials in SSB) are rather difficult to use in a pinch when you need them most. Aside from not being able to ledge grab, some of them require a bit of "pre-planning". This would be the dolphin's puddle that needs to be placed before you fall (and can disappear/be destroyed), or the maypul's leaf on the enemy that is needed for him to lasso onto the enemy who needs to be close by or unobstructed for you to be able to recover.

Not all of the up-specials give you upwards movement. In Brawl, almost every character at least had an upwards movement with their up-special, even if it was meant to be a "heavy" character or one that doesn't exactly have much "verticality". In SSB, the only characters who didn't inherent upwards movement were Ness and Lucas, but their up-specials could still be used in a pinch without any prior setup, so they're still better than what Orcane and Maypul have.

Even Ivysaur and Omar, whose up-specials are ledge grabbing lassos, still actually give them a little bit of satisfying upwards momentum, which helps the player feel in control, rather than helpless, even while falling off the map.

In its place, the game does have a walljump up-special system which technically does let you do more, as walljumps refresh your up-special, but this is far less intuitive and requires dipping into the tutorial or hearing about it beforehand to know about. This kind of thing will give you a bad first impression if you jump in after playing Smash and expect familiarity in the games mechanics.

I think the game would be vastly improved by improving these three things, because otherwise, it's unplayable to me.

Don't get me wrong, this game does many things right.

- Excellent sprite art.
- Excellent music.
- Excellent game feel. This one is actually the very reason I bought the game after seeing some footage of Clairen - I could tell that this game had very well polished and solid game feel.
- You can emulate SSBB's controls.
- No tripping.
- Second versions of stages without the gimmicks.

I don't plan to refund this game, and do plan to keep up with it in hopes that maybe these things will change.

Well, I'm not particularly hopeful, because I would imagine they've already had criticism about this kind of thing in the past, and that it's been out long enough that anyone playing would probably be used to how it is, but eh. I wouldn't want to keep this unrecommended if things do change.

----

There are good ways and bad ways to make spiritual successors to old games.

Here are examples of good things games have done:

SSBBrawl -> Smash 4
1. They removed tripping
2. They made competitive versions of every map
(Both things Aether has also done)

Team Fortress 2 -> Overwatch
1. Removed weapon switching from most classes, which makes it easier and makes players less likely to fumble.
2. Overwatch improves many systems TF2 has in order to make players knowledgeable of exactly what enemy is going after them, to give them every chance to succeed and have a fair fight.

2. Increased footstep volume, especially of enemy heroes you're weak to. Gives purpose to the normal footsteps TF2 has.

3. Every weapon/hero has unique sounds you can pick out from a distance. This feedback lets you identify enemies easily and know what's coming for you. Overwatch's sound design is said to be good enough that blind players can successfully play overwatch.

Again, an improvement of something that TF2 somewhat does, though it's not as easy to pick out different rocket launchers from each other based on the firing or explosion sounds, some things can be picked out, like shotguns vs rockets vs pipes vs miniguns.

4. Every projectile particle effect and hitscan tracer is unique looking, also allowing you to instantly identify your enemy.

This is something people never think about with the trails on rockets, pipes, and arrows in TF2, and Overwatch applies this concept to its entire set of heroes. It definitely is something that helps people succeed.

5. Auto-callout of enemy sentries/teleporters/stealth characters.

This is simply an improvement of TF2's manual voice chat, turning it into something that ensures these callouts actually get used and get used properly, helping your entire team identify what threats it should be dealing with (like sentries).

Super Mario 64 / Collectathons -> A Hat In Time
1. Improved movement with more recovery options.
2. A camera that's coded not to get stuck with bad camera angles.

----

The point is, these games add things to help the player succeed, be more in control of what's happening to them, and technically, "make things easier for the sake of more widespread accessibility".

Now, I know "dumbing things down" can be seen as a bad thing for players who want a less hand-holdy challenge, but I would say that all of these games are examples of making these improvements without hurting the main challenge.

The thing is, if you take A Hat In Time for example, if you decide that its movement controls are doing too much stuff for you automatically, that just means A Hat In Time could create more challenging platforming scenarios without frustrating the player, whereas it may have to avoid doing so if the controls themselves were a challenge to use.

Smash 4 and Overwatch are multiplayer games, so fighting humans with the same abilities will always be its own kind of challenge and making the controls easier only means more people will play and the good players will sit that much higher than the skill floor.

And since the skill floor will be lower, you'll have a bigger playerbase that can grow more over time.

More importantly, a lot of these top seller games all have this trait in common, and if you're going for a more punishing type of game, then your game will always just be [b]a niche[/b].

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Very fun and underrated game. By far the best attempt at a competitive platform fighter outside of Melee and Project M that's out there. 

I'm a competitive smash player and this game is an amazing stress reliever for me. Even if you're not into competitive smash, this game is a lot easier on the hands and more intuitive to pick up and play than those games since a lot of the tech skill from smash isn't there, the only thing you need to learn is wavedashing which is very easy to do in this game since you can just input sideways + airdash at the same time for a shortcut. 

Despite being a much easier game to get into the game still maintains that fast, chaotic, destructive feeling that Melee and PM have and doesn't go to being a slower game like the newer smash bros games are. The skill ceiling is still huge, the combo system is still deep, you can still do a ton with movement.

This is also the only Platform Fighter game (other than Brawlout) that doesn't just rip off smash characters. The characters might take some inspirations here and there, but they all feel like individuals and not just bootleg melee characters. In an aspect I love, all the characters have a mechanic (or even several mechanics) completely unique to them that changes up the gameplay in a big way. I'm going to list a few of them just to show the MMO-like variety available here.

Zetterburn - Specific moves give a burn status that does extra damage over time, burned characters take more knockback from smash attacks
Wrastor - All of his smashes are in the air rather than the ground, one of his moves summons a wind aura that buffs his movement
Etalus - has several moves that coat the ground with ice, this ice coating greatly enhances his wavedash and dash attack length. Several of his specials also have different properties if used on ice, including freezing the opponent and giving Etalus ice armor.

Each of the 9 (soon to be 11 as of tomorrow) characters has something of that variety. The music, aesthetics, and presentation are all also very solid. This game has the potential to create an entire genre, and I wish more titles would follow its passionate example and give us a greater variety of Melee-like games.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is an indie brawler the takes its gameplay mechanics from Nintendo's Super Smash Bros. series, as such this game will feel [i]very[/i] familiar to veterans of the series. Being a long time fan of the Smash series, I was able to pick up and play this game without going through any of the tutorial/practice stages. For newcomers, the controls, mechanics and characters are very easy to learn, but very hard to master which is a very big plus in my book.

The mechanics, as mentioned earlier, are almost directly ripped from the Smash series but with a few changes that have a drastic on how the game is played. For example, Smash fans will notice that there are no shields with them being replaced by the parry system (time the button press before an attack hits you to stun the enemy and counterattack). These are one of the few major changes that make this game familiar to Smash fans as well as help the game stand on its own two feet. Rivals of Aether also takes a few techniques from Melee, such as wavedashing which is an intended mechanic this time around, teching and many more techniques that I won't bother to list.

All of this culminates in a very fresh and enjoyable experience that is fun for both hardcore Smash fans, and newcomers alike, both casual and competitive (though the game caters more so the competitive scene).

However the only very, [i]very[/i] minor gripe I had with the game is the controls which may confuse long time fans as the default controls have three face buttons set to attacks (one for jabs/tilts, one for smash attacks and one for specials), but the controls are configurable and I rebinded my gamepad's face button to the stock standard Smash control setup (two buttons for jump and B and A for jabs/tilts and special moves respectively), so this was only an annoyance for the first few minutes of play.

Overall, I strongly reccomend this game if you're a Smash fan, or a newcomer and are willing to drop 14 bucks on a very well made tribute to the franchise instead of settling for a subpar f2p knockoff (sorry Brawlhalla, but that's how it is ;) ).

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is THE non smash bros smash bros game.
It's polished, well designed, and is very fun but also very good for competetive.
For veteren smash bros players it's pretty easy to pick up but there's a couple mechanics that are different: no grabs, no ledge grabbing, and instead of shielding there's parrying which stuns opponents.

It's also got a dedicated online community and it's very easy to get matches. Single player content is limited, there's a story mode which somewhat resembles classic singleplayer, and an abyss mode which is kind of like an "unending" trial. 

Despite being heavily inspired on another game, it's still very distinct and has its own unique feeling. I think it's a fantastic smash game and probably the best non nintendo one.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Amazing game! If you enjoy Melee, the you're going to love this!
It's easy to pick up for casuals and competitive players!
This game has it all! From wavedashing, dash-dancing, RAR, etc!
The graphics are retro, but suit this game extremely well!
The movement is very fluent, along with the FPS being a constant 60!
You don't even need a super powerful computer to play!
All the fighters are unique and have their own tech to discover!
DLC with reasonable prices and very new and diverse characters!
Stages are beautiful and have nice retro music to accompany them!
Super stable online mode! And some neat single player modes too!
10/10 game! Definitely sticking to it for a long time!

title: Rivals of Aether

HOLY CRAPOLA HOW DID I SLEEP ON THIS GAME

I now love this game more than melee, its not as fast or as complex but its one of those games where its easy to pick up but hard to master so thats fine.

I would whole heartedly recommend to buy this game if you are thinking of it, you will not be dissapointed at all.

With active devs, a great community and an amazing game with cheap amazing DLC, I couldnt ask for more.

Also the soundtrack is some of the best music ive heard in a game period.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you are still considering:

Rivals satisfies the Melee itch. 

Obviously some differences in gameplay such as:
-you can still do stuff after air-dodging
-wave dashing is easier (and more fun imo)
-wall jumping
-no shield, instead parry 

The No Shield might be a dealbreaker for some, but I think it just makes makes the gameplay more fast paced and a bit more offense driven. Without a shield, your defense relies on timing, spacing & movement- either parry, or dodge between hits or space away. Not to difficult to adapt to.

Each of the characters have much more depth and uniqueness.
They are well-balanced even with introduction of new character.
Multiplayer is great with a stable connection. Matches usually takes seconds to a minute for me (EU)

Developers also seem great, providing updates.
It would be great to develop the community even further with more players

I highly recommend this game to everyone, especially those who have played 64 and Melee.
Rivals does great what other games like Brawlhalla fail do to. So please give it a try!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is awesome. This game is basically melee but in an original universe. All of the characters are fun to play as and almost all of them to play against. The characters play like characters from Smash Bros. (Zetterburn is Wolf, Wrastor is Falco,  and Kragg is Bowser) but they have new moves and gimmicks (Wrastors Side b makes him faster and more agile, Kraggs up b creates a pillar so he can recover, Orcane leaves puddles of water in the ground and he can teleport to them) so at the same time they feel unique. The stages are pretty good, they're great for competitive play. So this is just a competitive Smash game. The Devs try to make the game a competitive as possible. The music is pretty good, and the sprites look amazing. So overall this is just a great game. 8/10 better than tr4sh.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
That was my review when the game was on early access, but some things have been added since then like the story mode. The story mode is nice, but its just classic mode with cutscenes, and the characters you fight against aren't even related to the story the game is trying to tell, except for the rival fight at the end. Another mode they added is abyss mode, which is kinda like the Wario Ware games, you have to complete an objective on a time limit, like launching your oppoonent into a portal or killing a cetain amount of enemies, etc. Its pretty fun, and it gets really hard on later waves. This game is also getting DLC characters, the first one being Ori, which i haven't played yet, and to new ones that are coming out pretty soon, Ranno and Clairen, they both look pretty cool. Overall, if you don't mind the small roster, (seriously, even Smash 64 has more characters) and if you like the Smash games (especially melee) you will like this game.
Keep in mind this game is supposed to be competitive so if you don't like competitive smash, the only thing this game has is stage hazards.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Okay, so I'm gonna give all of the positives, and (few) negatives I've found with this game, and hope that it helps someone to buy it. Because, well, it's a good game.
So here's the positives of the game: Fast paced gameplay that doesn't seem to get old, diverse characters that are easy to understand, but difficult to master, controller support for up to four people locally. and 1v1 gameplay online, the keyboard controls also feel amazing once adjusted, if you don't have a controller of sorts. the gameplay of course is influenced by the Super Smash Bros. series, but brings a lot of new concepts and ideas to the table that you won't find from that series, and it overall just gives a great fighting game that I love.
Now, here's the few cons: The online can have a lot of connection problems, anything from input lag, frame lag, or just people who leave their controllers unattended, As well as that, the amount of stages and characters is a bit low, but of course the full game will have 8 characters and 8 stages, so that's nothing permanent.
Overall, I'd recommend this game to anyone; I've only had it for about a week. and it's so fun to just lay down and go online to improve!

EDIT: 10/3/17
After the game's full release, and the inclusion of one new DLC character, with 4 more to come, I have to say, this game has turned out incredibly. Every problem that I could've seen with it before has been addressed in some way, and I'd recommend this title to absolutely anybody, casually or competitively.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals takes the foundation of Super Smash Bros. but makes it better. Don't get me wrong, Smash is amazing, but I feel like it sometimes finds it hard to find a good balance between casual and competitive play. Rivals was built to be a competitive fighting game for tournaments, while still having some fun stuff for casuals.

Here are some major perks about this game:
-All of the stages have a "basic" and "Aether" form. The basic forms have no stage hazards and all of them are tournament legal. Aether stages have hazards and are meant for casual matches. This option is amazing. It is what Smash 4 did with Omega stages but so much better.

-All of the characters are super unique. No two characters feel the same, and all of them feel fresh and new. None feel like they were ripped from Smash or don't feel unique. All of them feel so different from one another and you can't play any two the same way. The cast is also a LOT of fun, no matter who you pick. There is nobody who is boring to play as.

-All of the characters are balanced. All of the characters in this game are extremely well balanced. No character is definitely the best. All of them have their strengths and weaknesses. Plus patches are still being added to balance the cast further.

-It was made for tournament play. There is even a "tournament mode"  setting in the menu for local play for running tournaments. This mode gives you access to how big the sets will be, such as best of 3 and best of 5. It even shows the player's win count at the top in matches.

-The basic techniques from Super Smash Bros. Melee(Wavedashing and dash dancing) are made a lot more accessible, meaning that you spend more time focusing on learning combos and everything else and not having to spend lots of time learning movement options. It also makes you feel a lot more free and fluid in your movements, which feels amazing.

-The online mode is good. Unlike Smash 4, the online mode in Rivals is good. They are even played in sets instead of individual matches, further giving to the competitive vibe of the game. There are ranked matches, where you will fight players depending on your rank, which goes up or down depending on if you win or lose. Exhibition mode is basically unranked matches which pool all of the players together, no matter your rank or skill. There is also friendly matches, where you can play people on your Steam friend list.

-Great training mode. There are tons of options available to you in the training mode that are not available in Smash. For example, you can turn hitboxes and hurtboxes which are really useful for learning more about your character and testing combos out. You can also turn on frame advancing, which freezes time and lets you do movements on certain frames. There are a bunch of other options too, like changing the computer's DI, teching, action, etc, allowing you to practice all types of stuff.

-Fun single player mode. Unlike Smash 4, I found myself coming back to single player mode of Rivals. There are story modes for each of the six original characters, and I found myself coming back to it to try to beat them in the fastest time possible.

-At the time of this review, they are still adding content! This is what I used to love about Smash 4. Rivals is still getting new characters, stages, skins, patch updates, and features! It definitely keeps you invested in the game and excited for what they will announce next!

So, to conclude my review, you should definitely buy this game, especially if you like Smash or other platform fighters. It is a great fighting game and even surpasses Smash in many areas, in my opinion. It's fun to play both competitively and casually, and you will definitely get a lot of fun out of it, no matter what kind of player you are.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: As a platnium BH vet, I can say that the creator of ROA cares way more about their fanbase than BH. BH has a whiny fasebase, a rushed character cast, and bad dodge mechanics as of lately. ROA has everyone of those aspects better with custom colors and a story mode... Yeah. Nonetheless I still have my concerns for this game and its future. The ranked scene is super rare with finding a match taking 1-2 minutes to find someone. Half of the time I only play 1 game a day because if not I have to refight the same person again and again until I either go way up or drop 30-40 ELO which is a lot for ROA. Another issue is that 2v2s with friends dont exist at all! Seriously is a bummer if you want to play this with more than one friend and yourself. The last big complaint I have is fire 3 with Zetterburn on the custom color menu. I absolutely DISPISE this color because if it isnt white or black, it makes my eyes strain like mad. Not only that but people love using yellow bright pink etc to make it worse. This often causes me to lose my match and makes me feel humiliated due to how if this wasnt an option, I wouldn't of lost. Wrapping up, this game is great for comp play but absolutely play BH if you want friends to join you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Game's good, plays like a quite frantic and technical Smash Bros. clone that mashes a little from each entry of that series into itself(obviously with major Melee emphasis in there, what with the wavedashing, fairly quick fall speeds across the board and all that stuff), while also adding its own unique spins(perhaps most notably the lack of proper shields and grabs, being replaced by parries, and the removal of ledges in favour of letting everyone cover ridiculous distance if they get to walljump off the stage). There's few characters, but they're built around unique gimmicks(that often linger on and affect the stage itself and can be used in unique ways by their characters, both to control area as well as amplifying their moves in some way) and fighting styles(many characters borrowing entire chunks of moves from different Smash characters and thus playing like odd hybrids of them) so the roster is quite diverse in spite of that.

Music and overall presentation is great, much better than any comparable game I could think off on Steam, and feels nicely polished. Singleplayer content does its job giving you something to do outside of good ol' PvP and adding some minor world building to the game's setting and characters(nothing big, don't expect an anime fighter worth of plot, just some small bits that add some context to the game beyond "funny animal people with elemental powers punch each other until one flies off the screen". It's no grand epic and it doesn't need to be).
The meat of the game is the multiplayer though, which you get to enjoy locally and online. Unfortunately the game's practice/singleplayer modes don't quite feel expansive and elaborate enough to quite get you used to the game I feel, which is a bit of a problem as it is a quite technical fighter all things considered, and due to the game's comparably low(but still acceptably sized) playerbase the majority of the online multiplayer games consist of you playing a lagtastic match with a dude on the moon or getting bodied by a guy that plays like his life depended on it. Gitting gud is a struggle because of that, and you should be prepared for that if you buy this game. That being said, finding someone you are on a somewhat even footing with(and can play with a reasonable ping) is fun, satisfying and feels like a learning experience every time.

So yeah, it's pretty dope. I'd recommend it.
