review:
Although i love the game, I'm really pissed about the fact that I have to buy a new characters.....
I mean this kind of payment for new content or in this case for a SINGLE new character is okay for games that are free or game that offer a lot more content....but why should i pay 15€ in my case and another 5€ for 1 I repeat 1! fu**ing character.
That fact alone is enough, that i would like to refund the game, although i can't.
The second thing is ...why is online play with friends limited to 2 players. 
I mean sure the devs want to get a foot into the comp. scene, however they focused on that so much that they simply forgot the casual players, because some players just don't give a damn about the rating nore watch pros playing on tournaments and yet this game provides no fun for casual people.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I love the game, it is very fun! my only complaints are the sound design and lack of characters. The devs are adding new characters like crazy as of now, so thats being taken care of, however the sound design remains extremely unsatisfying.

If you land a fully charged strong attack on kragg for instance, it plays a sound seemingly identical to the regular punching sounds. The sounds dont really have any cracking to them, and as such just dont feel powerful. Many sounds are reused as well, which leads me to believe that they intend to fix this as well in the future. As it is the largest of any complaint I could have, I definitely hope so, but an addition that doesn't force the player to lock in their account and controls EVERY SINGLE TIME you start up the game would be appreciated as well. The online play is surprisingly good, but there is always room to improve with that kind of stuff.


Each of the characters feel unique, and have their own kind of gimmick to them. Kragg, my favorite character as of now, for instance has his rock and tower which change the terrain of the stage. All charatcters have some form of zoning and stage control, and that rules. Ori-and sein, the dlc champion, also kind of strikes me in an odd way. For such a small cast it seems odd to have a dlc champ, but its not actually a big deal. My issue with it is that the character feels too good. Not super busted mind you, but similar to zetterburn in that you get a TON of reward from doing some very simple things that require minimal effort. I dont think they should be nerfed to the ground, but I do think some tweaking is in order.

As long as the sounds become more satisfying, I will have no problem reccomending this game to anyone. Even if they don't, if you appreciate fighting games ((especially smash of course)) this is a must buy.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is one of the funnest Smash-type games I've played, and I played quite a few. It's got a few gimmicks, including..well, very unorthodox ways to go about attacking and combos with certain characters that wouldn't even remotely be allowed in Smash's gameplay.

Rivals of Aether is slowly gaining characters, and on their website, it showed that we'll be getting a new original Rival after Ori, plus 3 more, so that's 13, 1 more than Smash 64's roster. Well, maybe, who knows? I saw it mentioned in the Ori reveal on their website; maybe it'll even get to Melee's character amount, which would be really cool. The stages are all unique and have pretty much the equivalent of Omega Forms of stages in Sm4sh, built specifically for online play I suppose, or just to duke it out without stage hazards, which are also pretty cool too.

For me, Rivals feels like Melee, but plays a bit like Smash 64 in that it's pretty easy to combo if you know the character you're playing as. Each character plays very different to each other one, but it's pretty easy to tell which you like best. All in all I give it a really positive review in my book. It's got me interested in seeing how the new characters they're developing will play. I have yet to play Ori and Sein but it's gonna be a good time, but I'll probably still be with Absa. She's cool. :]

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
positives
-not brawlhalla
negatives
-not melee

But in all seriousness, this game is extremely flawed and tries very hard to be a competitive game. This game is beyond fixing to be viable in a competitive sense. It would need massive gameplay overhauls to become a more well balanced game. The attempt to be unique with the removal of shields and grabs just makes the game even more one-dimensional. The dumbed down techskill and the removal of L-Cancelling makes the game much easier to pickup, and appeals to a much larger audience, but that is a bad move when you are catering to a niche-melee audience, who are all obsessed with techskill. But on other hand, it's alright casually, I guess. Not much content to begin with, so all there is to do is a story mode and 1v1s/2v2s online. Not to mention the 8 WHOLE characters, all with their own little gimmicks (Gimmicks do not belong in a fighting game, but I will not get into that). And to top it all off, the release a PAID DLC character to a PAID GAME. 

Possibly thought I would give this game a positive review, but naw, they deserve a negative.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Had an origial review two years ago, but it didn't do anything for proving how good the game was. So I'm redoing it (not like any of you care, though.)

As it has most likely been stated many times before, Rivals of Aether is a brawler which draws inspiration from the Smash Bros. series. With this, similar mechanics are reflected, mostly from the Melee era, with air dodging being a mechanic as well as wavedashing alongside all the basic Smash Bros. mechanics (apart from grabs).

First of all, the tutorial to this game is a masterpiece. It teaches you the basics as well as some more advanced commands and even some things about specific characters, be it a mechanic that they're based around (Absa cloud, Etalus ice etc.) to a certain move having more uses than one (sweet spots, Etalus Fair). This tutorial gets you set for a brawler aimed at the competitive design of this game perfectly.

Second of all, the characters. As most of you know, there's 9 different characters to choose from (if you're not poor). Every single one of these characters can be played toe to toe with another with enough time put into each. This is one of the main reasons why Rivals has been such an amazing game - the character combo possibilities. Every character revolves around a single mechanic, but they all still have 5 aerials, 4 tilts, jab and a dash attack, so the flexibility of how each character can eliminate a threat is completely up to the player. All in all, each character created is fun to play and master, while newer characters are fun to see how to play them. And most of all, the developers of this game are so in touch with the community, it's insane.

So now I'll go over the developers. These people put so much effort into this game, it's surprising that they even have time to intertwine with the community online and at events at all. The development team is extremely interactive and sociable (at least, from what I've seen - please don't hunt me down for errors Dan) to the point where Dan himself enters his own Rivals competition just for the heck of it. They even go online to prove how to counter certain champs (well, apart from Alpha's Ranno vid, idk whether you've done it before, but I'mma put you in a positive light, dammit) if someone can't understand how.

Finally, the community to this game. Holy heck, this community is luscious. First of all, I have never seen a community for a game so competitive so friendly before (mind me, I haven't really gone into the Smash community very often, so I can't make relations. Jeez, just realised how much this review is filled with a bunch of hollow comments...). These people create guides for characters, are willing to chat abut nearly everything, shake hands after almost every game at an event and even set themselevs up as MENTORS for people to learn characters with so they get better at the game! WHAT KIND OF DEVOTION IS THAT?!

In conclusion, Rivals of Aether is not a 'Melee Rerelease' or a 'Smash Bros. Ripoff'. This game sees Smash Bros. and thinks "How can I make this better" by implementing their own ideas and mechanics, giving a funky fresh new experience for all Smash fans, or newcomers, to enjoy. Well one of the ideas apparently was removing grabs, but hey. I ain't complaining.

Also, the reason I didn't go in-depth about stages is coz they're stages. They look cool, they're all fundamentally playable and always going Random doesn't tear your hair out from a particular stage (except Treetop Lodge, but that's just me).

Rivals of Aether gets a 9.5/10. If you see this game, have a controller and can afford it, don't even THINK about spending money on anything else, because god dammit, this game's worth it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I really like this game. Bought it last April and got into it this Summer, it's a real blast to play. Controls are slick and each character is balanced, with their own mechanic that makes them unique (Wrastor's air smash attacks, Orcane's puddle reliability, Etalus' ice mechanic, etc.), so each one can be used by anyone. The music is clean (Spirit Tree and Blazing Hideout give me life) and the animation is smooth. Seriously worth the buy.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Finally a fighting game that takes a sort of unique spin on the Smash playstyle. It's like a less technical focused Melee.

Differences are that: no shielding (replaced with a parry system), no grabbing, and most importantly no ledge grabbing.
The game feels that it's way more aggro since there are less defensive options. It's really focused on gimping as well.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I don't need to get into detail as to what this game is so I'll just cut straight to the Chase and make this quick. It's a Super Smash Bros Melee Clone which does the Job very well too and for the most part I've been enjoying it. Oh if you're a Competitive Player unlike me there are no items like in Smash Bros so it's more of a fair fight, none of this being sent flying off the Stage by a random Bob-Omb falling down out of nowhere nonsense.

My only complaint is quite often more than not I find myself struggling with an Xbox Controller which makes the experience borderline infuriating. Even though I'm not a Competitive Player I have a Competitive Streak, I like to perform well and when you have Controls that IMHO hinder the experience I do get irritated as in very irritated. Having a whole minute added onto your time when you select Continue in Story Mode does touch a nerve with me admittedly and I just wish I had a means to play this with a Gamecube Controller but as it stands now I don't.

Despite all that I'm not going to let a minor hindrance influenece my rating for the game.

I rate Rivals of Aether 9/10

All the characters are so unique and creative. The online is peer to peer so it can be a little difficult if you keep running into people with bad connection but that doesn't happen too often. title: Rivals of Aether
review:
SM4SH RANT! dont worry, review is below it.
I have played smash almost religiously with my friends for years. got better and better at it. then smash 4 came out. i chose my fave. then they savagely nerfed it into unusabilty for reasons unknown (greninja). ok, so i moved back to my previous fave from brawl, lucario. who has the WORST design in smash 4. they made him slower much slower, his moves have awful frame data and damage. his poorly thought out gimmick mechanic is his only saving grace. a character who was supposed to be quick and powerful and supposed to be one of the heavier characters. is one of the weakest, slowest, and most fragile in the series. he was horribly nerfed in his introduction to smash 4 who was then nerfed EVEN MORE because his recovery was "too good" which was the point. he was supposed to be sticky and hard to remove so he could make use of his gimmick mechanic which increases the power of his moves based on how much damage he has taken. in brawl, lucario just clicked to my style. and started my pokemon obsession. it hurts to see completely clueless character balancing in a former favorite game. nothing kills a fighting game faster than when all the characters you liked get changed and now you have to tier whore just to keep up with your friends with characters you dont even like. something my friends and i started noticing more and more was that we ONLY favored fast characters and could NEVER knock eachother out without grabbing. we would get to 200+ until a quick nuetral was enough to knock us out. what used to be a game about getting in eachothers heads, learning their style and acting to beat it disappeared. now its about using one of few characters that can combo off of grabs. smash attacks are never used and our fingers never leave the block button and we travel by dodge rolling. any other tactic is outclassed by simply doing that.

RANT OVER!!! REVIEW TIME!
dont let its furry pixilated cover fool you. This game is WAY better than smash competitively. character design and theming are diamond solid. its obvious that a lot of careful thinking went into every little move to give every character their own bread and butter combos and strats. every character has unique mechanics and abilities that you gradually learn from playing teh game and constantly keep your brain working fast while fighting. the downside to that is that there are only 9 fighters. but its safe to choose favorites because they are extremely well balanced with very creative movesets.

gameplay overall is very closely a replica of SSB melee. physics are the same and you can air dodge in any direction once. however, they removed grabs which i think was a good idea after smash 4 became what it is. and it forces you to play mind games and make predictions on your opponent which is what made smash fun in the first place. they also remade the block mechanic into perrying. so instead of turtling an attack by holding block then grabbing. you have to time it like a perfect block but only in that small window will it take effect. no more spamming grab combos after blocking.

now content wise there isnt much here. story mode is short. and abyss mode loops every 15 floors (recomend randomizing the challenges up to the boss creature to make it more interesting.) but honestly if you played smash competitively, then all you really care about is character design and what stage is the flattest, right?

DEVS!!!
for the love of all things smash related. please continue this game. add more content and hopefully more characters. im having pure fun playing ALONE already. this game if it were to grow could become something truly amazing and potentially redeem the smash style fighting games. this game has such huge potential!

title: Rivals of Aether
review: As a casual Smash player I was recommended by a friend to play this game. It's good music, amazing sprite work, and good net code made the casual matches with my friend really fun. What held me back was the keyboard controls. I don't have a controller for my pc so I was planning on playing it with a keyboard. However, there was such a delay for using the keyboard that I couldn't respond as fast as I could have, noticing around a second delay from pressing the key and seeing the action on screen. It simply made the controls feel sluggish and heavy in response; like I was controlling a tank. I wish there was a better control scheme for the PC users that have to use a keyboard. If you have a controller then get this game, it is a great time with friends. If you're like me, then either dump $40 on a controller or adapter for your PC or just don't get it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is beatiful.  It reminds of Smash Brothers, but also has its own unique charm.  I'll cut right to the chase:
Pros:
-Extremely stylized characters with unique abilities
-Thorough tutorials for beginner, intermediate, advanced, and character specific
-Custom skin creation
-Competitive play
-Runs very smoothly (besides some latency issues somewhere along the line)
-Deep lore and story mode for each character
-4 player local play

Cons:
-Small player base leads to small matchmaking pools
-One may only compete with one other player over the internet
-Steep learning curve for those new to the genre

Overall, I really enjoy this game.  I am still new to it, but fell in love immediately.  It is a game that I can spend 3 hours dueling a friend and have a great time.  The small character pool honestly makes me more fond of the gaame because there is less to pick up.  Mechanically, I am still learning the more complex maneuvers like wavedashing, wavelanding, techs, and animation cancels, but I have a great time every time I load up the game.  Highly recommended.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I haven't played a lot (yet) but from what I've seen this game is insanely cool and I would recommend everyone who loves smash/brawlhalla/similar games buying Rivals Of Aether. The characters are very well designed and many of their moves are similar to moves from smash melee. What really made my day is the fact that if you (for example) spike, the attack actually sends the opponent downwards. The controls on a keyboard are quite hard to get used to though.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Game was good before it stopped balancing their characters. A good compromise for a smash clone if you're on a low-end PC, but don't get in here and expect learning to be a thing. Matchmaking is just nothing but Ori and Sein (The new pay to win hero. Can do true combos that get you from 0% to 50%.) and Absa. (A hero who can infinitely jab you, shoot lightning bolts from across the entire stage, zip around like pikachu, and float like Mewtwo.)

Everybody is either so good that you can't get them past 50%, or so bad that they fall off the stage more times than they hit you. There is no in between, and no learning curve. Whereas Brawlout has nothing but horrible spammers, and Brawlhalla won't stop breaking the game with new "features" that make it 10 times harder to punish passive players, (Which the game mostly consists of.) both of which are learnable and have decent matchmaking. If you have never played Brawlhalla before, you can be confident that if you sit down and play for a while, you'll soon start to see changes in your skill level, because its easy to learn from your mistakes and learn to be a better player. Here, there is no way to improve your skills without going into training mode. And even when you go into training mode, you get a false sense of confidence after finding a few combos, only to be stunlocked by somebody with 5 dollars and a B button ten minutes later.

The most fun heros to play are the first four that came out. I finally found another Kragg main and we kept rematching over and over just to play against another Kragg. That was fun, but the developers decided fun wasn't a part of the game anymore. The newer heros are completely unbalanced and absolutely stomp the older heros. I put hundreds of hours into this game on my girlfriends account and I can say it was fun while it lasted. But this is just another slow-paced easily-spammable poorly balanced fighter game we can add to the list of "Smash on PC" games that ended up nothing like Smash. Get dolphin and download project M, you're a lot better off.

If you're here looking for a Smash clone or something to remind you of Melee, you're in the wrong place.

review:
REWRITING BECAUSE I AM BAD AT WORDS AND DID NOT ACCURATELY GET MY POINTS ACROSS. ALSO I WAS REALLY SALTY WHEN I FIRST WROTE IT SO I WAS WAY MORE HARSH THAN I NEEDED TO BE.

I'm gonna start this off with a point that I can't say enough: this game has potential to be a really fun and really good game and I wish steam had a not good but not bad option because that would fit a lot more with what I actually think. However, as of right now I've encountered enough bugs that make the game much less enjoyable in only 20 minutes of playing and make me lean more towards not reccomend than reccomend. 

I hope that in the future these glitches are fixed but for the current build of the game it makes it hard to learn when you can't get past the tutorial because it wont progress. Another thing to note is that the game still is very limited in its content, as right now it only features 1v1 mode with more to come. Again, this is all subject to change and I hope that the future game modes turn out fun. 

Unfortunately, as of right now, the bugs that make its already small amount of content less enjoyable are currently, in my opinion, what stands in the way of this game most right now. Hopefully at some point soon these bugs are ironed out and then I can change the review to a reccomend, but until then, I just can't say I would buy it, escpecially not at its full price of $15.

The multiplayer aspect of this game is great, with almost no bugs. When bugs are discovered, they are fixed. You may easily play with people on your Steam friends list or choose a random person from around the world to fight.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is a game meant for Melee purists. I don't know what else I was expecting. For those looking for Smash on PC, turn away, this is Melee for PC. It focuses on using glitches present in the original as game mechanics and will kick your arse if you don't learn to master them right away.

I personally hate Melee and its following and am absurdly disappointed in this game for catering almost exclusively towards the competitive Melee market. As such, while I enjoy this game on the whole, it's multiplayer is simply not an anjoyable place to be for someone to get some friendly ring-out action. As such I can't recommend it to anyone. It's simply not a fun Smash clone, and that's saying a lot considering it's the most acurate one to the original. You're better off just buying a Wii U or 3DS and a copy of Smash on those systems. And if you really yearn for a casual experience, Get Brawl on the Nintendo Wii.

review:
Amazing. Ridiculously fun and the tutorial actually tells you about advanced mechanics like teching. The characters are all unique and interesting, and the game is very well-balanced. Each character has a multitude of moves and very different ways to play them.

The only downside is there isn't a ton of people playing right now. You can fix that!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game does a great job at making Melee an acessable game.
If you like melee GET THIS.
Brawlhalla is too simplified.
Brawlout is kinda shady (imo) and not very balanced.

 It doesnt require frame perfect L cancels, wavedashes, etc. and has a tutorial not only for ALL of the tech, attacking, and survivabiltiy (though its basic) but it also has specialized tutorials for each character. 

Me being one for aesthetics like that there is a way for you to customize each characters skin to what you like color pallet wise. Yes there are special skins (Shine Zetter, Burrito Kragg, 3 on the steam store etc.) these will run you $2-$5, the custom one cost you nothing. The speical skins are for supporting the game tourneys and/or participaring in them.

This game has an amazing practice room, easy (for the most part) tutorials, and even for the totally casual player a story and endless mode which is a lot of fun for a party game. What I think it lacks in is matchmaking which brings me to the next point.

If you play online and keep getting paired with people who 3 stock you they have a great community that is willing to worth with you through discord and MANY tourneys that nearly anyone can join in (MSB Ameture etc).

Pixel graphics are not for everyone but that being the case for me I can still say the game mechanics and gameplay are WELL worth the sacrafice in graphics. NOT TO MENTION I can play this on my on my little shitty I-3 laptop with hardly any lag (Minus maybe 4 Zetters burning the place down)

TL;DR: If you like Melee and are looking for something similar buy this game.
Highly recommend it!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
As we all now this game was inspired by super smash bros. melee, one of the best fighting games of our times. And if you try to make a spiritual successor to melee it better be the best gosh dang game of all time. 

So did it live up to its goal? Yes but I must admit that it has its ups and downs. This game feels just as fast as melee and can be just as fun if both players know the mechanics. The gameplay feels polished and the online can be a problem, but in my experience it is not that bad depending on connection (I would recommend using an ethernet connection for fast paced games like this one). However it also has its downsides. Some characters feel more inbalanced than others (though this is common in all fighting games), the roster could be a bit bigger (although more characters are coming) and the online only supports two players.

So in the end, I would recommend it if you have some friends to play with, especially friends that want to go competitive on it. This can be a really fun party game and I see it having a growing competitive scene that may one day be a major EVO event.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Honestly more intereseted in learning this than most AAA fighting games. 

As a platform fighter RoA draws a lot of inpiration from Smash Bros, that's the draw for most people. However from what I've played I can safely say it's pretty unique in its own right. Every character feels unique and they all have their own unique gimmicks and movesets that flow really well once you get used to them.

If you enjoy Smash or games like it then I honestly can't think of a reason not to recommend this game. [spoiler]Except for the people who main Kragg in Exhibition matches. ;-;[/spoiler]

Seriously fun and satisfying to play with a pretty well-rounded learning curve. I look forward to spending many more hours with this gem.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like the fast pace of Super Smash Bros. Melee but want a more accessible, cheaper, and easier game to pick up, then this is game for you!

I have, personally, loved this game ever since I got it back in 2015. This game is for both competitive and casual players alike. It plays rather smoothly and the controls are easy to learn. The soundtrack is great and will serve the purpose of getting the players into the mood to play a competitive set. The characters are unique and fun while they are all still viable in a tournament setting. This game is great for what it is and is just more than a simple Smash clone, I know Dan and his team are still consistently putting in time and effort to give the players a more balanced and interactive game while working on DLC characters, costumes, and stages. If you haven't picked this game up and like playing aggressively, go ahead and pick it up, I'm sure you'll enjoy it!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I played the game since early access, and it has only improved from there. All of the eight characters are playable and mostly balanced since there are more advantaged than others but the most important thing is that it makes some of the most advanced tech borrowed form it's ispiration (melee) and makes them more accesible with easy input timings, great tutorials and easy to learn characters (most of them)  without losing speed or making the less skilled players left out. 

Another thing that you don't have to worry about is reducing the skill gap because what matters more to the developers is the ability players have at the game. Even if you see some characters dominating at competitive level they are still working close with the community to fix the issues the game might have.

The only two issues i have is the grinding of the abyss mode on single player and the 2 hour campaign. Still they were more focused on the multiplayer aspect which is the most important one for a fighting game longevity.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
TL:DR AT BOTTOM


I have played this game since around the end of 2015 so i have seen it grow and i can say This game is amazing if you are into Competitive fighting games... It has a very active discord and monthly online tournements making it easy for anyone that wants to try it out and get more serious about it. Even with its competitive nature the community is very friendly and helpful not to include Etalus (or George) the Dev One of the most active and responsive developer in any game i have ever seen. He checks the Steam forums frequently and is on the discord and be contacted very easily. With all the positives of this game there are a few problems. At a glance the whole cast can be very OP and that makes it difficult for new comers to jump in and figure things out. How ever there are steps in place to make it easier. There are decent tutorials and The discord server allows people to find people of similar skill and people who are willing to help them learn. Another problem is the small cast how ever they will be adding more and have already announced a new character just a few  months after the whole release. With only 8 characters i find my self having spurts of Bordem(?) so i have to take a break from the game but i can always  come back. You may have noticed i Refer to the discord and the community in general as this game is more a community than just a game. Check out the discord and you can see that very clearly. If i had to do the basic and next to useless 1 outta 10 rating i would give this game a 7.5/10

TL:DR
This game is competitive and its good. Difficult for begginers but gives tools to help. Check out the discord if you plan on getting the game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It used Super Smash Bros. Melee as a foundation and did its own thing. Melee players will feel at home and new players can get up to par with the old balls through great tutorials and explanations.

7/26/17 edit: You're gonna need a controller for this game. Doesn't matter if its Xbox or gamecube (if you have a mayflash adapter, you just plug in and play!), all fighters are gonna need a controller. Haven't played with an arcade stick so I couldn't say, but it feels natural to me on a Steam Controller, Xbox 360, and Gamecube.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
While this game does pay some homage to the infamous Smash Bros, this game has done something that most smash clones haven't done, stand from the shadows of its master. Rivals of Aether is a game that I feel like is the game that does all of the right things and I can say doesn't feel like a Smash Bros game. 

With all of that said, I can definitely say that this game has a high learning curve for beginners and people familiar with smash bros. If you're going in thinking you can do all of the stuff you think you can do in this game, well this game will glady and swiftly send you flying into the blast zones upon thinking like that. This game optimizes combos and character familiarization to its prime. Yes, it doesn't have a crazy 58 roster like Smash Bros for the Wii U, but with 8 characters that have its own strengths and weaknesses, I found it easier to learn about every character's strengths and weaknesses with it coming down to putting in the time to play the game. DON'T GET DISCOURAGED, keep it up and you'll do fine. 

Anything that I was messing up on or need some clarity helps out in Local mode where there's a tutorial, story mode and abyss mode that can help you improve. Online allows you to push yourself to the next level. There's so many small things included in this game that makes playing each match enjoyable. From controller calibration, color customization, to ranked matches, and playing your friends online. For a clone, this game is amazing. With Ori coming out this summer, hopefully this will attract more people to play this game.

I would say for its for price, I think its worth it. With 8 characters, online mode, story, training and small subtle things in the game, there's no reason not to pick this up if it appeals to you. If you do, prepare yourself, competition is rough!

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
TL;DR: buy this game right now just do it trust me

This game is the best fighting game on the market that is not Super Smash Bros. or Street Fighter, in my opinion. 

While there are not many, the characters all feel completely different and fleshed out, which is helped by the storybook style of the story mode. Additionally, there are no "clone" characters, a common practice in fighting games (Fox, Falco). 

The gameplay is pristine and smooth and is an absolute treat no matter what you are doing. If there was ever a game to style gameplay after, it would be Super Smash Bros. Melee, and lucky for us, that's what Dan Fornace did in Rivals of Aether. If you've played any Super Smash Bros. game before (my personal favorite game of all time being Smash 4), you will feel right at home. Many of the characters even pay homage to the Super Smash Bros. series by including some of their moves. You will find that a few of the moves characters have originate from Smash Bros. veterans such as Marth, Fox, Meta Knight, and Mario. I would, however, strongly advise you play with a controller.

In short, I would definitely reccomend this game to anyone, especially fighting game fans. I can't wait to see what the team has in store for us, and I also can't wait for the Ori DLC  that is coming soon. Buy this now ;P

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you love competitive fighting games for the purpose of competitive play and nothing else, you'll enjoy this game. But if not, consider other games instead.

All of the offline modes are dull. There's a story mode that has lots of plot holes and is super short. The lore is so bad I enjoyed the rest of the game less after playing it. There's an abyss mode that gets old quickly. And the AIs are really awful. So what about online mode?

The online mode is really incomplete. The biggest thing here is that you can only play with one friend, even though the game supports four player slots. It doesn't make any sense. Another thing that bugs me is how there's only one stage selection method (a competitive, stage-banning one).

There's also no reason that you need to grind in order to unlock several stages and characters. All it does is force you to waste time unlocking them, and then once they've been unlocked, there's not much else to do with the currency you use to unlock them with.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals is like the easier Melee. It's still the fast paced, tense, and skill requiring game that Melee is, but a lot more forgiving and easy on the hands. I'd recommend this game to anyone, whether it's the casual gamer looking for a unique fighter to enjoy with friends or the competitive gamer looking to clock in tens of hours in an aggressive arena. 
If I had to boil the game down to where it shines and where it fails, this is how I'd list it:

+Unique playable characters
+Great controls and handling
+Allows for play at any skill level
+Pretty art style and fitting soundtrack
+Very helpful, comes with tons of tutorials to help out anyone who wants to learn some advanced techniques or even the game's core mechanics
+Works well with most computers
+One of the only Smash clones that does its job perfectly and excels

-Poor online play in options and connectivity. I don't think I've played a game that lags me so much for playing with players worldwide. Being in an area pretty far from North America where most Rivals players live, I can never get a game with less than 200ms ping. It's extremely aggravating and makes the game's best parts seem inaccessible to me
-The AI enemies can't really be considered too challenging, and the same can be said with the story mode and other areas of the game meant for solo play.  I won't complain too much about this since it's pretty standard for a game in its area though.

The game is great at its core but I feel it should try to touch up its other aspects, like options for group play, server connectivity, and solo play. Overall though, I'd give it an 8/10.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I love this game.

[i]Rivals of Aether[/i] is what happens when you take competetive Super Smash Bros. Melee and make it accessible to everyone.

[i]Rivals[/i] is a competetive Platform Fighter ("PlatFighter") which places extreme emphasis on movement and aggression. Many of the defensive maneuvers from Nintendo's Super Smash Brothers series are absent: you cannot grab ledges, and shields have been replaced with ridiculously strict (1/20th of a second) parries that leave opponents vulnerable. There is virtually NO defense in this game, so professional Smash 4 players need not apply (#ShotsFired).

As of this writing, the game contains eight playable characters, with an additional five to be added to the game before the year is out. They're all extremely different in playstyle, with each character posessing a unique gimmick that can affect the field of battle in some way. Zetterburn ignites his enemies to deal damage over time, Forsburn uses smokescreen and fake copies of himself, Wrastor lives and dies by his combo ability, Etalus can encase himself in ice armor, Kragg is [b]too f*cking versatile[/b] for a heavyweight character, so on and so forth.

If you're going to play this game online - and you really ought to, as the game's A.I. is garbage - then you will need to accept that you're going to get bodied. Like, a lot. I just got bodied three times in a row earlier today. [i]Rivals[/i] is NOT an easy game, and you will need to sink a lot of time into practicing the game if you want to start playing in the online tournaments and earning tournament-exclusive character skins.

Thankfully, the game's online community is generally non-toxic (most of the time), and I've met several incredibly nice people who have helped me improve my Etalus game immensely. There are myriad useful learning resources, such as the [url=https://discord.gg/ZcSNXDC]Rivals of Aether Academy Discord Server[/url], among others. Learning to play competetively can be a long journey, but you won't be alone for any of it.

The game's presentation is... mixed; and I'm not just referring to my personal vendetta against pixel art. Some characters seem to be lacking in animation frames when other characters have plenty of animation frames. The pixel resolution is at least consistient, and very rarely are any of the pixels 'rotated' like in games such as... well, 90% of all pixel art games.

The game's soundtrack is mostly excellent, though it's obvious which tracks were the first tracks composed, as they are only ~45 seconds long compared to later tracks which can be three times as long. My personal favorite track belongs to the Tempest Peak stage: [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ne4Y_q1FZOY]Lightning Pandaemonium[/url]. 

The game's Story Mode is... uh... well, it certainly exists. The real meat of the single player content is Abyss Mode, where you can customize your character with overpowered enhancements and take on waves of unique enemies and challenges. It's great fun once your character is fully decked out. There is also a toggleable Developer Mode which lets you customize the game's characters as you see fit.

The game has two major flaws. The first is that the grind to unlock all of the unlockable stages and the second custom color slot for each character is unbearably long, so much so that I resorted to save file editing just to spare myself the grief. The second is the aforementioned character Kragg, who is genuinely far too heavy for a character with the most versatile moveset in the entire game bar none.

So, in conclusion, even though the game is far from perfect, it is nontheless a rewarding experience with a surprisingly level-headed community surrounding it.

If nothing else, at least it's a better fighting game than Street Fighter V.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is a very fun fighting game if smash bros without items is your cup of tea. In fact,  the game does support Gamecube controllers if you have the adapter for it. The fighters are original enough and have some novel ideas require a bit of adjustment to this game if you come from smash (no ledge grabs, parry instead of shield, no grab). The roster is a little small but considering the game's price it's fair. I have been playing this game in Europe and all my matches so far have been from the U.S. so keep that in mind if you are interested in online play.

In terms of game modes, the game has the typical story mode, versus and tutorial modes there's an endless mode of sorts where you go through various challenges with a single stock. You can try the endless mode with a friend apparently but I haven't tried it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Okay, so I am a Super Smash Bros. fan and I was looking for a game that is like it. So I turn on my PC and log in to steam not expecting to find anything good when I find Rivals of Aether. I click on the game not expecting much but when I watch all of the trailers I become immediatly interested. I was so happy that this game was not like brawlhalla which was very repetative and each character felt the same. However, Rivals of Aether on the other hand has characters with unique movesets unlike in brawlhalla where every single moveset is basically the same. So when the summer sale started I immediatly rushed to buy this game. Overall this is one of the best games like Smash Bros. I would recommend to this game to anyone that enjoyed playing melee. Also for you newcomers there is a whole tutorial with step by step guides on all of the basic controls. If you are not comfortable with the default controls, you can even create your own custom controls. My favorite feature for this game is the fact that you can make your own CUSTOM SKINS that is what really got me hooked on this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Fun game! Coming from playing melee this game definitely carries over the fun aspects of movement, low lag aerials, and combos. Only downside is matchmaking can sometimes lead to really frustrating matches of getting bodied caused by this game having higher hitstun combos but that just comes down to me gitting gud lol.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Probably one of the best Smash inspired games I've ever played. While it feels a lot like Melee, it's different enough that it's a much different game to play. Every character has incredibly creative and interesting mechanics and the tutorials help you understand pretty much everything within a couple hours of playing. An absolute must buy if you've got a couch and some friends nearby.

Emphasis on nearby though, it seems pretty unanimous that the online needs some serious work. I actually thought something was wrong with my internet until I checked it with my phone. Unbelievably frequent disconnects, it's near impossible to even get a match with ping under 100.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is fantastic, the art is gorgeous, the music will get your heart pumping in no time, and the controls are spot on. There's a lot of depth here to explore like all the different ways Kragg can use his neutral special to wall off his opponent or all the insane ways Orcane can use his puddles to power up his smash attacks. If you like Smash Bros but want original characters, this is definitely the game for you.

But four warnings for those who want to pick it up:
1. There is no ledge grab. This seems small but it's definitely something to get used to for players who are just coming off smash and expect it to play similarly. Also expect to eat a few lives because your recovery came just short. No items too, but that's up to you if it's a good or bad thing.

2. Online has nothing stopping a pro from stomping a newbie. If you go online and you're not ready for it, prepare to be destroyed by someone three times your skill level. 

3. Blast zones are a hell of a lot closer than you think they are, just in general. The game wants you in the center to duke it out or on the side bars sparingly to style on an opponent, you go off screen, you're dead for the most part. No negotiating. The sky hitboxes tend to have the most leeway, but chances are if you're already up there from a juggle, you're not coming back down.

4. If you're fresh off Smash controls, be sure to hit the wrench icon on the character profiles. It can be very jarring to need a seperate button for strong attacks verses tilts or a seperate button to jump. Thankfully before you even hit start there's a great "test play" option to make sure everything's in working order before a match.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is an amazing game if you have ever played Super Smash Bros. (especially melee) this is a must have. With the ability to turn every stage into a more competitive version and in-game tutorials on how to perform advanced techniques such as DIs, dash dancing, and character specific guides. It's a game that even a newbie can become a pro and is why I highly recommend this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: On the surface, Rivals is a really fun game. I got it during the summer sale so I could play with my friends and luckily I was able to do that the day I got it. I jumped straight into the story mode to get used to the game. Despite it being blatantly tacked on, the story mode was a good challenge for me who has never owned a Smash Bros game but has played it countless times at friends' and reletives' houses for maybe 10 years. After story mode, I played with a friend who came over to my house and I introduced him to the game and he picked it up pretty quick, given that he plays Smash semi-regularly at home. After an enjoyable couple hours another friend of mine joined online, the friend who suggested I get this game. Strangely we found that you can't actually do a free-for-all online. Luckily you are able to damage your teamates so that worked out fine but the online features lack clarity (like how no one had any clue as to what was going on when picking a stage). Not having game setting customization is fine (to my knowledge; so no fun gamemodes like sudden death) but not having a free-for-all mode or being able to pick your teams is unexcuseable. At this point, I was still having fun but still was learning and decided to actually try the tutorial. Surprisingly, I found the tutorial very helpful and very in-depth even going so far as to tell you how many frames something lasts or needs to be done by and practice mode can show you the hitboxes of you and your attacks. But the more advanced tutorials show how the game wants to be played and I can't deal with that. The game not only teaches you how to play compettitvely like a pro; it expects it and the skill of some randoms I fought online compared to mine or my friends reinforces that idea for me. The tutorials teach you exactly how the game mechanics work and then immediately task you with abusing them before being alowed to continue. The edgeguarding tutorial alone took me around 30 minutes. Whether its true or not, you have to play dirty in this game in order to compete; you can't just get someone to 100% damage, hit them with a power attack, and expect them to die becuase few attacks have any real knockback on them and even then it's kept to a minimum. If you want kills, you have to push them over the edge and pummel them into the abyss yourself until they finally die. I like to fight a fair fight on the stage and I don't edgeguard becuase I'll either feel like a dick or be dead afterwards but this game doesn't facilitate that. There is no honor in this style of fighting. If your in to that, I highly recomend this game, otherwise, don't pick it up unless you are exclusively playing with friends you are comfortable with fighting. I'll still play this game with my friends, but I can't take it seriously anymore.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is basically an indie smash bros., if the trailer and pictures didn't make that obvious. 

Pros
- Gamplay: It's very smooth and each character is very unique in almost every single attack.
- Music: The retro feel is clearly there to pair up with the pixel graphics, but it doesn't get annoying. In fact, the main theme is still stuck in my head.
- Graphics: While it is pixel graphics, they're not annoyingly big pixels and it gives the game an authentic retro feel to me.
- Characters: Each character's design helps hint at what their playstyle is, and the color customization is awesome and cool.
- Abyss Mode: While this isn't a 'never-before-seen' mode, it really adds more gameplay to the game. I also thought it was cool how it was implimented with the story, but I won't spoil anything.

Cons:
- Story: The only issue I had with this is that some of the character's stories (cough* Wrastor cough*) felt stretched and short. But the ending makes me feel that there will be more story.
- Characters: I know that this is an indie game, and each character is really unique, but 8 characters for some reason feels too small, especially how you start with only 6 and the other two are paid with in-game currency. (And yes I do know that more characters are coming in updates)
- Stages: Again, I know that it's indie and there is a creative stage for each character, but the paid unlockables take 5 times the amount for a character, and I feel like it should be the other way around since character's typically provide more gameplay time than a stage.

Overall, this title is a great indie game and, in a lot of ways, almost better than smash bros itself.  I highly recommend it, even if the online mode sucks right now.

If you like Super Smash Bros. and that you're searching for a cool game to play online with Steam, then RoA is the answer.

Complex and technical gameplay, great characters and mechanics, good pixel art and ost.

Just go for it!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I had my doubts for a long while, never quite sure it was worth the price given my opinions on competitive SSBMelee, but then a half-off sale came along and I never for a moment regretted any penny spent.  This takes inspiration from Melee, but it is definitely its own game.  Maybe a bold statement, especially "only" 18 hours in, but I really feel like this could replace Smash Bros. in general for myself, especially if it keeps recieving updates and attention.

The animations are smooth and while I wish some sprites were just a little more detailed, they work really well.  The entire UI is clear and built for speed and accessibility from the main menu, to the stage select, to the character select controller and profile tweaking.  The characters all feel very viable, very strong in their own right, and have their own unique level of depth.  After some personal adjustment the combat feels right at home: fast but not overbearing, defensive and aggressive playstyles both work, and best of all, no ledge-grabbing and no shields!

The game feels like it was made with love and care, from the music to the art to the gameplay itself, and it really shows through.  A steal at half price and a solid purchase - and game - even at full price.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The game is really fun and I'm really looking forward to the Ori dlc.
Great music and great artstyle.


But online modes feel incomplete and speciatly when you want to play with friends.
You can only play with one friend.
I want to be able to play with more friends but the game doesn't allow me.

Even in team match always puts your friend in the oposing team and uses AI teammates. And you can't change the team compositions. I really dont understand why this is a thing. Why can't I have an other friend as my team mate and play with 3 other freinds even though the game supports up to 4 player slots.

Brawlhalla allows you to play up to 8 friends and you can manage the teams however you like. So why not in this game?

Even selecting a stage feels like its competitive with the banning feature. I'm playing against my friend and I should always be able to pick stages in a non competetive way. For example both players pick a stage and the game choses random the stage out of the slected stages.


I really recomend that they change the online system to how local brawl works.
So you can play with 4 other friends, change team compositions and change the way how stages are chosen.
Basicly being able to have more options to customize your game.

Its a great game but the online mode feels incomplete at this moment.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: #TheViewage

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is an amazing game. I played a lot of Super Smash Bros with my friends casually, and had so much good fun with it. One problem I always had with Super Smash Bros was the moves didn't feel heavy. In this game, which has a similar style to Super Smash Bros, does not have this problem. Each hit feels like it counts, and parrying is a smooth and skill based mechanic, which I prefer over shielding. It also has coding for things like wave dashing so it can get very mechanical to play, but is still smooth and not wonky. This game can and will take hours of your life away.


Pros: 
-Coded well, so has few bugs
-Great U.I. with smooth menu transitions
-Amazing character kits that flow well together
-Well balanced character roster (Basically anyone can be super op, well maybe minus Maypul (Rip Maypul))
-Great tutorial for beginners and experts
-Good control layout and custimization
-Character and skin customization
-Great community 
-Premium skins if you want to burn some money (They look really nice)
-Active developers so content is being added regularly
-Fun and interesting story mode
-Special rewards and skins for people who attent offical tournaments or follow social media
-A good and scaling AI system
-Controller support
-Online multiplayer


Cons:
-Will take numerous hours away from your life (I have 73 hours but another 70+ playing locally at friend's houses)
-Peer to peer connection (This can be a problem, but it makes sense for the size of the development team and the style of the game)
-Limited character roster, 8 to be exact. (However, the characters are done amazingly and more characters will be consistanly added)




Overall I would personally say this is a great game for both casual and competitive players, that is well worth $15. Also, playing with friends is really fun, I personally don't like online play that much. Seriously though, there is no better way to play this game than getting 4+ friends together and playing all night, while blasting music.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
After 5 hours of playing, I can definetly say that I'm in love with the game! 
The games's pixel art style is really good and won my heart with it's simple but good art. The controles are smooth, the AI is good and Story & Abyss Mode are a lot of fun to play! Just playing this game helped me improve in Smash 4, too, because of it's related mechanics. I even prefer this game to Smash 4!
The Practice Mode taught the basics and advanced stuff and that the developers took time to introduce their game to the player is amazing. Most fighting games don't explain anything.
The Story Mode was short lived but the backstory of the characters & how it turns out is really enjoyable to play. I wish there was more to it! (Sadly, pixelart is time consuming to make)
The Abyss Mode is just amazing! I really can't find any other word to describe it! The extra boosters and the level system bring something new in the play style. Even after some hours it's still fun but is definetly repetetive over time.
Since I think that I'm still too trashy to try Online Battles, I will practice DI and parrying until it becomes a second nature!
I'm really hyped about Ori coming to the game and I can't wait for him to come out! (Hopefully in July) If unlocking him would require money, I would happily pay for that!
After a rather long review I must say, again, the game is amazing!

Sincerely,
An amazed fan

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I like this game.

It's some of the best parts of melee; the speed, the skill required and the sheer unforgiving nature of the combo system.

For just £11, this is worth it.

I wish I had more to say about the game, but I am limited in my praise by the very evident lack of online play in everywhere except the US. This is more than evidenced by the fact that europe, asia and south america have only one available location selection, limiting how good your ping can be. The US, despite being the smallest of the server choices, has an option for both the east and west coast. This added to the fact that most of the playerbase exists within the US means that online play is worthless for anyone living in anywhere that isn't close to the US.

This game gets a good rating because of it's mechanics and price, but if you don'y live near the US, consider avoiding this game. You are severly limited in terms of ranked gameplay without a friend who is good at the game.

review:
Beta Reveiw
Well boys and girls put down your Nintendo controllers and start up your PCs because Smash Brothers is being replaced.

I know what you're thinking.  How can I make such a bold statement? Smash is the best. Espescially Melee! I can agree they are great games but from a competitive veiwpoint let me explain why Rivals even while in beta has more potential.


Blast Zone Fighters as I call them are fighting games that instead of a health bar that must be drained, you must knock your oppent far enough off screen that they reach a Blast Zone losing a Stock or Life. Super Smash Brothers being the first of this style. Now we have Rivals of Aether. I'm going to  cover many  aspects of what makes a these and other fighting games great and/or stand out.

Music- Rivals has a Amazing soundtrack that perfectly matches the high speed gameplay. Every stage being themed after one of the Four elements. Just listen to some of the tracks

Control- Perfect, the only word that will suffice. This game takes some melee movement tec wave dashes and landings and simplifys the imputs so there is not specific timing for every character. You hit jump, parry, and left or right as the same time. So missing a input that messes up your posittioning is very unlikely. Dashing and Dash danceing is very responsive and feels great. The jump arc of every character is very managable and easy to familiarize yourself with. Even when you are hit you have a great deal of control of how you tumble through the air while in hitstun. This is a game that a person can never blame the controls. No  " I missed an L-cancle or my wave dash didnt work"  those comments will not be true in this game.

Level design done right- There are two versions of every stage. Rivals has no stages with unfair elements like transitions or moving platforms when the basic stages are being used.(But now it has 2 with moving plat forms only one being a little annoying :note made 06/09/17) Every stage has a silly more casual version called Aether. Every stage has very different platform placement so none of them feel the same.

The Rivals- Every character in this game has a unique power that their move set is based around. Zetterburn can set you on fire doing damage over time, while also being able to absorb it off of his opponent to strengthen his strong attacks, this games name for smash attacks. Kragg on the other hand can summon a rock pillar to change the stages geometry or grab a boulder to throw at you that will remain on stage if it is not destroyed. Every character has something different they bring to the table and it is fun to experiment.

Whiff lag- If you miss an attack in this game you are subject to more lag or "The amount of time before you can begin a new action or retake full control" This leads to players that just throw out attacks being punished and players who plan out there attacks being rewarded with a True combo or DI (Directional Imput) dependent combo or "String".

I beleive tha Rivals has great potential as a competitve game. The game even has a built in Tournement mode that allows you to ban stages and set the amount of matches in a set. If you love Smash bros. Just pick this game up you won't regret it.

Full release addtions

Online- The online fuctionallity of this game much like many fighting games is not the best. Playing a person out of your reagion is almost pointless due to high pings. Low ping matches have different problem that can only be called stuttering. The match will randomly slowdown for 1 to 3 seconds causing input drops. This means all input. In a game that is DI dependent to survive strong hits this stuttering will be the cause of many deaths. The style of random matchmaking is also not a welcome sight. you will repeatedly meet the same players causing a staleness if the matches are one sided in your favor or the opponents. 

Rebalanceing- the characters have mostly been worked out other than, some small changes that I dont care for ( the shrinking of Zetterburn Down Str's 1st hitbox for one example) The character now feel very balanced so I never feel like I lost to a character rather than the player. This is something that comes from experiance so some people may disagree. 

Conclusion- One of the strongest entries in fighting games that I have played in a long time base solely on the style, combo structure,match interactions and overall design. As a competitive fighter this gets a 10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you enjoy Super Smash Bros. you'll like Rivals of Aether.
Created by the same person who made Super Smash Land, a free PC fan-made Smash game, Rivals of Aether is a fast-paced fighter that adopts the Smash Bros. formula. Play as 8 different characters, each with their own very unique set of play styles. Fight it out with up to 4 players, smacking each other around until one gains victory. 

If the normal fighting isn't enough for you, well this game also has a Story Mode! Dwell into the lore o fthe Rivals of Aether story and learn more about the characters. 

There's also an Abyss Mode, where you get put into many different trials that require you to complete in order to set on into the next wave. Level up your characters and give them over powered skills that'll make Abyss Mode more fun and exciting. 

New to the game? Well the Tutorial will help you get started,  not only does it teach to the common core basics of the Smash Bros. formula, but also teaches you advanced skills that the pros use such as teching and wavedashing.

Simply put: A game for casual players to have some fun. Exciting and intense for the competitive players.

The achievements in this game aren't especially hard to get. There's some that require you to KO opponents using specific moves, but most of them you'll get by playing the Story Mode, there are some Tutorial achievements and some Abyss achievements. Don't think this will be an easy trip though, there's an achievement that requires you to basically git gud in Story Mode by getting Gold Medals on all the different Story Modes.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A great platform fighter with some of the best aspects of smash bros that also brings a lot of new and unique elements to the table, Rivals of Aether is a game I wholeheartedly endorse. While its character selection (with a current roster of 8 fighters) may be smaller than most, each of them is wholly unique from each other, and they are all fun to play as and roughly balanced. The fast-paced, high-stakes action of the game is very satisfying, but the skill floor might be a tad high. Speaking from experience, it took quite a bit of time before I wasn't consistently being thrashed online. however, the player base is strong (avoiding a problem many fighting games face) and the high skill ceiling means you can always improve. Built in tutorial modes help a lot to get you started, too. All in all, it's a very fun, great, fast-paced game for fighting game fans, especially those of the Super Smash Bros series.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether takes the Super Smash Brothers approach to fighting games in more ways than one. Damage is only dealt to make it easier for you to launch your opponent off the stage and deplete stocks.

The differences from smash are what make this game so interesting though:

-There is no shield, tapping the block button initiates a parry animation making you invincible and opening up your opponent
-There is no ledge grabbing and there is a much heavier focus on wall jumping to get back on the stage.
-From the little I've played all characters feel relatively balanced and competitive in their own ways
-No items are in the game so battles are entirely skill based with very little random elements such as moving platforms on some stages

Rivals of Aether is an excellent platform fighter and is easy to pick up and play for veteran smash players.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Although i'm a big fan of the sprite=based art style and the gimmicks each charater has, the over all gameplay still needs a lot of work. If you are looking for a polished competative platform fighter, I strongly recommend you give Brawlhalla a try.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Basically, this is a fast paced platform fighter. There is a bunch of hitstun compared to Brawl or Sm4sh, which means that there is huge combo potential.

If you are a Smash fan, just buy this. Odds are you will enjoy it.

However, that being said, if you are new to platform fighters, this is not really a good introduction. The tutorial is useful, but odds are you will be playing players much better than you and you will get stomped over and over again. If you want a good introductory platform fighter on PC, then play Super Smash Flash 2. It is free and more beginnner friendly. If you enjoy SSF2, then you should consider getting Rivals of Aether.

Also, something [i]really[/i] worth stressing is that there are no grabs and shields in this game. At first that seems simple enough, but that can really throw you for a loop once you actually play without them.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Well, this should be different from how my last review looked, but I wouldn't get myself wrong about it. So Rivals of Aether had released on March 28, 2017, and I figured I should change my review based on its full release. Don't get me wrong, this game is still amazing to me but I want to say just a bit more about it in certain areas.

So, what's this "Wubilicious" guy got to say about Rivals now? Well it's still an amazing game with a really great dev team, especially on discord since well, that odd dream of talking to devs becomes a reality in the Rivals of Aether discord group. Even for people wanting to learn and get better, theres the Rivals of Aether Academy discord group, just as a cherry ontop of this crossover elemental sundae of a game. Not to mention any fears you might have about the people in the community should be remedied very quickly, as well, surprisingly people are very nice in this community compared to something like Smash 4 or even Brawlhalla. Not saying that those games have %100 awful people in their communities, not at all, I've just seen more toxic people in those communities compared to Rivals of Aether. Back to the positives, Rivals of Aether sports an 8 character cast with all their own strengths and weaknesses, all revolving around 1 of the 4 major elements, kinda like Avatar. All of these characters have fairly different playstyles and advantages/disadvantages on every stage (unless you're Zetterburn, the most balanced in the game >:C) Speaking of stages, theres a stage for each character, including some general stages featured from this games Abyss and Story modes, not to mention the current CEO Dreamland skin with it's rockin' remix from Rock Wall and the stage Tower of Heaven featuring from well, Tower of Heaven. The music is also pretty kickass in this game too! Don't just ask me, I'd take a listen for yourselves but my favorite track has gotta be the Fight or Flight track that plays on the stage Air Armada. So I mentioned both the Story and Abyss modes, what about those right? Well story modes a big hit in my book, as these characters are fairly unexplored in story since their only other piece of story is on the Rivals of Aether website. The story mode is fairly basic, you fight cpus that get higher AI levels each time you progress untill you get to the end of the story where you fight a more mysterious looking version of one of the characters. Sadly Absa and Etalus haven't been put in story mode but I'm sure some things are to change. Abyss mode is basically a odd minigame-esque mutli-man melee, you start off fighting really weak enemies but it gets more depth like breaking hexes (targets), absorbing light, and even fighting the boss of the games Story Mode every 15 or so waves. I'd say it makes up a lot of the solo mode time you'll put into the game, especially if you want the Ardent Rival achievement. I'd say most of the achievements in this game are fairly standard, being completed by doing a characters story mode or getting a K.O. with one specific move, however theres a small handful that really take time and challenge, so theres even things for the completionist in Rivals of Aether if they're interested. For anyone with some artistic ability, theres also a custom color palette maker for characters built right into the game, and it's fully supported to show in combat as well. It adds some nice variety from just fighting friends or doing abyss mode all the time I'll have to say.

So no game is perfect, right? Well that's not even exclusive to games in general but I'm gonna take a short look at the negatives. One mainly being the 8 character cast, while it's indeed impressive how much depth each character has, it's still only 8. To me honestly, it's not a big complaint, but I know the developers have new characters coming down the line as this is being typed. I'd say another negative is how there's a couple stages I personally don't enjoy, especially because I feel they just don't work in Rivals of Aether compared to something like Smash. I'd say the scaling difficulty in Abyss mode when you have people over isn't super rewarding, as you don't really get much more experience for characters compared to the amount of added difficulty you get with having help, infact it's kinda backwards. You'd think while inviting someone to help with Abyss mode you'd still have some difficulty increase, but it'd still be easier because of the second (or third/forth) person helping you, but thats not the case at all. I'd say some of the music in the game isn't super amazing, but even then that's my personal taste.

So thats really all I have to say. It's an amazing game, and if you can't believe me than try it out for yourself, it's not like you can't get a refund from Steam if you really don't enjoy a game nowadays. I know some people would also like a number grade for reviews too, but I think they're a bit silly. So for any of you who've played Devil May Cry I'll give this game the S rank, yea the devs honestly worked really hard on this game and it very well shows. Even my complaints are personal, well maybe except the 8 character one (that one's fairly common) so my complaints shouldn't be taken to heart or anything. Would I say everyone should check this out? Well not unless you enjoy Super Smash Brothers at it's core mechanics and not for the fact that it's a Nintendo fighter. I'd really recommend this game at least be checked out, whether a friend owns it or you just want to see what the game is beyond my review.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you're still thinking Melee is the best Super Smash Bros. game, you'll love Rivals of Aether. It doesn't have a lot of single-player content, but it's extremely polished and balanced for competitive play; in fact, it's just about to make its debut in big events, alongside series like Tekken and Street Fighter.

RoA is still in development, so there's more things to come. It's a legal way to play a Smash game on your PC, it has online multiplayer with both ranked matches and friendly matches with your Steam friends and couch multiplayer for up to 4 players. Oh, and it natively supports Gamecube controllers.

If any of those things sound cool to you, I can definitely recommend you getting RoA.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game plays like Melee, so if you like that you'll like this.

I do have some grievances though.

1. The Story Sucks
   The story lacks any development. You fight a Rival and see a scene. You do this until you fight YOUR rival with 2 stocks rather than one. The story scenes don't connect to the rivals that you fight until the very end. It's jarring and incoherent.

2. Zetterburn (and also a little bit of Kragg)
   This character is far too easy to pick up. I understand that there's a lot of depth to him, but when the entry bar is so low, it discourages experimentation. I would've rather they all be hard to pick up or be like Kragg, where they are easy to pick up but not totally useful in the meta. Without this consistency, Kragg seems useless, and Zetterburn seems stupidly good.

3. Parry on frame 2-5? Too much lag, not enough Time!!
   The Parry system is a good idea in theory, but the timing is far too strict for the itty bitty reward that you get from it. A parry should be frame 1-5, so at least you can do reaction based parries. All parries in the current state are far too dificult to pull off without a hard read. 

Overall, this game is just very fun. It's ridiculously fast paced, and never makes you wait. The art is well done and the music is catchy. 8/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I started playing Rivals of Aether in early access, but after its full release, I've been playing it a lot more.
The game plays a lot like Smash Bros., as that is its main inspiration.  However, what you'll get from Rivals is not a soulless Smash clone.  Instead, you'll get a game filled with its own personality, quirks, and tons of fun gameplay.
A fantastic inclusion is the two modes of stages.  There's an "Aether" mode and a "basic" mode.  This essentially doubles the number of stages in the game.  Aether mode stages have different gimmicks and stage hazards.  They aren't suitable for competitive play, but make for fun casual matches.  The "basic" stages are a bit misleading.  Rather, they're tournament legal versions of all the  stages, made for competitive use in tournaments.  These stages combine familiar layouts (such as Tower of Heaven using the triplatform layout of Battlefield and The Endless Abyss is a long stage with no platforms, similar to Final Destination), while including original stages that make for interesting additions, such as the quadplatforms of Merchant Port and Fire Capital.  The game includes built in striking and banning for stage selection, which should be familiar to fans of competitive Super Smash Bros.
The gameplay structure itself is fantastic, too.  Rivals of Aether puts its own spin on the platform fighter genre by removing shields and grabs and implementing a parry system instead.  This majorly increases the risk:reward factor.  If you successfully parry an attack, your opponent will be stunned, creating an opening for you to attack.  Parrying a projectile will reflect it.  However, if you miss your parry, you yourself are left open for punishment.  The removal of shields requires you to have more of a read on your opponent.  Movement is incredibly fluid as well.  Wavedashing in Rivals of Aether is much more simplified than in Melee, where it was already relatively easy to perform.  Dash dancing is also present.  There is one character with a double jump cancel, I'll get back to that later.  Hitstun is at a perfect balance, in my opinion.  There is incredibly high combo potential in this game, but most of it requires you to read your opponent's DI.
The sound design in this game is fantastic.  Nearly, if not every song is incredibly catchy.  I find myself listening to some of the music in my spare time (my personal favourite is Tempest Peak).  However, an aspect of the sound design that often goes unappreciated in fighting games is the hit sound effects.  All of the sound effects in Rivals of Aether sound incredibly satisfying, especially when you land a sweetspot.  My personal favourites are Wrastor's clap and Absa's sweetspot kicks.
From a graphical standpoint, the game is simple, but beautiful.  It uses charming pixel graphics to represent the environments and fighters.  The stages are all gorgeous and look fantastic.  Graphics accurately represent hitboxes, which is an issue some fighting games tend to run into.  As an added bonus, since the game is in 2D, there is no Z-Axis to mess with hitboxes, like in some other fighting games.
However, the real meat of a fighting game comes in the form of the characters, and in this area, Rivals of Aether does not disappoint.  There's a cast of 8 characters, with a 9th guest character having been teased.  Each character offers a different playstyle and unique options.  Some are more straightforward than others, but all of them reward skill.  The game is balanced incredibly well, thanks to it being in early access for nearly two years.  This allowed the developers to receive input from top players on matchups and characters.  As a result, everyone is viable, and you can play whoever you'd like at a high level of competitive play.
Each character has their own gimmick, with some being more straightforward than others.
Zetterburn can set his opponents on fire to do damage over time and power up his strong attacks.  Forsburn can create smoke on the stage to obscure the opponent's view.  He can also create a clone that is instantly destroyed when hit.  There's more to him, but that's the simplified version of it.  Orcane can create a puddle on the ground, which you can teleport to at any time, or have it bubble up for some interesting combos.  Maypul can "tag" her opponents, which makes her strong attacks wrap them up with vines and also gives her the option to swing over ot them with her up special.  Kragg has the ability to pull rocks from the ground and even create a platform/wall with his up special.  Wrastor has multiple jumps and can use his side special to create a small area that allows him to move more quickly and extend his combos.  Etalus can freeze the ground, which makes him surprisingly mobile for a heavy character.  He can also absorb his ice to become heavier and power up his strong attacks.  Absa can cancel her double jump to perform aerials close to the ground.  Her forward air, back air, and down air all have powerful sweetspots that are hard to land.  However, Absa can place a cloud on the stage.  By kicking this cloud with her aerials mentioned before, she can create a large shockwave that expands the size of her sweetspots.  The cloud can also be popped from a distance to control the stage.  Absa can also place a slow, but powerful attack on the cloud to make it act as a trap or create a thunderbolt between her and it.
I highly recommend this game to anyone looking to play a fun fighting game, whether competitive or casually.
