review: After playing this game for 80+ hours and owning it for a little over a year, I can easily say this game is fantastic and developed well. If you come from the Smash series, you're right at home. If you're new, there is a very helpful tutorial mode. I thoroughly enjoy the mechanics in this game, and I believe that it is incredibly balanced. Each of the 8 characters are unique and are fun to play. There is only one complaint that I could have here, and that is the full release of the game. After playing the characters Absa and Etalus for so long, they were randomly locked at the full launch. I understand that this is to insentivize you to do the story mode, but I don't think this should have been included for people who bought this during early access. I think that the story mode is pushed to much, because there are also stages that are locked. Other than these minor complaints, I think that Rivals of Aether is a near-perfect game that anyone can pick up. 9/10.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is a Hardcore Platform fighter that plays just like Smash.
The main difference that this game has compared to Smash Bros. is the lack of a Ledge mechanic, Shield and Grab mechanic.

++Pros++
Gameplay:
+Story Mode is challenging and fun to speedrun on
+Abyss Mode is an exciting game mode to play through and the rune system is as enjoyable as it is deep

Competitive Gameplay:
+The game is very fluid and fast paced and offers a lot of depth and offers players a game with a high skill/tech ceiling
+Characters are very well balanced that there is no need for a tier list in my honest opinion
+Each character feels different, feels unique with each of their own quirks
+Stages are very well designed which leads to players strategizing on what stage they should pick

Aethetic and Sound
+This game has a very vibrant artstyle which is composed of amazing Pixel Art
+The soundtrack of this game is absolutely phenomenal thanks to flashygoodness
+The UI is very clean and organized

--Cons--
-Lacks a proper matchmaking system

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Such a well polished game. Takes the best aspects of what makes games like Smash Melee and PM great like wave dashing, teching, DI, shines etc. and makes the game their own. If you have played Smash and think this is merely a clone you couldn't be more wrong. Dan Fornace has made this game his own with the introduction of parries and wall jumps in the place of having shields and ledge grabs. Having those two new aspects added makes the game way more fast paced and more dificult to play defensively but when you defend effectively you are well rewarded. His roster of characters are also highly diverse, taking inspirations from moves that smash characters have and then building around what would work well with it. An example of this is Absa who uses Pikachu's recovery and then uses Ness's double jump mechanics and then building a very zone based character around it with clouds that can extend, explode, create a linear blast radius between you and the cloud and even amplify hitboxes. Each character is very different as well unlike Marth and Roy or Pikachu and Pichu, they all have a highly different playstyle and major differences in every character's kit. So on top of making a great smash inspired game, with diverse characters, parries and wall jumps, they managed to even put in the little thing that every competitive smash player has wanted. They have an awesome button check feature that you can do in the character select screen, THE SELECT SCREEN! They actually understand what we want! Not only that but they have custom colours, and what I mean by custom colours I mean... CUSTOM COLOURS! For every layer you see on your character you can pretty much change it to be any colour you want on the colour wheel. THAT IS SO AWESOME! And this all comes free! The controller support is INSANE! The customization on it allows you to do almost what ever you want on your controller. The community is awesome and so supportive! I can't express how much of a must have this game is!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'll reccommend it, but as a competitive fighter, I don't think it's actually that great of a game. 

Problems: Character balance, Escape options, inconsistencies with hitboxes and poking with disjointed hitboxes. 

One DI option. It's out an away. On about 98% of all moves its out and away or continue to get comboed. Which makes "reads" in this game very easy and certain characters have an enormous upper hand in every situation in this game. It would be nice to be able to go up and over during juggles, or against certain moves as a way to really throw opponents for a loop. Unfortunately, in most situations you either DI out and away and half of the cast will Fair-chain you off the side, or try and stay in and get juggled. 

On that note, all of the characters have a "gimmick." Zetterburn has fire consume, Maypul has wrap, Wrastor has multiple jumps. Certain character's gimmicks are just better across the board and its clearly shows.

Projectile spam is heavy in this game among all levels of play except the highest level. (It's about as bad as Dhalsim yoga fire spam at times.) Certain character's entire playstyle is centered around constant projectile spam.

Hitboxes are the biggest problem I have with this game. Wrastor and Forsburn constantly have the upperhand in most situations, as their start-ups combined with their disjointed hitboxes can poke through a lot of things. I've also noticed that if one of these attacks hits while a Strong attack is currently landing against them, often times they will recieved reduced knockback, even if the opponent successfully landed the hit. There is a lot of inconsistency with "clashing" (and I say that because it is all but non-exsistant in this game.) 


All in all, its a fun game, but most of the time when I play I realize why I stopped trying to play it competitively half a year ago. Certain characters who are obviously better due to design have remained relatively unchanged is jarring in terms of how much the game is praised for being balanced. 

Stages and music are nice and unique. 

6/10. 

Also Parry frame 2 I will never understand.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a platform fighting game, inspired by Nintendo's Super Smash Brothers series, that you play for the challenge and the competition. It's retro-styled but pretty slick and well made, boasting nearly instant load times and great controller support.

You'll probably like this game if:
- You adore colorful pixel animal people.
- You dig fighters with small casts that give each character their own unique mechanics and tools.
- You prefer simpler control styles over Street Fighter-style motion commands.
- You play Super Smash Brothers and want a similar experience on PC.
- You think Smash is a little slow because of shielding and grabbing, and want to see how things play without them.
- You can get into time attack and co-op survival modes.
- You like to fight other people--there are strong players on netplay!



You might not like this game if:
- You don't use a gamepad. Keyboard controls are supported but they can be uncomfortable.
- You prefer the party chaos of Smash with items enabled. (In this case, play Smash instead.)
- You demand big character rosters, like to play a different character every time, or dislike mirror matchups. (In this case, I recommend Smash 4, or something like BlazBlue: Chronophantasma Extend.)
- You want a wealth of lore and exploration--this isn't that kind of game.
- You want to test your skills against strong AI instead of online play. The AI is somewhat competent, but most of the single player challenge is in winning fights fast while taking minimal damage, rather than fair fights against increasingly clever opponents. (AI is typically a weak point of fighting games, but you might check out the latest Tekken or Virtua Fighter 4 if you're interested in this.)

review:
Decided to update this review since the game is no longer in early access.

Rivals of Aether is 2D side scroll fighter game it's very similar to the Smash Bros. games only difference is that in this game you can't grab and shielding is replaced with parrying.

[h1] PROS: [/h1]

Exclusive tutorials for the characters instead and just simple "how to play tutorial".
Playing with the controller makes improving seemingly easier.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[spoiler]tdlr it's amazing buy it now[/spoiler]

[h1]If you're into fighting games, then you will love this.[/h1] 

Rivals of Aether is a Smash Bros inspired fighting game. I say "inspired" because the only real similarity between RoA and SSB is the simple movement. I'll spare the detail and just get roight into it

Rivals of Aether's main drive is competitive, and boy howdy does it nail it well. The skill ceiling is so high that everytime I play I figure out a new combo or a new trick. When you go online, people are pulling off some god-level combos, however this is integral for learning and improving. Playing online is the main reccomended way of playing, because honestly, the CPU are easy, even on the highest setting. Plus, by playing online you learn to adapt, therefore you "git gud"

However, RoA isn't all competitive. There's a story mode, which is kinda like All-Star mode from Smash Bros. Then once you beat that, you unlock Abyss Mode, which is an endless challenge mode where you have to either break some targets, capture a point, or defeat an armored enemy. Normally playing any mode will get you coins, which you can spend to unlock new characters, stages, AND special perks for Abyss Mode, that basically buff your character.

I'm such a slave for customization, and boy howdy, RoA let's you create your own custom skins for your character. On top of that, there are a few DLC skins that are pretty cheap, as well as promotional skins that you can get for participating in tournaments, or special events. Now I know what you're thinking. "Can't I just recreate the DLC skins in the skin creator??"
no
you cant
The DLC and event skins have a special taunt and particle effects that can't be recreated in the skins creator, which makes these event skins seem more precious. 
[spoiler]if anyone has a golden orcane skin they wanna donate pls hmu[/spoiler]

Seriously tho, why haven't you bought this game yet. It's cheap for all the content it gives you, plus new stages and characters are coming in the near future.

[strike]I'm not afraid to say that Rivals of Aether is better than Smash Bros, because imo it is[/strike]

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1]----- SUMMARY -----[/h1]

Grade : F D C [b]<< B >>[/b] A S
Main Pro: Demanding but highly-engaging gameplay
Main Con: Lack of content (particularly single player)

[h1]----- FULL REVIEW -----[/h1]

(Opening Note: A lot of my hours on this game comes from listening to that delicious music in the background. Its good, by the way. Just wanted to point that out so we don't mistake my level of fighting dedication for something it isn't!)

Full disclosure: I am not a hardcore fighter-type at all; I went to one local Smash 4 tourney a little under a year ago and essentially went, "Yeah, no." I've had an often hopeless fascination of their complex systems and tactics, but a lack of the mechanical skill and patience required to learn them at a higher level. In short, bear in mind that I'm reviewing this more or less as a "casual," which I'd like to believe will benefit someone out there reading this.

So here I am, once again trying to somehow eke out the technical satisfaction of conquering a fighter despite the stupid amounts of stress they can cause me. Does Rivals of Aether somehow break the mold of my typical fighter experience? Not entirely: this is undoubtedly a high-octane, competitive multiplayer game first and foremost. However, the convention-breaking finesse and quality of this game is enough to make me genuinely beam when things clicks.

Because if anything, RoA is unconvential. This is essentially a Smash Bros. (Melee) clone, but it does several things differently. First, there are no shields! Instead, you must rely on dodging or what is called a "parry", a way of essentially reversing the enemy's offense back on them. This is important, because the concept of "safety" is very fleeting in RoA. Battles happen quickly and often brutally, and the inability to shield can make it hard to get a grasp on your surroundings without getting absolutely slaughtered in the process. This can make for an unforgiving learning curve at the beginning.

The characters in RoA are frequently as unorthodox as the base mechanics, though this leads to some hero-specific mechanics that are incredibly interesting. Specifically, the interactions between different mechanics and hero attacks make for some nifty setups. Zetterburn can light foes on fire, which grants a knockback bonus to his strong (smash) attacks. Etalus can freeze the ground to increase the distance of his dash attack. Even straightforward tweaks--like Wrastor's strong attacks working only in the air instead of on the ground--really shake things up. Its the kind of stuff that sounds really amazing to fool around with... but reconciling all the nuances of a character, especially against high-tier opponents, can feel very daunting.

In short, RoA makes for some very deliberate, demanding gameplay. Its tough. Its crazy. But when you nail it... its quite amazing. RoA is the kind of game that can definitely push you outside of your comfort zone, but in exchange you can have some truly cerebral moments. Yes, you'll probably get your rear handed to you in short order more than once, but piecing together the elements of success and failure can come just as quickly: the game, in a way, demands it of you. If you can harness that intensity and intellect even for a moment, you may be shocked to find that even as a "casual" you can have your moments. Glorious, glorious moments.

Just remember, this is a competitive fighter first. Story mode is pretty standard fare, if not a little short even for this genre. The solo replayability is tied up for the most part in Abyss Mode, yet another unconventional but nice take on the "multi-man" melee modes from Smash Bros. Nonetheless, I wouldn't plan to get much mileage out of the single player content; its essentially a small appetizer compared to the multiplayer's main course. Despite the game's clear priorities, some may be disappointed in the overall lack of content. With a starting roster of only eight characters (perhaps for the sake of balance,) some might struggle to find a rival they really gel with.

I don't think RoA is going to drastically change my contentious, limited relationship with the fighter genre. But its dedication to rich, deep gameplay makes it feel more casual-friendly than one might think. I don't see myself tearing up the ranked leaderboards any time soon, but I may get me some occasional "slam dunk" KO's from Etalus's grab attack. Watch yourself!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's melee with powershields only, no grabs (Etalus doesn't count), no ledges, and every character is viable.

I've put probably 12,000 hours into Melee over my life and played every smash-like that I'm aware of. Rivals of Aether definitely comes the closest to the feel of Melee, though the two are different in their own ways. RoA is heavily focused on a combo/punish game centered around complex character matchups and general tech skill. For casual play I wouldn't necessarily recommend RoA as it can be quite daunting. Ever play against the one friend in Melee who mains Falcon/Falco/Fox and they just constantly pressure you and run you down? RoA is basically that, except every character does that.

What RoA has:

[list]
[*]SDI
[*]Teching
[*]Wavedashing/landing
[*]Character-specific techs
[/list]

What RoA does not have:

[list]
[*]L-canceling (to my knowledge...? Pretty sure everything is autocanceled, though edgecancelling is a thing)
[*]Anything to do with shields.
[*]Anything to do with ledges.
[*]Captain Falcon and his godtier taunts. :(
[/list]

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Well, I have been playing this gem of a game since Early Access, and the game has showed no signs of slowing down. For any Smash veteran, the gameplay will feel very similar, with the exception of grabs and ledges. All the characters are unique, and the game play is fast and fluid. Online can be fun, but don't expect to have a good time if you get paired with a laggy opponent. The story mode is short and fun, but I honestly felt like it was poorly written, with no reason why you were fighting everyone (with the exception of the last character you face in each character's story). After you complete story mode, you unlock Abyss mode, which is essentially Warioware meets Smash bros., with some of the tasks including Multi-man modes, Break the Targets, a "Metal" enemy, so on and so forth. Overall, Rivals of Aether is a great game, and it is absolutely worth every penny spent and second played. Just a warning: if you want to be good, you need to get a controller, keyboard controls do not work with platform-style fighters. Steam controller works great.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Active player who has owned the title since it first went into Early Access back in September 2015.

Rivals of Aether is a platform fighter with a competitive flair that oozes polish and offers you a great deal of control over your character's speed and actions (if you've played Melee, the tempo is similar). This is as close to the Smash-series a platform fighter can get (standard double jumps, percent based health, smashes (or strongs in this games)) while putting a fresh, simplistic spin on it through each character's very unique moveset and the parry mechanic.

Because it is a relatively simple fighter with a deep learning curve and an amazingly thorough tutorial mode, both casuals and veterans can expect to get hundreds of hours out of it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
PSA to anyone playing this game online: THE NETCODE IS BRILLIANT.
This game plays fantastically with almost no input delay online even over 100 ping. Don't be afraid of those high ping values!

To everyone else: Now that this game is out of Early Access, it is a STEAL for $15. Honestly, it's my new favorite fighting game on Steam. I'm a bit biased since I've been playing Smash Bros. competitively for a couple years now and have been playing since near day one of Early Access, but considering you get nearly the same amount of content for $15 as Street Fighter V gets for $60, this game is well worth the money I spent on it. Also if you're worried about buying a game for which the community might be dead, don't be. The game's community is incredibly active, and I've never had a time where I just couldn't find a match.

TL;DR - This game is INSANELY fun, whether you enjoy fighting online, or just want to play some solo modes like story or survival modes. I HIGHLY recommend you join our wonderful RoA community.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I hopped onto the Early Access train a little late, I only picked up the game in November, but watching Rivals grow has been an awesome experience. Dan Fornace, the game's creator, and the other devs are all supremely focused on creating a well balanced, competitive, fun fighting game. All of the characters are just as viable as one another in competitive play, all of the stages are designed with competitive play in mind, and yet it's still just so visceral and fun! Pulling off a sick combo, or landing an awesome set up, or hitting that optimal punish all feel so awesome. The game gives you nothing for free, but that means that you feel great once you've managed to actually land something.

The gameplay feels a lot like Super Smash Bros Melee, if you're familiar with that game, but with enough unique stuff in there that it doesn't come off as just another smash clone (even if we call it Furry Trash Smash). No ledges, grabs, or shields here, instead they've been replaced by wall jumps and parries, a new mechanic where you can block your opponent's moves and leave them in a state of hitstun for a brief moment, allowing you to follow up and punish them with (almost) whatever you want. The timing is tight though, you've got 2 frames to work with, and leaves you with a significant amount of endlag if you mistime the parry, so you can't just throw them out whenever. The game is very fast paced and combo-centric, with movement and spacing being vital for competitive play.

But the really interesting part are the characters. The roster currently holds 8 characters as of writing this review, with at least 6 more promised for the future (2 guest characters and 1 more for each of the 4 elements), and each of those 8 feel incredibly different from one another, and each have their own mechanics that interact with the stage in unique ways. From being able to create a destroyable pillar underneath you, to covering the stage in ice, to obscuring the screen in smoke, every character has a unique way to interact with the stage itself. But that's not the best part, the care and design that has gone into each and every character shows. While certain matchups may tend to favor one character over another, it's never more than a 60/40 chance at worst, and no character significantly outshines any other. High level competitive play regularly sees almost the entire cast, so who you play just comes down to personal preference rather than being forced to "play the meta."

The community around this game is wonderful as well, with several major Discord channels, including the "Rivals Academy," a Discord created with the sole purpose of pairing new players with more experienced Mentors (including some top-level players) to help them learn, a hugely active subreddit (/r/RivalsofAether), and almost daily online tournaments, you can almost always find someone to play with. The community has been nothing but helpful and friendly the entire time I've been playing. The general attitude of the Rivals community is that we're all trying to get good at a competitive fighting game, so why not help each other out.

Finally, it's a small note, but the amount of polish and awesome small features in this game is just outstanding. Everything oozes character, from the menu music to the character select screen. Here are just a few small details that I really appreciate as a player:

- Being able to create a profile, set custom controls, and playtest those controls, all without having to leave the character select screen
- Having a music toggle on the stage select screen
- Stage banning in the stage select screen
- CUSTOM COLORS (no seriously, it's a lot more fun than you think)

If you are interested in picking up this game, I highly recommend it! I came from having only a minimal amount of experience playing a platform fighter, I wouldn't even call myself an amateur at Melee, but was able to pick up the game enough to start participating in online tournaments after only a couple of months (not saying I was doing well, but I wasn't losing out round 1 every time). A few of my friends who I recommended this game to came from Melee, Smash 4, and PM and all still loved this game. The barrier to entry is not high (the game even has tutorials to teach you pretty much everything you need to know to play the game), even if the skill ceiling is. Basically, if you're interested in a competitive platform fighting game with a fantastic community and devs that actually care about delivering a quality product, then you can't go wrong with picking up Rivals of Aether.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
My favorite iteration of Smash, including Melee, 4, PM, SSF2 you name it. I like all those games, but this is number one for me.

The tech is there, but the design is based on simple inputs and deliberate timing and not accidentallly complex button inputs that you have to tear up your hands learning and using over and over. There are detailed tutorials that can help you learn the tech, down to how to individual characters work. The characters move sets are based on cohesive concepts designed for this game and not weird collections of existing IP baggage slapped together to pull in other fan bases. Though I understand two indie guest stars are on the way. Still the characters kits are well thought out. Pick the bird a do a bunch of arials combos, pick the smokey dude and be all sneaky with smoke screens and decoys. There are no garbage pokefloat levels you have to turn off. There are no items or finisher moves that make you chase a baloon. 

Sheild-grapple-attack has been replaced with a simpler parry sytem. Make your attacks too obvious and get punished. Ledges have been replaced with a wall jump system. L cancling has been taken out, there are no rising attacks, you land on your feet, but you can still tech roll to keep from bouncing off the ground. All of these choices streamline the game, taking out the nooks, crannys and weird invincibility frames and moving gameplay more towards hitting your opponent with sweet combos.

There's single player stuff with lots of replay value, more characters on the way and an active community with tournaments out at smash events and on the net. The devs listen to player feedback and cater to competitive play. I saw a well thought out nerf suggestion for the creators favorite character on their subreddit implemented with the very next patch. I can not speak highly enough of the people behind this game. It's fantastic right now and I have a lot of faith that it will only get better.

10/10, want to put a ring on it and smash for life

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I've been with this game since the 2nd half of its early access, and I gotta say, it was one hell of a ride.

I would definitely recommend this game to people who want to play Melee but find it too hard. I'd also recommend it to Smash players as a whole because of how it plays in general.

With 8 characters, it doesn't seem like a very diverse cast, but that's where looks can be deceiving, because each character plays so differently from one another, and Dan still intends to add more characters as time goes on! 11 stages is also a great number compared to the number of legal stages in Smash games.

All in all, this game isn't difficult to pick up (especially if you're coming from Smash), but the real challenge comes from mastering it.

Online can be a problem, because there will be people who just annihilate your very being (looking at you, Sino), but playing with friends and getting better at the game makes this all worthwhile.

The single player is also fairly mediocre, but let's be real, that's not what this game is about.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals or Aether, or RoA, is an indie platform fighter, meaning it has the samwe basic mechanics as Super Smash Bros. It takes mechanics from melee and more recent smash games, along with making up a lot of its own and put it together under the guise of a pixel retro art style.

The game is specifically designed for competitive play and in my opinion that it the way it is most enjoyable. Having friends to play with, especially local ones is where the game shines. It has a small single player story mode and the new abyss mode which are fun by themselves and definitely add more depth and value to the $15 game, but in the end are just distractions from the main event.

[b] Mechanics [/b]
If you're not familiar with competitive smash the next few things I'll be saying probably make no sense but what can you do. RoA takes the combo and movement heavy style of melee with features such as
-dash dancing
-wave dashing
-strong edgeguard focus
-lots of hitstun
however it also adds the good 'comfort' features of the newer games like
-buffering
-not freefalling out of an airdodge
-more forgiving/intuitive controls.
and it gets rid of shields (making offensive play more rewarding) and the ledge, so no edgehogs or planking.
Believe me when I say it all comes together and isn't just a huge mess of different games. it works and makes for some hugely satisfying combos and edgeguards, without it ever feeling to unfair or unbeatable.

[b] Characters [/b]
You'll notice that at the moment RoA only has 8 playable characters which seems like a very small number, and in terms of modern fighters it definitely is! however this isn't as big of a drawback as you may imagine. if you compare it to smash 4 with over 50 characters, every RoA character feels completely unique and I play and enjoy all of them. they all have unique tech and mechanics for them which you would need to learn in order to master the character. Also the small number of characters means balance is a lot easier to the devs, and every character is kept viable and strong enough to compete.

One important thing to note is that I highly reccomend you make sure you have some kind of game pad or controller before you buy this game. While keyboard controls exist it really doesn't allow the freedom and enjoyment for me and almost all other players. You can use a gamecube controller if you have a usb adaptor.

Overall I highly reccomend this game if you have a friend or two to play with and you want ti get into the competitive scene. as a standalone single player game I can't see you getting a huge amount of value, unless you have good internet to play with people either through steam or through its matchmaking system.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
From first glance it's a clone of Smash Bros., but after my time with it (52 hours at the time of writing), I definitely think it has enough flair to differentiate itself. There may only be 8 characters, but each one feels totally unique; not a clone in sight. There are mechanics in this game that I wish were present in Smash.

Graphics are pixelated, nothing too special to report here. The music on the other hand is pretty top notch.

There's a story mode but it's pretty barebones; move through 5 stages with 6 characters. There are some cutscenes between each fight, but they're only there to establish character backgrounds. The story themselves are mostly disconnected from the battle, but I guess this teaches you how to wreck the AI in each match-up to get the gold medal.

Abyss mode is a neat idea though; you gain character experience by completing different trials and challenges in rapid succession. You earn coins to unlock move enhancements (runes) for Abyss PvP or future Abyss mode runs. 

Practice mode is fleshed out. You can change the game speed and display hitboxes to figure out ideal combos.

The online only has 1v1, which means you will find opponents even if there aren't a lot of people playing.

Last, but not least, the devs are true to their word and are active in receiving community feedback. The game is constantly being balanced. There's even a Dev Mode, which allows the player to change hitboxes, character speed, etc. to balance the game to their liking. 

Bottom-line: if you want an actively-developed Smash-like game with solid mechanics and nuanced characters, then consider Rivals of Aether. It's a damn good title.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Was here since day 1 of its early access release, and i was happy to be a part of it! Sure, the game has many comparisons to Super Smash Bros but IT DOES have its differences. Ledges are non-existent in this game which makes every match more combat focused rather than stally. Along with that comes a small roster of 8 characters, each with their own unique playstyle (Orcane being my favorite). The Competitive scene is nice, small, and one ive found entertaining as its evolved.
Even the casual side of the game is great with friends as it offers several gamemodes for you to choose from. The only real downside I could say about the game is the dullness of the story mode but lets be real, no one is buying this game primarily for the story.

Aside from that, if your a fan of the Super Smash Bros franchise, you NEED to give this a try, you can wait for a sale if you want, but 15$ for this isn't a bad price.

[spoiler]Its hard to believe the one early access game ive invested in would evolve into such a good game[/spoiler]

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I adore Rivals of Aether.

The sound design and graphics are clearly retro-inspired, and this doesn't neccessarily help or hurt the game one way or the other. But they are definitely GOOD retro graphics, with a lot of attention to detail, and the characters are full of personality.

The gameplay is tight. RoA uses Smash mechanics like comboing, smash ("strong") attacks, tilts, aerials, etc., with its own mechanics like parrying. Oh, and you can't grab ledges, so getting back to stage is always fun. Character special moves can effect the stage in really interesting ways, like Kragg's pillar and Maypul's plant. And characters have their own mechanics like Zetterburn's flames and Maypul's mark that you have to watch out for.

If you have a few buddies and spare controllers, definitely check out the local multiplayer. Stages have "Aether" modes with fun gimmicks and insta-deaths, and things get really exciting with 4 Rivals on-screen at once.

You can also customize your character's color, which is super neat. And the best part is, the game isn't even complete yet. Story mode, and other features will be added in the final release.

Fantastic Indie Smash-like game. 10/10 in my book. Keep the quality coming, Dan.

title: Rivals of Aether

This homogenizes the interactions between players and often makes playing this game just, less fun, than what it's competitors offer.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game took Smash's idea of simple controls and ran with it.  Mashing is never necessary, teching is easy, and most inputs can be buffered.  This game is more focused on providing players with plenty of ways to mix up movements.  For example, when Etalus freezes a player, you can't mash to get out faster; instead, you choose a direction to tech roll when you break out.  Most recoveries have ways to be mixed up, too.  Even Zetterburn's, which is infamous for being linear, can be mixed up by cancelling a dspecial with a wall jump.  If you enjoy the movement of Smash but don't want to destroy your controller or hands, this is the game for you.

I understand that things get rocky when  and practicing matchups and labbing it up(doing your homework on characters) can solve these issues but the trip to attaining this level off skill is not fun when you know the other player doesn't have to work as hard.

and really know the dev who made this game is confusing aswell. an in interview a while ago he stated he wanted the combo system to be like smash 64 which is extremely combo heavy( think MVC3 is you know about it) yet has a character in the roster that dies at 50 and flies out of combos like crazy. 

oh and moves sometimes fly right through people at times,along with a ton of other tangable hitboxes that don't match visual hitboxes so thats a thing.(im talking full 3 hit jab combo can happen while someone is behind you). along with parry replacing block which is a terrible option when it plays out, considering your defensive option is NOW a risk in itself to be punished. which is crazy considering there are moves that can only be punished via parry, which is awful considering this game is mostly played online.

i really tried to like this game I did. but I can't recommend such a frustating experince with playing this game. maybe when its not barebones and it gets full release(which was suppost to come out like a year ago) maybe the content offline can help this be enjoyable.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Melee without grabs or ledges, replaced with a constant necessity for neutral and mindgames, and no real stall tactics, such as ledge regrabs for invincibility (cuz again, no ledges to grab).  The "Basic" versions of stages are all pretty great for tournament play, and the "Aether" stages are great for things like parties, what with all of the wacky stuff that can happen.  Cast is small, and a lot of them have movesets inspired by those of the Smash Bros. series, but hopefully (and probably) we'll see the roster grow in the future.  Wish that the GameCube Adapter could have native support, cuz my laptop doesn't have 4 USB ports for 4 separate Xbox/PS4 controllers lmao.  Overall, great game, really wanna see more in the future.

This game is actually playable.
So play it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1]This Game is Goooooood![/h1]

Before playing the game, I expected it to be good but I didn't expect it to make me get hyped again for a videogame. The game is pretty fun if you're a fan of Smash Bros, especially Melee, but if you're not, you should still give this game a try. Coming from a 2D/3D fighter background, I never thought I would enjoy this game as much as I'm enjoying it right now. The game actually made me interested in the Smash scene and I've been trying out Melee because of this game.
Here's a list of the pros and cons that I've noticed:

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]The tutorial is great for beginners. It's very well made and deffo will teach you the basics and some advance stuff in the game. It even has character specific tutorials!
[*]The game's roster is fun and pretty balanced. All the characters in the roster, at the time of this writing, are all pretty viable and all of them feels unique and the roster has a very wide variety of playstyles. For example, Wrastor is a very combo heavy character but is very light, another example is Orcane, a character that utilizes puddles to improve its attacks but needs a lot of planning and decision-making in-game.
[*}The game is still in Early Access. You might also take this as a con but being an early access game means the game still has a lot more room for improvement. Expect more characters and stages to be released because of this.
[*]The gameplay and controls are smooooooth as hell. Like what I said during the intro, I exclusively played 2D/3D fighters before this but the controls were so easy to learn that the transition was super smooth. The controls are also customizable depending on your preference.
[*]One word: [b]SOUNDTRACK[/b]
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]The online matchmaking is awful! It might be because the playerbase is still small but getting matched-up with a player that you declined thrice already is stupid.
[*]I don't know about other players' experience but online was laggy for me in general. I rarely get below 150 ping when playing online, even in friendly battles. I think it's because of my internet connection but my connection is pretty above average in my country's standards.
[*]The learning curve is pretty steep just like other fighters but with the great tutorial and some patience, it's pretty easy to get the hang of the game. But expect to dive deep inside the game for countless hours if you want to be borderline "good" in competitive.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Overall, this game is one of the best games I've played gamplay-wise. Everything is thought out carefully and well done. To be fair, it's not a perfect game per-se but it's a great one nontheless. The game might still be in early access and we're still waiting for the story mode and other single player modes, like the abyss mode but it's more than playable. I'll rate this game(in its current state) a [b]9/10[/b].

Play this game

The characters all feel very distinct and rewarding, from Wrastor's mastery of the air to Orcane's unique stage control with puddle and bubble based moves. title: Rivals of Aether
review: The game "Rivals of Aether" is commonly compared to the game "Super Smash Brothers" by Nintendo, But I rebutle with this, they are both very different in there own special way. One reason for this is that the characters in Rivals of Aether are completely original. Unlike Super Smash Brothers, this game does not have a story mode (yet) this somewhat benefitial for the game, in how you dont have to worry about the story, but instead, you can spend time practicing your favorite character. (Mine is Kragg). Speaking of Characters, each character in this game is completely unique, From creating explosions of smoke to bulling out boulders and throwing them at your enemys and then shattering them into pieces, hurting them even more, anyway, all characters are completely unique. I thank the youtuber "Aplharad" for pursuading me to buy this game. I completely recomend this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
RoA is most certainly a competitve Smash player's game. Everything about the game was made for them. Even down to the termonology used in the game. (although instead of saying "smash attack" they say "strong attack") That's not at all a bad thing. Even though there's only 8 characters, every character is unique. Same goes for the stages. 
Even though the game's great, there are some things I have to mention. The intermediate and advanced turtorials, for non-smash players, will most likely overwhelm you. A lot. It overwhelmed me and I already had some clue on what they were talking about. That being said, this is not a game for people who do not like or have any intrest in competitve smash. This game was made for people who play competitively, and the game simply doesn't have things for people who want to have nothing but a good time and don't care about tier lists and match-ups. So, if you liked Melee, yes. I highly recommend it. If you play Smash casually, no.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]
Rvials of Aether is an extraordinary game that is very reminiscent of the Super Smash Bros. series.  Most will compare this game to Super Smash Bros. Melee, but I feel it's actually closer to Project M, the mod of Super Smash Bros. Brawl to create a game closer in concept to Melee.

[h1] The Pros [/h1]
[list]
[*] The movement and combos in the is very smooth and fluent, even more so if you have played the SSB games before.
[*] Eight entirely unique characters to Rivals of Aether with inspirations in their movesets taken from existing characters in SSB.
[*] Each character has a unique trait about them that can be used to enhance their attributes or create a different result.
[*] The tutorial for general gameplay and specific characters is great for introducing you to the platformer fighter (party game) genre and giving you a basic understanding for each character.
[/list]

[h1] The Cons [/h1]
[list]
[*] Becoming remotely decent for a competitive level, can take several tens or hundreds of hours, if you're not already familiar with Smash Bros., however that still doesn't mean you'll be good here if you are there.
[*] Matchmaking could use improvement, while this can be controlled a bit if you set your region, you'll still encounter people with not so desirable ping or the same people over and over.
[*] Ping can be a problem depending on who you're playing with and where from.
[/list]

[h1] Tidbits [/h1]

You CAN change the controls for the game! Don't like jumping when you flick your stick up? Problem solved! Don't like doing a strong/smash attack when you want to do a tilt? Well you can solve that too!
I also hate how ridiculous the hitstun... Yeah, I went and said it. I don't like the super long lasting hitstun that pretty much allows this game's combos to function. I think that covers my additional thoughts.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Rivals of Aether is a very fun game to play as friends, both as a party game and a competitive fighter.  It is a great way to get into the platformer fighter genre without having to make an investment and I would recommend this title to anyone who has friends that they can play with or are already acquainted with SSB.

I give it a nice 8 outta 10.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
"Oh its just another smash clone, might as well just play something else..." ahem... THIS GAME IS AMAZING. Ok let me be serious my brother bought this game and i didn't think much of it, then i did the tutorial, now i LOVE it! This game throws smash 4's rules RIGHT OUT THE WINDOW!!!! It has the same mechanics as melee (which is a game that i love) and has its own characters, if people dont play this game who are in the competetive scene for smash, then i say give it a try, its one of the best games i have ever played on steam and is my favourite, i only had the chance to buy it a few days ago but i have spent countless hours on it on my brothers account and when he shared it with me, 10/10 would buy again, thank you so much Dan Fornace for giving me this game it is so amazing and i hope you keep developing it.

10/10 5 Stars IGN

Netplay is still laggy quit often, but it seems a bit more stable than I remember. 

There are also balancing changes that I noticed, but not looked into fully. My main zetterburn seems about the same, but I have noticed differences. Nothing too drastic however. Glad they are consciously thinking about balancing without over doing it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of the Aether is a pretty good clone of super smash bros melee.

It's got tight controls.
It's got good character abilities and attacks.
It's got great levels and customization.

As long as your not playing online, and just hanging out with some friends playing local, it can be a pretty fun game.
Online however.... hmmm.....

Guess the only way to put it is almost every online player feels like they have something to prove, and even in casual pvp, they make sure to rip you apart as viciously as they can. Don't get me wrong, I love a challenge, but not when the enemy literally acts like they are playing a tournament, and can't take casual mode for what it is. CASUAL.

TL,DR edition: The game is great. The online is FAR beyong tryharding.

review: Great platform-based 2d fighting game in a similar vein as Super Smash Bros. I've had a lot of fun with the game (30h in a week so far) in large part due to the helpful community of this game. That said, be prepared to lose online for a while if you buy before the full release as the current early access community is pretty experienced (I bought the game winter 2016 and it was already in early access for over a year I believe). When you face an equally skilled opponent there's nothing like it but against the better players you can sometimes feel completely defenceless and helpless until you improve and learn the game more.The music is good, the 8 current characters are all well balanced and offer a variety of playstyles, and the gameplay is really fun. If you don't mind spending some time to improve then I would recommend Rivals of Aether but don't expect to win often when you first start playing online.

All the characters in this game are unique, and every character has some sort of stage control. There are alot of interesting mechanics that I've not seen in other fighting games like this, and the graphics/music are amazing. For people who have played other fighting games like smash bros, alot of the basic mechanics are the same, while this game adds alot of new mechanics such as:
[list]
    [*]Parrying
    [*]Every character has a wall jump
    [*]No ledge grabbing
    [*]Direction airdodging (Like in Melee, and yes this does bring back wavedashing!)
    [*]TUTORIAL MODE (For new players and more experienced players to help introduce them to the new mechanics)
[/list]
The developers of this game are really smart, listen to the community, and balance the game alot better for competitive play. I don't know how well this game plays with keyboard, but if you have a gamepad (I use/recommend Gamecube) I would recommend picking up this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game stands out from the crowd, to say the least.

While seemingly just a knock off of everyone's favorite Smash Bros. franchise, this game throws you into a conceptual fighting game that requires a good amount of time and dedication to get the hang of. It's true, some of the abilities certain characters have are obvious imitations from SSB; most of them are used in conjunction with the rest of that character's kit. This introduces a larger field of outplay potential than most other games. A battle can demand constant focus as to where your opponent(s) are setting up to potentially annihilate you and in turn, makes you play accordingly. 

Despite the roster only featuring 8 playable characters at the moment, you may find yourself playing one for hours and all of a sudden discovering a new combo you can perform. What also sets this game apart from the SSB franchise is that there are 3 attack buttons and a larger amount of air attacks, which amount to somewhere between 15-20 attacks per character. 

Rivals of Aether is an incredibly complex game for how simple it comes off as and while you may find yourself encountering a lag spike occasionally, I wouldn't consider it to make the game unplayable by any means.

Through the combination of art style, music, SFX and mechanics, this game is definitely worth your money if you're at all into fighting games and even more so if you're a fan of the SSB franchise.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Before I begin: I have a couple of years of experience with Melee and Project M, and this review is mostly my first impressions.  Rivals is much like the Smash games, but it introduces some new mechanics for better or for worse.

The classic rock-paper-scissors of Smash is attack/shield/grab.  In RoA, the latter two do not exist.  In their place is a lone "parry" feature that cancels out the opponent's attack and stuns them for 40 frames (and reflects projectiles).  In theory, this was intended to make the game more aggressive, but in my experience with netplay, it seriously hurts the neutral game.  Parrying a move is much more advantageous than blocking it would be if you had the option, and it is equal to or better than hitting the opponent with a combo starter... so obviously it's kind of busted.  Rivals' answer to this is to make the first hit of jab not recieve stun from a parry, and also to make it cancelable into any tilt.  I haven't made up my mind on whether or not this is worse.  The tutorial also teaches parry baiting, which is basically the same as spotdodge baiting, except it also removes things like OoS options and shield pressure (as a Falco player, the absence of the latter is disappointing).

There's also no ledges.  Melee ledges are really dumb (even as someone who religiously grabs ledge when the opponent is offstage) so I can see why this change would be explored, but in practice it seems to really hurt Zetterburn (PM Wolf, basically) most and Wrastor (Marth + Puff +  Falco, also the best character in the game) least.

As for the mechanics it borrows from Smash games:
Directional airdodges, and thus, wavedashes, are possible.  They accept digital inputs, do not put you into special fall, and can be buffered.
SDI does not actually take smash inputs at all.  The tutorial introduces it in the context of escaping multihits, but in my experience, there are practically none of those that are actually exploitable, so... I guess it's just an addition to combo DI?

Speaking of controls that aren't the way they should be, the right stick charges smashes when held, which is quite disappointing from a game that borrows so much from Melee since only Smash 4 does this.  And also like Smash 4, netplay is more often than not a lagfest.  I've had better experiences here than with For Glory, however.

...And now that I have torn as much out of this game as I can, it's still the best Smash-like experience you'll find on Steam.  I got it for less than $10 and it's easily worth it at that price, especially if you intend to play locally with other people.  There doesn't seem to be a huge scene for it, but it's fun enough to deserve one.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Do you like Smash Bros? Yes? Alright then that's enough reason to buy this game.

This game is one of the finest "Smash Bros. but not Smash Bros" games out there, I'd go as far to say that it's the best one.
There are tutorials for literally every single character and every single technique. It's all there to help you "git gud". Comboing in this game just feels good. If you understand Smash, you will understand this game.

I will mention what I think are its shortcomings:

Only 8 Characters - This is not a huge deal, in some ways it's a good thing. Less characters means an easier time of finding your favorite. I'm just wondering if the character roster will ever see more diversity.

Not that many stages - Things get kind of stale just fighting on the same few maps, Yes you can alternate between an "Aether" version and a "Basic" version, but I found myself always playing on the Basic versions of the stages so the Aether versions don't matter that much to me. I would just love to see more options.

Okay those are the only shortcomings I can think of, but even then, this game has a ton of depth and there's still more to come.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is an all around amazing game and i have picked it up because it appeared to be the same smash style I loved but at a cheaper price with different mechanics that make this game unique

PROS
- All new unique characters
- No relied upon mechanic of shieilding or grabbing but reverts to dodgeing instead
- Cheap
- Low PC requirements

CONS
- Very few characters
- Controls are hard to pickup
- People are very picky with who they want to face agaist online and will often disconnect after the first round or jump of the edge because you outplayed them in one of your three lives

However this game is extremely fun with very little learning curve to pick up and play but very difficult to master which gives it a great balance of easy fun and tough challenges.

UPDATED - Nov 2016

RoA is still a massivley fun game but the dwindling playerbase has made it much more challenging to have exciting ranked games without playing the same player 4 times in a row. This may appeal to some people due to the grit that they must push through in order to come out on top. However, it makes it much more difficult to have short que times or to recieve players consistantly in a similar region as you. Making ping a major problem in the ranked system.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is an excellent game for fans of the Super Smash Bros. Series. 

It features similiar gameplay options: wavedashing, short hops, fast falls, specials, teching, wall jumps, DI, and SDI. While all of these mechanics are featured in Super Smash Bros. Melee, here in Rivals of Aether, they are much simpler to execute. The frame window for inputs is much greater allowing you to pick up these advanced techniques quite easily.

Ledge mechanics are different. You can not grab ledge, however it is still very important to prevent the opponent from recovering. 

The combo game is a big part of Rivals of Aether. Similiar to Smash Bros. you can "free style" your combos by reacting to DI and tech. 

Defense-wise, there are no shields. However, you do have a block. When timed correctly, this block can also stun the enemy for a short time. You also still have your standard rolls and air-dodges.

The game is wonderfully designed. You have 8 characters, all with a wide variety of movesets. You have a decent amount of maps, each with a "competitive" variant. You can create custom skins for characters. There is a button check mode right from the character select screen, excellent for quick handwarmers. There are in depth tutorials that teach the basics and advanced techniques of the game. There is local and offline play, against a second player or AI. There is also 4 player teams. Story mode and Abyss mode (a wave based gamemode) are on the way too. There are also new maps and characters planned for the future. 

It is also important to note that you are able to use a GameCube controller (as long as you have the proper adapter). So if you have played any of the Smash games on the Dolphin Emulator or are coming from Anther's Ladder, you will be all set.

While this game isn't an exact copy of Super Smash Bros., fans of the series will find and enjoy many similarities. All in all, a great game designed with the player in mind. It is easier to pick up, yet still difficult to master. I highly reccomend it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like fighting game, this game is a great change in gameplay. It is a sumo-fighter, like those in the Series Smash Bros series, but it is designed with a competitive mindset in hand. The characters feel both balanced and fleshed out, providing a great experience. I first noticed this game on Humble Bundle, and I was skeptical at first. While, I had played Brawlhallah, it the characters felt empty and unbalanced. The mechanics were also a little unclear, unlike Rivals of Aether. In RoA (Rivals of Aether) exhibition matches are done as a best 2 out of 3, and while both games feature the "sumo" mechanic, where the objective to to knock the opponent out of the ring, RoA's normal gameplay doesn't reward you points for a knock out, but instead penalizes you for getting knocked out. This, in contrast to Brawlhallah's normal scoring system, rewards player for not just knock outs, but kill streaks and kill steals as well. I felt as though it cheapened gameplay, and rewarded those who were good at the latter, but not necessarily completely competent in overall skill. The biggest differences in mechanics, generally speaking, compared to others are that: 1) you cannot grab ledges, but each character is given a wall jump and can use their recovery move once before and after the wall jump; 2) shields do not exist, you can still "perfect shield" like in the Smash series, but it will only activate a "parry" which allows you a brief window to punish your opponents mistakes; 3) it has no grab/throw mechanics, other than Etalus's up air; 4) there are three types of attack buttons, jab/tilt with a normal attack, special attacks, and heavy attacks (like Smash attacks). I feel that, with these mechanics in place, it creates a much different environment and experience than that of other Sumo's, or "Smash-likes."

   In summary, I feel that Rivals of Aether offers fun, balanced gameplay with unique, well-developed, and creative characters, all while keeping the game feeling fair and offering a true test of mettle in gameplay. Now I could go on about how greatly unique and fleshed-out each character feels, or how the stages, hazardous or not, are well designed and approached with a competitive mind. Unfortunately, I can't in my right mind do that, because then when you get the game you won't have any surprises left.

- Fast paced, allowing plenty of combos.
- Plenty of balanced stage options.
- Charming graphics.

- Up to 4 players.
- Controller support.
- Balanced fighters.
- It rewards skill, not luck.

Cons:
- Only 8 playable fighters, so it can get stale at times.
- Online play is shoddy. You need a good connection to play online.
- Not many online players.

Overall I'd give it a 8.5/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is an awesome game. Do you have too much money and want an amazing fighting game? This is the one.
Lets get down to this.
Good stuff. 
Fluid gameplay.
Every charater is very different.
With smash, the characters are thrown in the game with moves from their past games. This game, the characters are made FOR the game. All characters have some form of stage control. So many strategies for all of the characters. Its really great to see.
It takes the wavedash glitch from melee into this game, and openly explains it to you (for your hardcore people, you can buffer the wavedash. Im not sure if you can do that in melee, but with my experience in melee wavedashing was really hard.) 

Not so good stuff.
A lot of people dont play the game yet.
The game is yet to be complete. (even though they patch and unpatch, they have yet to add their single player modes. Its all a really long process.)
You'll soon find out how bad your are.
There's a learning curve if this is your first competitve fighting game.
 
Look the bad stuff isn't that bad, just buy the damn game so Dan can add more stuff to it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Melee and PM veterans will feel right at home here. With Zetterburn being able to "waveshine" and feeling like Project M Wolf, Absa having strong elements from Pikachu and Zelda, Maypul having that same rushdown playstyle that Sheik has, there is a character here for everyone. Enough changes for the game to feel like a breath of fresh air, but with enough technical depth to appeal to old school smashers, I can say this game has a long future ahead of it. Devs are working on balancing the roster and improving matchmaking at this time, but will be adding fun single player modes soon. Very competitive. Watch the Summit 3 Rivals of Aether highlights on Youtube if you aren't sold yet.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: [i] Rivals of Aether [/i] is one of the first games in a new sub-genre of fighting games called the "platform fighter." This genre is based off of Nintendo's popular Super Smash Bros. series and is particularly influenced by [i] Super Smash Bros. Melee [/i] and its competitive gameplay. [i] Melee [/i] has been played competitively for 15 years now, and [i] Rivals of Aether [/i] builds upon the foundations set by Melee's gameplay and builds on it in order to create a fresh new experience that stays familiar to competitive [i] Melee [/i] players. It's a fantastic game and I would recommend it to anyone who likes [i] Super Smash Bros. [/i] or fighting games in general.

review: I can't think of a better platform fighter on the PC market, this game is not only fun for when I played casually, but also competitively. The gameplay is so intricate, and there's always something new you can learn. We have a great little community with weekly tournaments specifically for beginners so newer players can get into the scene without the wall of experienced players. We also have weekly tournaments for all levels of play (all free to enter), allowing everyone to get into the competitive scene easily with online play. Great game, highly recommend, fans of melee will find it different yet very familiar.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Not only is Rivals of Aether a great competitive fighting game but it is one of the biggest surprises of indie gaming. The project has been lead by a passionate and talented team and it clearly reflects on the product after playing for hours upon hours. All the characters are well fleshed out be it through their colorful appearance to their distinctive gameplay. The sprite work is a love letter to retro games but reinvents it in a new and modern way. The musical scores are charming and suit the feel of the stages beautifully. The game on the surface is easy to learn for beginners but rewarding to those who want to devote the time to master it.

Although Rivals is a fantastic game it does have its share of problems that I hope the team addresses heading launch. The game is unforgiving to people who play with keyboards. Keyboard play feels unintuitive and just jarring compared to controllers, which may alienate many potential consumers and owners to continue playing. Also, the $15 pay wall indefinitely hinders the game to grow. I agree with this payment method personally and see that it supports the development team, but objectively it does pull consumers away to other titles which are cheaper or even free. Unfortunately, if such problems continue to exist it will negatively affect the game and it's playerbase in both the short and long term. Alienating potential players will make the game less lively; there will be less people to play against in either the ranked or exhibition mode. A lack of new blood will raise the question if it is worthwhile to continue playing to veterans. Admittedly, these are difficult issues but I have complete faith that the team will succeed. 

Ultimately, Rivals of Aether is an outstanding game and an even more special experience with friends. Most importantly, you will not regret buying this game if you are striving to 'get gud'.

Each of the 8 characters is flashy and unique, watching high level play make think this will end up dominating smash once it gets properly finetuned and released.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I don't really know how to categorize this review. I guess Ill recommend because Im glad at least platform fighters are getting attention and I want to support developers. 

As a melee player I want to badly to like this game but every time I pick it up I find myself more frustrated than having fun. I think the character designs are interesting. The art is good and the music is great. I just can't get behind how pervasive aggression is as a strategy and I want more defensive options. Neutral game feels pretty absent for the most part as everyone if crazy fast and online parrying is unreliable. Ill stick to melee thanks. Good work to the developers, game just is not for me.  

tl;dr good game for some but the lack of sheild triggers this defensive melee player

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Easy to play, hard to master. The core gameplay is very smooth, and if you've played Smash you'll get the hang of it pretty quickly. The skill ceiling is massive yet it's fairly simple to chain attacks into combos. There are plenty of unique abilities and playstyles for each character. The mechanics are similar to Smash, but the game feels much more responsive with less lag/delay which makes it more enjoyable. For an early access game, it is incredibly balanced and well-designed. I've encountered practically zero bugs and crashes are extremely rare. RoE is a great game to play with friends or solo!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[b]This game is better than Melee.[/b]

Wait, hear me out.

So, there are two things to look for when designing a competitive game: the degree of [i]challenge[/i], and the degree of [i]fun[/i]. When it comes to mainstream games, we associate the former with competitive viability and the latter with "casual" appeal. For example, some might argue that the later Smash games are more "fun" than Melee, even if they're less "challenging."

But there's fun in competitive design, too. Do you enjoy playing Peach vs Puff in Melee? Or even Puff vs Peach, for that matter. I'm a Marth main, and I dislike fighting ICs, even though he's good against them.

There are aspects of Melee's design that make it [i]not fun[/i]. Yes, it's competitive, and it has a high skill ceiling - but Marth vs Fox when the Fox is above 100%? Not fun. Just frustrating.

It only took a few hours of Rivals of Aether to realize that the game rights many of Melee's wrongs. For example, knockback seems to scale more for kill moves than combo moves, so damaging your opponent too much never makes them harder to kill. That's more intuitive than Melee's approach; why should Fox at 150% be more of a threat than Fox at 75%?

RoA is filled with tons of little improvements:

* Horizontal wavedashing makes it easy to get a "max length" wavedash.
* Wavedashing without a directional input gives you a wavedash in place rather than an accidental air dodge.
* More recovery options make gimps harder, but you can still get edgeguarded for days.
* Blast zones are closer to the screen, so there are fewer of those "Samus bomb-jumping back from the corner of Dream Land" situations. Either you're in a fast-paced edgeguard situation, or you're dead.
* No Tournament Winner, thank god.

On top of that, RoA adds its own layers of depth. Parrying is an awesome mechanic, and it'll grow more sophisticated as people get better at the game. Air dodges actually add movement options in neutral, not just recovery - lots more to explore here too.

Honestly, the only thing this game needs is players. Its design is already better than the games that inspired it. It just needs a higher skill ceiling - and I think the potential is there, if we develop the meta. Keep it up, Dan & team!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A great indie game and a very well-made Smash clone so far. Though there are only 8 characters, all of them are unique and varied in their playstyles, and have so much depth I could never get bored of using just one. My favorite is Orcane, with his slippery...slippery-ness and water abilities, though his recovery isn't always the best.

Gameplay is fast-paced and very focused on offense. There are no shields, so your only forms of defense are well-timed dodges and a new parry mechanic which lets you punish an attack or reflect projectiles, but can be punished if you don't use it correctly. No items, but I don't miss them and the game can get chaotic enough with four characters at once. Stages either have fun gimmicks or can be toggled to be more friendly to the serious player. Online is 1v1 only at this time, but the netcode is great as far as I could tell.

There's some great features of its own as well, like the ability to make your own color schemes for every character, a well-made tutorial that walks you through the basics before covering more advanced techniques and character-specific info, and playtesting controls ON THE CHARACTER SELECT SCREEN. Frankly, every fighting game needs something like this.

Don't get to play it as much as I like though, which is something I need to fix! The game does not seem far off from its full release, so hopefully more people can check it out. I highly recommend it (the music is great too)!

title: Rivals of Aether

I hope the roster gets a bit bigger (2 more characters would be good) but the polish on this game is insane it feels so good to land big hits and get KRAGG'S DOWN AIR AND SPIKING SOMEONE TO HELL! Highly recommend it, but don't get too mad going online and getting destroyed, do your best, play exhibition and look up some youtube guides and just enjoy the game. Kragg is my favorite character. Kragg. Kragg. Kraaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaagg.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Is RoA an amazing game? Yes. Does it have the basic elements of Smash Bros.? Yes. Does it have a similar player base? Not even close. 

The only reason I down voted this game was because of the current player base. The casuals have left the game for the most part, leaving only those who aspire to perform well in the game's recently added ranked mode. This game is very beginner friendly with a variety of tutorials; however, you're going to have to look up tips and tricks for whatever character you want to learn in order to do well online - a bit too much for me.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether, simply put, is Super Smash Brothers but more competetive. And yes, I know Smash CAN be competetive, but it wasn't made to be. Anyways, onto the review.

Pros:
Amazing spriting and animations
Excellent gameplay that could replace Smash in competetive play
A tutorial mode, to teach you competetive Smash techniques like Wavedashing and DI

Cons:
Hard for casual players to get into
Hard for non-smash players to get into



Overall, I rate 8/10, The game is still in beta, so I might make a more in-depth review then.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[b]DISCLAIMER[/b] this reveiw is specifically on a patch I do not agree with and I am not saying the game is bad, go buy it it's amazing.

I genuinly loved this game until they nerfed forsburn so you cant attack with the clone unless you have 3 smokes stored up, he was really the only thing going for it to me and they removed what made him cool instead of nerfing what actually made him broken. I'm probably gonna stick to melee icies for now unless they bring his clone's hitboxes back, but I do have a few ideas as to how they could bring back attacking with the clone while also making it balanced.

[u]Idea number 1[/u]:smoke charges. I think a cool thing they could do would be this. If you have 1 smoke stored forsburn's clone attacks once every 300 frames or 5 seconds, 2 smokes stored every 180 frames or 3 seconds, and when you have all 3 it attack's every 180 frames and you can control when it attacks.

[u]Idea number 2[/u]:buffing charged clones. So I actually do like how you still sorta can have a clone that can attack if you have 3 smokes stored but that's not as easy as it may sound AND the clone can die from 1 single hit making your efforts almost meaningless. I think giving the charged clone 2-3 hits before it dies would make your efforts a bit more meaningful so it wont get killed right as you spawn your hard work, though multihits will count as however many hits the move has, making it still susceptible to an early death. Now i know it'd be hard to keep track of how many hits the clone has until death so maybe each hit it'd change color, like to whatever the original skin you chose was.

Anyways this game is still great and i highly reccomend it, but I just wish they didnt hit forsburn so hard.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
My views on this game are skewed for expecting a Melee clone. Do not go into this game expecting Melee. Fans of Smash 4 or Project M will enjoy this game more than I did. Although there are more positives about this game than negatives, the negative points made me unable to enjoy this game.

Pros:
+Gameplay does feel tight and responsive
+Diverse bunch of characters
+In theory, focused on more active and aggressive play
+Combo-heavy
+Stages are pretty nice

Cons:
-Most characters have "gimmicky" mechanics that obstruct combat (raising platforms, traps, teleportation, gusts of wind)
-Hitboxes seem a bit wonky and very simple

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I definitely recommend this. It is fast paced and more fun than super smash bros. It's not that hard to become good. Online has very skilled players so be careful. For now (August 2016) the game is only set to a 1v1 tournament-like mode online. If you're playing offline there currently isn't much to do but practice and fight CPU's. You have to wait for the other modes to be released. I hope that will change soon. I'd like to sit and relax online with 4 players and even teams. Once you get the hang of the game you'll see that it is actually quite balanced. It may not seem so if you play online but thats just the skill level gap i promise. In my opinion this is a Steam essential.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is basically an indie version of Super Smash Bros. Melee, but every character is competitively viable and it's a LOT easier to get into competitively. The game is a little different from the Smash series with the ability for all of the characters to walljump, but they can't grab onto ledges, and there are no grabs. The game also has advanced techs from Melee like Wavedashing and Dash-Dancing, but these are very, VERY easy to pull off. The game supports almost every PC controller (including adapters for controllers for different systems), so don't worry competitive Smashers, GameCube controllers are compatitble with this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you're not already seeing this game's trailer and basing it on the photos then it's really doing an injustice to the game. For many who love to play Super Smash Bros. or even like to play just a decent brawler will definitely love this game for what it's worth. The mechanics are solid, it gets good updates at a steady pace, and the characters are so unique in their own right. If you wanna look for something that feels like Nintendo on PC then this is my immediate recommedation to anyone as it really shines like no other out there right now. If there even is any other game out right now trying to live up to the Smash Bros. title.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you played super smash bros and were ever like, "This is a cool concept, but I wish it was a game whose sole focus was being a competitive and skill based fighting game." Well, congrats this game is for you. There are no items, rules default to being stock (cough, cough smash 4,) and the stage gimmicks turn off without becoming all the same fd. Online play plays out in bo3 sets and you can choose to rematch your opponent if it was a good match. All the characters have their own gimmick that helps them win neutral, all the characters are unique. There are some moves you can point to and be like, Oh, that's from C. Falcon, or that's totally Marth Fair, or wow is that supposed to be shine? Most importantly though, everyone is mostly viable. Another way this game is different from Melee (lowkey shots fired) is that you can't ledgehog or grab ledge in general. Instead you have a wall jump that can cancel special fall and most stages have a flat wall to jump from. This game is in beta and They are actively working to make it more balanced and fun so i think it's worth the amount of dollars (15) I put down on it. 9/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Do you like fighting games? Do you like 2D fighting games with platforms? Do you like Super Smash Bros. Melee? And most importantly, do you like playing as an anthropomorphic deer that can control the very essense of lightning itself? Well than this game is for you. Seriously, it has like almost all the mechanics of SSBM, except without a block/shield (It's a counter in this game) and without being able to grab on the ledge but hey, you can use your recovery after wall jumping and every character can wall jump. It also has online play and controller support, so that's cool. All in all, I recommend this game. Just don't expect too much right now because this game is still a WIP.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is far from being just another Smash Bros. clone. 
It is inherently clear that Super Smash Bros. was the foundation Rivals of Aether was built upon, yet the end result is completely different from anything Nintendo has been able to create and what some may argue 're-create'.

A major difference between Smash Bros and RoA is the absence of shield and grab abilities. While that may sound like a major con, it is actually quite the opposite. The removal of those two basic features really brings out what I believe to be the original intent of the developer. COMBO'S, COMBO'S, and more COMBO'S!

Launching the tutorial mode also brings upon greater insight on just how different this game is from anythings within Super Smash Bros. franchise. Advance techniques such as wave-dashing and wave-landing are now treated as a fundemental part of 'normal' gameplay, rather than some glitch only high-level players found useful. In tutorial mode, you also discover that while the shield mechanic has been removed, it has been replaced with, what I personally believe to be a more technical function; that is of course the parry mechanic.  

Overall, I am glad to see the smash genre growing and heading in this direction. Even if this game goes nowhere, I hope that developers pick up where RoA left off. However, I am more than happy with the outcome of RoA in it's current state and anxiously await future updates!
