title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This has more heart than Brawlhalla ever will.
I saw this game on an article in Kotaku and I thought, "Smash bros with Pixel graphics for PC? sounds like the best Idea ever." At first I was reluctant when I saw this game was in Early Access. (It still is, but new updates have dropped recently.) But I eventually caved and purchased this game, and I did not regret it.

The controls are simple, you have a Jump, a normal attack, strong attack, and a special attack. Each of the eight characters have a unique playstyle and you can try them all to see which of them you like best. I highly recommend you play this with a controller, because you need to do some advanced tecniques only a controller can provide comfortably. you can customize the controls to suit your play style, which is a great thing in my opinion. 

The game can be enjoied with local and online multiplayer, you can invite four friends to play local multiplayer allows. But only two players can play online. 

But it's still in early access though, so anything's possible. My hope is when the final product allows four player online matches.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like Super Smash Bros. Melee for its great number of fast, precise inputs, this game probably isn't for you.
Now that that's out of the way, this is a great game. It's known as a Smash clone, but that's largely because it's part of the same unexplored genre, commonly referred to as a platform fighter. Granted, it is a very specific genre, and one that Smash practically invented, and Rivals of Aether also borrows a few mechanics, but I digress. The game has numerous mechanics that make the game very easy to pick up, including a very well-made tutorial mode where your charming guide Orby explains everything about the game, from the difference between walking and running, to how to properly DI so you don't die to a sourspot back air, and more. However, don't think that you can finish the tutorial and then immediately start climbing the ladder on Ranked mode - the skill ceiling in this game is astonishing, and you can easily discern the difference between a scrub and a veteran. Newbies need not fear, however, as the game's active community, including Reddit and the official North American Discord group, are very welcoming and helpful. Or, if its online mode doesn't attract you, there's always the local mode, where you can play against up to three friends or AI opponents.

TL;DR This is a fun game. Buy it, and play it. Like, now.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A pretty damn good game.
As a game that essentially tries to be a Super Smash Bros Melee for the PC, even down to replicated 'pro-play' mechanics like Wavedashing, it's still fun and has it's own style. All the characters actually feel different and not like reskins or clones of other characters. The artstyle is great to look at, the characters and controls are tight and responsive, and the music is something to behold (Air Armada especially). 
However at the moment the game still feels rather bare with the only modes just being online and local fighting, but hopefully future updates should change that.
Works with Xbox controller and even works with GameCube controllers (if you have a Mayflash Adapter).

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1]ESP:

¿Deberías comprar Rivals of Aether? La verdad,  si en algún punto de tu vida te ha gustado algún juego de la serie Smash este juego seguro que te encantara.[/h1]

·Pros:
-Jugabilidad tipo Smash pero con pequeñas variaciones que lo hacen crear un estilo propio
-Personajes Variados y cuando digo variados me refiero a que realmente cada personaje tiene una manera de jugar  diferente y que  hacen al personaje unico.
-El hecho de que sea un Early Access, nos prometen nuevos mapas, personajes y modos.
-La estética Pixel-Art: Detallada y bonita de ver. Animaciones muy trabajadas.
-Ranking Online, marcadores nacionales, tutoriales de juego y otros dedicados al manejo de los diferentes personajes.
-Se trata de un juego destinado al competitivo donde desde el principio te enseñan técnicas como tech, crouch-cancellling, wall-jumps, dash-dancing...
-60 FPS Baby!

·Cons:
-Dificultad para obtener una buena conexión al jugar online, tanto en ranked como en exhibición.
-El proceso de acostumbrarse a los controles ( la Y (del mando de Xbox( por dios juega con mando)) para saltar) y la entrada al online y el hecho de que te destrozen es complicado
-Actualmente el juego ofrece poco contenido  (esta review esta siendo escrita en 4 de Julio de 2016 y el juego se encuentra en su versión 0.14.1) Solo 8 personajes y 7 mapas, de momento el modo historia  se encuentra bloqueado pero parece que esta al caer.
-Esta en Early Acces, así que tu te arriesgas.

Dicho esto, ¿Deberías comprar Rivals of Aether? Te lo recomiendo.

[h1]ING

¿Should you buy Rivals of Aether? Actually, if at some point in your life you enjoyed a game of Smash series  for sure  you will love this game.[/h1]

· Pros:
Gameplay-Smash-like  but with minor variations, creating it own style
-Characters Diversity: Every one has his own way to play it.
-The Fact that it is an Early Access, the promise of new maps, characters and modes.
-The Pixel-Art aesthetic: Detailed and nice to see. Good animations.
- Online,ranking, national markers, game tutorials and other dedicated to the management of the different characters.
-It's a game designed to be competitive, from the beginning  it teach you techniques such as tech, crouch-cancellling, wall-jumps, dash-dancing ...
-60 FPS Baby!

· Cons:
-Online issues
-The Process of getting used to the controls (the Y (the Xbox controller (for the love of god play with Controller)) to jump) and the fact that you'll be raped the first time you play an online match.
, Currently the game offers little content (this review is being written on July 4, 2016 and the game is in its version 0.14.1) only 8 characters and 7 maps, time story mode is blocked but it seems its incoming.
It's in Early Access, so you take a chance.

Having said that, ¿Should you buy Rivals of Aether? I recommend it to you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's like Smash Bros. Melee but more easy, and I don't mean that in a bad way. For example there is no L-canceling, as there is already almost no landing lag.
The tutorial, however, is really great. It's the best tutorial I have ever seen in a game. It goes over everything, including the more advanced stuff like DI (Directional Influence). If you're into any of the Smash games you'll most likely enjoy Rivals of Aether.

Also this game has full GameCube controller support, which is frickin' awesome, along with rebindable controls.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is what Smash should have been after Super Smash Bros Melee. It's fast paced with lots of advanced tech to learn, but without the technical barrier SSBM has. All the characters are unique and and each one can be played with so many different styles, you can bet there's a character you'll love to play. The community has developed nicely, featuring competitive weekly online tourneys and even a coaching program.
This game is a must-have for any Smash player that's mainly a PC gamer.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I recommend this game to Smash lovers. Specifcally Melee players/project M players.

Brawl and N64 and 4 players will probably enjoy this game, but it follows a similar style to melee, and if you're like me who got annoyed by all the projectiles in Sm4sh, this will be some fresh air for you :)

One thing I think that is great about this game is that it's amazing at getting down how you want to play this game. In smash bros, you have to use mostly nintendo only controllers, or cheap knock offs and etc. 

But here, you can use a keyboard, the gamecube controller just needs an adapter and it works perfectly fine you just need to plug it in to an adapter. Logitech controllers, if your mouse had enough buttons you could use that.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
TL;DR this game is amazing




This game is a perfect blend of Super Smash Bros. Melee's speed, with sm4sh's easy-to-learn, hard-to-master. 
The characters have a lot of depth, and play very differently from each other.
 It's not to input-heavy (*cough cough* melee *cough cough*) but isn't slow like Brawl. 
If you've realized, I'm comparing this game to the Super Smash Bros. Series because it's an extremely similar game to the series (platform fighter).
Even though the game is still in beta, I could tell it knows what it wants to be.
The online works well (better than some triple-A games). The matchmaking is nice.
It's furry smash bros. (if you're into that thing)
The community is great. It's not toxic like [league of legends], but they're open minded unlike [Undertale] (be honest the Undertale community is made up of fan-boys. Game's good though)

Overall: 9.28/10
P.S don't trust me with reviews, this game is good though.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is one of my favorite games of all time right now, and I can honestly say that I actually like it better than Super Smash Brothers. I still play smash 4 just as much as this game, however smash 4 is not even close to this game in terms of balanced gameplay and competitiveness. Why do I say this? Well first I will describe a few game mechanics.

-The game focuses on the main mechanic of percent based health, the higher percent you are at, the more knockback your character experiences.
-There are 3 types of moves, Normal attacks (tilts), Special attacks( (specials), and Strong attacks (smash attacks). The Normal attacks and Strong attacks are on different buttons, and while this is a major change from Smashes smash attacks, I think its for the better. It is much easier to preform tilts and strong attacks without accidental interchanging them.
-Air dodging is very similar to melee's air dodging, except it does not put you in free fall.
-Since Air dodging is like melee, you CAN wavedash.
-There is no shielding. Instead, if you press the shield button, you do a parry, which will reflect projectiles and temporarily stun your opponent if they make physical contact with you. This mechanic makes the game much more aggressive and much less defensive, which is a good thing for fast and fun gameplay.
-While there is no shielding, rolling is still pretty much the same.

Those are the base mechanics of the game, however there is a few more features that I should note.
-Excellent Tutorial
-Online play that disciplines disconnecting mid match, and before you challenge someone you can deny because of their ping.
-The game Dev's are really nice and are super active in the community. Constant updates and very easy to reach out to them. I have seen multiple twitter polls and reddit threads that they have made asking the community how to balance the game and how to make it much more fun. And I can say that many if these polls have resulted in actual changes.
-Game has 8 characters. While that does not seem like much, it makes the game extremely easy to balance. The game is actually really balanced, and if one character becomes super overpowered, theres' at least one balance patch every month and it should fix it.
-Game supports both DInput and XInput. I connected gamecube controllers to the game easily.

Negatives? I have a really hard time thinking of any. Some of the only things I can think of is this game is very hard to get in to if you are new to completive fighting games, and the lack of characters. However both these things could be viewed as positives also.

All in all, if you like smash brothers and wish the game was more fair, balanced, and completive, please for the love of god buy this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Never played meele type fighter games like smash etc, and bought this on summer sale to get the experience.

As a casual 2D fighter gamer (KOF, Street Fighter, Samurai Shodown etc), I'm suprised about the complexity of this type of games. The current gameplay in ROE beats Street Fighter 5 by miles.

Pros:
1. Simple command like mortal Kombat X (directional input; no 360/720)
2. Stage design is an important part of the game.
3. Movement is important in this game (don't commit suicide by jumping of the stage); hop, jump, jump cancel & recovery.
4. Main tactic seems to secure better location in stage (forcing player of the stage), parry attack to gain frame advantage and combo player to increase hit percentage (higher means  easier to force the player of the stage with strong attack hit)

Cons:
1. No clear tutorial on how to actually "win" the games. It assumes you're coming from the meele fighter community.
2. Difficult to separate command like down-tilt to moving down in a stage.
3. Still an "early access game"; minimal content.

Highly recommended; even without sale discount.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Played for about an hour and here's what I think

It's a great game for a fighting game on Steam. You really can't beat it if you buy it on sale for $10 or less. I wouldn't pay a full $15 for a game that only has 8 characters and has DLC costumes already, though. Food for thought. 

-Pros

-Wavedashing, Who doesn't like wavedashing? -wish,woosh,wish,woosh-
-Lots of fun combos that can be strung together to create unique kill moves
-If you play competitive Smash you will move than likely enjoy this games mechanics (Its NOT Smash though)
-Netcode is pretty good but there aren't a lot of online players. If you're picking these up you should expect to play it locally with friends that come over or online with friends in your area. I'd suggest buying a copy for a friend if you pick this game up. (That's what I did)

-Cons

-Small character roster (at least characters work well)
-Already have DLC skins (I hate DLC with a passion) 
-No stage without platforms, this could easily be added and would help all players with developing their neutral game
-I haven't been able to find a single person to play with me that isn't on my friends list :/
-This game doesn't have a tournament mode or host its own events. Would be a lot cooler if it did

Overall I think the game is worthwhile if you don't spend more than $15 for it and the DLC characters. Fun game if you enjoy Smash.

But srsly tho f*ck Orcane and his god damn bubbles.

It is basically melee without L-cancelling and some other super advanced techs but is extremely fun, and with the small roster every character can do well if you put enough effort into them. This game is great and I cannot reccomend it enough if you are a melee fan.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a platform fighter heavily inspired by Super Smash Bros. Melee. The thing that Rivals of Aether does different than Super Smash Bros. Melee is it automatically performs all the advanced techniques automatically. Wavedashing is more lenient as Rivals of Aether lets you airdodge while still in the jumpsquat state. Aerial cooldown frames are shortened when compared to Super Smash Bros. Melee. Aerials in Rivals of Aether are usually very easy to follow-up on due to how they position the character.

This is also where I would describe some of these choices as flaws. Due to the fact that many of the techniques from Super Smash Bros. Melee are simplified, there leaves little margain for error. What this does is gives every player powerful tools for no expense. 

Overall, this game is a fun way to get into the competitive platform fighter genre. As competitive as this game may be described, it is definitely only a stepping stone. But if you want to get into Project M and later Super Smash Bros. Melee, this is the game to play.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Disclaimer: I came to this game from the Super Smash Bros series, I learned and mastered most of the advanced techniques from Melee and I learned fundamentals and spacing and making reads from Smash 4. I have no idea what this game is like to new players, or to casual players who don't constantly try to up their game, so I'm not going to speak for them.

I mainly came to Rivals of Aether because I needed a fresh new start. Playing Smash was getting self destructive, to the point where I would cry after every loss. RoA was an attempt to get back into the mechanics I loved, but maybe this time I wouldn't hate the game by the end of it. And you know what? It succeeded. I'll talk more about this later.

Rivals of Aether delivers all the depth and complexity of a Smash game with only 8 characters. Every moment of the game you're making a conscious decision in an attempt to counter whatever you predict the enemy will do. If they're going to attack, parry. If they're going to parry, wait a bit, then attack. If they're going to wait a bit, just attack. It maintains the rock-paper-scissors quality of other fighting games while increasing the pace and the satisfaction of reading your opponent correctly.

Every character is drastically different in how they play, accomadating for each playstyle, so you'll usually find yourself really just maining one character. If you're the fast offensive custom combo type who personally prefers the air, Wrastor has you covered. If you're the heavy hitter who wants to fill your opponent with shame every time you land a hit, Etalus is your character. If you want to piss off your opponent to the point where they can't think straight, well, actually every character does that

The interesting thing about this game is that every character has some quality about them that you can shift the blame to if you lose as them or against them. If he launches you offstage, Etalus can create armor for himself that allows him to take one hit without taking any knockback or flinching. Forsburn has that fucking smoke that he can create at will and basically prevent you from seeing him. Even the stage design has sense of cheapness to it, especially in the stages with high platforms that you can pretty much just camp on to stay safe most of the time. It's really easy to shift the blame onto a broken character or stupid weakness your character has, which might be good or bad depending on your personal viewpoints. I like it though.

One major complaint I have about this game is how unpopulated the game is. Seriously, I'll be waiting minutes just for a match in ranked. Which is why you have to get this game, I'm serious, if what I've said about this game has gotten you interested, buy this game and go on ranked right now so my chance of being able to face someone increases. Please, you'll do the whole community a favor.

All in all, this game is just really fun. It's exactly what I want from a fighting game, and if you're like me, looking for a fresh new start, get this game.

title: Rivals of Aether

Recommended for people that have experience with Melee or Project M [SSB In General]

characters to the mix.

My rating - 80/100

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I bought this game, because my friend recommended it and I also really like SSBM; that is the same reason I tried hard to like it, but some things just aren't meant to be.

Positive:
[list]

[*] The necessary Tech-Skill ceiling is low, so even the low-level player is pretty consistent in his execution and your Melee Tech-Skill will carry over (atleast movement wise).

[*] It is developed to be a competetive fighter right of the bat, rather than a community made one.

[*] Better than Sm4sh / Brawl.

[*] High speed with lots of combos.

[*] There is no way to stall even a little bit, which together with high-speed and lots of combos creates a fast paced game.

[/list]

Negative:
[list]

[*] Defensive options are next to non-existant, you can completely ignore them, as DI-ing properly will still result in a 6 or more hit combo, thanks to imba Offensive options and parrying is almost as inconsistent as Power-Shielding every move.

[*] You will get combo'd hard very often, which can at times be frustrating. (Just imagine every character has Falco's punish game).

[*] I don't know if it's just me, but the stage-control moves all seem really... well janky to me. I know it is supposed to be original, but for me it does really take away the neutral game, as you can't zone or space effectively. To give an example: Apart from her Smashes, Maypul is a rather short ranged character, but she does make up for that with high speed and attacks that link really well into each other. Sounds familiar, right? Now she doesn't have a shine, but instead her down-special is a plant, that is placed on the ground and hits an enemy as soon as he gets in range. By placing it in the right place she can gain stage control easily and doesn't lose it, until the opponent gets hit by her plant, which coincidentally sets up for a combo, if she is within dash-range.

[*] There is literally no reward in learning Tech-Skill.

[*] The recovery/ledge system is not very intuitive. It's not straight up bad, like Sm4sh, where you live forever and  recover from anywhere, but it is making recovering unnecessarily hard and takes a rather long time to get used to.

[*] Some decisions seem rather questionable, like Absa's F-Tilt, that acts as an instant projectile that covers the whole stage in front of her (luckily there is no FD), Orcanes Puddle, allowing teleporting from anywhere or that you can instantly follow up Forsburns Dash-Attack with his Up-Smash, which can only be avoided by very good DI.

[*] Where the hell is Captain Falcon?! ... Okay I'm only semi-serious about this, but the killing point for me is, that there is no character that I personally have fun with.
[/list]

I would not recommend this game for people like myself: Melee enthusiasts. 

I would however recommend this game for players of other platform-fighters, who seek a different experience or people that are frustrated with learning Tech-Skill.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1]EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:[/h1]

Rivals of Aether is considered by many to be a love letter to Super Smash Bros. However, it's actually the product of hardcore fans looking at all the games within the series and declaring, "Hey, we could do better."

Upon seeing this on Steam one fateful day, I just KNEW that I had to make a purchase. Combining the combo potential of 64, the speed, competitiveness, and meta of Melee (intentionally; wavedashing isn't a glitch in this game), the accessibility of Brawl and the fine-tuning of Sm4sh, as well as adding some unique flavor, some fans would even dare say that this game is superior to any Super Smash Bros game before it.

[b]What It Has Now[/b]

Rivals of Aether currently has all eight characters, a VS mode, a plethora of tutorials for newcomers and hardcore fans alike, about eight stages, controller support, and an online mode. The online is rather primitive, only allowing 1v1 battles as of the time of this writing, but ranked battles have recently been added.

What truly makes this game stand out are the fighters. Based after various animals, each character can control some aspect of nature; fire, smoke, water, ice, air, thunder, rocky earth, and plants. There are no "clone" characters in this game, as each contestant stands out as their own. 

The only thing I dislike is the fact that some characters (read: most) rely on some sort of central gimmick; Orcane relies on his puddles to teleport around the stage and attack, Absa uses her thundercloud to zone, and Forsburn uses his smoke to charge his attacks, as well as generally be sneaky. These character rely on this central aspect to succeed, which can make it difficult for new players who might think that all the attacks are disparate in nature.

[b]What It Will Have[/b]

The full version will have a Story Mode (complete with unlockable "aether stories" which act as codex entries), an Abyss Mode that functions as an endless gauntlet, and assumedly a fuller online experience. Currently, the devs have no plans for future characters, although they are open to suggestions on their website forums, which suggests that they simply don't have any more ideas for character designs.

Beyond that, there isn't much else. As this is an indie title, they are focusing on gameplay rather than content, especially since it is a fighting game.

[b]Will It Happen?[/b]

This game is made by dedicated fans of Smash. They already have all eight planned characters. All they need now are the Story and Abyss modes, an updated online mode that runs smoother and has a four player mode and a casual mode (perhaps combined into one), and some further character balancing. I think it is safe to say that the devs are halfway done. 

They have a website where they post updates to the game, and the latest update focused on fine tuning the online mode and adding tutorials for all skill levels. Updates move along at a consistent pace now, usually one every one or two months. There are no signs of abandonment so far, and I think it's safe to say that they will complete this game by the end of the year.

[b]Worth A Buy?[/b]

If you have an itch for local multiplayer, want some online action, or if you're one of those weirdos who can spend up to an hour in VS mode fighting the CPU (like me) then I suggest it. As far as fighting action goes, I think there is enough content for potential ROA fans to get their feet wet. If you're a Smash Bros fan who just wants to try something a little new, I'd also suggest buying. Dedicated devs, an active community, and a unique spin on the Smash formula make this worth trying out.

Recommended

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Wonderful fighting game based on Super Smash Bros series. The creator has a fair understanding of game balance and the competitive aspects that made Melee fun.  The result is a fast-paced SNES-style Smash Bros game with great online play.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So, most people would say, "Hey, isn't this just smash bros.?"
It is, and so much more!
Imangine smash bros, copypasting every gimmicky character into it
That's Rivals of Aether
The thing is, that the gimmicks are so diverse, that every character feels different (Except Zetterburn, Absa, and Etalus)
And, if you're into competitive Smashing like me, then this game will not only explain various skills such as teching, but also builld upon those said skills
For example, it wasn't until I purchased Rivals Of Aether that I used tilts
Before, I relied on ariels and charged attacks to ledge guard, and kill my enemy
I now realized that I could use tilts to help that process.
Also, there is so much to this game.
Just yesterday I discovered the tutorials. And although I know how to tech roll, DI, and fastfall, they're all a blast to playthrough, and pretty tough at sometimes
Now here come my complaints
Biggest one on this list, Zetterburn
He feels incredibly broken.
I have a strong dislike to this character. 
For me, he's incredibly hard to DI away from, he spits fire everywhere like me putting my mixtape out on the internet, and his spacing is incredible. Mix that in with the power to basically fill your anus with fire and then blow that same fire up, and you've got a broken character.
My secong complaint, I'll mix into one. 
Absa and Etalus
Absa feels way to gimmicky
Like, without her cloud, she's like Rosalina without her Luma
I can see Orcane without his puddle, yeah he kinda stinks, but I'll tell you two things,
One, I've won twelve matches without using the puddle once, (my friend challenged me to it,) and two, technically speaking, his puddle is just an enhancer, makes his moves better. Absa on the other hand...
And that brings my to Etalus. His problem? He's not gimmicky enough. I tried playing him, even read his info screen, (which I do with every character,) and I was still like, "so where's the part where I find some cool way to combo this guy."
And it never came.
Look, I'm willing to give both characters a chance, if they fix their seperate problems
My other complaints are more about the game then about the charcters
WHY DO YOU TEASE US WITH THINGS LIKE STORY MODE?
LIKE, IT JUST SITS THERE ALL LOCKED UP AND I WANNA PLAY IT SUPER BADLY
BUT I CAN'T
Lastly, I'm kinda sad over the fact that the roster is complete. I feel like there are so many more characters to be added, I could think of some, but then they'd be furrys
Should you buy this game?
Positively
If you like fighting games, then you might as well prepare your wallet.
And even if you don't, this game is still great and an awesome time killer.
Y'know, just hop and and play a couple of matches.
Also, if you're into competitive smash, but can't get used to it, I suggest Wrastor. (Not because he's my favorite or anything.) His multiple jumps allow you to get used to air combos fairly quickly
Also check out their DLC
I think they should advertise it, because I didn't realize it existed till I was watching one of Alpharad's videos and I was like, "Hey wait, where can I get that?"
I bought all three, despite the fact that I picked up Maypul for a day then stopped using her.
They're so unique, they even do something special with the character!
Might I suggest spangled Wrastor.
His special thing is, how do I put it?
Patriotic

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I have sorely underestimated this game. I thought this game was going to be a lot like smash 4: a slow paced fighting game with few options to your movement. Instead, I get something that's more akin to project M (with fewer characters stages). It has wavedashing, dashdancing, and a indepth tutorial about its mechanics. There's no ledge to grab onto, but you can still edge guard once you get used to it. 

DISCLAIMER: I'm not saying smash 4 is bad. I just don't like the game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I\'ve put a bit of time into this game and Brawlhalla as well, and because they are contantly in conversations together I will continue that trend and mention that game as I speak about this one.

Rivals of aether is an fun and amazing game very similar to the original smash bros. The game is complex but interesting and have a fair amount of character diversity to make the experience enjoyable. Compared to brawlhalla this game has the better formula, but it suffers from some major lag issues. Make sure to play this game with an ethernet cable at all times and if you play online watch the ping of the other player. If their ping isn\'t yellow don\'t bother playing them or else your match will be plagued with input lag. 

Aethetically, the game isn\'t too pleasing and seems like an retro game (guess this appeals to some people), but if you\'re willing to overlook the oldschool graphics you have a whirlwind of fun coming at you. It is obvious this game isn\'t in full release which is evident in the limited online play. Currently, online is limited to only one vs. one as opposed to brawlhalla\'s typical four to eight player free for all. Hopefully the devs can fix the lag issue and improve the game\'s net code. 

If you compare this game\'s characters to that of brawlhalla, brawlhalla has the larger roster. ROA\'s character roster may be smaller but every character feels unique and have their own unique move-sets. On the otherhand Brawlhalla\'s character slection is based a select seof weapons and every character have similar move-sets. 

With all that being said, this game is exetremely promising and it\'s your go to game to get your fighting-game-fix. I recommend the game, but be warned that the game definately feels incomplete in its current form.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: To start things off, Rivals will most definitely piss you off if you are a competitive player when it comes to fighting games, but in a good way. It is in many ways a clone of Super Smash Bros. Melee, which I personally haven't spent much time playing, and making a transition to it from Brawl and Smash 4 wasn't that difficult. It is a very fast paced and technical "King of the Hill" typed fighting game where you really do not want to be off stage. This game is worth the price and may eventually be lowered, because there is only one person working on this game alone, Dan Fornace, and we are still waiting for updates. I would recommend this game to anybody who loves Smash Bros., especially melee, or any fast paced competitive game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So I'll admit it. I suck at Melee. My Marth struggles to move fluidly and can't even combo spacies 1/1000 as well as M2K. But I sure can wavedash. 
Rivals of Aether (ROA) is a  platform fighter that's heavily based off of the Smash Brothers franchise, but it has its own elements that make ROA very different, such as the lack of shields and ledges to name a few. I also believe that this games development is fully considering the competetive players. That's not to say that casual players such as a group of friends or family won't find it fun, as the core mechanics are easy enough to learn but hard enough to master to get the balance between ease and skill ceiling. 
In my opinion, this game sits in the middle of Melee and Smash4, the two most played games of Smash Bros. It has the ability to become technical at times where combo heavy characters can flourish, like in Melee. But, there is also a much higher need for careful thinking before acting, like in Smash4. The recent inclusion of ranked play with leaderboards makes winning and losing count many times more than before. Finally, the ability for almost any controller or keyboard to connect and work is an absolute joy. I would not have bought this game if I could not use my GameCube controller with it (which will work with adapters, including Nintendo's. Just Google how to make it work.)
As for bugs and glitches, I can say only once has my game crashed and the bugs that I have not encountered are being taken out by the dedicated dev team.
Overall ROA sits comfortably as my favorite fighter to play (Melee and Smash4 still hold my eye for viewing) and I look forward to seeing the community grow both online and at tournaments.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A good game in theory, but it fails to deliver any true competition. The game is too easy to cheese and be good at, especially with how awful the online netcode is. Lag is a constant feature, and every character is too gimmicky to be worth it, just spam their special moves and eventually you win. The easiest way to win against anyone 1 on 1 is to simply sit underneath a platform, poke through with your moves and specials, and parry any attempt to attack you. There is literally no way to approach a campy and defensive playstyle with most characters. The characters are just bad rehashes of Super Smash Brothers characters, moves and all. And the characters that are most viable are simply the ones who can win off of two hits, special or otherwise.  Being badly balanced, poorly made, and featuring a lack of actual competitive viability killed this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Remember when Brawl came out and a billion low effort, cheap or free-to-play clones of it were released? With a scant few characters with very little to set them apart from each other and very poor balancing?

Rivals of Aether is not one of those games.

Rivals is a game designed by and for fans of the SSB franchise who want a platform fighter that plays to the strengths of the more fast-paced and competitive entries in the series, particularly melee. It is built upon the foundation of the competitive melee community, even using a default ruleset that emulates that of melee tournaments (best of 3 sets, set to timed stock matches) and takes many techniques that are central to melee gameplay and encourages them (where the later smash bros games removed them).

That isn't to say that this game is only for competitive melee players or even for people who enjoy melee - it brings a great deal of new and innovative gameplay concepts to the table by designing each character's moveset specifically around their effects on the stage itself (Wrastor's whirlwind allowing him to move faster and be more dominant, Zetterburn's flames allowing him to lay traps, Orcane's allowing him to move around the stage at will). If you enjoy any of the smash bros games, you should enjoy this. It's a great game for both casual players and competitive players looking for a quick fix.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[h1] Rivals of Aether Review [/h1]
Pros:
Diverse characters with unique moves, with each being very competitively viable. 
Combos feel very rewarding. 
Fun stages for casual play, unintrusive stages for competitive matches. 
Great controller support.

Cons:
Very light on content (at date of posting).
Getting comboed is very frustrating.
Early Access could mean that this game will never 'take off'

If you want some fast-paced 2D fighting action I'd reccomend it, but if you are just an average gamer and don't have much of a sweet tooth for fighting games, it's best to hold out on the purchase for now.

TL;DR:
A bit of a gamble to buy right now, but the best framework of mechanics for a PC fighting game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Consider this game to be an 8-bit a game where Super Smash Bros and Avatar the Last Airbender got hit with a fusion spell. With an underwhelming cast of 8 characters, it never feels dull considering the beautiful environments, great soundtrack, and the fact that said characters have unique, elemental abilities that afftect the stage in a unique way. This allows you to dictate how the fights go or eve change the tides of battle. 

The 8-bit style is creative and visually appealing, but not distracting. The controls themselves are pretty tight, similar to that of Melee. My only problem with this game so far is that you cannot set custom control preferences. This can be very tedious as this means you will have to configure your button layout every time, even if you only plan to play for a couple minutes.

This is clearly a game with a large learning curve as you will have to learn combos, mobility with the full and short hop, as well as dodging and parries. With that in mind, the game allows you to either play casually or competitively by adjusting stages to be aether (which there are things that happen around the stage itself) or basic (which allows you to play without shenanigans). This game was worth getting my hands on for prerelease. However if you're wanting a full smash experience, I recommend waiting until the game is complete.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a very decent Smash clone - or rather, I should say would be, if an attention to the details were to be made.

Either the in-game hurtbox/hitbox visualizers are broken, or the hurtboxes/hitboxes themselves. You will constantly see moves with no visual representation of a hit (i.e. Wrastor's wing during his fair not touching the opponet, but them still receiving damage+knockback). This leads to a frustrating amount of moments in which someone made the correct play, spaced a move the way it SHOULD be spaced, but still gets hit.

Riding on the coat-tails of the broken boxes is the absurd amount of trading moves in this game. A "trade" is when two players throw out moves without clanking (when two moves hit each other, make a "clank" noise, and nullify each other) but both players taken damage+knockback. There are some situations where trades make sense - you throw out a move that touches the opponets hurtbox without touching the hitbox of his move and vice versa. You will encounter, however, many more situations that just leave you scratching your head saying "That's actually physically impossible."

If Dan, the creator, spent half the time fine-tuning details of the game engine itself instead of pandering to a community that every month finds a character to crucify and raining nerfs from the heavens like some holy manna, this could be a really good game. In its current state, I would pass.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
At last a great platform fighter (i.e. Smash clone) on PC. I’m somewhere between beginner and intermediate, so I can’t comment on how the game is played at high level. I’ll share my experience and thoughts as a casual player.

The controls have an elegant simplicity that grants the game its appeal and low skill floor. Simply input a direction and one of the attack buttons simultaneously to perform an attack in that direction. There are three attack buttons corresponding to tilts, strong attacks and special attacks. The same controls apply universally to all characters and they all share quite similar tilts and strong attacks, so that once you learned to play with one character, you can find your bearings with any of them.

There are only 8 characters but each has a pretty unique moveset with some specific quirks, especially when it comes to special attacks. This can be both great and somehow bothering at the same time. Great because every character has a distinct playstyle and everyone is guaranteed to find at least a few tailored to them among this small but varied cast. Bothering because it steepens the learning curve for two reasons when compared to Smash. First, it slightly gets in the way of skill transfer from character to character. Secondly, matchups knowledge becomes more important.

By no means I want to give the impression that this is an actual issue and that the game is in fact hard to learn, it is still very easy to pick up, it only makes it harder to master. And yet, RoA brings some of its own simplicity to the genre. It pares down the mechanics and trims the formula to its essential components by removing grabs, edge grabbing, L-cancelling, shields (replaced with parries), … What remains at the core is a streamlined gameplay that prominently features exhilarating kickass combos.

The result is a mechanically tight game with a low skill floor, high skill ceiling, and a learning curve sloped to quickly and comfortably project players towards the more fast paced, technical and competitive side of platform fighters.

I absolutely recommend this game to anyone who prefers Melee to other Smash games. This is the closest you will get on PC. It manages to capture both the simplicity and depth that I enjoyed in Melee while still having its own flavor and charm.

Although it isn’t a party game and is definitely positioned towards the competitive end of the spectrum, I also strongly recommend it to newcomers. I mostly play casually with friends at my skill level, and even so I enjoy it much more than the few other alternatives on PC. The action is fast paced, the combos you can pull off even as a beginner are really awesome, and it’s overall extremely fun.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I will admit that I discovered this game when looking for super smash bros look-a-likes. 

I have since seen it for much more than that though. Smash fans will feel comfortable with the 2-D arena combat. The combat system is also easy to grasp while offering a lot of diversity to spice up gameplay. There is no doubt that this game utilizes a combo system that allows for really sweet and punishing combos. If you spend time with this game, you will quickly find all of the characters offer something unique and useful with their special moveset. 

If you want a game that you can play with friends, this is perfect. With Rival of Aether's amazing controller compatibilty, I was able to use an xbox 360 controller and a PS3 controller (with the right drivers) and play with my friends right from my couch with no hassle. I have found that the most preferred controller it seems to be is the use of Gamecube controllers. I would say the Gamecube controller offers a really responsive experience. Not to mention all button configurations, and sensitivity settings are easily setup and saved by profile (much like the smash bros. profile/button system, but easier to access). 

I am very optimistic about the future of this game. I think it's a true beauty in it's current state, and I'm now a dedicated fan (as well as have turned many others into fans) and will be following this game all the way through it's development. I highly recommend this game. If anyone would like to play a match, I'm down!

5/5

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game feels like it was made for the GC controller. I was playing using the x360 pad, and was getting kinda frustrated by somewhat unresponsive controls. Plugged in my GC pad through an adapter (this is a Smash clone after all) and man... smooth as eggs. I recommend this setup, espcially since GC controllers are back on the market and adapters are cheap.

The game is actually very fun. In a VS setting it's basically par for par with Smash Bros, except the items which don't exist in this game.

Characters are more focused on setups rather than straight attackers, but there are a couple that are straight forward enough for newbies to get into. Oh and there's wavedashing! Really adds to the feel of movement in this game, which is very important as you'd expect. 

Some levels can feel kind of cramped, especially if the level effects are on. 

Anyway, I think this game is well worth the asking price. Maybe we'll see this game in EVO someday. It has the potential to be very competitive.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
As a competitive Smash Bros player(#2 in my country) I think this game is insanely bad and I'm saying this because I've put 90+ hours into it. At first people think it's amazing and I also thought so but after around 30 hours you start to realize the game's issues. Bad mechanics, extremely bad character design and weird stages. Wouldn't recommend to anyone.

It DOES feel like a good game at first, don't get me wrong. But once you realize it's weaknesses you'll regret buying it and probably go back to Smash as soon as possible.

Okay, I can elaborate.

Bad mechanics:

Parry: Parry is a fighting game mechanic and it's good in some games such as Street Fighter series or Pokken, where it actually works. In a platform fighter like RoA however, it doesn't work. It's basically powershield but worse because smallest mistake can lead to a 0-death combo. If you're playing Smash 4, you know Bayonetta has a similar move called Witch Time which is essentially RoA parry. You know what happened when they added that move to Smash 4? Everyone got crazy over it and now they're considering actually banning Bayonetta because she has a parry. That's how BAD parry is in a platform fighter game. In these kind of games(RoA, Smash 4 etc.) there are moves which are high risk high reward, and low risk low reward. In Smash games, there are shields and if you commit to a low reward move, you'd expect to get punished lightly. But if you commit to a high reward move and get shielded, you'd expect to get punished heavily. In RoA, parry completely shits on this balance and makes every move high risk, because parrystun is the same even if the move is a high risk move, or a low risk move. This essentially makes the game extremely defensive, to the point where whoever hits first might get punished too heavily so both players would have to play too carefully. I don't see a high-level future for this game simply because of this mechanic. 
Random meteor hitboxes: For the sake of making some characters go for crazy hype  meteors and stuff, all hitboxes that goes downwards were given a meteor hitbox. This makes characters like Zetterburn(up-b) or Kragg(nair) meteor the other characters randomly for no reason. Completely unintentionally too. This isn't too much of a big deal but I'd expect a fighting game to be a little more consistent. I like examples of games where you do things and those things work as you meant. In RoA that isn't the case.

Bad character design:
 
Absa and Orcane:The developer seems to be confused about how the game should be played. He makes zoning heavy characters that punishes approaches, then realizes these characters slows down the game and nerfs them. Shuts down what they have and makes them unusable in high level play. Absa got nerfed twice, and Orcane got nerfed three times. Their zoning tools got nerfed heavily, for no reason. These characters' movesets and designs all compliment to a zone-heavy defensive gameplan. Then he weakens them and buffs other tools they have to make them play more offensively. It doesn't make sense. Very bad design choices by dan fornace. (They should've stood the way they were)

Kinda tired of typing, I'll type more later.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
After about 200 hours playing this game, it's probably the most fun I've had playing a fighting game. Very easy to pick up, hard to master completely. Teaching my friends how to play was a breeze and close matches are pretty much a give in. I've never really been interested in fighting games until RoA.  Balancing in the game has been extremely fair and it feels like most characters get smoother and better with each update, except for the occasional couple of bugs. None of which have been absolutely game breaking for me. 

If you're on the fence, then trust me it won't hurt to try it out. You WILL get sucked into it though, so keep track of your playtime.

If you have lag issues, try port mapping 1972 and 1973. I used to have a lot of dc issues, but after openining these ports, it solved my problems.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I am very much on the fence about this game. I love it and I hate it at the same time. 

Pro's
Characters are cool in design
Gameplay is usually solid
All characters are useable online as in they are easy to pick up
Stages can be switched between gimicky and not so gimicky 
Honestly is a good deal of fun offline

Con's
Zetterburn run jab spam
Input lag online
Constant input dropping online
Characters need nerfing
Stages are really gimicky if they aren't on basic
Some characters are hard counters on others (I.E. you lose because screw you)

It seems like I have more negative things to say about this game and honestly, I do. However it is early still and they are working on it. If things don't change soon though I will have to not reccomend this game just because of its balencing issues online. 

Tl;dr It is a fun game but don't expect that to last if you play competitively.

review:
Indie? Platform Fighting? 8 charachters? Retro Graphics?
Do you think it is a bit weird as of 2015-2016 to read such description?
Well... don't fear. this game is all that above - and it is wonderful.
Designed to be a less casual\more competitive Smash Bros. this game nails it perfectly. the graphics are charming, playing is swift and sounds are nice. the roster is pretty well balaced. It is tons of fun in short little matches that take no longer than 10 minutes. It takes some hours to get the feels of the game - untill them expect to get whomped online... but after some hours of practice you will start to fight properly and games online will be a thrill - not easy at all - but fun anyways.
I wasn't so sure about buying a game in early development stage, but this guy d4nace who is the chief developer behind RoA has done a wonderful job and the game is quite complete as of now! it'll in fact only gain functions as time goes by.i bought it in a promotional price, quite cheap - but it is definitely worthy of its full price!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Killer game. Proves that the Smash formula is a recipe for success, and while it is truer to its influence (unlike games such as Brawlhalla), it just goes to show that melee-like gameplay is solid on its own and doesnt need to be changed. the game feels extremely tight, characters control amazingly, and I don't feel too limited by the engine. balance is okay, and the netplay is extremely solid. this is an awesome game that has been designed incredibly well, and has enough depth to remain interesting.

BUT --- and a big BUT, -- it also feels a bit empty. characters are a little gimmicky and I feel it lacks the depth its father games have, with its removal of many mechanics without new ones to compensate. it won't replace Smash for me, but maybe if they gave the game a few more quirks, I would feel differently. right now, it's a great side-game to Smash but I just cant see it having the same insane depth that keeps me fully invested in a way Smash does. 

in a way, it doesnt have the same "happy-accident" feeling. you can tell that all the mechanics are HIGHLY deliberate. while this helps to streamline the gameplay, i feel like they've forgotten all the wacky engine quirks from Smash and are compensating with much more unique character movesets -- which is a good concept, but it makes me feel like the playstyle for each character is far more narrow, since I don't feel the same freedom Melee's vast pool of techniques gives me.

tl;dr, great arcadey fighter, but if you're looking to delve competitively, I would pick up Melee or Project M. this game just simply isnt deep enough to remain interesting forever. there's a reason Melee's scene lasted 15 years, and I don't know if i trust this game will do the same

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Amazing game, it is the direction Smash Bros. should have gone in after Melee.  It's very impressive that every character has a very distinct gimmick, but not in annoying or broken way.  Shout out to the indie community for once again showing that a single dev/small team can put out a better game than AAA devs.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Great game, especially for SSBM fans.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is the smash bros nintendo wont give us.
The trailers truly do not do the pace of this game justice. It is way quicker and more combo intense than even both trailers let on.

It is an incredible combination of Melee movement and Smash 64 hitstun. This comes together in the form of incredible combos that can sometimes be 0 to death if you read peoples techs and DI properly. 

YES! THERE IS DI. Combo DI and Smash DI. There is wavedashing, wavelanding, edge cancelling, reverse aerial rush, some characters can jump cancel, theres a character with a double jump cancel and the 8th character can DACUS. Ignore the negative reviews. The lack of shielding makes this an incredibly strategic and aggressive game and the latest patch really made camping difficult and the balance of the game has never been better! The negative reviewers need to GET GOOD. Learn to parry god dammit!

 There is no ledge, every character has a wallkick that refreshes your recovery and the recoveries in rivals are insane so edge guarding is incredibly fun. There are no items. The stages are all playable and there are no "banned" stages. Hazards can be put on for fun but they are always disabled in online play and in fact ive never seen them used. 

This game is a love letter to competetive smash fans and i am incredibly passionate about it and would hate to see people turned away by comments like "i cant parry good enough games imba!!111"

If you love smash, just buy it right now. Quit wasting time! And if your a fighting game fan in general, theres definetly the depth of gameplay youll need to find something here.

Let this game reach its full potential. <3

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
THIS GAME IS NOT LIKE SSB

I say that to the die hard SSB Melee fans who come into this game thinking it will be like that. It has some similarities, but they are two very different games, and that's fine. I love playing this game, the controls are a little funky at first, and I set up my own button mapping. 
The game is super fun, I play it a lot with my roomates. It is simple enough to pick up and play with friends, but deep enough if you want to put time in and get good at it.

Also its really easy to wavedash.

review: Sweet and simple. If you're familiar with the Smash franchise at all then you'll very comfortable with this game. As of right now it's just multiplayer. No solo or anything. Zetterburn is the closest to an actual smash character so naturally a lot of people are good with him.... Like really good. Looking at this as a huge smash fan, I have nothing bad to say about this game. I'm very excited to see what they put into it in the future. From a casual gamer kinda stance, I'd hold off. I don't think you'd really enjoy much of what this game has to offer.

PErsonally, I love this game. It fun, creative and has taken some inspiration from my favourite series, super smash. I quite like all the different characters, and I main wrastor.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Not my type of game, controlls feel really floaty and i find it really hard to properly pace myself to even perform simple moves letalone proper combos. 
Playing this on a fight sick is also a complete nogo while the button layout for controllers imo is horrendous, you have the ability to change controlls only while at the character select screen and even then you have to change them everytime you play somone else since it just reverts back. 
I would only suggest this game to anyone if they really enjoy playing smash and only smash, comparing this to other fighters is just impossible.

other notes:

I really hate pressing a button to jump especially when its bound to Y. Sorry bethesda.

Playing with a fightstick i ran into the game still recognising stick imput ghosting, Hold stick right and let go it will still keep going for a few milliseconds after release even causing you to run off ledges right when the game starts if you just let it do its thing, i was able to recreate this problem 36/50 tries, it even does the same with the cursor in character select. 

Only 2 people fighting at a time, for this kind of game i was hoping for 4 player combat. 

Because of the way the controlls of the game work its alot of work to even position yourself properly to even hit your enemy and with most of the moves having these delays, just missplacing yourself out of reach to hit your enemy, a problem i haven't had in any fighting game including smash itself,

Playing a game is supposed to bring you excitement and you enjoy playing them, but with this all im getting is dissapointment that i wasted $15 on a game i probably would never play again based on its lackluster and barely working mechanics.

review:
I bought this game expecting it to be a fine smash experience, but thats not the case. Its a bit different, and although it borrows some move ideas, and other mechanics from smash, it feels totally different, I find myself constantly holding down the R button trying to block, but it doesnt happen, so if you are a defensive player, You will hate this game. But all together it is a well put together game, pretty visuals and cool characters. EXCEPT ABSA, I really hate absa. Especially ina game where there is no defensive option except for a roll and parry. She can literally wreck you without being next to you, which leads to people spamming online (reminds me of for glory)

Also, Wrastor is the Captain Falcon of this game, and you will run into a lot of them.

Everyone plays Wrastor and Absa online, so I wouldnt recommend it if you hate fighting the same thing over and over.

Step 1: learn a good combo
Step 2: practice it
Step 3: do it
Step 4: do it again and again, because your enemy can't do shit about that
Step 5: YOU WIN
Simple as that. Good enough for you ? if not, don't buy it for the online, because it's good enough for the players online...

This creates a frustrating and extremely unwelcoming environment for new players, who will consistently be matched with significantly better players. [list]

[*]You are willing to dedicate yourself to this game and be a try-hard.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I showed a friend this game, his response was: "Man I don't wanna play this game! It looks horrible, they could've at least put a little effort in the graphics!"

I then convinced him to play it, 5 minutes in, his response was: "How is this so fun!"
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This game is great, when I first saw it I was sceptical, I'm not gonna lie. But this game is fun! Sure it doesn't have next gen graphics, but who cares! That doesn't make a game. Who looks at game such as Smash bros. Melee and says "Man this game's graphics suck! It's no fun at all." If you did, I would slap the side of your face. I mean, really? I see some many great games not getting the credit that they deserve over graphics. Sure there are games out there that are just plain unplayable due to the graphics making it unclear of whats going on, but this game is just simply not one of them. I'm going to make another Melee reference here. Imagine Super Smash. Melee that gets updated and has completely original characters. Thats Rivals of Aether for you. And I can't wait for the full release. I'm really interested in how they'll make the story mode, but most of all, I want to see how big the roster will be, and what new characters they'll add. I just going to finish this review by plainly saying, this game rocks!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
THIS GAME IS AN ABSOLUTE BLAST. If you've played Smash and even remotely enjoyed it, you will LOVE this game.

Although the game is a bit short on content at the moment, the online matchmaking and local multiplayer are really fun.

Pros:
- Characters have a ton of depth. They're easy to learn, but nearly impossible to master.
- One of few in this kind of "push your opponent off the stage" genre on PC.
- Frequent updates and patches to balance characters (all characters are viable).
- Awesome controls. Very responsive and fast.
- Rebind keys for controller and KB+M
- Many reused mechanics from Melee so it won't be too hard to be good at both games.
- Beautiful pixel art.

Cons:
- Very, very dry on content. (hopefully by the full release it'll all be there, but if you're looking for content definitely don't buy this until the full release)
- Matchmaking seems to be kinda wonky for me. I keep getting put up against really good players, but that might be just because I'm super bad.
- Unplayable on KB+M. Be sure to have a controller for this title.

I give it an 8/10 at the moment because the game is still amazingly solid despite having a serious lack of content.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Pros
-Perfect online code for an indie game. 
-Very nice and memorable 16 bit music
-A very cool and very diverse roster to relate yourself with and all of them share a few moveset seen in smash bros.
-Not a smash bros clone; it's a different game, different feel... As in dota 2 is not like Lol.
-I coudln't tell if this game was in Early Access, i only found out after a long session of gameplay.

Cons
-Controls are not exactly like it is in smash bros so you must get used to the changes.
-No ranking as of yet; be prepared to lose again and again...

Style:

This game reminds me of Megaman more than Smash bros because of the sound effects. 

When you die, same sound effect as when you die in a megaman game. Each stages looks like a bit of what you usually see in a megaman game. 
With that said, you will have the impression that each enemies come from a megaman game(the bosses). I know, i sound like a broken record by now, but if you play it yourself, you will eventually get it.

Gameplay and differences from Smash bros:

-Blocking has been removed and replaced with a parry. On parry, your opponent become unable to move for a split second which leaves you enough time to counter-attack.
-You can no longer use grapples and theres no grapple-type character.
-For the melee freaks, you can wave-dash and it's a lot more easier to perform. 
-You can perform Air-dodge only once while in mid-air. Afterwards, you can do anything else while still in mid-air.
-After Up+special(Up+B smash bros), you can only do it again if you bounce off the wall and you can no longer edge-guard.
-Extremely reliant on juggles-combos. 

ROA vs SB: 

More like melee, but you don't feel like you must exploit the game to win and while everything is easy to perform (including wave-dashes), high level play is still a very long way after you feel confident enough.

I personally find this game to be a lot more addictive than any other smash bros game; even the online net-code is better than the one found in smash 4.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is an excellent fighting game--one of the best I have ever played. I have played every iteration of Super Smash Bros. and this game's strong resemblence to Super Smash Bros. Melee make the game familiar, yet it improves upon what was lacking in Melee. The gameplay feels great, the online match works well. The amount of hitstun allows for creativity when performing combos and Developer Mode allows players to alter everything about the Rivals, making the metagame balanced (or whatever you call "balanced") or as unbalanced as you desire. I can't wait for the game reaches its full development and I get to experience the other pending feature like story mode! If you appreciate fighting games, I'd highly recommend this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Basically a Smash game with amazing netplay. Rarely have lagging matches. Parry adds another level of mindgames once you get good at it as it might seem whiff punishing, rushdown, and zoning are the best strategies when you first start it. Combos are easy against bad opponents, which there are a lot of online. This game's level of fun is inversely proportional to the disparity of skill between both players, meaning if you're too good or fight really bad players, the game might start to lose its spark for you. However, if you can find good opponents, this game will always be fun and never lose its luster. Definitely worth the buy if you're not a casual and enjoy competitive games. Keeps the pace of a fast Smash 4 match as shielding isnt an option. My only critique is that there isn't a grab button. It leaves something to be missed in neutral as it should directly counter parries rather than to bait and wait. It should only be able to throw the opponent up or down OR and shouldn't lead to a kill, but a small percent increase with the potential to increase combos given the player makes the correct read with unchanging knockback that is fast and forces the opponent to choose between missed tech, tech in place, or tech left/right. Each character should have a throw height that corresponds to a specific distance to a platform. Down throw should only work on platforms and sends the opponent to the ground or platform closest to the ground.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game's great. I love the counter system, and no grabbing. 

As well, the controller setup. They have a button for tilts/basic attacks, a button for smash (basically a C-Stick), and special button. 

The game still needs some balancing. Like, some characters have less of a counter window than others, but it should be the same for all. And the fire-lion might need some delay after or inbetween his fire-throwing skill. As he currently is, he requires much less effort to be good like Ryu/Ken or Terry Bogard. So, the competitive scene is flooded with them. And all you see is hundreds of hadouken spammers... Not too fun to fight against. 

Great game though, I just hope that area that bothers me gets addressed.

review: All I can say is having played 1000+ hours on competitive melee this game is really similar to melee and it's really fun. Even though there are only 7 characters they are very different from each other and play differently. I can easily see some parallels between the characters here and the ones in melee which is nice. The stages are really good with no real obstacles in the way. Some of the mechanics in this game are different than in melee. In this game there is no ledge grabbing and no shield. However mechanics like teching wavedashing and DI make a return. Based on what I've played so far I can say it's a really good fighting game. Right now I prefer using orcane. From what I can tell zetterburn is the best character in the game with wrastor being second.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether Review:

Do you love Super Smash Brothers and want more?

Then play Rivals of Aether! It is a lot of fun to play another fighting game that uses the creative formula of smash.

Unlike other Smash Clone games, it is hard to call this game that. It is made very well. It has creative attacks and ablities like smash attacks in air(Wraster), fire that allows you to power up your smash attacks(Zetterburn), or being able to be a liquid organism that makes people scared of puddles! (Guess who that is...) Also, this game has an awesome and easy combo system. The game plays like smash, but with more hitstun and less knockback. That means lots of combos that require strategy to avoid.

The issue comes in the form of errors. Errors appeared alot when I was playing this game. That really made it fell cheap when the game so well crafted.

However, the errors don't appear too often. It is too much fun anyway, so it is worth it to play the game. Even if those errors are an issue.

Overall, I give this game a 4/5! Play it when the full version releases. So far, the game is worth $2.00 at it's current build.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Music is nice, spritework is fantastic, gameplay is fun and addictive (like Smash but with all-new, unconventional and really creative movesets), and there's more coming too.  I can easily see myself putting hundreds of hours into this game.  For $15, this is an absolute steal.  Any Smash Bros lover NEEDS this game.  Even non-Smash players will find tons to enjoy.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
You smash? Get on this game.

First successful smash indie IMO.  Super fast, crazy combos, much enjoyment.  You will enjoy this game immensely  if you play Super Smash Brothers Melee or Project M.   

To new players.....don't get disheartened!  I read a lot of forums where people are complaining about it being a "1st to combo wins" game. Not true.  You will be playing against a lot of people who have been competively playing SSB melee for years now.  The skill translates over for the most part.  If you don't know what competitive smash looks like you are in for a world of spankings.  Learn the mechanics, watch videos of good players, and keep at it!

See ya on the battlefield.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Okay, so instead of my usual gushing over smash stuff, here's my pros and cons list
Pros:
[*]The netplay is really good. Got a bad connection? the worst you're looking at is some pause hiccups inbetween combat, so pretty seamless, so a lot like KI's if you've played it
[*]Melee tech is MUUUUCH easier to pull off, minus the L-cancelling, because this game decided landing lag isn't a good thing to put in a game (good job, Dan). Dash dancing, shuffling and wave dashing are as easy as pressing two buttons together at the same time... probably because it is
[*]Every character is unique, and has their own learning curb. This makes learning every character and their mech-tech (* ahem * mechanic technique) pretty fun, and they're easy to grasp and use, and only a little harder to start incorporating in combo play
[*] Does NOT take a strong computer to run, you'd probably guess that from the spec list before, but my experience with most spec lists are liiies
[*]D-pad play feel. 'nuff said. (Really though, I never use d-pad in fighting games, and I feel much better using it here, despite it being a lot like smash)

That being said, there are some things that I found less than stellar (which I'm sure will be fixed down the line, in which case, I'll just remove this whole thing)
Cons:
[*]Absa reminds me of Rosalina. All the control, little weakness. There are few instances where I would think of a character needing nerfing(although, in smash 4s case, they all need to be BUFFED)
[*]Full screen seems to give it a hard slow down for some reason. (that might just be my laptop though, so if someone corrects me on that, I'll cross this off)

tl;dr Buy this game. That's it. It's a GREAT game that deserves as many people interested in it, competitive or casual. It's easy to get into, and does not have that gargantuan learning curb competitive melee has. Also, no Fox.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like competitive-style Smash Bros, this game should be in your library. It's a very fun game and hits a happy medium between the ultra hardcore technical skill required in melee and the casual method of playing.
This is easily the best fighting game on Steam if you're not into traditional fighters such as Street Fighter.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: The only flaw I have noticed in the game is the lack of a ranked ladder. I am not good at this game. I try to do my best but I always end up going against some tremendously better than me or someone who gets bored and jump off the edge after a minute. If you had incentive not to lose and a way to go against someone your own level the game could be really enjoyable. Until then it is difficult to learn and frustrating.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like smash bros, you will like this. it's pretty much the same game with fresh new characters and ideas. It take skill, but I would probably say less than smash, but that is just due to the amount of time that people have been playing it and had experiance with it. Also, the inputs are easier compared to melee, for instance. This game is like somehwere in between PM/melee and brawl/smash 4 and the devs have nearly hit the sweetspot.  this game is fairly balanced, though I do have a few things to pick on and say to the contrary.

(EDIT: below I complain about forsburn. He is not the easies to play but he is very strong, I have come to realize. He is a top tier character and this game is very well balanced for the most part.. people used to think fors and maypul were bad but it turns out they are the best in the game. All the other characters are still competitive, though. The opinions below were premature and do not reflect the current meta, but a much earlier one; they also reflect how I felt as a less skilled player. If you like fast paced platform fighting and competitive play get this game. the cast is small but that is for balance reasons. THe cast is very diverse while small, and this game has given me some of the best experiences of any I've ever played. The community is very good for the most part. I have literally added 80 to my friendslist through this game)

This game is great but it defnitely needs a few tweeks. I play forsburn, probably one of if not the hardest characters in the game, and while I am happy with him, it is hard not to fall prey to  the rest of the cast, particularly wrastor and zetterburn. 
Heck he has a hard time agains most everybody. Once you get to learn how to play him, things do get easier and more doable, but it's not hard for things to become and uphill battle if your opponent know what they are doing as well. I think he requires a bit more awareness and reads, which is not bad i guess, but it is also true of bowser, the worst char in melee. 

So I think forsburn may be a bit underpowered, but that may just speak to the difficulty of playing him. its not that his moves are super bad, they are just easier to punish than most other characters.

The rest of the cast seems really tight. wrastor is ridiculous but they just nerfed him so.....  not gonna go any further than that. Not that the rest of the cast isnt great. wrastor can just wall you out, his moves have a ton of priority and range, and he can through out tons of them.

anyway, this game is a lot of fun and i played 16 hours in 2 days.. it's a bit addictive.... props to the devs hope to see more great things.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is like Melee and Smash 64 combined. A lot of advanced tech is back (wavedash/waveland, DJC, dash dancing, worthwhile DI, blip blip blip 20XX zetterburn multishines etc.) but it's now a bit easier to perform. The game is very combo heavy and although there is a limited roster, I have enjoyed playing as every character, and each one provides its own unique gameplay. You have the option of Aether stages or Normal (Aether has walkoffs, hazards, moving parts, etc. and normal leaves just platforms and removes walkoffs/hazards) which is something that has needed to be in Smash games since literally forever. Online is great, have had very little issues with lag, and although I sometimes get destroyed by some really good players luckily there are a lot of newer players on right now so anyone can fit right in. Cannot recommend this game anymore than I am.

It's a bittersweet feeling entering yet another community similar to that of smash, but this one is special. The controls feel absolutley amazing and even this games lacking roster has a character for every play style. I wouldn't be surprised if I see this at mayor tournaments in the near future. If I had any criticism, it would be towards the structure. It's very unlikely that you'll join the flow of the playstyle if your not a hardcore platform-fighter, not impossible. Overall, I'd recommend this to any platform-fighting game player looking to improve. It's either a sandbag or a nostalgia trip.

The character is delt damage in percent, and flys farther away with increasing percent. It is very much like Smash bros, and the other game I have to compair to on Steam is Brawlhalla. Even though its gameplay is very simelar, it is very much worth the money. Its the closest to smash on PC, and with RoA and Brawlhalla a PC gamer can get almost the entirety of the smash experance for a fraction of the price without using emulators or ROMs. 
The new smash is 60$ and a WiiU exclusive, and a little over a year ago I got Melee on gamecube for 90$. This is 15$ and brawlhalla is Free to play. 
Iv won most of the AI battles, and I got a match online at a reasonable amount of time, although my butt was handed to me 3-0 in 2:00.
