title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A Smash Bros. style fighting game done right! Suck it, Brawlhalla!

Rivals of Aether is one of my favorite fighting games ever, topped only by Super Smash Bros. Smash fans will find themselves at home with its similar style and mechanics. Even some technical terms are relevant in this game, such as Teching, Dash Dancing, and Wavedashing. It supports Xbox controllers, but it's terrible to play with it. You can actually get some Nintendo controllers with this game, like the Gamecube Controller, Wii U Pro Controller, and the Wii U Gamepad. I'll explain how to do that at the end of the review.

There are some things missing, though. Well, more like one thing, but it's something many other fighting games have, including Smash. Grabs. You can't grab. That's the only con aside from the lack of content, which is forgivable since the game is still in Early Access.

SCORE: 95/100

FINAL NOTES
Get it if you're a fan of Smash and want something fun to play.

CONTROLLERS
Wii U Pro Controller or Wii Remote (With any attachments) - Look into getting the Toshiba Bluetooth Stack working on your computer with the Pro Controller. Then get WiinUSoft to convert Wii controller inputs to a 360 controller.
Wii U Gamepad - Check out USendMii.
Gamecube Controller - Buy a Mayflash Gamecube Adapter, which actually works for PC and Wii U.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Being a competitive Super Smash Bros. player, I thoroughly enjoyed Rivals of Aether. The retro themed music and  graphics are very nostalgic. The stages are very well done and all the characters are reminiscent of characters from the game they were inspired from. For example, Zetterburn plays similarly to Fox and Absa plays like Zelda and Ness. There is also an online mode, which is nice since it allows for online tournaments. Overall, I couldn't be more excited for the game's full release. One thing though: if you decide to pick up the game, do yourself a favor and use an Xbox controller or something. The keyboard just doesn't work in my opinion.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I've played an absurd amount of Super Smash Brothers Melee competitively, and when and Project M was released I was happy to give that a shot and it was neat. The big issue with the two is that the communities are small and online ones even less. When I heard of ROA I was excited. Looking at online videos it looked somewhat promising, so I figured I'd give it a go and support the dev in hopes of an alternative to SSBM and Project M. After dissecting the game in its current state and playing online many hours I've arrived to the following conclusion:

If you're expecting great gameplay like the two games mentioned above, Rivals of Aether will not deliver. 

Here's biggest reasons why:

==Spam friendly==
  -You can get big % by chain dash attacking your opponent or just using gimmicks (skillful right?). Online gameplay is swarmed with people dash spamming with Maypul, Orcane, and Zetterburn.
  -A lot of moves have little recovery frames which leads to rewarding mindless attack spamming. This also leads to easy air juggles. Many characters can do air 2-3 air attacks in one jump. So you can just spam airs while jumping no problem. Online you'll probably run into an average skilled Zetterburn that will dish out 70% damage by dash attack spamming, short hop air spamming onto his neutral B to accomodate. If you've played Melee, you'll relate when I say I constantly feel like I'm playing against Sheik players (low skilled dash + tilt spammers).
  -Some dashes or tilts can be cancelled right into smashes which will connect.
  -Can't crouch-cancel weak attacks or dash attacks, so you'll just eat more of them if you try to as you'll end up DI'ing downwards instead.

== Lacks mechanics ==
  -There is no block mechanic or grab mechanic, which skews gameplay to be all about offense. These mechanics would allow punishing dash spamming or any noob friendly behavior. All you're left with is "parrying" your opponents moves or gimmicks. So if you're playing against a Maypul dash dancing and dash attack spamming, you better have great reflex or be able to predict your opponent. Also, keep in mind that when you parry any move that has more than one attack (like neutral standing attacks) your opponent can cancel out of the parry into a roll and punish you for trying to punish.

The skill curve for this game is easy and the skill ceiling is low. Any skilled veteran SSBM or PM player can easily 3/4 stock an average player, but in ROA whoever can spam better wins.

TL;DR
ROA is a noob-friendly game full of rewarding spamming and gimmicks, while lacking mechanics which makes the game have a flatter skill curve. I would not recommend the game as it stands (Version 0.0.9).

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Ever wanted to play smash without having half the characters suck? well then this games for you.
Rivals of Aether is probably one of the best smash clones around ive got 44 hours on it nearly and im still enjoying every minute of it.
What makes Rivals of Aether stand out is that all the characters are able to add to the environment somehow or another whether its through leaving a fog you cant see into, a puddle that can be blinked out of or a giant pillar blocking the path.
This adds a very unique feel every match because everybody can use these skills differently.
Its got extremely satisfying sprites each with a plethora of recolours to choose from. 
Each stage is made very well and making it so you can play each match a different way.
Pros:
Great Gameplay
Fantastic looking sprites
Unique Characters
Different feel to each stage
Has offline multiplayer
Tons of recolours
Fun Soundtrack
Great for casual play
Cons:
Its still very much being worked on
Online can sometimes be a pain with all the lag
No arcade mode yet
Bots kind of suck 

All in all I would strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys smash or fighting games in general.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a Super Smash Bros inspired platform physics based fighting game. It is not a total Smash clone, however and there are many things to separate it from Smash. The most common thing across games is the percentage mechanic, the emphasis on combos and strategy, and things like teching and DI.
How the game works:

You choose one of 7 characters so far, and play on a stage that is a platform with other little platforms, boxes, etc.

Here's what to do:
1. Rack up damage through combos and strategy (like punishing players when they mess up, openings you find)
2. Make sure that doesn't happen to you through defensive strategies like rolling, dodging and parrying (a mechanic not found in Smash!).
3. Do the above but this time with a kill move or "smash" (in this game "strong") attack to launch the opponent off-screen, or have them fall off the stage by other means.

Rivals of Aether is about stage control like Smash, but unlike the newest installment, SSB for Wii U, this game favors offense more, which bring mechanics that are now absent from Smash like directional air-dodging, that in turn brings things like wave-dashing from Smash Bros Melee. There is more control over your character (they don't slide as much as they do in SSB4) and combos are easier to hit because of increased hit-stun (the time before your character can do something like dodge or attack back) and moves have negligible landing-lag, which makes defensive players who are used to shielding in Smash not able to punish successfully shielded moves as easy. Parrying replaces shielding, which is an instant guard that stuns the other player, but the frames (the actual frames in gameplay that determine whether your action works or not) are slightly different from what is expected with Smash.


In conclusion, if you want a fairly balanced game that doesn't adore For Glory Link spammers who shield your moves, only to then grab (no grabbing and throwing in this game!) and pull off easy-bake combos, get this game. It has local multiplayer, (a plus for PC!) online, and as of this review, the game is still in Early Access, which means more content, balancing and gamemodes to come.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game, although unfinished, is one of the most fun I've had with a steam game in a while. Being a huge competitive smash player, I appreciate that there is no "Final Destination" style stage, as platforming is a big part of smash, although it would be a welcome addition. The cast has very few characters, but this honestly helps with the game's approach with each character revolving around a specific gimmick such as; Orcane's teleportation, Frosburn's cloning and Wrator's midair smash attacks. I do belive as of no some characters do need to be nerfed *cough* Absa *cough* the ballance is mostly fair. Even though the game is still in developement it does lack things such as a campaign but the modes are still displayed on the menus to tell the player what's to come. Some suggestions for additions are items to make the game playable by a larger audience of smash fans and to make some platforms more visable in the foreground to make it easier on new players.

Overall: 8/10 A fantastic game for smash fans and non smash fans alike. I am extremily exited to see how this game develops alongside the fanbase. At least this game is here to dry our tears as we mourn the loss of Project M.

Rest In Ridley: Project M 2011-2015

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I REALLY wanted to like this game. I did. But as it stands, it's far too gimmicky. Online play is very laggy due to P2P without region lock, and about 60% of your games will involve one side or the other suiciding to avoid the terrible lag. But the bigger issue is that the characters are all very gimmick based. Zetterburn can KO characters at 60% if he sets them on fire (and considering every one of his special moves spreads fire, isn't very difficult), Kragg isnt killable until he hits close to 200% and can just spam attacks that don't even allow you to approach him, and Orcane just down airs you into oblivion. Worse is that the other half of the issue isn't in their strengths, its in their weaknesses. Sure, the idea of Maypul's recovery is cool, but its easily telegraphed, as is Orcane's recovery. This doesn't necessarily mean any characters are over or underpowered, just that... well, if you can light someone on fire and destroy them immediately, why would you ever do anything else? Which I feel means that at the lower to average level of plays, there is little to no variety. Everyone spams fire and strong attack on Zetterburn, pillars on Kragg, side specials on Maypul, etc. I feel like the game devs wanted to make a game for a competitive scene, so they said "eh, if you're really good at the game, none of these things are an issue." Which is all fine and dandy, but if you don't want to be a pro RoA player, the game is very unforgiving, and often is very unenjoyable. Parrying is a cool mechanic in the game, but is very difficult to time, and, if there is even a shred of input lag, is worthless. And it feels like every one of those "OP" attacks only counterplay is to parry... So there is no counterplay. Get your opponent into a juggle combo of attacks before he does the same to you or its gg.

TLDR: Lots of lag issues, every character has a gimmick rather than just being naturally well-rounded, devs try to appeal more to the competitive side which makes it a poor game for the average gamer. Buy it on sale to play with friends, and try to avoid the pain and suffering of online play.

let me first start of by saying this is a good game like smash i did not grow up with melee witch is what this is modled after but i love this game SOOOOO much. i love Rivals Of Aether and hopfully more charictrues are added as though the charictures are divers there are very few choices 8 is lower than smash 64 witch was 12 if we could get like 20 or hopfully more charictures that would be nice also more stages and im hoping in the full game a sub-space embessary type mode that would be cool and is one of the things i miss most from ssbb and maby something for more cassual players like something to collect like trophies though i dont think trophies would work but maby something could work ill leave it up to the games creatores, so far iv seen a few bugs (like kragg using 2 rockes and wraster using two air streams) but im sure they will get patched out, on the other hand online workes well but i find myself getting disconeccted from 90% of matches befor they are complete or i even can get one game in so that could be inproved alot but when it works it works grate and even befor i get kicked out there is little to no lag witch is why i get confused when i am kicked but i think that it will inprove as the game is updated. i feel like i am one of the few who perfers the key bored tho i have custome controles because i used to play ssbf and set up controles like that game (W,A,S,D for directions:SPACE BAR for jump:P for attack:O for strong attack: I for parrie: and U for spicals) hope thats a good idea for anyone who gets confused with the regular set up as i find it easyer to control with X and Z being what they noramlly are. i hope those contrulle sceams help people looking for the best keyboard controlls. I hope my review what helpful for both the developer and also other consumers looking to see if they would buy this game or maybe as my key setup secton is help people already playing.


                                         Thank you for reading my comments

                                        yours truly,
                                        purpplexenon

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is amazing!!! Beautiful music and graphics, nice and smooth gameplay and to top it all off it has an amazing set of playable fighters. Pick this game up if you love smash melee or just want an amzing yet differnt fighting game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Pros:

+ Fast-paced gameplay (since it is inspired by Smash bros. Melee, this should be a no-brainer)
+ Noob-friendly
+ VERY fluid movement (Wavedashing and dash-dancing requires less timing skill than Melee , etc etc)
+ Each character has its own unique playstyle (Forsburn with the smoke, Maypul with leaves, etc.), allowing for some interesting matchups
+ GAMECUBE CONTROLLERS (idk about you, but this is a huge +1 for me)
+ Great art style (May be biased since I love pixel art-style games)
+ Great soundtrack
+ Can run on a potato

Cons:

- Small roster & stage count (since it's still very early in development, I guess I should let this one slide)
- Laggy servers (at least where I'm from ~Southeast Asia~. But I've heard people in the U.S. do just fine)

tl;dr Get this game if you love Smash bros. Melee, or fighting game in general. If you're new to the genre, get it anyways. It's unique and a lot of fun.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Great game. Nice fast paced, platform fighter. Would recommend using a gamecube or xbox control because the keys can be a little difficult to use for a noob like me. Small download, and good multi-player. Early access at this point so excited for what comes next. I give this game as is a 5 star. Worth the $15 and waiting for the xbox ome version. Hope i cam get a multi-platform discount. Fingers cross.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Storytime: Me and some of my friends have been playing this game during classes and lunch at school and we can't get enough of it (The reason I only have a bit of time on this game is because I moved it my school netbook which is where I usually end up playing this game). Typically we'd play Super Smash Bros. 4, but after playing it for a year and a heavy portion of salt over the last couple months we needed a breath of fresh air and Rivals may have saved RHS Smash Club from dissipating!

Just moving around in Rivals feels amazing. The lack of shields and grabs allows you to spend more time on mobility and air combos. Personally, in Smash 4, I got pretty sick of going for an aerial attack only to realize it’s a futile endeavor and end up getting punished by a shield grab.

The developer, Dan Fornace, has worked on Dust, Killer Instinct, Battleblock Theater, and Mark of the [freaking] Ninja.

This game is in early access but does not disappoint and is in entirely worth every penny.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is a great game if you have played the smash brothers series, specifically Super Smash Brothers Melee. I was told about this game by my friends and I decided to buy it. This game has a great soundtrack to go on top of the great fighting mechanics. Using a controller is recommended and if you would like to use a gamecube controller, check out this link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yVu8xJ7Bs6o

I surprisingly enjoy local play more than online. Althought it is fun every once in a while to go online and totally destroy someone, I still enjoy playing with my friends on the same PC more. Being with people and having friends to play with locally makes this game much more fun as you can do 2v2s, which can lead to some amazing and really funny combos. I hooked an old PC i had to a tv using an HDMI cable and love it. The large TV screen is much more realistic when playing with multiple people locally, but it is possible to play on a monitor. 

This game is amazing, take my word for it. Even if you have not played smash brothers, check out super smash flash or a game similar to that. Even though super smash flash doesn't run too well, (since it is a flash game) it would still help you understand whether or not this game is for you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I highly recommend this game if you had any bit of fun playing Smash.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A well balanced game that feels very much like SSBPM, every character has an interesting level of play above the smash games.  The way that each character's "gimmick" interacts with other's, as well as with their kits makes the game satisfying  and fun no matter how long you play it.  each character feels good to play, and while there are matchups that benefit one character over another, those benefits are often mild, mostly due to the how the gimmicks interact.

The only problem I ever have is input lag, when in fulscreen there is a little lag, and while it is expected, internet lag is a problem sometimes (though it might just be the Uni's internet that is bad).

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Note: I play exclusively online, so the review applies to online play only.

If I wrote this review when the game first came out it would have been a thumbs up and a glowing review. But I cannot recommend this game as it has some serious flaws.

1. The netcode is atrocious and is not anywhere near appropriate for a fighting game. Inputs get dropped, input delay changes on the fly, and each player will experience lag differently. I have fought many times where the player I was fighting was getting lag and input drops but I didn't feel a thing, and vice versa.
2. The characters are way too gimmicky. This is very fun when you first play the game and you get to see how unique each character is, but eventually it becomes boring and turns into "each character has one play style and X number of auto/near auto combos you must do to be competitive."
3. Due to the character gimmicks, the game is mostly about hard counters. It feels like most matchups are 7/3. For example, Zetteburn v Kragg is ridiculously in Kraggs favor.
4. At an advanced level, combos can be cool, but in order to be newbie friendly, way too many simple and boring combos exist that feel cheap, especially when you miss a tech due to online delay. I'm specifically referring to Forsburn and Zetteburn sprint spam, Wrastor bair spam, Forsburn and Zetteburn uair & fair spam. You end up seeing and using the same combos over and over and over because they work. Originality only has a place in the very top % of players.
5. The parry mechanic is an original idea with a terrible implementation. Parry is spammable, and landing a parry vs a player at a high % is essentially a guaranteed kill.

It's early access, these issues can be fixed. I'll update my review accordingly if the issues do get fixed. But for the time being, I'm putting this game down. The frustration of dealing with the subpar netcode and lack of balance vastly outweighs any fun.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Absa doesn't really make this game fun anymore... First of all, this lacks character choice creativity, because EVERYONE will choose Absa. Second, the character balancing was fine until Absa came along, not that I'm saying Absa should be removed. Finally, it may be just me, but from what Dan Fornace said on Twitter, making a weak character would NOT rise up the percentage. There wouldn't really be a reason to make a character in general. Again, it may be just me. I will still recommend this game, but I feel the game's popularity is wearing thin.

PLEASE NOTE THIS IS MY SOLE OPINION IN THIS GAME. I do not intend to burn this game to the ground.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you are looking for a SSB (Super Smash Brothers) type of game I honestly recommend playing Projecy M, a mod for Brawl. If you can't figure out how to play Project M, just play Melee. This game is definitely not worth the $15. I only feel frustrated playing this game. I have spent 50+ hours playing this game and definitely 1000+ playing smash brothers games and  can honestly say that this game is not worth your time. 

Every single character has a 'clunky' gimmick.

I only feel angry when I play this game. If you want to have fun, this is not the game for you.

3/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Excellent step into the genre of "platform fighters". If you're a fan of the Super Smash Bros. series, or simply want something akin to that experience, this is a great game to get into. It's made to play fast, and feels like it's been constructed from the blueprints of Melee's competitive scene. Additionally, a small roster keeps anyone from feeling overwhelmed by a large moveset. Despite this, the variety in the characters and their designs means there's one to fit every playstyle.

I would highly recommend this game for: competitive Smashers, general fans of Smash, those looking for more "platform fighters", or people looking for fast-paced and responsive gameplay.

If you don't like Smash's construction, or if you want a slower, more tactical approach, this game may not be for you.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I love this game, It's the greatest smash inspired game to ever come out. The game is extremely smoosth and unlike other smash like games, this one does it right.

Pros

Great gameplay and mechanics.

No sheilding creating more offensive play.

Few characters, but all are unique and fun with none of them being too OP (Krag is not that bad people)

The stages are interesting and fun to play on with both a tournament/competitive version and a fun casual weird style.

All characters have something unique about them and are each easy to pick up but hard to master.

The game includes wavedashing but unlike melee it's not needed to be a good player, just there if you would like to play more competitively.

The movesets of the characters are things you would never see from a traditional smash game, making it see one of a kind.

Great servers and online connection, very little lag if any, the only type of lag would be from you having a bad internet, not the servers.

Cons

Not as many characters as I would like, though they will be brought in eventually.

Even the level 9 AI is easy to beat, making online the only real place to practice, and if you're downloading something then it might suck.

No way to see players steam profile after a match if you want to friend them to have a good practice partner.

These are all minor complaints for what is a fantastic game, from someone who is highly into the competitive smash scene(Going to local tournaments and practicing online constantly) I have to say that I like this game more than smash. It's easier to pick up, and with less character and more room to focus on each match up, much easier to get into competitively.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
While I have a love/hate relationship with its online mode, I absolutely adore this game.

The first thing you need to know about this game is that it is a "Smash clone". However, it is not a Smash clone. I'll let that sink in. If you come expecting a platform fighter with fast-paced yet deep gameplay, this is the game for you. If you came looking for a game with shields, grabs, or ledge mechanics, prepare to be disappointed.

There are other reviews here that go more into detail. Suffice it to say, this game is very fun, and plays very fast. Combos are king, and it isn't always noob-friendly. If you keep at it, though, you will find a very rewarding and engaging fighting game. Best played on the couch with 1 to 3 friends, though the online is serviceable, albeit not amazing.

Expect lag in your online matches, but do your best to move on. This is probably the best advice I can give the enterprising Rivals player. The netcode is still in the works (remember, this is Early Access), so it's not perfect. Fixes have been promised. I, for one, am optimistic.

Finally, I restate, this is an Early Access title. From what I've seen of others, it is a pretty darn solid Early Access title. Little content means the game is what you make of it, but the gameplay (arguably the vast majority of a fighting game) is incredibly tight and polished. A lot of stuff isn't perfect, but the devs are hard at work and publish patches semi-regularly.

A few "Quick Hits"
[*] There are only 6 characters. There will be 7 come 11/19/2015, and 8 by full release
[*] There are only 5 stages. Some are great, some are meh. This will vary depending on your character
[*] Shields are replaced by parries. If you hit one of the shoulder buttons (or the equivalent on the keyboard), you will have a short window of time where enemies who hit you will be stunned.
[*] Ledge Grabs are replaced by wall jumps. Hit the jump button while moving toward the wall, and you will jump off. This allows you to airdodge and up-b again. Very helpful, but a little hard to grasp at first

All in all, even if you only get a handful of hours out of this game, it is only 15 bucks. That may be steep for some, but with the amount that I have enjoyed playing this game, I easily would have paid even double that. If you're not convinced, wait until the full release and buy it then. I'm sure a lot of the complaints people have will have been addressed by then.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Many would compare this game to the Super Smash Bros. series.
And many people are correct.
This is a retro-style Super-Smash Bros. esque game with a small roster of characters with their own individual moves. 
It features time and stock (lives) modes, online, and local play. 
It's very fun, simple, and once you get the hand of it you can destroy people in no time.
As of now I give it a 8/10 (simply because its early access and a lot of stuff is unavailable) other than that I'm sure (very sure) that it will be worthy of a 10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
#1 First and foremost this game has no native controller support. If you do not already own a $25 controller and $20 adapter you have to play with a keyboard. The GameCube controller is terrible for this game - seriously, I've played with both controllers and the XBox controller is 100x better and more responsive. It seems very obvious to me that there are a large number of keyboard players who lose to players with GC controllers, and a large number of GC controller-users who lose to players with XBox controllers. It really is that significant a difference.

#2 This is a fighting game with no balance. There are six characters and every character has matchups where they are 7-3 or 3-7. When we get to eight charcters, will we see lots of 8-2 matchups? When the full twleve characters are released, will we have 9-1 matchups?

#3 Most characters have powerful, non-interactive gimmicks that discourage approaching. This does not give me confidence for where the game is heading.

#4 The stages are terrible.

If you think this game looks interesting, come back in a year. There is no reason to purchase the game now in its unfinished form. It's simply not good enough.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is hands down the best PC fighting game I have played, period. 
Rivals of Aether is crazy smooth, fast and fluid. Imagine Smash Bros Melee, but in 2015; wavedashing, dance dashing, 0 to deaths, autocanceling, it's all here. Complete with near lagless online that I've never failed to find a quick match, with multiple opponents in a row. 
Even in early access, I highly reccomend this game to everyone: if you love fighters. 
I will for sure be playing this for years to come.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A fantastic game for those who are a fan of Super Smash Bros: Melee (SSBM).  I don't typically endorse games that are "clones" of other games.  Having said that, Rivals of Aether(RoA) attempts to blend mechanics that fans and professionals felt set SSBM apart from other fighting games with new mechanics that are designed to make the gameplay feel smooth.

*No more shields - This has been replaced with a parry system that is similar to a powershield in SSBM.  I think this is a well-implemented and a great change to the feel of the game.  It emphasizes the timing of guarding against attacks, and empasizes reflecting projectiles with parries.  This ultimately leads to less stalls in combat due to shield spam.

*No ledge grabbing - I think this is an extremely positve change for the state of games like this.  In SSBM, people would often take advantage of the invulnurability frames that ledge grabbing gives, as well as the fact that in SSBM, only one person can grab a ledge a one time.  If a player is to quickly ledge grab during his enemies recovery, the enemy just drifts past the ledge to his death.  While this is sometimes an interesting mechanic in SSMB, I think doing away with it leads to much more interesting edgeguard sitations in the game.  

While I never played Melee competitively, I've been interested in the scene for a long time now.  I find that RoA has very fluid mechanics, and it's a great pick up.

It's the game that every smash fan have been waiting for. A fun, fast paced fighting game that is actually balanced. this might be due to the small roster. Albeit its size, they bring together characters from different universes in the true spirit of a smashbrothers rippoff. you have all your favourites right there, dukin it out on the battlefield.

If you like smash brothers, or if you like fighting games overall, you will not regret the investment. The only person who i can think of that would not like this game would be graphic-elitists who thinks a game can't be good if it cant be played in at least 1080p, but those people can go to hell anyway am i right?
Simply put, 10/10 would bang again.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game. Where to begin.

Overall:
To start, the game is fairly simple and easy to pick up (Controller is recommended). It has a massive SSB feel, with a free-flow combo system, and characters that are aren't too complex. This game is a lot of fun, is already building a competative scene quickly, and plays really closely to Melee.

Pros:
-Graphically, is really great
-Easy to learn
-Updates are pretty often (about once a month/other month)
-Controls are tight and feel great (on a controller at least. Never played it with a keyboad to be honest)
-Online isn't all that laggy (in my experience with it)
-Characters are fairly simple and easy to pick up and learn to fight against
-Wavedashing
-Extremely fun

Cons:
-Characters are pretty 1-demensional
-While being easy isn't bad, it almost feels too easy
-Stages are either extremely different, or essentialy the same one. This is only an issue because some of the stages feel too small. This is more of a preference thing. Diverse stages in a fighting is uncommon, and not a real issue. It's more the size, which only one, maybe two stages fall under being too small.

Conclusion:
Trust me. This game is worth the $15. I've played a lot of fighting games, and most of them are fairly complex, and require a lot of practice to get with. This one isn't like that. It's really easy to learn, has local and online multiplayer, plays great, controlls easily, looks really good, and sounds great. BUY THIS IF YOU LIKE SMASH BROS!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Regarding characters, that is what matters for me, every one of them have a unique fighting mechanic and they feel really interesting to play and master.

The only negative point I can think is that just 8 characters (6+2 to come) are gonna look very few once we get used to fight them. I just hope that the game could get expanded after the final release.

Balance is also an issue, but being on early access I suppose it's just matter of time. It's not super-unbalanced, but at least the best (Zetter) and the worst (Fors) need an adjustment.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A high-speed Smash-like game almost entirely built around 1v1 duels. A small roster, but every character is incredibly unique and powerful in their own right. The game flows incredibly well, and every move feels well thought out in how they link with other moves, resulting in lengthy and delicious combos. Online is 1v1 only at the moment, but 4-player Free-for-alls and 2v2s are possible offline. The game is only in Alpha at the time of writing this, but even in its incomplete stages, I have had an enormous amount of fun in this game.

The game is remarkably easy to pick up, and aims to reduce or outright remove a lot of the barriers that prevent a lot of people from playing Smash at a tournament level. It gives a big boost to intermediate level players who just don't have the time or patience to learn the dozens upon dozens of techniques crucial to tournament-level Smash. Those who play Smash are probably used to accidentally performing a Smash attack by accident when they intended to perform a Tilt. In RoA, Smash attacks (Called Strong attacks in this game) and Tilts (Weak attacks) are on seperate buttons, preventing you from accidentally performing one or the other.

If you are looking for a game similar to Smash that's easy to pick up and actually designed to be a fighting game, I highly recommend Rivals of Aether. The game feels incredibly good to play, and there's never a dull moment in battle.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This could be a fun game. I think that when Early Access is over, hopefully everything will be fixed.

What I mean by that is it has the POTENTIAL to be an extremely fun game. However, I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME... at least for the moment. I wouldn't feel right about pretending to recommend it. 

About 1 in every 5 games do I have a connection that I can actually play without disruption. 8/10 games the connecton is so bad it freezes over and over again. Eventually someone will get sick of it and will purposefully suicide due to the terrible connection so that they can move on and hope they can connect to the next person.

Characters are simply imbalanced. There are a few that are just better than others. Better moves, stronger kill moves, more plentiful ways to combo that "stun" long enough to not allow you to get out of it. It's just the way it is. This NEEDS to be fixed so that two players of equal skill levels don't lose to the other simply due to having a character with stronger attacks and better kill moves. 

So no, don't buy this game. Don't give the developers any more money until they earn it. Character balance fixes, connection fixes, input lag fixes. All of this needs to be fixed before I can recommend Rivals of Aether.

However, the few times that the connection is good and the characters in the current game aren't one of the imbalanced ones Rivals of Aether can be very fun. It's those VERY few times that keep me coming back every day. Hopefully I'll look back at this review and think, man I'm happy I kept playing.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
My problem with this is game is how the characters' actual potentials aren't utilized. With my experience online, it's the same characters using the same moves. Zetterburns just using the fireball and then spamming you with side smash, the Forsburns just using the backstab mid air. The Kraigs just spam the same side attack until you're off the map and then they throw rocks at you. The Wrastors just hitting you up in the air and then finish you with a spin move. This game got really annoying and boring fast to the point where I would just lock in Zetterburn and just throw fireballs and side smash. Can't beat em, join em, Probably the only two characters that actually seem like they do more than one thing is Orcana and Maypul. But of course I rarely encountered any online and they were the most fun to play against. All the trailers made the characters look fun to play against and to play as, but it turns out no one bothers with that and they use the same abilites over and over. I didn't even know Wrastor had drill kick side ways until 2 minutes before I wrote this review. 

The online matchmaking isn't that great either. You get paired against a random person of any skill level and for me it was either people who actually pulled some cool combos or the spammers. To bad I don't get to see much of the former. Its quite interesting seeing the pros pull some amazing combos that look really good and it gets me pumped to versus someone online and when I load the game up then I'm stuck seeings Zetterburn after Zetterburn doing the same thing over and over and I just lose interest. 

So why am I recommending it?

Because its fun with friends like smash is. You and your friends load up this game see the amazing art and fun music and you guys just play. No one uses the same moves over and over like online. The yelling and screaming and discovering what combos with what is just a blast with friends and probably the only reason I might open up this game from time to time.

Do you want a fun game with great visuals and music? Do you want to play smash with your friends and enjoy the different characters? Do you enjoy a great netcode? Do you hate ledges? If you answered Yes to any of these questions then this game is for you. 

Do you want a fun online experience and would only play it for the online? Do you like seeing diverse characters and a big pool to choose from? Do you like balanced matchmaking where you get paired with people around your skill? Do you hate spammers? If you said Yes to most of these, you should look for another game. 

Hopefully most of my problems will get fixed and I will update the review, but if you're looking for an online smash type game and you don't have anyone to play with, friends or just people online, then the online feels like a chore. 

Great game, mechanics, visuals, music, and direction. Poor online.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A very fun, Smash-like game. Overall the game is incredibly fast paced and fun, and would highly recommend it to anyone who likes Smash or other fast-paced games like it. The dev team is dedicated to making it appealing to both competitive and casual players alike, and to keeping the game balanced.

As far as characters go, I do feel like some characters will always just beat out others if two players are on an equal skill level.

My personal tier list:

S) Wrastor - Very quick in both air and ground movement and has great kill potential in both combos and raw Strong attacks, though can be kind of difficult to control if you're not used to him. His side special allows for greater air mobility, and has insane recovery with the multiple air jumps.

A+) Zetterburn - Very fast on the ground, and his side Strong attack is very good at catching opponents off guard if used correctly. His fire attacks also slowly accumulate damage over time which can lead to higher kill percents more easily. Also has decent kill potential. The only real problem with him is that his recovery is pretty linear, which can be read easily. Think of Fox's or Falco's Up-B in smash.

A-) Kragg - Slower than most of the cast, but his kill potential more than makes up for it. Most, if not all, of his aerial attacks can kill pretty easily. Combine that with his pillar and rock-throwing and he can zone just as easily as he can bring pain in combos. His side special also has armor, which can be used to great effect in throwing opponents off guard.

B) Maypul - Very quick on the ground and combo oriented, though he does seem to have a slightly higher execution cap; meaning players will have to spend more time with the character to learn to play him effectively. That being said, marking his opponents makes it easier to kill if they aren't prepared, and can also aid his recovery if he gets knocked from the stage. The only real problem is that he has relatively weak recovery without the mark, making it somewhat easier to kill him than some of the other cast.

C+) Orcane - More of a trap/zoning character than an aggressive one, laying down his puddles can be used for both mixing up and comboing his opponents. His side aerial attack is good for trapping opponents in place for a short time, as is his down special after the puddle is set. Like with Maypul, however, his recovery is pretty terrible without the puddle, and can be read and punished easily by more experienced players, setting him up to be killed easier. Still, he can be overwhelming in the right hands and has decent kill potential from his Strong attacks.

Finally, C-) Forsburn - My own personal character of choice, though I do believe him to be the weakest of the current roster. I play him as a very aggressive character, going in and setting up my clone and smoke whenever I can. In the right hands, the clone can be used in tandem with the player and cause massive pressure on the opponent, and his smoke can be used to hide the player and cause deception. His smoke can also be absorbed, in which after 3 absorbtions he can use his down special to cause an explosion around him with great kill potential. Think the Wario Waft in smash. The reason I consider him the weakest, however, is for three reasons: One, his smoke and clone can be dissipated with an attack from the opponent. A single attack removes any cloud of smoke on screen or can be used to the destroy the clone, if not both. Any projectile will dissipate the clone and the smoke as well. Wrastor is probably his worst matchup because Wrastor's side special can blow through the clone and clouds with ease. Two, his kill potential is somewhat lacking. Other than his strong attacks (which aren't too bad, actually), his only two kills moves are his back aerial attack and his explosion, which brings me to number three - using any special other than his recovery removes one of the charges needed to cause the explosion, meaning you have to absorb another cloud of smoke to trigger it. His recovery is also somewhat predictable and can be read by the opponent relatively easily.

Like I said, this is a personal tier list and can be taken with a grain of salt - this is how I see the game thus far.

I'm looking forward to the continued development of this game - it really is a lot of fun.

review: This is a fantastic game. It combines all the technical aspects of Super Smash Brothers with a very fast and dynamic gameplay. A few minor dislikes I have with the game is that it needs more characters and stage selection but considering this game is in beta I have a feeling more will be on their way. title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Bought this game on a delirious whim at 5am while unsure whether I would like it.

All I can say is that this game is fucking SAVAGE. It features:

A four-legged orca that can kill you... by teleporting and spitting on you.
A badass flying birdman that keeps the entire game in the air... by halting all his momentum to charge an attack, completely still.
A weird-ass raccoon-ferret that stabs you... with... leaves?
A stereotypical animal shaman that uses smoke to hide himself... He should probably lay off the cigarettes.
A Heracross looking mofo that is apparently not a bug type, since he uses Rock Throw, Rollout, and Stealth Rock.
A lion that is apparently pretty upset about someone lighting his mane on fire, since he seems to be on a quest to make sure EVERYONE feels his pain.

Every combo in this game is fast and brutal, and yet it's so fluid, natural, and easy to pick up that it... well, it RIVALS that of Super Smash Bros. Bad puns aside, the fast-paced action, ease of access to new players, great artwork, fantastic gameplay, and a clear potential that only keeps rising as this game gains Steam truly mark this game to be watched.

This could very well become one of the best indie games I have ever played, and I can see all that just from the community its brought up in such a short time.
\\\\\
Dan Fornace, you take my $15 and you do something fuckin' wonderful with it. This game is gold, and it was and will be worth every Goddamn cent.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
****NOTE**** At the time of this review, the game is in Early Access - so many features and aspects of the game are not fully developed.

Honestly, this feels a lot like a Smash Bros for PC, so that is what I am going to compare it to.  (Note: I have many hours invested into the WII U & 3DS Smash games)

Similarities to Smash Bros:
- Controls
- UI
- Gameplay

Things this game does better than Smash Bros:
- Online play. By a lot. Far, far less lag. Matchmaking is quick.
- Loads far quicker than Smash Bros for WII U or 3DS
- New, interesting characters (Zetterburn FTW)
- No blocking. This game is incredibly fast paced because of it.


Things that Smash Bros does better than RoA:
- Huge roster of well known charaters
- large variety of stages
- Items in battles
- More than two characters in online play (although Smash lags fairly often, even on 250mbps internet connection with nothing else connected)
- Larger variety of modes available


Parting thoughts:

If you want Smash for PC, go buy a WII U or 3DS and Smash. You should probably also buy this game.

If you are looking for a fun game that has a lot to offer at an extremely attractive price, get this game. I highly recommend it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I really like this game. It's a great Smash Bros inspired fighter, but at the same time it's not a straight up Smash clone. There's no edge grabbing, and the blocking/dodging mechanic has been revamped entirely. There's 6 characters so far, and each of them have a very strong gimmick to them. For example, Orcane can teleport to wherever he places his puddle, but he doesn't have a recovery, so if you're knocked off the ledge and you don't have a puddle, you're screwed. Wraster can use smash attacks in mid-air, but he can't on the ground. So far, it's a great and diverse cast of fighters, each feeling unique. It's only gonna get better as time goes on too. The game itself feels like a mix of Melee and Smash 4, except it's a lot easier to pull off sweet combos. I LIKE THAT. A LOT.
The music is for the most part pretty good. There's a few really good tracks in there, and some mediocre ones. It must be hard to try and create music that has that awesome Nintendo-ish charm to it.
In the future, I'd love to see:
-Omega versions of stages like in Smash 4. And along with that maybe another version (Alpha ?) that's like Omega stages but with a three platform setup similar to Battlefield. 
-A story mode that lets you get to know a lot about the fighters. I like being able to connect with the fighters, that's part of the reason why I love Smash so much.
-An arcade mode similar to classic mode.
-Different costumes besides color variations (don't get me wrong, I love those too!)
-Goku, Ridley, and Geno
-That last one was a joke, but keep adding good unique characters. Ice based, electric based, dark based fighters would be cool. And don't be afraid to derive from animalistic character designs too. Some humans or robots to throw in the mix would be pretty cool.

69/10 would recommend to any Smash fan
Also, please keep checking tier lists and keep balancing the game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I went into this game expecting a fun, smash bros-like game and I can say it's far exceeding my expectations. ROA has great pixel art, with each character and stage looking vibrant. ROA has an interesting selection of 6 characters (2 additional characters planned in future updates), from a four-legged orca whale to a styling avian. Each character is completely unique, my favorite being Forsburn, a dagger-wielding assassin type character with abilities such as 
- smokescreen (neutral special) to deliver a surprise attack from an unknown position.
- decoy (side special) to throw off the opponent, with the same abilities as its source, its attacks can also create/extend combos.
Another thing I like about Aether is the crazy amount of moves that combo into each other, it's all so smooth, and the game is only in alpha so there's no doubt it'll even further improve.
My one complaint so far is the online matchmaking. About 90% of my matches have been players immediately self-destructing without even attempting to fight. Though this may be due to lag on the other end, it's not apparent to me as each of the games have been smooth on my end. it's. really. annoying. It takes forever to get into a match where the person actually plays. I feel like some sort of penalty could possibly be implemented to fix this. 
If you're looking for an interesting fighting game with endearing art, music, characters, and smooth gameplay, you're in the right place! I can't wait to try it out with friends. This game no doubt makes a great couch co-op game to waste time with.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Whilst still in early access, this game has a lot to boast about. Its core gameplay is Quick, Fun and Fluent. The art style used is brilliant and while there are few character choices they all are very unique.

The biggest let down is the input lag in the occasional online match. I find it annoying that you spend time in and out of lobbies in the hope of finding one that is responsive. 

With this problems fixed I would see it being a very suitable competitive fighter. 

Absolutely a great game, giving the PC its own super smash!

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is amazingly fun. Along with it being fun it is very unbalanced. The characters are very fun and diverse but only a few have problems. Orcane can spam attacks and along with that his attacks do a whole bunch of damage. Kragg before the new update could do this as well. Forsburn isnt all that good of a character his attacks are slow and hard to pull off. Wrastor is a very good character because although his combo set might be a lot better than most of any of the other characters, its actually hard to pull off and feels rewarding unlike orcane where you can just spam it the whole time. Maypul is the same as Wrastor in terms of being a lot more fair. Zetterburn is very mixed. His attacks do a lot of damage but along with that his attacks are extremely easy to block. Orcane can block almost anything, rarely dies because of the ink/water that he can use to send him on the stage again. Speaking of stages they all feel to small for what the game is trying to pull off. Overall the game is very good, along with its minor flaws A.K.A spammable attacks, hard to play characters and small maps. This game gets an 8/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Hot damn is this game fun. Probably the best smash-like out there.

Balance is tight (very tight, in my opinion, although people will disagree,) physics feel just right, and it feels really good when you land a kill setup. What makes the game really shine, though, are the characters, each of which have something that make them feel totally unique and interesting (yes, even Zetterburn has some neat stuff.) 

Since it's early access, the game is quite limited, though. The six characters never get old, and different playstyles can change up these characters dramatically, but the roster will feel very small to a lot of people. There's also only local multiplayer and online, with the only really single player option being against the ai, and the ai is pretty easy once you get a handle on the game.

Online could also use a bit of work, as the netcode doesn't feel spot on a lot of the times, and a few network glitches make it hard to find a decent game a lot of the time. Lots of people are also rage quitting right now, sometimes seemingly over nothing, but I guess there's no avoiding that.

If you want a solid smash game to play online, this is a very solid choice. If you're looking for stuff to do alone, though, it would be better to search elsewhere, or maybe wait until it's out of early access.

I for one have never played Melee or Project M, only having played SSB4 and Brawl I don't know how well I can judge this game, but the fast paced fights (nearly every aerial feels as if it autocancels, you can dash into any attack, wavedashing into attacks feels so sweet), the tight controls, awesome pixel art and soundtrack are simply bliss. The game stages and characters all feel unique (they're ALL balanced and FUN)  and the game isn't even finished yet! Would I recommend this game for any Smash brothers or "Party" game fighter fan? Yes, yes I would. 
I give it a 20XX/10 would Fox again

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is based of Super Smash Bros. Melee AKA Best Smash game. The available cast is small but unique with each characters having their particular mechanics and styles of play. It incorporates some of the adanved techniques found in Melee like Dash Dancing and Wavedashing (Which is made incredibly easier to perform). L-cancel isn't present as the landing lag is very low in general. The combo game is top notch making his game one that you would spend hours practicing and performing combos. Story mode and Abyss mode are not available yet and 2 characters have yet to be announced officially. 

Verdict: As it stands, Rivals of Aether is a stellar and fun addition to the growing Platform Fighter genre. It is a satisfying game with the components that made Super Smash Bros. Melee such a fun game with great retention value that made the game played all the way up to this day. A great gateway game into the Smash inspired Platform Fighter genre.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
if you are a fan of Super Smash Bros then you will without a doubt love this game, id compare it to SSB Melee with how fast paced and smooth the fighting and controls are. all of the controls are exactly the same as Smash Bros, so its really easy to pick up and play. all of the characters are very creative in play style but you will see subtle little things that will remind you of certain characters from smash. also there are a few minor differences, you cant edge grab the stage, instead you  cant stick to the side and it gives you a fresh jump to recover again.
this game has so much potential and i cant wait for more characters and story mode, the online vs mode is very good and there is no lag as far as i could tell.  i realize its in early access so there isnt much meat to the game yet and only 6 characters to play as, which is understandable but it is still a con to me. some characters are also a little more OP than others which i can also understand because they still need to get feedback from the gamers so they know who needs to be reworked.

Pros:
-creative characters
-sprite graphics
-awesome stage design
-great online vs mode NO LAG
-amaing controls and smooth frame rate
-amazing chiptune soundtrack
-custom controls

Cons: (Based on early access content)
-no edge grab
-need to balance the characters a little more
-only 6 characters (right now)

In conclusion, BUY THIS AWESOME FUCKING GAME  TO SUPPORT A DEVELOPER WHO IS TALENTED AND UNDERSTANDS WHATS WE WANT.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: It's very much like Smash Bros but not an outright clone by any means. The parry system and lack of shields, grabs, ledge grabs, etc will probably throw Smash fans off at first, but it makes for a more fast paced and fluid game that I'm really beginning to appreciate.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: I cannot say enough good things as this game. I honestly did not think I would love this game as much as I love melee. The hitstun has the perfect melee touch that makes combos possible but escapable. The combo game at a low level feels much more rewarding and fun than melee, while setill having a reasonable amount of depth to comboing people and being comboed. No sheilding allows for a playstyle where there is reduced reward for playing defensively and that offensive players do not have to learn how to quadshine into grab to feel like they are getting through the wall that is melee shield. The lack of ledge I did not like at first, but the replacement of a ledge with wall jumping after special moves allows for a recovery game without "gimicky" invincibility refreshes. If you love melee, get this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is like Super Smash Bros. Melee ft. steroids and arcade graphics.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is better than smash bros from a competitive standpoint. It's quite similar, but it's better;

1. It's $15 as opposed to the hundreds of dollars for a Wii U and Smash Bros (you still have to spend money on a gamecube adapter and controller if you use those, but you can use any USB controller or keyboard if you prefer.

2. Made by a company that wanted to make a more competitive version of smash. They succeeded by making a platform fighter that has an incredibly balanced (albeit small) roster, no items, neutral stages, and advanced techniques reminiscent of Super Smash Brothers Melee to create a high skill ceiling.

3. The simple graphics allow almost any computer to run this game at 60 fps with no problems whatsoever.

4. The online matches don't feel as laggy as the online mode in Smash Bros for Wii U.

5. The characters aren't limited to pre-existing games/universes like they are in Smash Bros. The characters in RoA are original and actually feel like they were designed to beat each other to a pulp, unlike some Smash Bros characters *cough*wiifittrainer*cough*.

6. It has much better practice mode features, such showing hitboxes and knockback direction as well as being able to advance frame by frame.

7. There is no tripping, rage, or stale moves. This removal of variables makes combos go off much more consistently and intuitively.

This game is just really, REALLY good. If you like Smash or any fighting games, it is DEFINITELY worth the $15.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rivals of Aether is a great fighting game heavily based off of Super Smash Bros. The style of the game is outstanding and the characters all seem well developed. The gameplay itself is near flawless. Some characters are a little over powered though, but none are so overpowered that the game is unplayable. For a game only in early access, this game seems suprisingly finished. Yet, there is much more to come, and I can not wait for the full release.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is completely amazing. If you're a fan of Super Smash Bros Melee, or fighting games in general you need to pick up this game. The online works with little to no delay 90% of the time and even if you are playing in offline mode the CPU's are programmed beautifully. Can't wait to see what the developers are working on next.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is fun. Full of problems and things to be improved on, but fun. Rivals of aether truly puts the "really early" in "early access", or at least i hope. The game needs a ton of stuff added and improved on before it can be considered even close to a releasable game. we'll do a pros cons list cause we're Hip

Pros:
-great combat, tight controls
-characters feel unique with their own gimmicks that feel extremely satisfying to pull off *cough orcane cough*
-pretty background art
-extremely fast to get into a game

Cons:
-character designs are for the most part god awful
     -wow i've never seen a FIRE LION before
     -obligatory bird character with goggles
     -a dolphin with meaty legs
     -a dolphin with meaty legs
     -a dolphin with meaty legs
-lack of characters and stages (early access duh)
-can't play in full screen (only me? i don't know)
-the online. two of my hours on this game were spent trying to get it to work properly. its mostly because my computer is weird and only has a monitor refresh rate of 48hz. everything runs smoothly and looks fine on my end, but my opponents must have experienced extreme input lag, which would mean they just suicided three times to get to a different match. in order for me to play i had to mess around with my computers settings and disable vsync and mess with other stuff and play in windowed mode. this needs to be fixed, no one should have to mess with their pc settings and settle for less than ideal conditions just to play the game
-lack of communication. the above would have probably been figured out way faster if there was chat in the end game screen or something
-lack of competitive matchmaking. the player base of this game currently is probably something like 75% super smash bros veterans and 25% people who heard about the game and decided to give it a shot. learning the game is difficult when you get three stocked over and over by some zetterburn main and you can't get a hit in. matchmaking would probably solve this: either all the try hard git good players play competitive and are matched against same level people and would be happy not playing against noobs and the baddies like me get to practice in normals, or people keep tryharding in normals so baddies like me go to matchmaking and practice at the shit tier where we belong until we git good


my cons list looks huge in comparison, but overall i do think the game is really something special. i just hope that the developers care enough about the cons i've listed to fix them and make this the great game it could be. if this game gets fully released as the game we all want it to grow up to be, expect tournaments, youtube content, professional players, guides, fanart, etc. because this is unlikely to be something that dies out quickly if its good. if you think your computer might have issues running the game, please wait for the devs to make it more reliable


TL;DR: game's fun. it has a really really long way to go though

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It is a great game so far. However, if you're buying in early access you may be dissapointed with the online. It will constantly disconnect in fights making it very difficult to actually play a whole round through. However, I assume this is just a server issue being worked out considering it is still fairly new. Once they get that fixed I can honestly see me playing this for hours. Combat is tight, fluid, and punchy. It has just the right ammount of weight to it. Classes seem to be very well balanced atm, (Excluding Wrastor. His whirlwind ability can be spammed and can get quite annoying at times.) The music is simply phenomenal, matching each stage's theme with incredible accuracy. As far as the art style goes, I can honestly say I haven't seen sprite work this good in years. The game is freaking gorgeous. I'm very much looking forward to story mode and "Abyss Mode"... whatever the hell that is. 
    As for whether you should buy it in early access, I would say yes and no. If you're like me and have been following this game since it's aonouncment some time ago, and want to see this game thrive and grow, then you should of course buy it. But, if you are just looking for a solid game to play RIGHT now, I would say hold off untill the offical release date.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The best COMPETITIVE Smash experience you can get on PC, short of emulating a console. It has a super charming art style that would feel right at home on a Super Nintendo, and while it may not have the most memorable soundtrack, the gameplay is EXTREMELY solid and any Melee or Project: M fans will feel right at home. Be wary if you're looking for a more casual time; the game is still fun, but single player options (in early access) are currently limited, and there are currently no plans to ever add items or supers.

Still, if the small roster and stage selection currently has you second guessing a purchase, put it on your wishlist and keep an eye on it, because it has a ton of potential to be really amazing!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
this is how smash would play, if it werent so busy wasting its potential.  in this case, wasted potential means going through the motions with mash-up cashgrabs balanced around items, stage hazards and four-for-all.  if thats what you like about smash, then you may not dig this.  but if you like smash for the fun movement, varied and deep playstyles, flashy combos and exciting moments of 1v1, then you will be playing rivals of aether for hours on end

get this game if you genuinely like platform fighters for all they could and should be; going by my aforementioned critera, it is easily the best game in the subgenre!  if you think this game is a "smash clone", just know that it would be smash mewtwo, if that were true.  also, prepare to realize how wrong you are after playing for a couple hours

... eh, actually i guess they werent "going through the motions" with smash.  after all, the last game gave us smash run... and smash tour... and... palutena... god, that game sucked... oh, wait but the game before that introduced the super fun mechanic of tripping!  alright, alright: enough shitting on smash for this paragraph

the netplay, balance and lack of bugs are all really impressive, especially for a game that isnt even completed yet.  it is made very clear that the creator loves this game and believes in the community, through frequent interaction and early access updates.  if the game does well enough, he may continue to add content post-release. best of all, he actually listens to his fanbase!

both sm4sh games: $100 for 15 hours of chaotic fun on the couch with a few of your friends and family, whether they play games or not
rivals of aether: $15 for 100 hours of exciting fun on your PC with a great community and/or your best buddy that plays fighting games

it all boils down to selecting your audience and knowing what makes a game truly fun and replayable for them

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
While you may think that this game looks like an uninspired clone of Smash Bros, it is actuallly a quite original and high quality game. 
The mechanics for each character are very unique and would likely never be found in a smash bros game. For example, the character Wrastor can perform strong attacks (smash attacks) in the air while the character zetterburn can set you on fire in order to activate his sweet spots for his attacks. Recovering to the stage is also very different from smash bros as ledgegrabbing is not in this game. This causes you to be very creative with your recovery and rely on walljumps to get back to the stage. Other differences include parrying instead of shielding and a lack of grabbing. 
Even if you have put in countless hours into Smash Bros, you will find a fresh and enjoyable experience with Rivals of Aether. The game is smooth, fact, and filled with satisfying combos. Rivals of Aether feels less like a smash bros clone and more like an entry to the platform fighter genre. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys smash bros or fighting games.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
(Word of warning, I'm gonna use some Smash terms)
As someone who is a semi competitive Melee and PM player, this game really clicks with me. If you play Melee and PM at a high level, you can probably pick up a character in an hour or two. If you're a competitive Melee or PM player, you can probably pick up a character in an hour or two.


This game is ACCESSIBLE
The gameplay is fast and smooth, and incredibly user friendly. The learning curve is lessened from Smash due to the lack L-Cancelling, replacing it with low landing lag, making combos smooth and easier to perform. There aren't edges to the stages, making edge-guarding less read based, but, the wall jumping and air dodging lets you mix up your recoveries just enough to keep opponents guessing, but not to the point where you could do 3-4 different things recovering. Also, you can attack and move out of an air-dodge, which makes a missed wavedash off the stage less punishing. There aren't any shields in Rivals. Instead, you have parrying, which keeps defensive play to a minimum.

I haven't even talked about the characters yet.

Wow.

Every character is completely unique, with really well executed ideas. Zetterburn can set opponents on fire, and if he connects a strong attack (the non copywritten name for smash attacks) while the opponent is still on fire, the attack does quite a good deal more knockback and damage (Try aerial side-b into F-smash ;) ). Wrastor is the godlike combination of Falco, Marth, and Jigglypuff. He utilizes a wind current that, if he is inside it, raises his speed and his already insane aerial speed. He also has 4 jumps, so, uh.

BACK AIR BACK AIR BACK AIR.

Anyways, Forsburn can create a clone of himself (ICs anyone?) and can create smoke, store it, and use it to create an explosion around him. He can also Ken combo. Orcane uses a puddle that he creates somewhere on the map. He can teleport to it, make it evaporate into bubble has a trap, and enhance some moves of his. Maypul is an extremely small and fast character that can mark opponents with certain special moves. If she uses a strong attack while the person is marked, they are stunned for a small amount of time, which is a really simple kill setup. If the opponent is marked and she up-Bs, she will pull herself toward the opponent, and control her direction, which is great for mixups. Kragg hits quite hard, but is a good deal slower that the rest of the cast. He can create a big stone that he can throw in a myriad of directions. If he isn't holding it, he can break with an attack, which sends a bunch of rocks in the direction he attacked. Depending on what attack you use and what direction you hit it at. His up-B is really bizarre, he summons a pillar of stone wherever he is. It's really useful for comboing, by getting an opponent between Kragg and the pillar opens tons of combo opportunities.

So, is this game worth buying? Yes, absolutely, One of the greatest games in early access right now.

Hope to see you online!

review: forsburn is a perfect character. wrastor is crazy as fuck too. pick this up if you like melee and/or sm4sh. i personally enjoy both and find this to be a very fun and interesting title. full disclosure: there's no shield or grabbing in this game. however, there is both a dodging and airdodging mechanic that's very similar to melee's, and wavedashing is a neutral option in this game. so the emphasis is often on player movement instead of more defensive options- just keep moving, never be too predictable and get some really good hits in. a solid fighting game, because it's not only fast- it's fun.

review:
Coming from smash, I absolutely love this game. I've only had two issues with it. The online seems to be buggy, as in I get kicked out of games and my opponent sometimes (most of the time) just SDs (Jumps off stage) and then disconnects after the match it over, which I'm pretty sure is not something they are doing on purpose. I assume this is some type of desync isssue but I have no clue. Also, when I am in fullscreen I randomly get kicked out as if I magically alt+tab'd. I can pause vs. Cpu's but when playing online I cant do anything for a few seconds until I click it back on.

Aside from those issues, as I said I loooove this game and hope that future patches can resolve them. Would 100% reccommend.

I love this game. I'm completely obsessed with this game. I ADORE THIS GAME.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
The game looks at first to be a clone of Smash. but when you play it, you see that it in many ways is very different from it.

Obviously the characters are different, although there are some parallel characters.

The control scheme is a little awkward for me, i just have to get used to it, you jump with the Y button on an Xbox controller, regular attack with a, "strong" (smash) attack with b, and special with X, because of this, it is difficult to jump and do attacks, i would like it if the developers added an option to jump by pressing up with the joystick or the D-Pad.

The graphics are good. its an indie-style pixelated game, so it looks like a game that maybe could have been on the SNES or the Genesis (during their later years) but they are technically Hi-def and the game can play in either windowed or fullscreen. 

The gameplay itself is a little lacking, but it is still in early access. Because of this, i will return to this once the game is at its full release.

the only true problem i have is that there are only a few characters and stages, but im sure there will be updates that add some stuff in the future.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Unfortunately this smash clone (and proud to be) does not natively support gamecube controllers yet, leading to a terrible experience with such a controller.

The features are very basic. No game settings online, no 2v2s, no spectating, very few characters, no ranking, no matchmaking to find opponents your level; etc (list goes on). A casual player will have a very poor experience right now. The game its in current stance is not close to being worth 15$ so I strongly suggest you wait until full release.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Have to follow what other reviewers have said. Awesome game, very deep and interesting mechanics even with only 6 characters, HUGE potential and very fun (especially if you enjoy Smash Bros Melee). In fact, this game may do what Brawl and Sm4sh have thus far failed to do: Ween me off tap-jump. That in itself is an amazing achievement. 

That said, the community is trash. I'd assume that people who would shell out for early access to a fast-paced, competitive fighter would be able to, you know, FIGHT, but maybe half of the people I play against quit halfway through. I hope we get a larger pool of people as more people realize how awesome it is, and I'm betting the quitters will weed themselves out eventually as well.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a great 2D spiritual succesor to the Smash Bros. series from Nintendo. I love the unique characters with both original moves and moves inspired by characters from the Smash series. The mechanics and rules in the game differ than that of Smash as well, and to that I say "well done!" If it were just a blatant knock off of Smash, it would not feel as original and innovative as it does. 

With all that said, I'd like to share some my personal knitpicks about the game.

For starters, the character Kragg feels a bit too overpowered. His movesets are easily abused by campers and veterans, making him extremely difficult to fight against. He also has a good bit of speed behind him for a heavy-hitter. Now I may just be a John or a Scrub for these complaints, but I may also not be the only one that feels this way about him. I just can't help but find myself hating going against this character, especially when they are spamming the rock throw and rock scatter attack. It feels nearly impossible to get around it.

Second, online play can have some SEVERE lag issues. Sometimes it can run fine depending on the connection, but often times, there is a HUGE delay in the controller input when playing online, which can make it extremely difficult to play. I understand if someone I'm playing with has bad wifi, but their has got to be a way to patch this.

Lastly, I think the overall controls are a bit too stiff. It may just be me, but I find myself parrying A LOT when I am simply trying to dodge roll instead. Sometimes my inputs don't match what I am trying to do either. 

Now I know this game is in Early Access and it is FAR from done, but I figured I would just give my two cents about my thoughts on the game so far. All in all, for it being in such an early stage of development, it is pretty damn solid! I tip my hat off (if I had one) to Dan Fornace and his team on this game. It's fun, it's innovative, and I absolutely cannot wait to see where this game goes when it recieves it's full release in the next few months! Good luck to you all, and I hope my inputs on this game help you out in anyway.
