title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a fantastic game that balances the best elements of similar games like Super Smash Bros. 

Pros:
  -It retains some of the technical skill involved in Melee and Project M (i.e. wave-dashing) but does not overwhelm you with constant skills like L-Cancelling or SHFFLing. I have personally found L-Cancelling to be a hassle, so I was happy to find that there is very little (maybe even zero) landing lag in Rivals of Aether.
  - The basic attacks are all there, but a lot of characters have much more interesting mechanics (i.e. Wrastor's aerials freezes him in the air.) Combo-ing with these attacks feels awesome due to the small amount of hitlag on each attack.
  -There are no more grabs or ledge grabbing which some people find questionable. However, the lack of grabs adds to much more fluid gameplay relying on attacks to start combos rather than grabs. Also, ledge grabbing has been pratically replaced with wall jumping, which is much different to say the least.
-In my opinion, the characters in this game are much more unique than the characters featured in Super Smash Bros. Each character in this game has a unique gimick besides just attacks, specials, and aerials. I hope that future characters will flow as well as the current ones.
  -Rivals of Aether is a game that endorses competetive play and is built for it. This game will feel like a Smash Bros. game made for competetive play. If you like Smash Bros. You will like this game.
  -Has support for Xbox 360 controllers and keyboard. You can also use a Gamecube controller if you follow these instructions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yVu8xJ7Bs6o
  -The music is very good, and I personally love the art style. However, due to the lack of stages the music can become   repetetive.
  -Comes with a cool training mode that allows you to experiment and play with bots in any way you want.

Cons:
  -Many of the fights experienced online will be choppy and filled with button lag. From my experience, most games I've played have been realtively low on the lag scale. Whenever I play with friends there is no noticeable input lag or choppiness in the gameplay.
  -The game is in early access, so you don't really know whether this game will really become something with your money. I say this from personal experience with many early-access games that I have purchased, which I'm aware is my own mistake.
  -I don't necessarily know if this is a con, but to all the Melee fans out there: Rivals of Aether is not Melee 2.0.
  
Conclusion:
I definitely missed lots of pros and cons, but overall, I believe Rivals of Aether is very entertaining and worth the price tag due to the replayability of the game. As stated previously: If you like Super Smash Bros. in any way, shape, or form, you will like this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So far, it's a really fun time. Fast game pace, thoughtful and tactical mechanics, and a styling roster to boot. 

Things that have been really enjoyable thus far:
-Decent variaton in level design without ridiculous crap. (as opposed to the extremes of Smash Bros.)
-Mostly*** balanced characters
-Nice looking sprites/animations
-Growth potential for players to explore characters and combos. This is a big plus.
-Very unique character mechanics/stage control options. Everybody plays distinctly, and that's a lot of fun.
-There are not many negative points (see below)

Things that have been frustrating thus far:
-Forsburn has this combo: dash attack into dash attack into dash attack into dash attack into dash attack into dash attack into dash attack into dash attack. That's getting real old real fast. Yes, DI can save you eventually but only after several of them. Thus, we end up with Forsburns running around dash attacking everything into oblivion. That's very boring gameplay. If this could get nerfed/fixed, I think players would appreciate it. 
-Zetterburn has one similar situation that people love to try to abuse. Side special into side smash. Again. And again, because the first one powers up the second. Thankfully, this one is easier to get around and punish. 
-Occasional lag spikes making matching virtually unplayable. (They are thankfully uncommon.)
-Nothing else!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So lets first mention the elephant in the room: this thing is awesome!
I feel better now that this is out of the way :-)

To put this review into context, a small info from my end: i am a long time smash player and still play Smash 4 on a daily basis but soly 1vs1 for glory. So i am focused on the competitive spectrum of smash play.

Rivals of Aether is exactly that, a "smashlike" with laser focus on competitive 1vs1 play.
This shows in many aspects of the game:
1.) There is no blocking. This might sound harsh but it is the right thing todo, since blocking has always been a flawed mechanic in smash. To compensate you get a pary. Just press the button at the right moment when an enemy is about to hit you and you get a few frames of invincibility to counter your enemies moves.
2.) No ledge grabbing. The ledge grabbing has always been a special part of smash games, but it also slowed the games down and in some matchups lead to a VERY simplistic interpretation of rock, paper, scissors. In RoA you cant grab the ledge but any character can wall jump and do his recovery afterwards. This results in a much faster and skill based meta for of stage recovery/edge guarding.
3.) Easy wave dashing. Wave dashing is back and easier then ever. Just press a direction and the pary button + jump at the same time.
4.) very distinct characters. even though there are only 6 characters in the game so far, all of them are very unique and each matchup playes completely different.

Even though this is early access the game is  VERY enjoyable and the netcode is allready better then in smash 4.

So do yourself a favour and pick this one up asap.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[strike] Rivals of Aether is a Fire Emblem fighting game where characters that have the move Aether fight each other.	[/strike]    

Rivals of Aether (ee-thur) is a Super Smash Bros. inspired fighting game with tight controls, cool movesets, and combo centric gameplay. This game is fun if you are playing for shits and giggles, but can sometimes be frustrating so bring a salt shield.

There are a couple of characters I believe need tweaking and balancing like Zetterburn and Forsburn and maybe Kragg, but other than that the characters are all balanced, but they each require huge skill to be decent with. I recommend using Zetterburn for transitioning players from smash to get used to how the game works and moves. FYI, you can wavedash for those who know what that is.

There are 6 characters at the time of this review, and those characters are [b] Zetterburn	[/b] and [b] Forsburn	[/b] (the Fire characters), [b] Kragg	[/b] and [b] Maypul	[/b] (the Earth characters), [b] Wrastor	[/b] (the only Wind character right now), and finally [b] Orcane	[/b] (the only Water character right now).

The game if fun and highly competitive. There isn't much to do but to fight locally or online, and sometimes online matches have huge input delay spikes which is a bummer but it isn't [b] that	[/b] frequent.

Also, here are some youtube videos that are kinda [b] Radkeys.	[/b]

https://youtu.be/d1JyN-9iadY And so is this one.
https://youtu.be/PiutTzdgY1g Some good Kragg gameplay

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether takes a lot of inspiration from the Super Smash Brothers titles (namely Melee), and adds its own unique twist to it. The combat is very unorthodox, even compared to the already unorthodox Smash Bros series, with each character being able to control the stage in their own ways.
If you are a fan of Smash but find the formula starting to become a little bland, then pick up this game. Just be aware that since it's still in early access there could be a few bugs, but of my (almost) 20 hours of playing it, I haven't run into anything game breaking. Online matchmaking is a bit finnicky at times, with some matches lagging more than others, but I've had hardly any problems playing with friends.
If you're looking to get into smash, or have no other alternative, then I'd definitely pick up Rivals of Aether. It's a great game with a lot of similar aspects to Nintendo's hit brawler franchise, and there's no better alternative than this.
I'll actually be a little envious of Xbox One owners when this game hits the Arcade.
Final thoughts: Great game, interesting gameplay, awesome characters and movesets. Online is a little iffy at the moment, and there are some bugs, but those will probably all be ironed out as Early Access nears its completion.
8/10 would play for another 20 hours and more.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is a great Smash Bros-lite for PC, probably the best attempt at translating the mechanics of smash to another game that I have seen. If you enjoy Smash, you will likely enjoy the basic gameplay of this game. At the time of this review, there are 6 characters, 5 stages, and only 2 modes (2-4 player versus and 1v1 online). While this isn't a huge amount of content, what is there is really good, and there seem to be 2 more characters and I believe 3 more stages planned based on the greyed out options in the menus. There seems to also be two more modes planned, including a story mode. Based on this, I can safely say more content is coming, and the content promised is likely to be delivered as it isn't all that much more than what is already available,

As far as comparing the game to Smash, I would say that for a $15 title it compares well. While it has no where near the amount of characters as Smash, falling short of even the original N64 Smash Bros, the characters available are all quite unique and varied. Most of them have moves and abilities unlike anything I've seen in Smash, and this helps differentiate the game from its source of inspiration. Some particularly original abilities include the Earth Beetle's up special, which pulls a giant pillar of stone from the ground right under the character's feet. So cool! Another example is that the Bird character can shoot a whirlwind that leaves a trail of wind behind, making his movement speed faster inside the trail. The attention to detail is really impressive here, as each character's abilities fit perfectly with their look and the way they handle. The bird is lightweight and has wings, and thus focuses on aerial moves and speed, whereas the beetle is larger and slower, focusing on slower, heavier attacks and keeping his feet firmly planted on the ground. The other 4 characters have their own quirks and specialties, but I won't spoil them for you here. While Rivals doesn't offer the breadth of content of a Smash game, it maintains a similar level of quality with the content it does provide. As someone who sees the Smash titles as some of the most polished games ever made, this is a big compliment.

The graphics  are a simple, 2D, pixelated style often seen in indie games. While this is not out of the ordinary, the art direction and design of each character and stage conveys a unique sense of identity and place. This is the perfect example of a game that uses the pixelated 2D style that is so common and elevates it, making it something original and aesthetically pleasing. I like the choice of anthropomorphic animals, as it ties in well with the four elements theme the game has.

Overall, this is a great game, and one of the best early access titles I've ever played. While I usually avoid early access titles, as they can feel half-baked and unfinished, this game is an exception to that rule. The base mechanics and gameplay are all here, and the additional content to come will simply add to an already great experience. If you want to wait until all of the content is out, feel free, but if you buy now you are still getting a great experience, and will have reason to revisit the game later once further content is released. The game is already in a polished, playable, and (most importantly) fun state, and I whole-heartedly recommend a purchase, especially if you can hook up 4 controllers and gather some friends around your TV or monitor.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals Of Aether is a taste of Melee tech mixed with a more accessible and colorful cast of characters.
I've spent some time playing and following different streams, and everyone seems to think that a different character is OP. This indicates to me that the game is pretty well balanced. While a cast of 6 may seem slightly underwhelming, there are no clones and each Rival has a very unique playstyle with special setups. This means that the player is likely to play all of the characters with equal interest, as opposed to solely maining one in any another fighting game. 
The soundtrack is very reminiscient of the SNES days, and the pixel art and animations are cute and pleasing. 
Rivals already has me hooked, and it's only in alpha. I highly recommend it.

10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review: If you're a fan of SmashBros then you'll absolutley love this game! Most of the mechanics are the same except you can't grab on ledges but instead jump off walls and use your up special again, and the shield is replaced with parries which can stun the oppent for a short time. This adds a lot of variety to the game such as edgegaurding and comboing ( yes, combos longer than 2 or 3 hits) which makes the game a refreshing vamp to smashbros. The characters are all developed in depth with different abilitites making the small pool of characters available understandable. The gameplay is adtoundingly fun and I find myself doing quick matches in between homework or chores or whatnot. As of now it looks like the game has potential to go competitive, so keep you're eye on this game ;). If you have any doubt about buying this game, watch the videos of gamelplay on youtube while the game is installing.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Great game.  Similar to Smash Bros Melee.  No grabs, shields, or edge grabbing.  Everyone can wall jump.  Wavedashing is easy.  Steamworks is already integrated, so online is great (when it works).  It's still a bit buggy, but that's to be expected from an early access release.

In its current state it's a very fun and competitive game that gets your blood pumping.  If you enjoy fighting games, Rivals of Aether will feel great to you.  I've definitely already got my $15 out of it already.  Excited to see how this game's development progresses.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Rival's of Aether is like a piece of pie.  It's really good while you're eating it but once you're done than you don't have any pie.  This game has single-handedly made me believe that a whole genre of games could go down as the worst of my personal gaming history.  Honestly this game is supposed to be like the game Super Smash Brother's Melee when in fact it is close to the new League of Legends Juggernaut update.  Every character has some stupid gimmick that literally just wants to make you scream what the fuck.  In the end though you had some pie so it may be alright.  Writing this review has given me more joy than my 27 minutes of this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Do I recommend this game? Yes and No.

This game has amazing potential, but despite its quality, it's lacking in content.

- 1 on 1 Online
- 6 playable characters
- 5 Stages (With the ability to toggle each for a Final Destination-y version)
- AI that can scale in difficulty

For some, the gameplay alone can justify countless hours with a friend, While others will shy away due to poor online connectivity and a lack of variety.

I will shelve this game for now, but you can bet your bottom dollar that I'll be back when this game finally leaves Early Access.

No Nude Tayne 0/10.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is spectacular. Would recommend to all Smash Brothers fans and fighting game aficionados across the Steam platform. Take a break from Street Fighter and Tekken and play a game where you can make your own combos with such a small amount of moves; plus, it's a break from the ultra-realistic 3D gore and special effects. ^^;

My second time trying out a game such as this (after prior experience with Smash Brothers' replicas such as Super Smash Flash 2), I was exepcting something less impressive or similar to all the others. The controls are easy to adjust to and pick up, especially if you're using an XBOX PC controller, then it plays like a dream. The pixel-art is amazing, kudos to all those involved in this game, amazing animation and stage design. The characters, I thought there would be at least one or two characters I wouldn't want to play with, but after around a few hours of gameplay, I'm comfortable with them all. The moveset for each character is rather unique; no repetition whatsoever. Hopefully, other online modes will be available in the future, but hey, baby steps. This is only early access and I'm already impressed. I procastinated over my homework to play a couple more hours of this game. I can see that there are some suggested features but not available for choice. Such as 'Online' in the options menu and the other spaces in the character roster. I'm most looking forward to Story Mode and Aether Mode; curious as to how this will be executed. 

:)

Still hard to believe this was made in Gamemaker:Studio.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is, as you've probably gathered at this point, a Smash Bros style game. It sets itself apart by being more aggressive than Smash has become and having extremely unique characters. Ever character has their own little set of gimmicks and tricks, such as Kragg's ability to create a pillar and block that effectively act as part of the stage until destroyed, or Orcane's ability to lay down a puddle he can teleport to or "burn" for a blast of bubbles. As a result most of the characters play quite a bit differently and become fairly technical (though some are still fairly simple to pick up and play; notably Zetterburn and Kragg). It gives the game a sense of depth I feel Smash is somewhat lacking and really reinforces the differences between a so called "platform fighter" and a standard fighter. Stage awareness becomes much more important as well as an understanding of your opponents capabilities.

The game also has some key differences from smash in terms of standard gameplay, namely that ledge grabbing is not a thing, all characters can wall jump (gaining a second use of their recovery as a result) and there's no shielding, only "parrying" (which stuns opponents for a period based off how powerful the move was). As noted previously, the game is more aggressive, and this is partially why. Recovering becomes a lot trickier with no ledge to grab and having to effectively time your "shield" makes it harder to turn back an offensive. Oh, and unlike later Smashes, comboing is very much a thing in this game.

With that, you may be wondering if this is a game you should try casually. The game, while more aggressive, is still quite accessible to new people. The more aggressive mechanics aren't burdensome for the most part and just require some adjustment. About the only thing to keep in mind is that wave-dashing is in game, and while infinitely easier than Melee, is still something casual players will likely to find too much of a pain to bother with. This shouldn't effect most players anyway. 

NOTE: Currently the game is early access, and online is 1 vs 1 only on random stages with no hazards. If this is a dealbreaker for you, you may want to wait.

So honestly, I strongly suggest giving this game a shot. For fifteen dollars getting an awesome Smash-esque experience on the PC is super worth it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Connections Issues is why I cant recommend this game, right now at least.

So far the game has been fun playing with friends, online with randos is a different story.  The competiton is even so far but about 1/2 games have disconnected mid way through a fight.  The lag will start then slowly characters freeze then you get hit with a disconnect.  Once the server issues have been fixed this game will get better.  This game is a blast when the servers arent having issues.  I have real solid internet so I know its not me.

Right now Im goin to not recommend this game.  If you are planning on playing random people online exclusively wait on this game, but local play is great.  Once server issues are fixed ill change my recommendation to yes.

Also, this game needs 2v2 or a 4 player free for all online mode desperately.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is a great little game that is very fun as is and has a lot of potential.

It is a platform fighter (AKA "Smash-clone")  It uses many of the same concepts as Smash and is fairly technical.  The key difference so far is that there are not blocks or grabs/throws.  Instead of a block you have dodge/parry button.  

The dodging works similarly to Smash.  However, if you hold still and hit dodge you will parry. The parry works somewhat like parrys in Street Fighter III.  If you parry an attack, you recover more quickly than the attacker, which gives you a chance to counter or escape.  Since there is no block, grabs/throws are not really needed.

Also, there are no items.

The balance of the characters seems good so far and each character is pretty unique.  The netcode for online play seems to be more than adequate as far as I can tell.

Seems to me they just need to add more characters and make the 4 player free-for-all available online and we will have a great little Smash alternative for PC.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is amazing!!  This is that one game like rocket leauge that everyone should just HAVE so you can use it to settle arguments. ;)

But in all seriousness, amazing game.  I thought it was going to be awesome and it was even better than I had expected. I've been playing for a few days now and it's really awesome to already see people getting better in online matches! There's a real feeling of a community when playing against others. It's a game that feels very reminisent of Smash Bros. Melee, which I personally loved, among millions of others. I mean come on! This game has Wavedashing!! What could get better!?

It takes all of the bad things from games such as Melee and changes thenm to make it better. The stages are more interesting, the characters are wacky, and the moves are so unorthodox that the smash series wouldn't even dare to try something like this, but Rivals of Aether really pulled it off and made it outstanding.

+Great Stages
+Wacky Fun Characters
+Puts A New Twist On Fighting Games
+Gameplay Is Incredibly Smooth
+Online Play Is Lagless (or as close to)

-Have To Wait For An Amazing Story Mode ;)

DEFINITLY worth 15$

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
pretty fun game, more akin to melee than the other smash games, but still unique enough that its fresh to play. obviously, first week of early access there's going to be problems and some balancing issues; there's also the fact that half the game is not yet avalible, so bear that in mind when getting it. It does come with offline play against bots, local pvp, and an online 1v1 3 stock mode, which is pretty fun (side note on how the online play is: for the most part, I've had decent connectivity while playing others, 3/10 I'll get someone with chuggy internet, but overall its good enough to play properly). As far as playable characters, it seems 6/8 of them are availible to play, I'm don't know if word has been spoken on the release date of the other two, but I can't imagine it will be too long. I'm not sure what else to say about this... Good animation, great character design (although, based on each character's backstory, it seems like there's an actual plot and that might mean a campaign mode? could be fun), and nice crisp control of you character. Takes only a lil bit to get used to the mechanics and you can remap your controls on your controller/keyboard (sidenote #34: now i have this generic china made fake xbox controller i use for ps games and havent yet had trouble with it, but some people have had trouble getting their controllers working in game and thankful, some nice ass people posted a guide in the discussion section of the community hub for setting up your controller to work in RoA).

all in all i really enjoy the game and think it came into beta looking really nice, which just makes me look forward to how its going to be fleshed out in the next 6 months. at this bit of the game, i think its version 0.0.3 (?), ill give it a 8/10 based only on whats available. if i include whats not in there and how its not yet availiable, 7/10. get this game and get this community going, its worth it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
THIS GAME. IS. AWESOME! Best $15 I've spent in a LONG time! Unlike what people have been saying, it's really not just a Smash clone. It's so similar, yet so different. Similar in a good way, so it feels natural to Smash players. Different in a few MAJOR factors: No blocking, no grabbing, no ledges, and every character is unique in some way.
Want an ACTUALLY stealthy character? Forsburn is perfect. A character that can teleport between "portals" they lay down? You won't find anyone like Orcane in Smash. Or how about someone who can make ENTIRE WALLS right below him, instantly? That would be Kragg.

So basically, this game is different enough from Smash to be fun for Smash players, yet similar enough so it's easy to learn. I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who likes Smash, or anyone looking for a good, easy to run fighting game that's good for partys.

Complaints: Spam is a little hard to deal with in this game, especially Zetterburn fireball spam. That's really it. I do wish they added support for the Gamecube to USB adapters, as Gamecube controllers just feel much more precise than Xbox 360 controllers, but that's just a minor complaint.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I'm a Super Smash Bros junky, so I have been following Rivals of Aether’s development for months now.  Its finally here, and it doesn't disappoint.  I love the offensive nature of this game when compared to recent Smash Bros titles.  

There are NO Shields, Throws, or Ledge Grabs. A simple Dodge button replaces Shield/Grab and it allows you to Pairy, Roll and Air Dodge. A Pairy is a lot like executing a Perfect Shield in Super Smash Bros. There is stick timing and it puts your opponent in stun so you can go on the counter attack.  Using Roll as a defensive option on the ground is not nearly as effective as it is in Super Smash Bros Wii U/3DS, for example. In the air you can Dodge in any direction, but only once before touching the ground again.

Super Smash Bros Melee featured a movement technique called Wavedashing. By Jump Canceling your Air Dodge into the ground diagonally in either direction you can slide across you ground, allowing for fast micro spacing that could be used both offensively and defensively. This technique makes its spiritual return to the Smash genre in RoA.

Edgeguarding an opponent attempting to return to the stage has always been a core of competitive Smash gameplay. Although you cannot Ledge Grab in RoA that hasen't changed. Players returning to the stage in RoA will find themselves with more resourses than a typical Smash game. Every character has a Wall Jump. Not only that, but you can Wall Jump even after using an Up Special and going into Free Fall. You can also use your Up Special again after a Wall Jump. This mean recovering from the depths is possible even without being able to grab the ledge.  

With all these unique gameplay elements Rivals of Aether definately brings a fresh take to the Smash genre of fighting games!

review: Honestly amazing from what I have seen so far. This game stays true to its goal of bringing smash to pc, not only does it have the feel of melee but it isnt just a clone unlike all the other browser based smash games. The characters are honestly my favorite part about it, every single one feels 100% viable from a competetive aspect. Even Kragg, who fills the role of the slow paced big character, which usually is out of place in the smash games, feels great and playable against the rest of the cast. All of the cast feels vibrant and different from the rest which is amazing to see. For example my favorite (orcane) has entire strings that are possible off of a bubble detonation from a puddle. In a competetive fighting game, diversity is a GREAT thing to see, as it keeps the game fresh. It gets tiring to see the same characters all the time. From my short time playing it I can already see this game has immense potential in both a competetive sense and just for casual fun with friends. I would definetly reccomend this to anyone who is a fan of the smash franchise or just fun in general.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
If you like competitive Smash Bros, get this game. It may look like a simple copy-and-paste of SSBM for the Gamecube, but this game is NOT just a Melee clone. For starters, it removes the mechanics of shielding, grabbing, and ledge-grabbing. Shielding is replaced by "parrying", which is an alternative to counters from Smash. So basically, no one's Down-B slot is taken up by some stupid counter. The absence of ledge-grabbing makes off-stage play intense and gratifying. Combo potential, on-stage and off-stage, is fantastic. And of course, it's no competitive Smash-style fighting game without wavedashing and L-cancelling, both made way easier. And the characters are unique, some invent new ways to control the stage (like Orcane's puddles or Forsburn's smoke), while others take inspiration from well-known Smash Bros playstyles and revamp them. Forsburn takes aerial and tilt inspiration from Marth, but his Side B creates a clone of himself that reminds me of Ice Climbers. Wrastor has the unstoppable airgame of Jigglypuff, but his attacks on the ground parallel Captain Falcon, Falco, and Meta Knight. Zetterburn, the game's main mascot, takes Bowser's strong attacks and mixes it with Fox's specials. But even with these comparisons, experience in playing Jigglypuff will not translate over to Wrastor. Experience with Bowser will not make you instantly understand Zetterburn. 
So, a recap: Takes best parts of competitive Smash Bros and revamps them, combos and techniques are easier to learn for casuals, characters will remind you of popular Smash characters but make them new. Oh, and the music and art are great as well. 
I'll rate this game A Bag of Chips/10. It has all you love about Smash Bros, from the competitive to the casual. And it adds awesome advancements to the game, making it accessible for all players but still appealing to the competitive audience. It's all that Melee is, and a bag of chips!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Awesome game! I've been anticipating this game since only Zetterburn and Orcane were out, so I'm super stoked that it's out now. However, note that this early access version may not be for everyone. While I personally LOVE this game and love being a part of the early access development, some may want to wait until the full release. I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone as $15 is a great price for even a full game, but you may want to consider a few things before buying:
[list]
[*]As of now, I've found that many people of the RoA community are from some part of competitive SSB. This may appeal to some, but may make others wary of purchasing the game due to the large skill gap if you haven't played a smash game before.
[*]This games meta is not at all yet developed. Some characters are broken and some seem to be lacking. I personally think it'll be awesome to see how the game is balanced as the meta progresses, but some might get frusturated by these early issues. For example, right now a lot of people are getting extremely frusturated with Zetterburn as his f-smash kills at really early percents. I'm not sure if this will be patched later, but if you get frusturated with games that aren't balanced, you might want to wait until the full release of this game to buy.
[*]Building off the first point, if you really want to learn the meta to this game you will need to proactively look to get better. Wavedashing and other advanced tech are not explained as this game assumes you have prior SSBM experience. This isn't really a negative, but it is something to consider.
[*]Again, this is an *early access* build, it does not have all features that the final build will have. There are a limited number of characters and stages in thi build, not that it makes it any worse, but if you're not into early access stuff you might want to hold off.
[/list]
Those are just a few things to consider before buying the early access build of RoA, but like I said I would recommend this game to anyone who is willing to learn it! While it may sound like I was just bashing this game, I love it and think it has way more pros than cons:
[list]
[*]This game is very fast due to little lag and minimal defensive options. Parries sound broken at first but cannot be spammed as easily as you'd think.
[*]Combos feel great to pull off.
[*]Character depth is insane. Each character has its own stage control options, adding a slightly neglected aspect to this genre (with exceptions being characters like Snake and Rosalina).
[*]Stages are extremely interesting. Not all platforms are level with each other or even making for interesting combos and playstyles.
[*]Lots of support from the developers! I can tell Dan is very passionate about this game and wants to make sure everyone likes it as much as possible!
[*]It's fun! The game feels nice. Doesn't feel like Melee nor PM, but like its own game. The roots, of course, are obvious, but it's very impressive that this doesn't just feel like a knock off clone!
[/list]
So overall, I would definitely recommend this game. Yeah, there are a couple things to consider if you're new to SSB style games, but if you're a veteran or willing to take the risk then you should definitely buy this!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
So far, the game is fantastic (as long as you bring along your Dual Shock 4 :) ). The characters are all very unique and interesting, the levels are lovingly crafted, each with clever mechanics, but most importantly, the game is a blast. So many Smash Bros. clones fail to copy what it is that makes the series so special, but Rivals of Aether nails it, and as a result, may end up becoming a Rival of Smash Bros. in the future. Hope to see more characters and levels soon!

The only slight issue I'd say needs to be worked out is the "down charged" attack. It's quite difficult to pull this off a lot of the time as the game seems to have trouble distinguishing between down and forward "charged attacks".

If you're a fan of 2d fighting games (Smash bros being the most notable),  this game is almost a definite buy. If you've ever played Super Smash Flash, this game is very similar in art style and handling. There's only 6 playable characters as of now, but at least two more are expected to be added. There's also some balancing issues (Kragg and Forsburn being the most powerful), but every character has a unique playstyle, and there's no clear cut matchups -- It's all about playstyle. 

Overall, the game is super fun, especially if you enjoy the Smash Bros series, and definitely worth the price of $15.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is addicting. For the price, it's well worth your money whether you're looking to play Smash but don't have a Nintendo console or are already really into Smash. There's a lot this game offers. The character roster may look small, yes. Right now it has a mere 6 fighters with 2 more to be released by the game's launch, and only 5 stages with 3 more to be released, but the depth the gameplay brings to the table is so engaging that I find it hard for me to not look forward to coming back to it again and again. 

The fighters take a lot from multiple Smash characters and mix them into one but a lot of their movesets and specials are so unorthodox from Smash that it's a breath of fresh air for avid fans like myself. The major differences you'll notice right away are that there is no ledge grabbing and there is no shielding. You can wall jump (usually) after doing your up special and you can parry attacks (hitting the block button exactly when the other person's move would hit you). It leaves them vulnerable for a second for you to counter-attack. It fits with the game's playstyle and it's really cool to see new takes on standard Smash mechanics. 

Wavedashing is also here, and it's much easier to do than in any of the Smash games. No character has a short wavedash, so it's viable for everybody and useful to learn and apply to your fighting eventually. Overall I'd rate this game a 9.5/10, would be a perfect score but for real can we please nerf Zetterburn and Kragg a bit? Thanks.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Take everything you know about Smash Bros., reskin it to make everyone an animal, and pixellate it. Now remove the shields, the camping, and bring back directional airdodging. Rivals of Aether, everybody. This game brings out the best traits from each game (yes, including you Project M, BUT NEVER BRAWL) and places them all in a beautifully rendered setting. The Aether mode stages (stages with hazards) cater to people just wanting to play some Smash without playing Smash, while the Basic mode (stages without hazards) offers the unique platform designs of the stages without the competitively unbalancing hazards. The stage diversity is nice, and, while only have 6 characters at time of writing, each character brings their own neat gimmick or movement option that keeps you drawn in. All-in-all, worth buying in early access.

My final rating: 10/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game, as of 0.0.2 (9/24) is loads of fun. 

Pros:
-Incredibly easy to pick up (I mean seriously easy, you probably know most of the combos just from even watching melee)
-Cool characters
-Each character is unique
-Online is good with randoms
-It has Wrastor
-Wavedashing feels great
-Chrono Trigger-ish music

Cons:
-Balancing isn't great, as it's first day. Maypul is pretty bad and Zetterburn is too good.
-Online with friends has huge amounts of delay (why?)
-Wavedashing is not really needed in this game
-Not enough characters
-Not enough maps
-Not enough Chrono Trigger music
-Absa not included

Extra:
-There are no ledges in this game
-No grabs
-No shield (although there are frame parries)
-Maps have hazards

Now it seems like that's a lot of cons, but trust me, this game kicks ass. It's fun and fast paced and really easy to learn. I suck at melee and PM and am only good at smash 4, although this game feels completely natural. I play on a 360 controller, so it did take time to learn some things, but it's really good all around. Recommend to anyone that has ever, EVER played a smash game before. It's a good detatchment from smash, as it feels incredibly similar, but at the same time, incredibly different. You never notice how much shields, grabbing, and ledges affect gameplay speed until you take it out. The two big problems I have with this game is the balancing, which is an easy fix if they ask around on Reddit or something, and the amount of characters. We need more! We want more! We want more because we like this game!

Good job, Dan Fornace. As I mostly play games just to play games, I play this one because it's fun. Oh, and I guess the other smash games too, I guess.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Boring. Controls and mechanics feel clunky. I'm a daily Project M player and would much rather play that than this. If you play PM, Melee Brawl or Smash 4 on anywhere near a regular basis don't let the videos fool you...this game fails to really even compete or compare.  I thought it could bring something new to the table but after 16 minutes of play I'm convinced even if I did keep this game in my library it would take a second seat to any Smash brothers game quickly. Refund pending.

overall its a pretty solid game IMO.
8/10

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Honestly I love this game it is a great change of pace from smash 4 and melee but it needs some work and thankfully its early access so it will get that work. What does it need you ask well I will tell you in a multitude of rants please join me below.....

Edit: I just wanna mention for the people who say that the servers are bad I have had zero problems with lag or DCing yall need better internet I think cause I have had 100% smooth gaming online,

(Start the rant here) 
First things first you should not be ably to spam your f-tilt and win that should not in any way shape or form work. You also should not be able to play Zetterburn and spam side b and down b while yeah sure i can go Zetterburn and spam too and I usually win that fight problem is thats no fun I don't want to have to counter pick characters this isn't Pokemon is it? The fact that Zetterburn is the only character who has a form of projectile camping is an issue. 

(Zetterburn in a nutshell ... "rivals of aether was such a great game... But that all changed when the fire nation attacked")

I realise we have parrying in the game and yes it reflects them just like a perfect shield in smash but the fact is why can he camp give someone else a projectile or an actual reflector I don't know. Now parrying that is another one of my issues with this game. Whle yes the system is really cool and original you shouldn't be able to spam parry and win the game cause for some reason it is 100% possible. Put more lag on it or something don't remove its usefulness obviously but make it riskier for more than just Maypul to use cause for some reason hers is like 2 frames slower which makes no sense why do i have to learn multiple parry timings? And yet again I know i can run up and bait the parry get in a combo and then bait the parry and get a combo and bait the parry and get a combo you see where I am going its boring as all hell. Anyways I'll stop complaining.
(Rants over don't worry) 

 Now for the actual review. This game is great buy it if you enjoy playing smash with your friends. Or enjoy any fighting game with your friends. But thats where the fun stops for now. Online is full of spamming and for some reason only 2 characters Zetterburn and Wrastor. But for some nice couch co-op with friends this game is super fun. 

As far as controls I am personally using a gamecube controller and it feel soooooo good. It took some work to get it to work but man it feels like I am playing smash. Movement is god like you can dash dance super easy wavedashing is in here too and it is also super easy. 

(Wavedash rant)
Although I have one small bone to pick with the wave dash. Why did you put it in here? nothing has lag at all. You can do everything but F-tilt out of a dash. and everything auto cancels on its own. So why is it here for the show i guess cause I see no use for it. Now if you couldn't do literally everything out of a dash maybe it would be used more. Atleast as far as I have seen it doesn't help anyone do anything so for now it is just random flashy tech to show your buddies. atleast it would be if it wasn;t the easiest thing to do ever.
(Another rant down)

So what we have here is

Pros: 
A smash like fighting game that works well
God like controls and movement (serious props for that one guys)
Nicely designed original characters (inspiration from smash but all different in their own way)
Awesome stages (wheres FD guys.. in 20xx I want Zetterburn only no items Final Destination)
Seriously great music like wow I want a sound track 
Great couch co-op gameplay (sadly being lost in todays gaming thanks for keeping the dream alive)

Cons: 
Unbalanced fighters (not super bad but need works I know its in alpha)
Limited fighters to chose from (More on the way so this ones kind of a for the moment thing)
Limited stages to chose from (again more on the way so as i stated above it's for the moment)
Lack of options 
^(What I mean by this is you can do 2 things when you aproach A. attack B. parry yep thats about it. Now I am not saying it is a bad thing I like it but it leads to whoever gets that first actual hit off gets the game basically.)
(Hitstun Rant)
 Hitstun is forever I mean forever in this game so any attack you are hit by leads to another and another and another. If each player is good that is you read the di you attack you read the di and attack. I know they don;t want to make it an exact clone of smash but I mean grabs would be nice or just one more option like a spot dodge that would be easy to put in and very useful.)
(end the final rant I think)

All in all as I stated above I love this game it is so good just al little tlc and I think it could grow pretty big. To melee levels no sorry not gonna happen but it will take off quick as it is so yeah. Thats my review great game with alot of potential. 

(One last thing is it just me or do we need an avatar character you know master of all the elements? ... just a thought ...)

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Combines the feel of all the Smash games! Playing defensively is rewarded, playing offensively is rewarded, there is no losing style! 2 hours and it is already on my favorites. The key, and my favorite difference is you know in smash playing as diddy where in order to get some of the best comboes you need to be juggling banana peels? Every character feels like that. You need to set up traps, etc... to get things to really heat up!

Edit: 8 hours straight marathon playing update! The counter mechanic replacing sheild and grabbing is insanely satisfying. Makes fighting in the air safer, but fighting on the ground is just so dang hectic. Seriously if you are on the fence... Grab the dang game. If you like smash brothers at all you will love this game. Be careful heading online if you are casual though. Playing people online has taught me so much, and the game is insanely deep. I don't know how good match making is considering I mostly just destroy people, and occasionally cant even touch the other guy. It is pretty high level in there. If you do not know what a  wavedash is, stay off the online match making. :)

title: Rivals of Aether
review: A Smash game build by competitive Smash players, RoA delvers deceptively complex play while simplifying the controls and techniques of the game it pays homage to. Every character has a unique feel and a large amount of room for skilled players to find combos, advanced techniques, and movement options. The lack of grabbing, shielding, and ledges feels extremely odd at first, but the refinement of wall jumping and the parry system will soon make it feel fluid and fast paced.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: this game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. if you were always impressed by super smash bros melee's incredibly fast and precise pro gameplay, but couldnt emulate the movement and combos yourself, this is THE game for you. automatic L cancelling, easier wavedashing, easier short hopping, easier inputs in general, yet very similar types of mind games and what im calling a "freestyle" type of combo system. The online function works very well too, little to no lag. Super cool characters, Super fun game, BUY IT

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Rivals of Aether is a game clearly inspired by the Super Smash Bros. series, but with it's own innovation on the formula. The core idea is the same: Deal as much damage as possible to your opponent as possible, while taking the least you can. Higher damage means you get sent farther when hit, ultimately resulting in players being sent flying off stage, either colliding with the end of the screen and dying, or being forced to try and make their way back to the stage with their opponent actively trying to prevent it.

If you're looking for a fun fighting game featuring some stellar game design, you've come to the right place.

If you are a fan of Smash, you absolutely need to play this game. The unique mechanics it brings to the table make it familiar but also a breath of fresh air.

Even though there are only six this can keep you entertained for a very very long time. The art is great as well a nice reminiscence to snes graphics. The characters all look great and playing them just makes me feel like a megaman x boss, and thats sick. Overall this is probably the best early access game i've ever had the pleasure of playing. Buy it.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
k. this isnt professional or anythin so ya. deal with it. 

this game is good for what it does. Its smash for the pc, but not at the same time.

think of it like this.

The game plays and feels like smash bros. The characters each handle differently with different and with diverse movesets.

But..... on the other hand those characters are so unorthadox that Smash would never ever consider this. 
 
No ledge game, you get 1 wall jump and 2 Up+b if you can even make it to the wall

DI is still a thing. Teching is not. Air dodging has the same properties as melee. But no wavedashing (ive tried) 

Game feels rough. Online can range from absolute joke to amazing. Its not complete by anymeans. 

Soundtrack is well done. Spritework is good but is a bit choppy (plz fix) 

Overall..... its good for what it does. its a smash game for the pc. best one ive played. 

(This game supports GC controllers. Go get one before playing this. its makes it SO much more fun. they even have a guide set up on how to do it.)

So my opinion. Dont get unless your a fan of smash and want something to play. if your a laptop user with a nvidia card, u dont get f**ked by optimus. IF your not into fighting games, this is a good one to pick up for casual gameplay vs bots. Newcomers to this style, just pick up a gamecube or wii and a copy of smash. its better and it will give you a handle on how this works, then come back to this. However if you dont want to that then buyer beware. 

Final Verdict. 6.5/10 Its good for what it does. its fun, its enjoyable, its good to look at. But smash is not gonna be cloned anytime soon, but this was a DAMN good attempt at it.

So let me start off this by saying that this game is great... it is beyond great... it is absolutely amazing. Even with the short time I have played this work of art, I can say that this is a must buy game for any smash enthusiasts like myself. However, it does have its differences to smash with makes it feel like a whole new game rather than a cheap spinoff. The controls are very simple. I play on a xbox 360 controller and it feels amazing. I know that I will be playing this game for a very long time!

I recomend this to anyone thinking about buying this game and to anyone who loves smash.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Great fighter with alot of similarities to the smash series.
The 8-bit art style is great and reminds me of http://www.supersmashland.com/
I believe Orcane is modeled after vaporeon in that game, my favorite character.

Things that could be better:
-AFKers in online matchmaking currently (9/23/15) aren't removed from being paired with you
-When binding keyboard controls, you cannot choose to change a menu button unless you also change the in-combat button as well for a single key.
-Had to use xpadder, game doesn't work with my logitech controller
-Matchmaking often pairs you with someone across the country, resulting in 1 player with a lot of lag.

I give this game a solid 8.5/10

The gameplay is great, and I can't wait for the adventure-style mode,
and am looking forward to the last 2 characters being released.

review:
Its a good smash brothers like game. I think the character design is a bit better then smash brothers, and the combat feels good. However, the number of characters and content is very small.

Further, this game was made in gamemaker, and while that itself does not mean the game is bad, anyone who has used game maker knows that its a pain to code anything serious in. On that point, I would be surprised if this game gets any significant update in terms of scope.

All that said, the designers clearly have a good design concept and I would love to see what the director could do with better resources.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
What it does right:
1. Competitively viable.
2. Plays and feels like a mix of SSB4, Melee, and early Street Fighter titles.
3. Multiple stage versions (like the version of the walkoff stage that, well, doesn't have a walkoff).

What it needs:
1. A grab.
2. Built-in support for various popular controllers (I had to remap my GCN controller in JoyToKey).
3. Nametags to define control schemes (just like in Brawl/PM/Wii U).
4. Online game modes such as Doubles, Casual, Competitive, and With Friends.

What I want:
1. Stage builder? Please?
2. Optional mouse navigation of the menus.
3. Smoother animations. The current ones are satisfying and all, but the frame rate of them is very low. The game would feel a lot better and moves would be more distinct as a result.

--

This is the single best Early Access game I've EVER played. Here's to hoping that it gets big enough to make an appearance in fighting game tournament series such as EVO.

EDIT

I forgot to mention that Kragg is OP as fuck and anyone who plays him is a scumbag.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game have truly potential, the gameplay is an outburst that reminds Smash Bros. Melee at his best but with a twist and some more. No ledges but wall climbing, no shield or grabbing but parry and wavedashing. This changes make feel the gameplay very dynamic, very wise decisions.
And what about the character desing?, POKEMON 100%, great art design with that mix between 8 and 16 bits era. Besides the music, pure and gorgeous 8-bit mixes, really beautiful. BTW, this game could pass like a beta, quadruplicating the amount of characters and they have a full release, easily.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is what an amazing alternative to the Smash bros-esque gameplay that we all know and love. Its suprisingly well balanced for just having hit early access and brings some new fun mechanics to the table while removing things such as grabs and shields, opting for a perry system to maintain a faster pace in gameplay. The developer seems to have a realistic plan that he's serious about completing involving more exciting content that will add to both the multiplayer and single player experience. The game right now has some of the best netplay ive ever seen in a fighting game and even though right now there is only 1v1 matchmaking the developer has confirmed that they are working on having more players in lobbys. 

Already its a great game and i believe it will be even better in the future, its definitely worth 15$ and hours of your time.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
THAT AIN'T FALCO.

On a serious note, this game is amazing :>. As someone who plays Smash competitively in huge cities, I can tell you now this game combines a lot of Smash elements (obviously but, it's from different series).

You get, the intensity of Melee in fights.
A speed in my opinion is between Smash 4 and Melee.
The flexibility of combos in Smash 64.
The ease of controllability of Smash 4.

And thank god, nothing from Brawl.

Overall, it's a pretty good fighting game.

I'm looking forward to online play with Teams~.

title: Rivals of Aether

title: Rivals of Aether
review: This game is very addicting for people who like Super Smash Bros. esque mechanics. I highly suggest purchasing it if you are interested and have a friend or two to play it with. That being said, at the time of this review it is just now in early access, so it's not without its faults. All of the time I've spent online (which has been about 1 hour total) has been ridiculously high on input lag, making it virtually unplayable. I also don't reccomend it for people who aren't going to be playing with a friend for the time being. The game doesn't have all of its single player content, so if you don't have anyone to play with, it's just fighting cpus and laggy online players. Overall I've had a very enjoyable time with the game and seeing as it's in early access, there is probably a lot more content to look forward to making for even more fun.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
A more accessible Smash-esque game than Melee without all of the "dumbing-down" which afflicted Brawl and Smash 4.  Most of the overhead of Melee which was required for competitive play, such as L-cancelling and wavedashing, has been simplified without a significant narrowing of the skill gap.  Would be even better with a larger character and stage selection, but that will come in time.

Looking forward to a competitive scene developing for this game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: For supposedly being in version 0.0.2 or however, it feels fully fleshed, at least in terms of moment to moment gameplay. Each character has a game-changer ability or two that can modify the playing field, from obscuring vision, teleportation, to adding additional blocks and platforms. These strong abilities definitely create a creative space to play around with how best to combo and mixup opponents. The online matches are best of 3 and you can find a new opponent after a set, which is so much better than dropping out in smash 4 every time you want a fresh opponent. As well the net code seems to be a lot more responsive than smash. It's a refreshing take on what makes the smash series great.

I do enjoy the play style as it is different but it is far from balanced.  3 of the Characters are just straight better than the others.  I do reccomend it especially if it gets cheaper but you need to have a group of friends and 4 controllers to make it fun.  Don't expect to be playing online.

Only thing I'd really say is lacking is the online gameplay. Personally I just can't get a match that's not a complete laggy mess and precise inputs are key for this kind of game.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: For those of you who love Super Smash Brothers, this is the game for you.  It is a Smash like fighting game in which you damage other players in order to knock them off the screen.  The great thing about Rivals of Aether vs a Smash game is that it's mechanically less intensive.  The game doesn't need L-Canceling while keeping wavedashing fair, but not needed to play well.  Shields are also removed replaced by a parry mechanic.  The game is an incredible joy to play and for $15 is a great value for the entertainment of playing with friends.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
For a guy who played super smash bros for a long time this game is a really worthy competitor. 

It features 6 character at the moment, 8 when it comes out of Early Access. That's the only negative point I could imagine. Every Char plays completly different so 6 chars at the moment are totally okay. I would like to have like 14-18 chars at the end of Early Access. That wouldn't be that much of a problem because all the chars come from a different element. So there are enough possibilitys I think. 

The online-play is great and the lag comprensation is fair for both players. If someone has a bad internet, there will be slow downs for both players. Good job!

The maps are based on the elements, too, and are very good. 

All in all it's a really good brawler and every char is great in it's own way. For 15€ you can have fun for hours and there is still more content to come. I totally recommend this game to every brawler-fan. <3

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
It's like Smash! But it's not Smash!

This game solves all the problems you never noticed were keeping you from liking Smash. Things like Ledge Invincibility and Guarding that make the game slow and lame when the fun part of Smash is the dance: trying to tease your opponent into your hitboxes while weaving between theirs.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is the new game a lot of Super Smash Bros. fans have been waiting for. This game feels very fresh, but still familiar. I think I'm enjoying this more than any other Early Access game I've purchased. The graphics are nostalgic and crisp, the gameplay is very solid, and online play works very well if you have a reasonable ping/connection speed.

There's currently only 6 characters available, but 2 more are to be released when the game is officially out. There is a small handful of stages to pick from, each giving you a "basic" or "aether" variation. The "basic" versions remove walk-offs, stage destruction and stage hazards, presumably for competitive play.

Much like the smash bros games, each character has 4 sets of moves. Regular attacks (think tilts), areal attacks, heavy attacks (think smash attacks), and special moves. But unlike smash bros, there is no shield button. There is a sort of spot-dodge like button that can be used to parry, but requires very goos timing. Also removed is the ability to grab the ledge. Instead, each character has the ability to wall jump, and use their up-special a 2nd time after the wall jump.

Balance might need a little work, but it's all there. Also do yourself a favor and get a USB GCN adapter instead of using the X360 controller. It just works so much better, despite the extra setup work it requires.

After being very disapointed in Smash 4, it's great to see a game that's really had some time and love put into it. Fantastic game, and I would HIGHLY recommend it to anyone.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Only just starting, and I'm already in love. 

It may at first seem like a super smash bros clone, but actually has a bit more unique character than you'd think. While it does borrow the same percentage/KO system from smash bros, the gameplay is a new animal entirely (no pun intended). No characters can grab the ledge, yet all can wall-jump, making recovery much more interesting and dangerous. No landing lag, allowing for a 0% to KO combos provided you don't miss any oppoprtunities. Unlike smash, you do not have any shield, and you can't grab. Instead, you "parry," Which is nothing like smash's defensive play at all. So far, Inturrupting a combo stream with a well timed parry is extremely satisfying. 

If you are a fan of super smash bros (especially Melee and project M) I cannot recommend this highly enough. It was made by a smash bros fan with smash bros fans in mind. However, there are some things you should know. This is a competitive game. It does not have the party gimmicks (items and final smash moves). It's made to be a sport. Also, we're still missing 2 characters and the entire story mode. It is early access after all. 

10/10 (so far)
I'm pretty sure I won't be playing anything else for a while.

EDIT: I learned how to do controller mapping!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
[strike]10/10 Like Smash Bros with Furries[/strike]

All joking aside, the first few hours of this game were a solid first impression. The character designs are all unique and charming in their own way. Each character has their own set of tools to use, and I can't name any "clone" characters on the roster. This game is also an interesting take on the Smash Bros style fighting game (this really should be a named genre instead of just "Smash Clone") in that it has mechanics of its own, such as the Parry. Wavedashing is easier to do than it was in Melee and Project M. 

My only gripe as of now is that the matches against random players online can be laggy, but most of the time the connection is decent.

My real score is 9/10. The -1 is just because the game isn't finished yet and there is some content I'd really like to see added, such as the two unlockable characters, the single player mode, and other options that are currently unavailable. The fact that these features are added as options but aren't accessible is at least a sign that the devs will deliver on these features.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Even in it's current state, Rivals of Aether is definitely a game I could not recommend more if you're into well-polished arena fighters akin to Smash Bros.

The Gameplay is very crisp and smooth (except when you get matched with people who have bad internet/netcode flubs, but that's to expect with any online games). The game has a small cast, but that clearly made it easier to balance. There doesn't seem to be any hard counters to a character; for the most part each of them have something for one another to be afraid of.

Graphics are clear, articulate and beautiful. Whoever did the spritework, major props. The music, while scarce, is very well-written and fits with the stages.

I'm looking forward to seeing this game progress!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This game is so fun. It is 2d smash bros with its percentages system, game play (if you have a controller) ad how they feel. The characters are unique and have their own special atributes that Smash can't really copy, like Orcane's puddles give him a teleport spot and powers his nex attack if he absorbs it. That's something new. It is very fast to learn them. They have great combos as well its pretty easy to learn after a few practice rounds with the AI. I have had a few problems with lag but overall it has been clear. The sprites are nice to look at and are so far very clear in indicating things like when someone is dodging. 
Complaints is that the battles only have one song which after trying out today is getting a little old already. The initial keybindings are weird they make no indication that you are supposed to hit Z to enter your choice on the menu. I would strongly recommend a controller for this game. The main concern is the limited roster of characters. It lets people know the characters very well, but even with 2 more I wonder if it will be enough variety. Overall its good fun, so if you like smash bros you'll like this.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
What a great game. I've heard of it since a few months back and heard a lot of positiv things about Rivals of Aether. Now I'm playing it and having a blast even though setting up a different controller was quite difficult since I don't enjoy the XBox controller with fighting games.

Other than that, it feels like a fast paced Smash-esque game with incredible selfmade combos, various movement options and good movesets for the characters.
Each of the characters brings something unique with their playstyle which makes finding your beloved rushdown- , spacing heavy or gimmicky character fast and easy to pick up.
The sound and music is fantastic and fits the grafics and theme overall.
The grafics, even though they are 2d sprites are well designed so much that every attack has it's quite distinguishable animation.

For the money in this state most people might seem scared of buying such an early acces title, but this one is a full fledged gaming experience with more to come with time.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: It's everything competitive Smash players want the game to be, but it stands out enough to not be a cheap cash in on Smash's success. The gameplay is fast, fun, and tech skill is there in bits and pieces, though it'd dumbed down some. The characters are all good when played right, the whole cast feels satisfying, and the engine is fantastic for the kind of game this is. The graphics look apprealing enough for a fighting game, but most of the presentation's shine is from the marvelous soundtrack. My only compaint is the input delay online, but that's not something easily fixed and it's splendid that we even have online multiplayer upon release. I'd complain about the lack of certain features, but they're present in the menus, implying they'll be added in the future. Theres almost nothing bad to say about this one, it's simply a brilliant play on the Smash formula

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I was a bit annoyed at first by the clunky keyboard controls. Plugged in an xinput controller, figured out how to change the controls on the controller to fit my SSB4 settings and this was the result:
-Fresh 2D gameplay
-UNIQUE character gameplay (hardly any skill overlaps, loads of fun mechanics and counterplay)
-Not too much imbalance. Fire does a bit more than I'd like as it basically makes a huge danger area for no reason at all.
-Easy to learn (after about an hour or two) but near impossible to master.

Negatives? Sometimes you are matched with the same 3 people with like 550 ping. Annoying. Also no chat, double edged sword right there. Less toxic, also less banter between people who want to compliment each other.

This is a game in ALPHA 0.0.2 or something. It FEELS finished.
With some new modes and a snazzy ranked system which allows you to dodge games with crazy pings, this game will be well worth it. Still have to test local party mode, looks fun.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
I really do enjoy this game and I will recomend it to anyone who has played Smash in general. Not just Melee. Here is why:

The combos are satisfying and not too difficult to pull off.

The developers got "Omega Stages" right.

They do take a bit of getting used to if you have played Smash, but the controls aren't too complicated.

Parrying is easy and dosen't require much practice unlike in Street Fighter 3.

I hardly came across any lag online.

The music puts a smile on my face, and I can't usually say that to describe music in a fighting game.

The  characters are balanced.

I do have one major problem about most of the players I find online, however. A really small amount of people I fight online actually want to play the game, and a large ammount just seem to want to kill themselves. I have come across so many people online that just kill themselves as soon as the match starts, so I hope the develpers can find a way around that problem.

Overall, Rivals Of Aether is a fun, satifying and smashing (I'm sorry) game that is barely flawed.

review:

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
Like Smash? Then this game is for you, simply put. 

By competitive players for competitive players. Though there certainly are options for the casual crowd, this game is largely designed for the level of depth, speed and fun brought forth by Super Smash Bros. 64 and Melee, tailored to boast the same accessibility of Sm4sh, with unique style and flair to give RoA its own identity.

In Rivals, gameplay guides character design. Since the cast is entirely original (with some animations borrowed from Smash) the devs have the freedom to keep the roster fit for specific playstyles. The goal for RoA was to create something more aggressive, and to accomplish that they threw out the concepts of shields, grabs, and ledge camping. Instead, we got parries, which are basically "power shields" that stun the enemy so you can punish them, and a very, very diverse combo game for all characters.

A lot of familiar mechanics show up in RoA: wavedash/land, dash dance, reverse aerial rush, and a slew of new advanced tech for the community to discover. Each character, based on one of four elements, has their own tech and traits that make them distinct. Zetterburn can light his enemies on fire for a DoT effect and burning enemies take increased knockback from strong (smash) attacks. Kragg, of the earth element, can change the stage using his up and neutral specials. He can create a giant rock pillar to wherever he is located, and pull a big, stone block to place and block enemy movement temporarily, or use as a projectile. Now apply that sort of diversity and clever design to the 6 others.

The game's small roster bolsters its ability to remain focused and balanced. Dan has stated that the game is to be balanced around 1v1s, ensuring that all characters have the tools they need to deal with any of the others and dittos of themselves. He's been very receptive to feedback, which is fantastic and an absolute blessing for a competitive fighting game.

All in all, this game has been incredible even before its release. Controls are smooth, art is beautiful, music is engaging and catchy, characters are unique, deep, and interesting, online play is (usually) smooth, and overall Rivals of Aether makes for a great platform fighter either as an alternative or supplement to your Smash collection.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
First off, I really like this game.

It feels fair and responsive. The learning curve is low and the skill cap very high, exactly how it should be.

The thing that immidiately noticed was how different all the characters are.
Obviously this gam eis going to be compared to smash bros, and all I can say it that it feels kinda like melee. 
The Air dodging is something that they improved on over smash bros in my opinion, in this game air didging can be done in any direction. This game does not have grab and that breaks the "rock, paper, scisors" counter that smash has, but I haven't played enough to say if it is better or worse. Grabbing is usually used for combo's anyway and  this game already has some clear combo's. I'm not sure it's possible to counter perfect counters, but they are so hard to perform it might not matter anyway. 

At first I was a little disappointed to see they were aiming for only 8 characters, but when I played the game I noticed that they were exceptionally well designed, it understand would be hard to think of more characters that are of such high quality and unique. 

Personally I'm not a fan of pixel art, but I guess the pixel art makes it possible to play this game on my shitty laptop. 

Thank god for the option to play maps in "basic", I really dislike the aether version of the map "treetop Lodge". 
On a scale of 1 to 10 enviromental insta kill is NAZI AS FUCK. Hitler would be proud.

Kragg is my boy, he definately immigrated from the earth kingdom where he was the first earth bender.

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This isn't just Smash Bros. on Steam, it's a genuinely clever take on the formula. Some of the core mechanics are different, like parries instead of shields and grabs, but it's still going to feel pretty familiar if you've played Smash before. What really sets it apart and makes it feel unique is each individual character's design.

There aren't many characters (6 so far, 2 more on the way), but each one has some kind of mechanic in the form of something they can place somewhere on the stage. Orcane can place a puddle on the ground that he can teleport to or detonate into a pillar of bubbles; Maypul can create a plant that can snare enemies or redirect her projectile; Wrastor can create a horizontal jetstream that he moves faster in, etc. Each character is extremely unique, and it makes the small roster feel a lot bigger than it is.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: Finally. The fighting games us PC smashers have been waiting for. This game is nothing short of fantastic, even in its early stages. It combines the thrilling and exciting gameplay of Melee with the accessibility of Smash 4, which makes it a perfect medium. The gameplay is smooth, the controls are solid and they even let you change them to your preference. Online is great because it plays out as a best 2/3 set against your opponent (the format in which a majority professional Smash sets are played out). Overall, a must have for fans of the Super Smash Brothers series, and fighting games alike. Pick it up today!

title: Rivals of Aether
review:
This is a fantastic spin on the Platform Fighter genre originally created by Smash. The mechanics have been tweaked to feel fresh and familiar. Shields have been removed and replaced by Parrying, which limits defensive option meaning offensive game play is amplified. The removal of ledges and increase in recovery options makes the offstage game very different and more high risk high reward then ever. Akin to Melee and Smash 64 this game has combos and lots of them! From BnB to mix-ups to creative combos, this game really puts a certain satisfaction in landing each blow. The game is also made easily accessible to anybody new to the genre. Inputs that were difficult in other games are made much easier allowing even the most casual gamer to have fun with in a 1V1 environment.

The game also boast a small but healthy cast of characters, each with their own mechanic. I could go for ages about each character cause they all have so much depth but I'll spare you the wall of text. Despite each characters unique traits they are all extremely well balanced and are extremely fun to play. Not to mention the character design is very creative and each character is identifiable on the battlefield. 

The only real issue with the game as of right now is the online. It can be laggy at times but I think that's mostly dependent on the players internet rather then the netcode its self. But the online as of right now is actually really well designed, allowing for quick Bo3 matches with the option to rematch. If your not feeling like fighting random people you can always play your friends online as well.

For a game in Early Acces it sure has pasted my expectations and as a competitive Smasher myself has made me eager to get into competitively. If you like Smash in any way please do yourself a favor and buy this game. The developers of this game put a lot of heart into making this game and they deserve for this game to be heard.

title: Rivals of Aether
review: 2D Smash Bros. Melee what more can you ask for? Each character has a unique play style that draws elements from your favorite Smash characters as well as bring new elements that aren't seen in Smash. The music for each stage is also really good! There is occasional lag between match ups online but most of the time the connection is great. I recommend using some type of controller when you start playing this game but it's still playable with a keyboard.
